HEADLINE: Argentina's Bid to Save Itself 

 BODY:
Argentina took an important symbolic step on Monday in its struggle to avoid financial collapse. The country's Senate passed a law committing itself to a balanced budget, paving the way for wage cuts for public employees and tax increases. Whether the provinces will follow the federal government's orders of fiscal prudence remains to be seen. But in the meantime, leaders of the world's economic powers should help Argentina by speeding up aid and expressing confidence in its latest efforts. 
 More than anything, recession-plagued Argentina needs time. Several months of quietly servicing its debt of $130 billion without incurring new obligations might lure foreign investors back. A second debt swap, now under consideration, would help by replacing a relatively small issue of three- and six-month notes, sold every two weeks, with 18-month notes sold at longer intervals. The country's new "zero deficit" law is meant to prevent additional borrowing, but it will work only if the provinces cooperate by restraining spending. Argentina needs fiscal responsibility to guarantee a future that should eventually include less debt and exchange rates that are determined by the market. 
 During any respite, Argentina would have to avoid a run on its banks. Deposits are already falling. Civil unrest orchestrated by thousands of unemployed workers could increase fears of financial distress. The government must be careful not to create flashpoints with an authoritarian reaction.
A run on the banks would be a problem not just for Argentina but for financial markets elsewhere in Latin America, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. It would also threaten the stability of a country just beginning to blossom as a multi-party democracy.
The world's big economies have a strong interest in seeing that Argentina weathers the storm. The comments by Tony Blair, Britain's prime minister, praising the Argentine Senate's action will help to reassure depositors. John Taylor, America's under secretary of the Treasury for international affairs, also suggested speeding up I.M.F. aid in recognition of Argentina's recent progress. To further bolster confidence, President Bush should join in standing behind Argentina's economic reforms.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Blessed Are the Weak

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill recently gave an interview in which he dismissed claims that the dollar was overvalued, arguing that concerns about our trade deficit are based on "trivial and wrong notions." He also thinks that concepts like gross domestic product are obsolete. I took his remarks as an indication that the dollar's inevitable decline will probably come sooner rather than later. And while that will be embarrassing for Mr. O'Neill, it will be a good thing for our economy.
 Why does Mr. O'Neill's nonchalance suggest that the strong dollar's days are numbered? Because there is a clear analogy between the soaring dollar and the recent tech bubble. As Robert Shiller pointed out in his book "Irrational Exuberance," a gradually rising asset price acts like a natural Ponzi scheme, in which each new wave of investors creates capital gains for the previous wave. If this goes on long enough, it can silence the doubters. 
 But eventually the process ends -- and you know that the end is nigh when white-haired executives reject old-fashioned accounting. That means that the mania has spread to the suits, and that the Ponzi scheme is about to run out of suckers.
The dollar has been rising against the currencies of other industrial countries since the middle of the 1990's. This sustained rise has made dollar bears look foolish, but it has also priced U.S. products out of world markets. Since 1995 the U.S. current account deficit, the difference between what we buy from foreigners and what we sell to them, has quadrupled to an astonishing $450 billion. It goes without saying that this is the biggest such deficit in world history. More startling is the fact that at 4.5 percent of G.D.P., the U.S. current account deficit is a bigger share of our economy than the deficits of Indonesia or South Korea on the eve of the 1997 Asian financial crisis. 
In the past, deficits this large have always led to a currency plunge. True, one hears arguments to the effect that the rules have changed, that this time is different. Those arguments were presumably what Mr. O'Neill had in mind when he dismissed concerns about the payments deficit. Alas, it would be easier to take those arguments seriously if they weren't so similar to the arguments people used to justify the high dollar of the mid-1980's, just before it started dropping. 
More ominously, I heard exactly the same arguments -- especially the claim that rising productivity justifies a strong currency -- used to dismiss concerns about Mexico's current account deficit just before the 1995 peso crisis, and again in Asia two years later.
But would a sharp drop in the dollar be a catastrophe? Probably not. In fact, if the dollar is going to plunge one of these days, now would be a pretty good time. I wouldn't have said that a year and a half ago; but times have changed.
Not long ago a drop in the dollar would have been a clear negative for the global economy. A weaker dollar, which makes U.S. goods cheaper compared with the products of other countries, redistributes world demand toward the U.S. and away from the rest of the world. Back when the U.S. economy was booming, this would have been shipping coals to Newcastle; we already had plenty of demand, while other economies were depressed. 
Now, however, the U.S. economy has stumbled, and the strong dollar is one of the reasons the Fed is having trouble pulling us back from the brink. So right now a weaker dollar is in America's interests. It still might create some problems elsewhere -- but on the other hand it might be just the shock needed to wake the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan from their policy slumbers.
Is that a call to action? Should we actively seek to drive the dollar down? There's a precedent: In 1985 James Baker, who was then secretary of the Treasury, organized an international effort to tame the too-strong dollar. It's still debatable whether his efforts made any difference; possibly the dollar would have fallen in any case. But it was a political triumph: Mr. Baker managed to take credit for the dollar's decline. Alas, Mr. O'Neill's ramblings have probably prevented him from achieving any comparable feat. 
But never mind Mr. O'Neill; the great dollar decline is coming, and we should welcome its arrival.

HEADLINE: Use of Shelters By Families Sets Record in City 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The number of homeless families lodging nightly in New York City's shelter system has risen higher than ever and the trend is accelerating, city officials said yesterday. With a critical shortage of low-cost housing, and applications for shelter running 30 percent higher than last year, officials say they expect new records to be set this winter. 
 No single factor explains the startling growth in homeless families in New York, which has been echoed in cities around the country, including Washington, Chicago and Oakland, Calif. But city officials and national researchers said likely explanations include housing costs driven higher in an economic boom, followed by a slowdown that has hit poor families harder in an America cutting welfare and a new reluctance by landlords to accept subsidized tenants. 
 By July, there were a record 6,252 families, with 11,594 children, in temporary beds, city figures show. Overall, there were 20,655 members of homeless families in the shelter system, surpassing the previous peaks of the late 1980's and mid-1990's, when about 18,700 people in 5,700 families were in temporary shelter. Current figures reflect an increase of more than 1,000 families since July 2000 alone. 
"This is off the charts," said Leonard Koerner, the city's chief assistant corporation counsel, who has been defending the city's homeless policies in court.
At the Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx, New York City's sole access point for homeless families seeking shelter, city figures show a number of applicants at levels not seen since the recession of the early 1990's. But with the city no longer supplying the stream of low-cost housing that absorbed thousands of families from the shelters in the past, fewer people are leaving the shelter system even as hundreds more crowd in each month.
Among them yesterday were Elizabeth Marrero, 29, and her two children, Bianca, 7, and Peter, 8, who have been shuttling between short-term beds and the unit since July 19.
"There's people sleeping on the floor, kids crying, the place is dirty -- it's like a nightmare," Ms. Marrero said. "If I would have a place to go I wouldn't put my kids through this." 
She added that her son had been unable to attend summer school for lack of a stable place to live, and would have to repeat the third grade.
New York City has the only shelter system in the nation that operates under a court-ordered right to shelter for the truly homeless. On a typical night in July, it gave beds to 28,029 people, including 5,682 single men and 1,692 single women.
The number of single adults in the municipal shelters traditionally rises in cold weather, so by the end of the year, city officials and advocates for the homeless predict, the number of homeless people in the shelter system will exceed the previous high of 28,737, recorded in March 1987. That level spurred the Koch administration to begin a 10-year effort to get permanent housing for the homeless.
"This is completely careening out of control," said Mary Brosnahan Sullivan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless. "The next mayor may be sworn in on Jan. 1 with an all-time high in the number of homeless. How shocking that is at the end of an economic boom."
The boom itself has played a role, by raising rents to levels even many working families cannot pay, city officials and advocates agreed. Even as housing costs stay high, families at the bottom now seem to be catching the brunt of a national slowdown in the economy. And in a recent change in policy, the Giuliani administration is now scrambling to add low-cost permanent housing to the mix, but city officials say they are having little success.
Hundreds of Section 8 vouchers, federal subsidies that bridge the difference between income and a moderate rent, are going unused, Mr. Koerner said, because landlords are rejecting them despite city bonuses and a streamlined bureaucracy.
"It's not peculiar to New York City," Mr. Koerner said. "It may be a function of the good economy -- they're treating Section 8 as tenants of last resort."
Martha Burt, an authority on homelessness who directs social service research programs at the Urban Institute in Washington, said similar complaints were echoed by providers of homeless services in 25 research sites around the country this spring.
"There is nowhere in this country that anybody can find housing with what you can pay under Section 8," she said. "All over the country that is the story, and getting people placed is extremely difficult. New York City, with its right to shelter, is actually experiencing something closer to the truth than other communities whose actual delivery of family shelter is limited by the resources the community is willing to supply, and whose level of requests is limited by people's knowledge that they will be turned away."
But advocates for the homeless in New York attribute much of the current problem to the lack of low-cost housing initiatives since thousands of tax-delinquent apartments were rehabilitated under the Koch administration's 10-year plan.
The city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which had produced 1,500 apartments a year for the homeless at the peak of the Koch plan, provided only 117 apartments in a nine-month period last year, city officials told the City Council recently.
Mayor Giuliani and his predecessor, David N. Dinkins, both turned away from the use of hotels as family shelters in the 1990's, and most regular shelter is now provided by private nonprofit groups by city contract. But under pressure from court orders to stop leaving homeless families to sleep on the floor of the Emergency Assistance Unit, the city has sharply increased the use of temporary beds.
Last month the city had more than 2,100 families in hotels and "scattered site" shelter, paying landlords the equivalent of $3,000 a month for night-to-night apartments.
"The city has created an incentive and a market for landlords to rent apartments for three times what either a federal subsidy or a city subsidy would cover," said Steven Banks, director of the Homeless Rights Project of the Legal Aid Society. "The city's put itself in this bind by neglecting the housing needs of low-income and working families for eight years." 
Last January, Judge Helen E. Freedman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan found that more than 700 people were crowded into the Emergency Assistance Unit daily, including children missing school because only one-night beds were provided for them, and that as many as 32 families a night were left to sleep on the floor or on benches.
In April, the judge found that the city had redoubled its efforts, and extracted a promise from Mr. Koerner to show a steady reduction of families repeatedly shuttled to different shelters for a few hours of sleep. 
But Mr. Koerner said yesterday that city plans had anticipated an 8 percent increase in homeless families applying for shelter, not a 30 percent rise.
Monday night, 8 adults and 14 children were left to sleep on the floor of the Emergency Assistance Unit. They were still there yesterday morning when the Marrero family returned from a temporary shelter placement in Queens to reapply. 
"I felt so sorry for them," Ms. Marrero said. 
So did Bianca, her daughter. "I'm hoping they'll replace us somewhere where we know we'll be all right," Bianca said. "The worst thing is when your friends see you they, like, tease you and stuff -- 'You're in the shelter, you don't have no home.' "

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
The industry is abuzz with speculation, but few hard answers, as to when the downturn will end.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

DATELINE: ATLANTA 

 BODY:
ROUND and round went the toy train on a platform the size of a kitchen table. A man at the Amtrak display booth intently watched the little five-car model Acela Express buzz across the track, as if it were moving in something other than a circle.
 Where better than at the railroad booth to pose the question that many of the 4,000 attendees at the annual National Business Travel Association convention and trade show were pondering here yesterday as they went to seminars, heard speeches and cruised the acres of exhibits from travel suppliers and others in the corporate travel market: Does anybody see the light at the end of the tunnel? 
 I asked Dennis J. Graham, the brand director for Amtrak's ballyhooed new Acela Express high-speed train, which began on the Washington-New York-Boston corridor in December (with disappointing business-travel ridership so far, industry analysts say). "No sign of it yet," he said as laconically as a platform conductor looking up the tracks for an overdue train. 
Mr. Graham said that a lot of corporate travel managers had been stopping by to look over the Amtrak displays and reservations systems, and no one is talking about a quick resumption of the kind of frenetic business travel pace we saw last year.
"I'm afraid we haven't seen the complete bottom of this yet," he said pessimistically.
Still, the only palpable gloom discernible among those in attendance came in the muttering here and there about the diminished quality of the promotional souvenirs passed out at exhibitors' booths this year. Mostly gone were the caps, T-shirts, battery-operated blinking key chains, and corporate mascot pinatas -- replaced in many cases by plastic key chains and pens with logos.
The reality of how quickly and unexpectedly the climate went bad in the business travel industry was underscored this week by a report by the Air Transport Association, a trade organization for the major domestic airlines, which predicted that the airlines would lose a total of about $1.5 billion this year. Last year, the trade group had projected airline profits this year of over $2 billion. Airlines make most of their money from business travelers.
"The actual number of people traveling now is not that far off from the record level of last year," Leo F. Mullin, the chairman and chief executive of Delta Air Lines, which is based here, said in an interview before he delivered the keynote address at yesterday's lunch session of the convention.
Leisure travel is holding up "reasonably well," although fares and revenue are down through a combination of promotional sales and intensifying consumer price comparison shopping on the Internet, he said. "But in the major business markets we are seeing a 30 percent drop in our most lucrative business traffic," which is the last-minute full-fare customer, he continued.
"The walk-up fare has tremendously dropped," while business travel in general has been "cascading down from first class to business class to coach to not traveling at all," he added.
Light at the end of the tunnel? "I would say that in the last month to six weeks, we've seen what I would characterize as a plateau," after the sharp declines of the spring, he replied, adding: "Business is not worsening anymore, but it is not improving, either. So the good news is, I feel we are on this plateau; but the bad news is, I don't know how long we'll be on this plateau."
Some executives found opportunity in the slowdown, meanwhile. 
"It's just amazing what a pack mentality we all really have," said Marka Jenkins, the chief executive officer of Highwire Inc., a developer of corporate online travel technology based in Seattle whose clients include Microsoft and other high-technology companies. "A year and a half ago, with all the dot-coms, especially, there was not a thought about cutting back on business travel." 
When cutbacks suddenly arrived, one ramification was an accelerated shift by many corporations to requiring employees to use proprietary in-house Internet booking sites to make lower-cost travel arrangements. The corporate online booking industry took off as a result.
On Monday, Galileo International, the international provider of computer reservation services for the travel industry, announced that it had acquired Ms. Jenkins's company.
"The catalyst for that was the current slowdown," said Babetta R. Gray, an executive vice president of Galileo, which, she said, plans to plunge more enthusiastically into the in-house corporate booking business.
"It certainly is my opinion that we're not going to see any recovery in business travel this year," Ms. Gray said. "Most of our customers have made their adjustments for this year. The intelligence I'm hearing kicked around is look for the return sometime during the second quarter of 2002. That's what the large customers are saying."
Brian J. Murphy, the vice president for sales and marketing for Aer Lingus, the Irish airline, said, "Everybody's looking to everyone else for a sign." Aer Lingus has recently begun a major push for business travelers as Ireland's economy has boomed.
A few aisles away, Cheryl Berkman, the chief executive of Music Express, a provider of luxury limousine services based in Burbank, Calif., that caters worldwide to entertainers and business travelers, said that she thought she saw that sign.
"In the entertainment business, there are constant premiers, concerts, parties, and those people never cut back anything," she said. "Corporate, they tightened their belts this year. But now, we see them starting to come back more. Corporate people who a few months ago were very conservative are loosening up, like they're ready to rock and roll again."

HEADLINE: Chief Abruptly Quits Business Magazine Group 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
In a move that underscores the fragility of a critical sector of the magazine industry, David Carey, the president and chief executive of the business magazine division at Gruner & Jahr, resigned yesterday after just six months and will return to his previous job as publisher of The New Yorker. 
 The suddenness of Mr. Carey's departure shocked executives in the magazine industry yesterday. A highly visible publisher with a challenging mandate, Mr. Carey had been hired with a generous salary and the promise of long-term bonuses. More important, he had joined Gruner & Jahr as an entrepreneur who would shape the multimedia vision for the newly formed Business Innovator Group, which included Fast Company and Inc. magazines, both acquired by Gruner & Jahr last year. Many executives said that their high-ticket price tags -- $200 million for Inc. and $365 million for Fast Company -- required an established publisher like Mr. Carey who could prove that the products were worthy of the price tags. 
 But rather than acting as a entrepreneur to expand the division and develop new businesses, Mr. Carey found himself struggling to save it as advertising revenue dropped off sharply. And according to Gruner & Jahr executives, Mr. Carey was also frustrated by the company's slower, more committee-oriented management structure and by the fact that pivotal financial decisions were often made final by Axel Ganz, the president of the international magazine division. At Conde Nast, which owns The New Yorker, Mr. Carey had been able to make publishing decisions after meeting with the chairman, S. I. Newhouse Jr., or the chief executive, Steven T. Florio, executives said yesterday.
When Mr. Carey left The New Yorker in January, no one had yet predicted just how radically the advertising slump would affect business magazines like Fast Company and Inc. Many of their advertisers were either casualties of the dot-com bust or became reluctant to spend money on print campaigns as the economy sputtered. 
In the first six months of 2001, ad pages for Fast Company plunged 47.2 percent, to 512 pages from 969.9 pages in the period a year earlier, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.
Advertising pages at Inc. have fallen 44.3 percent, to 478.5 pages from 859.1. 
David Verklin, the chief executive at Carat North America, a media services company, said that business magazines in particular were suffering.
"Advertising is in the nose cone of the American economy," Mr. Verklin said. "And if advertising is in the nose cone of the economy, the business magazines and business-to-business advertising is the heat-resistant tile. They are all struggling in a really difficult economy."
Gruner & Jahr, which is owned by Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany, was been expanding and retooling since Daniel B. Brewster became chief executive in May of last year. Last June, Mr. Brewster supervised the purchase of Inc. from the privately held Goldhirsh Group for $200 million, and last December bought Fast Company from Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the New York real estate investor, in a deal that eventually paid Mr. Zuckerman close to $365 million. 
Yesterday, Mr. Carey said his departure was not necessarily spurred by the negative advertising news from Fast Company and Inc. 
"It is a year of great change in the publishing industry, which everyone knows," Mr. Carey said. "I was offered a chance to essentially turn back the clock and return to a job that I loved doing and did reasonably well, and I enjoyed a very close relationship with the magazine's editor. That is an opportunity you have to take seriously."
Under David Kahn, who took over as publisher of The New Yorker after Mr. Carey's departure, The New Yorker performed reasonably well, considering the marketplace. For the first six months of 2001, advertising pages fell 4.6 percent, to 1,100 from 1,153 in the period a year earlier, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. But revenue rose 10 percent, to $53 million, for the first six months of this year, according to the bureau.
Mr. Kahn, who had served as Mr. Carey's deputy, will step aside to become the chief executive of a new division of Conde Nast, the Conde Nast Image Center, which will market and license material from the Conde Nast archives.
Mr. Brewster sent a brief memorandum to Gruner & Jahr staff members yesterday, detailing temporary management plans. A company spokeswoman, Sue Geramian, said that he had no further comment.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Tries to Counter Lack of Support Among Women 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31 

 BODY:
Republicans inside and outside the White House are focusing anew on the party's disadvantage among women in the electorate, a problem that has persisted -- and by some recent measures worsened -- through the beginning of the Bush administration.
 Earlier this month, the Republican National Committee announced that it would pump millions of dollars a year into a new campaign, "Winning Women," to be led by the committee's new co-chairwoman, Ann Wagner, who eagerly introduces herself as a 38-year-old suburban mom. 
 Later this week, when Vice President Dick Cheney attends a special meeting of Congressional Republican leaders, a key topic will be the need for Republicans to talk more about education, an emphasis intended to appeal to women.
In addition, the White House and the Republican Party are trying to draw fresh attention to the large number of women in senior positions in the Bush administration. 
Several recent surveys by Republican pollsters suggest that the party's focus on a sweeping tax cut and the Bush administration's widely criticized environmental decisions have cost Republicans some support among women and widened Democrats' advantage among them.
A poll last week by Public Opinion Strategies showed that while men, by 43 percent to 37 percent, said they were more likely to vote for a Republican than a Democrat, women were more likely to do the opposite by 47 percent to 32 percent.
"This is not happy data," said Bill McInturff, the Republican pollster who conducted the survey.
Mr. McInturff said the size of the so-called gender gap in his survey was not enormous and might turn out to be something of a blip.
But it was nonetheless consistent with the results of monthly surveys that David Winston, another Republican pollster, has been presenting to House Republican leaders.
Although Mr. Winston declined to discuss specific figures from his research, Republicans familiar with it said they were similar to Mr. McInturff's and revealed, in particular, a precipitous drop since February in Republican support among married women with children. That subset is one with which Republican candidates traditionally do best.
Mr. Winston said the trend was attributable in large part to the way in which, during President Bush's first six months in office, the administration and the party let taxes and the economy eclipse issues like education and health care, which are especially important to women.
"It's just a pure example that if you're going to sustain a coalition, you have to talk about issues that matter to that coalition," Mr. Winston said.
Mr. Bush himself seems to be doing better with female voters than the Republican Party in general. Polls over the last two months have put his job approval rating among women well over 45 percent and not more than five to seven percentage points below his rating among men.
But several Republican strategists and pollsters said some of the administration's early decisions had undoubtedly alienated women and probably contributed to the party's problems with them, difficulties that could haunt Republicans in Congressional elections next year.
"The president needs to understand that in the first six months, many women believe that he has drifted to the right," said Linda Di Vall, a Republican pollster, adding that his actions "on the environment in particular have caused him some trouble with women."
Although administration officials say they are not concerned, some of their activities, along with the efforts of the Republican National Committee, suggest a fresh concern with strengthening support among women, who are a majority of the electorate.
Both the White House and the national committee are trying to arrange events around the country at which leading businesswomen can be introduced to high-ranking women in the Bush administration. One of the first occurred last week in Manhattan, where female magazine editors and publishers met not only Ms. Wagner but also Lezlee Westine, who directs the White House's public liaison office, and Mary Matalin, Mr. Cheney's top political aide.
Several administration officials said the White House and the party were not getting the credit they deserved for the number of women in top White House positions, a fact that they said would impress and help attract female voters.
To that end, Ms. Wagner said, a Web site affiliated with the "Winning Women" campaign will feature profiles of people like Karen P. Hughes, counselor to the president, and Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser.
Ms. Wagner, who joined the national committee earlier this year, is also traveling widely and carefully marketing herself as a kind of soccer-mom everywoman. She said in a telephone interview today that what defined contemporary women -- and what the party needed to speak to -- were their crammed, busy lives.
"We're juggling a lot of balls," Ms. Wagner, who lives in a suburb of St. Louis, said from her R.N.C. office here. "I know I am, as a working mother of three children -- 12- and 10-year-old boys and a 6-year-old girl. My daughter, Ruth, is running around here right now."
"I sing in the church choir," she said. "I run into women at the swim meet conferences, the Little League games, the grocery store, airports. I talk to real women every single day."
Ms. Wagner, Ms. Matalin and other Republican women involved in new efforts to reach female voters said that both the Republican agenda in general and the Bush agenda in particular had strong appeal to women, so long as they were sold and explained well.
They pointed to Mr. Bush's push for education reform, which is likely to be enacted in some form. Pollsters and strategists agreed that Mr. Bush and other Republicans could gain ground among women by drawing more attention to education. Mr. Bush and House Republican leaders plan to talk about that issue extensively during the August recess and in September.
But Ms. Wagner, Ms. Matalin and other Republican leaders also said that women, as the principal balancers of checkbooks, could be made to appreciate the tax cut more and that women, as the principal caretakers of children, could be made to care more about a missile defense shield that might serve as a protection against terrorist attack.
Some Republican strategists and lawmakers scoffed at that thinking as optimistic and shallow, saying it focused too much on the packaging and not enough on the product.
"It's fundamentally a question of the issues," said Representative Marge Roukema, a New Jersey Republican. In her view, she said, most women do not support the Republican position on a patients' bill of rights or abortion, and that is a problem that outreach will not cure.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY TO ACQUIRE XTRA

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, agreed to buy the Xtra Corporation, a container leasing company, for about $590 million, the companies said yesterday. Berkshire agreed to pay $55 a share and to assume another $710 million in Xtra's debt. Berkshire's investment comes as shipping companies that lease Xtra's equipment struggle in a slowing economy. Xtra said yesterday that profit in its most recent quarter fell 57 percent because of lower freight demand and increased costs. Julian H. Robertson Jr., the billionaire who leads Tiger Management and is Xtra's biggest shareholder, agreed to the transaction. Xtra will remain at its headquarters in Westport, Conn., and operate as a wholly owned subsidiary.

HEADLINE: WHITMAN TO ISSUE ORDER TO DREDGE HUDSON FOR PCB'S 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The federal Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, Christie Whitman, has agreed to go ahead with a plan issued in the closing days of the Clinton administration requiring the General Electric Company to spend more than half a billion dollars to dredge PCB pollution from the Hudson River, according to officials at the agency.
 The draft order, which will become official in 30 days after a government review, will set into motion the biggest environmental dredging plan in United States history, after more than two decades of disputes over the science of dredging and the political, economic and moral issues of corporate responsibility. 
 The order to dredge a 40-mile stretch of the Hudson north of Albany is a huge defeat for G.E., which had spent tens of millions of dollars fighting the proposal. The question of dredging the Hudson had also become a test for the Bush administration, which has been pilloried in recent months by environmental groups for its policies on energy and the international efforts to control greenhouse gas emissions. 
"We're staying the course," said a senior official with the agency, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "It's time to move on, and we're committed to cleaning up the river."
The official said that White House officials had been briefed about Mrs. Whitman's decision, and that in the next 30 days, New York State and federal agencies that would have a role in the cleanup, including the Interior Department, would have an opportunity to comment. No changes in the plan are expected, the official said.
There was no immediate indication of whether President Bush had been briefed on the agency's decision. 
The company's vice president for corporate environmental programs, Stephen D. Ramsey, declined to comment on the draft order, saying G.E. did not have adequate information yet. 
After the Clinton administration approved the preliminary cleanup proposal in December, the plan entered a public comment period that extended through the early months of the Bush administration. Environmental officials said that they had to extend the comment period because of the huge volume of people and organizations that wanted to respond, and that it had taken until this week to analyze all the information. 
The draft order closely follows the Clinton administration proposal, which would require G.E. to pay for the removal, or remove by itself, about 2.65 million cubic yards of river bottom of the Hudson from the Troy Dam to the Thompson Island Pool, about 35 miles north of Albany. 
An estimated 1.1 million pounds of PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, which have been linked to cancer in humans and various disorders in wildlife, were spilled or dumped into the river by G.E. from its plants along the upper Hudson from the mid-1940's until 1977, when the chemicals were banned. The draft order, as did the Clinton administration plan, proposes to remove about 100,000 pounds of the oily chemical from the river. Much of the PCB's that entered the river are believed to have dispersed by now. 
The new draft order will create a few changes in how the cleanup will proceed. E.P.A. officials said that the changes were intended as improvements but that they could delay the cleanup. Officials said that unlike the Clinton plan, the draft order would create a staged cleanup process, and that performance would be reviewed at each phase. Among the issues that will be examined are noise, odor, effect on river traffic, and especially the question of resuspension -- that is, whether the dredging process itself stirs up PCB's from the river bottom mud and recontaminates the water. 
The possibility that dredging could somehow backfire and repollute a river that by many measures is cleaner than it has been in generations became a nagging fear expressed by many people living near the proposed dredging areas. Officials at the environmental agency said last night that the draft plan took those concerns into account. 
They said that if the performance reviews found that PCB's were actually being freed from the bottom mud, the dredging process would be re-evaluated. A major change in a cleanup order, once it has been issued, could require the entire plan to be redrafted, and officials said that resuspension, if it occurred, could be a big enough problem to force a redrafting. 
"Yes, there are some unanswered questions about all of this," a senior E.P.A. official said. "But the agency believes it's time to move forward, and our own scientists have said we won't learn everything until we do some of this stuff. What's different here is that we're trying to respond to the concerns of the impacted communities."
General Electric, which waged an extensive public relations campaign against the dredging, as well as a far-flung scientific effort to investigate how PCB's behave under the changing conditions of a river bottom, had contended that the Hudson was essentially cleaning itself by entombing the chemicals under successive layers of silt. Declining levels of the pollutant had been measured in fish caught in the river, the company said, a sign that a natural process was at work.
Company officials, and allies of the company, also argued that the technology of dredging, especially on a scale envisioned by the federal plan, was far from foolproof and that active dredging was therefore both dangerous and unnecessary. E.P.A. scientists, in defending their plan over the last eight months, agreed that PCB levels had declined in the river fish, but said the improvement had leveled off in recent years, indicating that only full removal of the chemical would entirely solve the problem.
Under the federal Superfund law that the government has applied on the Hudson, a final order for a cleanup cannot be challenged in court, and E.P.A. officials said last night that they planned to begin preparing the engineering design for the project as early as September, a process that is expected to take up to a year.
But there are major questions remaining about who would actually do the work -- G.E. or the government -- and E.P.A. officials said there were several issues within that part of the order that could bring the parties into court and produce delays. 
Specifically, G.E. could agree to do the work itself. If it declined to do that, then the government could proceed with a cleanup itself, or get a court order requiring G.E. to do the work, and it is that court order that could be challenged, E.P.A. officials said.

HEADLINE: Air Force One Has Flown, but Clinton's Still Celebrity in Chief 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
He used to stop traffic. Now he sits in it.
 He used to run government agencies like the Internal Revenue Service. Now he shares a building with their ground-level outposts. 
 He once negotiated treaties with Ehud Barak and Tony Blair. Now he teams with the songwriter Babyface to advocate his causes. 
Such is the day-to-day life of Citizen Bill Clinton. After a raucous rally welcoming him to the neighborhood on Monday, he is settling into Harlem, and his new life. At every turn something reminds him of the presidential trappings he has lost. 
But at every turn, something else reminds him of the power he still has. The requests to serve on boards and to support causes have come by the hundreds. So have the interview requests (from major media outlets, obscure foreign publications and even a cigar magazine, wanting him to pose for its cover). Countless citizens have written with ideas for him to implement.
With such an array of options, a man never known for his discretion at a buffet must choose carefully. 
More than anything, his public service now relies on private commitments and contributions. He implored "ordinary middle-class people who don't have a lot of money" to donate to fight the international AIDS crisis yesterday. He wants corporations to invest in Harlem and other inner cities. 
After months of quiet groundwork, he has begun to take his priorities public. Yesterday, he held a news conference with Kenneth Edmonds, the multi-Grammy-winning songwriter and producer known as Babyface, to discuss his support for the International AIDS Trust, a nonprofit run by Mr. Clinton's former AIDS czar, Sandra Thurman. Mr. Clinton heads the organization's board of advisers. Mr. Edmonds, a friend of the former president's, will give concerts and produce a CD to support the cause. 
Whether the small conference room at the Midtown offices of Sun International was packed with reporters because of Mr. Clinton or Mr. Edmonds, it was packed. And so, calling himself the "resident policy wonk," Mr. Clinton reeled off facts about the epidemic spread of AIDS -- now at 36 million to 40 million cases worldwide. He said governments' putting money into fighting AIDS was not enough; it was equally important to develop the mechanisms to spend the money effectively for treatment and prevention.
He stressed repeatedly the world's interdependence. "This is not an African problem," he said, "and it's not a problem America has solved, because we have it in our backyard." He stressed, as well, that he was acting only as a private citizen. 
After the news conference, it was into a Ford Expedition for a 23-minute, stop-at-every-red-light ride up Madison Avenue to his Harlem office. A yellow cab carrying a reporter beat him.
He met and posed for pictures with visiting Arkansas legislators. He met with Richard D. Parsons, vice chairman of AOL Time Warner; the presidents of Tommy Hilfiger and Court TV; and others to discuss the National Campaign Against Youth Violence. 
He sat for a long-promised interview for a documentary on the rise of the global economy, discoursing with erudite enthusiasm about the importance of trade and the need for global responsibility on issues like the environment. 
Then it was off to the Dakota apartment of Jane Rosenthal, the president of TriBeCa Productions, where close to 100 people had gathered to hear about the AIDS trust. Mr. Clinton spoke movingly of the need to act, as did Mr. Edmonds, who drew loud cheers from the upscale crowd when he called Mr. Clinton "one of the best presidents we've ever had." 
In the crowd of celebrities, Mr. Clinton was still celebrity in chief. He greeted, often with bear hugs, friends like Robert De Niro, Harvey Weinstein, Donald Trump (who invited him to play golf) and Oscar de la Renta.
Then it was off to LaGuardia Airport for the 9 p.m. shuttle to Washington, to see his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and her mother, who is recovering from surgery. 
Peppered throughout the day were those small reminders that Mr. Clinton was just Mr. Clinton now. At the Dakota, where during his presidency the police had shielded his limousine from public view with a blue tarpaulin, he simply hopped out of the Expedition in the driveway and shook some hands. 
Earlier at his Harlem office building, when aides and Secret Service agents piled into the Expedition, he tried to upright a lowered seat back so he could sit. 
It was stuck. He tried again. And kept trying. 
"Sir," an agent said from the front seat. Then he leaned back and lifted the seat. Mr. Clinton hopped in.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Portrays Himself As a Leader for Hard Times 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that New York City was descending into rough economic times and predicted that the city's budget would be battered by declining tax revenues and rising costs for labor contracts and welfare over the next four years. Mr. Bloomberg, a Republican mayoral candidate, said his business background made him particularly qualified to lead the city through any slowdown.
 But even as Mr. Bloomberg, the billionaire founder of Bloomberg L.P., argued that voters should look outside the political system for a new mayor during this time of fiscal distress, rather than to any of the career public officials who are his rivals, he offered only the most general indications of how he would deal with the situation he warned of. 
 Mr. Bloomberg, who has never held public office, said that if elected, he would rely on his commissioners for suggestions on spending cuts and take steps to expand the city's tax base. Such steps, he said, would include encouraging private development and making New York a more desirable place to live by repairing the city's school system. Mr. Bloomberg also said he would bring to City Hall the methods that had improved the morale and efficiency of employees at his financial information company. 
He cited, for example, company picnics, dinners with employees and his insistence on first-name interactions with employees. He said the "only time I snap at people" is when they call him Mr. Bloomberg. "My name is Mike," Mr. Bloomberg said. (But with limits. "You can't have free food for everybody," he said, signaling that one Bloomberg company perk would not follow him from Park Avenue to City Hall.)
Beyond the issue of the city's economy, which was clearly his central concern during a 90-minute interview with editors and reporters of The New York Times yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg broke from his opponents as he contended that the city could best encourage construction of middle-class housing through the private sector, rather than by using public subsidies. He argued that the city should instead remove what he termed cumbersome land-use and environmental reviews that discouraged developers from building.
He said he opposed a proposal that has been raised by most of his opponents: that the city use any increased revenues from the operation of the World Trade Center to finance housing construction.
Mr. Bloomberg, who has been courting the support of the city teachers' union, took a less stringent approach to ineffective teachers than some of his opponents had, putting more emphasis on training than on ways to remove them from the classroom. He also predicted that the Board of Education would be effectively abolished by the time a new mayor took office, a timetable and a view that are in fact not widely shared by government officials in Albany, where such a change would need to be approved.
Mr. Bloomberg faces a Republican primary on Sept. 11 with one major opponent, Herman Badillo. But his attention yesterday was focused on the general election with a Democrat, reflecting the view of his aides that he will easily defeat Mr. Badillo. In setting out such a stark view of New York City's economy, Mr. Bloomberg offered a glimpse of what would be his general election campaign appeal: a successful businessman is better suited than a career politician to lead New York through difficult times.
"The economy for the next four years does not look like it's going to be the economy" of the last decade, he said, noting reports of layoffs, declining tourism and a falloff on Wall Street.
"The outlook at least for the next few years is not one that should give you comfort that the city is going to be able to do everything," he said. "What I will say to the voters is it is going to be hard times and somebody has to manage and somebody has to make decisions. And sitting there and saying, 'I'm going to do everything' or, 'I'm going to do what's politic' is not going to get us through the next four years."
He added: "All of the people you interview have an awful lot more in common than I have with them. And say things differently and I mean I would argue that I am the only one running that has" the skills needed to run City Hall.
Mr. Bloomberg arrived for the interview after a month in which some offhand remarks he has made -- like suggesting that there was minimal discrimination in the Northeast -- have attracted news coverage that Mr. Bloomberg's advisers worry could distract from his campaign. By contrast yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg spoke mostly in generalities, and he frequently responded to questions by offering a detailed discussion of the problem without suggesting what he might do about it.
For example, when Mr. Bloomberg was asked if he believed that a certain level of civil rights abuse was a necessary trade-off for more intense policing in New York City, he responded with a discursive answer that began with a review of the human rights situations in China and Singapore.
"Well there is a level that we -- whether it's this level or a different level," he responded. "The extremes are places like China where you have no civil liberties, but a billion-odd people do have jobs. They're not starving in China, but there's certainly no freedom. Singapore where it's -- the Singapore people if you -- most Singaporeans would think that they made a good bargain."
When a questioner asked if Mr. Bloomberg might bring the question back to New York, he responded by offering his view of how he thought New Yorkers saw the issue. "In New York I think if you ask most people are they willing to have certain limitations placed on them if the quid pro quo is safe streets," he said.
The candidate said he would not release any more financial information about his private business partners than that required by the city to guard against potential conflicts. "Why, so you can go and harass them now?" he asked a reporter.
He bristled at questions about how much of his own money he intended to spend to win City Hall, as he rejected the suggestion that his personal wealth gave him an unfair advantage over his opponents. "I'm the David against Goliath because I don't have all of that visibility and public awareness," he said.
Throughout his interview, Mr. Bloomberg offered a different perspective on government and its procedures, often expressing frustration over practices that people in government tend to take for granted. 
Why, he asked, are traffic agents not using digital cameras to take photographs of illegally parked cars, and mailing them to drivers with a ticket, to avoid problems of illegible tickets? Why, Mr. Bloomberg said, does a Federal Express delivery agent instantly know the precise location of a package when "the cop doesn't know who he's talking to and whether they have a criminal record?" He added, "We haven't used technology very well."
More conventionally, Mr. Bloomberg said he supported the extension of rent stabilization laws and did not agree with the argument of some developers that the laws were what accounted for the housing shortage in New York. He also said he opposed legislation that would require New York City police officers to live in the city, saying it would only complicate the task of filling vacancies. He said school principals should be given increased authority to decide on classroom assignments for teachers.
On the budget, Mr. Bloomberg said he would oppose any tax increases, warning that they could further erode the city's fiscal standing. He also said that he would support reducing or eliminating some minor taxes as part of an effort to cut back on paperwork for businesses.
At the same time, though, he talked about ways he would spend money as mayor, beyond the salary increases that he noted would be provided for city workers in new contracts. "People are sleeping on the doorsteps of churches. You can't leave them,' Mr. Bloomberg said.
He also said New York should not abandon ambitious public works projects in the interest of austerity. "This is the Big Apple," Mr. Bloomberg observed. "You have to think big, you have to think long term. We can't walk away from the grand projects."
Mr. Bloomberg said the first thing he would do, if elected, would be to ask Mr. Giuliani to impose a hiring freeze. Beyond that, he said he would approach City Hall the same way he would approach his company if it faced fiscal difficulties: he would summon city commissioners and ask them to find areas that could be cut.
"You've got to go to every department and say, 'X percent, you've just got to cut,' " he said. "And then you listen to those, let them make cases where they have reasons why you shouldn't. And then you exercise what you've been elected for: the judgment to say yes, no, yes, no."
Yet Mr. Bloomberg, as he considered his remarks, said there was a limit to how much could be saved. "There is an enormous waste out there," he said. "There are some wastes -- and you can certainly do some things. But you can't just overnight say, 'Oh, I'll go and I'll get a 30 percent raise for the teachers by cutting out inefficiency.' Come on. I mean, government -- if there were those kinds of inefficiencies, you would have written about it and there would have been a firestorm. And they would have -- that's not the real world."

HEADLINE: Gas Giant In Russia Told to Guard Its Assets 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 31 

 BODY:
The directors of Gazprom, the Russian gas giant, ordered the company's managers today to keep a closer watch on Gazprom's property and to curtail the privileged relationship that Itera, a Florida-based gas trading company, has enjoyed with Gazprom.
 At a board meeting, the directors discussed the results of an audit by PricewaterhouseCoopers of the links between Gazprom and Itera. Investors have said they suspect that Itera is secretly partly owned by Gazprom managers, a charge both companies deny. 
 Gazprom, 38 percent owned by the Russian government, is at the center of the country's economy. It has come under fire from both private shareholders and government officials, who say valuable assets like gas fields have been improperly transferred to outside companies. Last month, President Vladimir V. Putin replaced the company's entrenched chief executive with a close ally, Alexei Miller; today's meeting was the first since then.
The four-month confidential audit found that Gazprom has indeed allowed assets to slip away, but concluded that no laws were broken in the process, according to the United Financial Group, a Moscow-based investment bank, whose clients, investors in Gazprom shares, are represented on the board.
"A lot of suspicions of investors were confirmed," said Boris Fyodorov, a board member representing minority shareholders. Still, he said, "this isn't a 100 percent open battle, where all the wrongs are corrected immediately."
"Yes, there will be some improvements," he said, "but we'll have to analyze concrete actions over the longer term."
The auditors reported that they were not given enough information to answer a central question: whether Gazprom managers benefited from the asset transfers.
Some of the damage the audit found may be reparable. The report laid out how Gazprom could retake control of Purgaz, a Siberian gas producer that it sold to Itera very cheaply in 1999. And the board voted at the meeting to buy back control of Zapsibgazprom, another Siberian gas producer. Gazprom's stake in the company was diluted last year when it opted out of a share issue; it tried and failed to regain control earlier this year.
Complicating the Zapsibgazprom matter is the question of who controls the licenses for its gas fields. Its reserves accounted for 3 percent of Gazprom's total, Mr. Fyodorov said. 
Gazprom has lost control over a number of subsidiaries in one-sided deals. Though Kremlin officials, including Mr. Putin, have acknowledged that Gazprom was shortchanged and sometimes acted against its own interest, officials say Russian law offers little or no scope for criminal prosecutions. 
"Everything was done without violating the law," said Dmitri Avdeev, an oil analyst at the United Financial Group. "I don't think the assets will be returned. What's lost is lost."
Gazprom's audited 2000 accounts showed that it had extended $3.4 billion in loan guarantees to unrelated companies, including Itera. At a shareholders' meeting last month, Rem Vyakhirev, the former chief executive, refused to explain why such guarantees had been extended to Itera, ostensibly a competitor.
The mood at today's meeting was much more open and businesslike than in the past, showing that "a lot of things have changed in the last month," Mr. Fyodorov said.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Delays Effort to Give Bush Latitude On Free Trade 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31 

 BODY:
Short of votes to push through President Bush's top trade priority, Republican leaders of the House said today that they would delay until fall the effort to give the president broad authority to negotiate new trade agreements.
 The decision was a setback for the president, but it was not unexpected. While Republicans had held out the hope that they could act this week, no bill has yet been written in committee on the contentious issue that sharply divides the Congress. 
 And Republican leaders have devoted most of their attention and muscle to the president's energy agenda and the battle over a patients' bill of rights as they push toward a summer recess at the end of this week. 
"The long and short of it is we don't have enough Democratic votes," said Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, as he announced that Republicans would wait until fall to consider legislation granting the president the authority to negotiate trade treaties that could not be amended by Congress and could only be approved or rejected via an up-or-down vote.
President Bush, answering questions from reporters in the Oval Office, spoke out against those who oppose giving the president such a free hand to strike trade deals. "Some people in America don't believe in free trade," he said. "Some people believe that a protectionist policy would be best for our country's economy and the workers. I strongly disagree."
He said he remained optimistic that he would prevail. "Whether we get it done before August is obviously up in the air," he said. "But I believe when it's all said and done that Congress will realize the benefits of free trade to the people of America."
The delay buys more time for the administration and House Republicans to mount a concerted lobbying effort and to negotiate a bill with the moderate Democrats whose support will be critical in the House.
But the delay could also pose problems for the president, making a Congressional timetable ever more uncertain. Last week, Mr. Bush said it was crucial to have the authority in time for a World Trade Organization conference in Qatar in November that could start a new round of global trade talks.
Every president since Gerald R. Ford has had the ability to negotiate trade deals that had to be voted up or down by lawmakers without changes. But after winning passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, President Clinton allowed the authority to lapse rather than take up a second trade issue that would divide his party. After that he was never able to win Congressional support for the authority.
Mr. Bush is encountering many of the same crosscurrents that stymied the Clinton administration -- including fierce resistance from labor unions to giving the president a free hand in trade talks. 
While Republicans generally support free trade, their support is not universal. That means Mr. Bush must draw votes from Democratic moderates in the House. Representative William M. Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, has begun trying to reach a compromise bill with some Democrats.
The moderates, however, want some assurances that labor and environmental standards can be safeguarded as part of trade negotiations, while conservative Republicans say they do not believe that trade agreements should be vehicles for enforcing social standards.

HEADLINE: Some Energy Executives Urge U.S. Shift on Global Warming 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN and NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
With President Bush continuing to oppose international or domestic restrictions on gases linked to global warming, among the losers are energy companies that favor government action and have already spent millions on voluntary efforts to cut emissions.
 Given little credence by the White House despite large expenditures on lobbying and longstanding ties to administration officials, these companies are shifting their focus to Congress, where several bills that would impose emissions restrictions are being debated or prepared. 
 But in that effort, the companies face formidable opposition from other energy concerns and trade groups that are fighting against any limits.
"There's an enormous amount of lobbying going on," said Rob Long, vice president for government affairs at the National Mining Association. "It's a three-ring circus." 
Among the companies that want the United States to embrace some form of greenhouse-gas limits are oil producers including the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and BP, as well as power-generating companies like Cinergy, AEP and Entergy, all of which have moved to reduce their own emissions. 
Another company holding this view is the Enron Corporation of Houston, whose chairman is Mr. Bush's friend Kenneth L. Lay. Enron was the largest contributor among energy companies last year to the Republican Party.
These companies, which include some of the world's biggest producers and users of fossil fuels, have concluded that limits on carbon dioxide and other greenhouse, or heat-trapping, gases are inevitable. They say that by packaging reductions in greenhouse gas emissions with other environmental measures, like cutting other power plant emissions, they could win concessions on other pollution rules.
And to plan long-term investments, they want the predictability that comes from quick adoption of clear rules, although more flexible ones than those agreed to in Bonn a week ago by 178 countries that have accepted the Kyoto Protocol, the worldwide climate agreement that President Bush rejects. 
Most of these businesses share Mr. Bush's view that the Kyoto agreement could hurt the United States economy and that it unfairly requires emissions reductions only of big industrial nations. But many officials of these companies said Mr. Bush had blundered by rejecting the agreement outright instead of trying to repair it.
"What businesses want is policy certainty," an environmental expert for a large international energy company said. "Bush has injected only turbulence."
For all their wealth, power and influence, though, these companies say they have been cut out of discussions at the White House. The only ideas that have risen to the highest levels there are those of companies staunchly opposing limits on emissions, according to lobbyists, government officials and executives.
The Bush administration denied last night that it was excluding any options or ideas in trying to develop an approach to global warming. A White House spokeswoman, Claire E. Buchan, said: "We are taking this issue very seriously. We're listening to constituencies who represent all perspectives."
In contrast to executives of companies seeking limits on the gases, people representing companies opposed to restrictions, including Exxon Mobil and many coal companies, said they thought that their message was resonating. 
Fredrick D. Palmer, executive vice president for legal and external affairs at Peabody Energy of St. Louis, one of the world's largest coal producers, said it was not really necessary to lobby the Bush administration on the issue, because Big Coal's interests and the administration's views were in sync from the start. 
"We don't need to be talking to the White House to know what they want," Mr. Palmer said. "I understand the importance of fossil fuels to the American people. Dick Cheney understands that. The president understands that."
For the moment, the two corporate camps -- which have dominated the discussion, with environmental groups largely locked out -- have turned to Congress, where an array of influential members from both parties is hoping to seize the initiative in policy making. 
Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, the independent and new chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, has said that global warming is his top priority. Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, has joined with Senator Robert C. Byrd, the veteran Democrat from West Virginia, a leading coal-producing state, in introducing a bill aimed at controlling emissions. Mr. Stevens has recently expressed deep concern about the apparently growing damage in his state from climate change.
The energy industry now is focusing its efforts on the energy legislation moving through the House. But company executives and lobbyists are also meeting with members of Congress and administration officials to shape the discussion over a variety of impending emissions measures and proposed changes in regulations. 
In mid-August, the Environmental Protection Agency is expected to make recommendations to the White House on how to reduce releases of nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide and mercury from power plants.
And Mr. Jeffords plans to hold meetings with industry, environmentalists and agency officials in September to seek a consensus on a bill to control the three pollutants, along with ways to limit carbon dioxide, the dominant greenhouse gas. 
The one thing so far that unifies the energy industry is its opposition to the Jeffords emissions bill in its current form, mainly because it stipulates that old power plants install the latest technology to clean up emissions within five years. Power producers say that the timetable is too stringent and that such a change would disproportionately hurt the Midwest, where most of the power is generated by older coal-fired plants that are targets of the legislation.
Beyond that, the industry separates into distinct camps. For energy companies willing to accept some limits on warming gases, one goal is to firm up a market for tradeable credits earned by companies that make sharp cuts in emissions or plant or protect forests, which absorb carbon dioxide.
For such credits to have value, a limit on emissions must exist, the company officials say. Aware of corporate resistance to mandatory limits, some energy industry executives and lobbyists have proposed that the government sponsor a voluntary program to reduce emissions. Once enrolled, companies would have to meet mandatory goals on reductions of greenhouse gases.
"We haven't said there must be mandatory caps on CO2," said Jeffrey Keeler, director of environmental strategies at Enron. "But it's been proven that voluntary programs don't work well; that's why we are where we are today. We can have limits from the top down and not endanger the economy."
Whether the Bush administration will accept even voluntary limits remains to be seen. And later this year, the White House will again be the focus of policy making. 
Businesses that share the view Mr. Bush expressed in March, when he rejected any binding limits on the warming gases, whether in a global accord or federal legislation, say they are confident that there will be no big shifts.
For example, Mr. Long, the mining association official, said he was perplexed by those companies that want to reduce carbon dioxide, which his group and its allies do not see as a pollutant or a threat to the environment.
"I think some of this is the hangover from the Clintonian era, when some of these emissions changes seemed inevitable," he said. "And I think some people got locked into that mind-set. I think the world changed in January. It can't have escaped their notice that the new president won't support constraints on CO2 ."
One of the staunchest foes of limits on carbon dioxide is the Southern Company of Atlanta, whose nuclear and coal-fired plants span Georgia, Florida, Alabama and Mississippi, and whose donations to the Republican Party last year were second only to Enron's. 
The company recently enlisted Haley Barbour, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee, as a lobbyist. Mr. Barbour mainly works to loosen enforcement of environmental regulations affecting utilities, though other Washington lobbyists said that he had also argued against action on reducing carbon dioxide emissions.
Mr. Barbour did not return phone calls yesterday seeking comment.
Power companies trying to find a way to reduce carbon dioxide emissions think they have greater sway with Congress than they have with the White House. "The closer we get to midterm elections," a utility executive said, "both sides of the Hill will feel a high degree of vulnerability on environmental issues, and some will retreat from the White House if they feel they need to."
In the meantime, opponents of emissions limits are not assuming that the Kyoto accord is dead, despite its having been greatly weakened by the rejection from the United States, the biggest emitter of greenhouse gases. 
Their lobbyists were out in force at last week's negotiations in Bonn, and they said they would keep working to defeat the international agreement, which is still subject to ratification in scores of countries. Among other things, they plan to keep pressure on the Bush administration to propose no alternatives -- particularly anything resembling a limit on greenhouse gases.
"The protocol is like the Titanic," said Glenn Kelly, executive director of the Global Climate Coalition, which has fought against the Kyoto agreement using contributions from industries that regard gas restrictions as a threat. 
Eventually, he said in an interview in Bonn, the Kyoto Protocol will hit an iceberg, but that will not be the end of the matter. "After it sinks," he said, "there are still going to be lifeboats that survive to be picked up by the next ship that comes along."
