HEADLINE: Making Plans for the New Economic Reality in Store for New York 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from an interview with Michael R. Bloomberg, the media entrepreneur and a Republican candidate for mayor. The interview was conducted yesterday by editors and reporters of The New York Times, and it is the fourth in a planned series of interviews with each of the major candidates.

Q. One guy all the candidates are talking about is Mayor Giuliani, about how they would be like him and how they would be unlike him. Give us your -- how would you be like him and unlike him?

A. Rudy has done the city a great service over the last eight years. I don't think there's any question but that by most measures this city is much more livable for almost all its citizens than it was eight years ago. Rudy was the beneficiary of a good economy. Rudy was the beneficiary of Washington focusing on helping cities. Rudy was the beneficiary of some demographic trends. But to not give Rudy credit for making a difference in this city seems to me ridiculous.
 I think his great contribution other than showing that the city was governable was the technique that he used. I would describe his management contribution to be trying to take down to the neighborhood level the accountability, responsibility along with authority, if you will, to tailor the delivery of services to each neighborhood. . . .
 Rudy's management style was to take down to the local level the delivery of services, tailoring it. And I think -- we can talk about education later -- but that is in fact exactly what you have to do. You have to find a way and there are all sorts of reasons why it's difficult to do, but every school is different in the same way every precinct is different. And you've got to find ways to let professionals deliver services tailored to the neighborhoods. And I think that's Rudy's big contribution. . . .
 I think the mistake that everybody makes when they try to compare themselves to Rudy is that Rudy governed during the last eight years and the next mayor is going to govern during the next four years. And those periods are going to be very different. There will be different opportunities and there will be different problems. The greatest, the most obvious, difference is that the economy for the next four years does not look like it's going to be the economy of the last, in number of years, 8 years, 10 years. . . .

Q. But circumstances aside, economic or otherwise, you've started putting on commercials in which you've said in essence that you will continue Rudy Giuliani's work. In a more personal way, how would you do that?

A. . . . What I've done is, I've focused No. 1 on our -- the only asset that matters, and that is our people. You can replace our technology, you can replace our data, you can replace our customer base, you can replace everything. I defy you to go ahead and try to put together 7,000 or 8,000 people that work together, that cooperate, that feel that they are making a contribution, that want to service our customers.
 That's what I've done. And my whole style, management style, is to focus on people. And I think that is the mayor's, in some senses after -- I'm saying a vision. The mayor's job is to get the quarter of a million people in this city who actually deliver the services to work together. . . .
 And my strategy, my style, has always been: the only time I snap at people is if they call me Mr. Bloomberg. My name is Mike, because I want to address everybody else by their first name. I am trying to do everything I can in our company, and I would try to do everything I can in the government. And they are different organizations and you can't do it the same ways. But the intent is certainly the same. In our company, we don't have walls. Nobody has private offices, including me. Why? Because those are impediments to people working together. . . .

Q. Give us some practical, practical ways in which you'd do that with this quarter-of-a-million work force. . . .

A. You've got to go and visit each department. You've got to have -- you've got to sit down. Most of the workers of the city are unionized. They've got to understand that you have a personal relationship outside of the adversarial contract negotiations, which unfortunately go on and on and on. The real damage there is that there's never a time when the mayor isn't an adversary. Once you make a pact, then the mayor, instead of being an adversary, is the advocate. And that's what you've got to find ways to do. And they are not big things. They are small things, of going around -- the mayor has to spend time in every borough, as many different neighborhoods as he can. But the mayor's got to also focus on all parts of the city, all of the different departments, and make those people understand. It may not be the biggest priority right now. We may not have enormous problems with that particular department. But that the mayor cares.

Q. Would that -- I'm sorry -- would that alone deal with the hard times that you say could be ----

A. No. Absolutely not.

Q. So what else do you do then?

A. . . . There's an awful lot of evidence that the future is happening right now. Visitors to the city -- down. Which means tax revenues go down. Wall Street business -- down. Means tax revenues are going to go down. Layoffs, tax revenues. I mean it's a whole variety of reasons why you know that the scenario from now on is lower tax revenue.
 At the same time, we don't know yet, but it's starting to look like the demand for services will go up. . . . And you know that the expense of the labor force is going up. . . .
 What happens in scenarios like that? The first thing that is normally done is smoke-and-mirrors accounting. That's a bad idea. Deferring maintenance. That's a terrible idea. And borrowing. All three things postpone for the future the solution. They take all the pain and roll it ahead so that you don't have to face it today. It's a feel-good thing. Everybody's happy. Whether it's the leader in a company or in government, those are the natural reactions.
 And I think we've seen just how bad the effect is of all three of those.
 Then, the next step, if things really get bad -- and everybody says they won't do it -- you have to cut services and/or raise taxes if things get really bad. You can't just print money. We're not the federal government.
 No. We are up against borrowing limits. You don't want to do that. Tax rises -- I don't think so. Particularly, you don't want to raise taxes when the economy is slowing down, and you want to make this city more attractive. . . .

Q. So what are you going to cut? What are your priorities? Which departments are first?

A. Well, I'll tell you how to go about that. It's very simple. Every department you have -- you can clearly go and say we're under pressure, no more hiring. That's the first stop. . . .

Q. Would a hiring freeze include the Police Department?

A. We unfortunately don't have to put a hiring freeze -- at the moment we cannot maintain the current size of the staff. And I think you have to do that. You have to -- in every case you have to say, if you cut back what is the effect and are we willing to tolerate that? . . . The first basic service that government has to provide is the safety of its citizens. You've got to be able to go out without looking over your shoulder. If you don't have that you don't have anything else.

Q. So is that what you're saying, that your hiring freeze would not apply to police?

A. No. I didn't say that. I said it would, if crime started to go up, I would make sure that it did not.

Q. What about the Board of Education? Would the same stand for hiring teachers?

A. Board of Ed. Let's talk about education. No. 1, I assume that by the fall -- by January -- or at least I hope by January the mayor has control over the Board of Ed. or chancellor, but controls the school system. There are a variety of ways you could work it out. There does seem to be a political consensus to give the mayor control. . . .

Q. Would you abolish the school board?

A. I don't know there's any reason, necessarily, for them. But it doesn't matter as long as the mayor has direct control. . . .

Q. What is the role of the mayor? You can exhort, as you are at this table. But how do you get what you want?

A. Well, the mayor's not without power. No. 1, in the new world, we hope the mayor will appoint the chancellor, either directly or through a board. No. 2, the mayor does negotiate the contract with the unions. You know, it's easy to go and to whip the U.F.T. But the last time I checked, it took two parties to make a contract. And if somebody in -- some mayor agreed to every single thing in the U.F.T.'s contract. And some of the stuff in the U.F.T.'s contract clearly does not help the educational process. I think that's a nice way to phrase it. Can you imagine what kind of police services we would have? What public safety we would have if every police officer could pick which neighborhood they worked in and which job they took and which shift they took? Come on. That's exactly what's happened with the U.F.T. contract. But you can't just blame the U.F.T. I suppose you can't blame them at all because their job is to get the best deal for their members. It's the city that has abrogated its responsibility when it came time to negotiate. . . .
 The principal is the person that I would put in charge of the school and make them responsible and accountable and to make sure that they have the authority to do what they need to to. The U.F.T.'s contract says that the teachers can pick the school, pick the grade, whatever. Can't do that. You have to let the principal move the labor force around and assign teachers to where they are needed. . . . 

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, Mr. Ferrer was in here the other day and said that fear defines the relationship with a large number of people in the city, between them and the police.

A. I don't know whether large is the right answer -- the right word or not. But I think it clearly is true. . . . How would you like to be a young teenager bopping down the street on a dark night and you turn the corner and there are these two big cops coming at you? Forget about whether they're black or white or Latino or Asian or whatever. There is a natural fear. It comes out of abuses in society -- some probably written about more than -- it's not every day with everybody. But there's no question that that is a fact. O.K. Let's do something about it. . . . You go to the schools; you go to the churches; you enlist the teachers and the clergy; you invite people down; you find programs that get the teenagers and the police to get to know each other a little better. And you have education programs. You have measurement tools to make sure. You know, nothing wrong with looking at the racial makeup of those stopped and then decide whether or not it is racial profiling or whether it was reflecting whatever that particular community happened to be. I mean, you know, there are problems. . . . And you cannot have any tolerance whatsoever for the abuses. . . .

Q. Mr. Bloomberg, the message coming from this mayor, unspoken, the last eight years is that a certain level of civil rights abuse -- not Louima . . . but stop-and-frisks, for example -- a certain level of what many would say are civil rights abuses is tolerable in order to keep crime down. And that's the bargain that society has struck in New York City in the last two terms. Do you think a certain level of civil rights abuses are tolerable to keep crime down?

A. Well there is a level that we -- whether it's this level or a different level. The extremes are places like China where you have no civil liberties, but a billion-odd people do have jobs. They're not starving in China, but there's certainly no freedom. Singapore where it's -- the Singapore people if you -- most Singaporeans would think that they made a good bargain ----

Q. Let's talk about ----

A. I was working down to New York. In New York, I think if you ask most people are they willing to have certain limitations placed on them if the quid pro quo is safe streets. Yes. I'll give you a good example. Washington Square Park is under constant surveillance now by police cameras. It is posted. It says: area under surveillance. Whether that has satisfied the A.C.L.U. or not, I don't know. I haven't seen anybody take them to court, so presumably they don't mind it or they think that they would not have a good case. But I think most of the residents who live around that park would say having that surveillance, that intrusion on their personal privacy, is a good compromise for getting rid of the drug dealers.

Q. What about stopping and frisking? . . .

A. Well, No. 1, if it's done based on race, clearly it is against the law.

Q. Well if you're in a black neighborhood they're going to be black. To play devil's advocate.

A. Are they doing the same things in the white neighborhoods? That would give me some comfort that it was not racial profiling. That would be a test. In white neighborhoods, do they stop four teenagers as frequently as they stop four teenagers in a black neighborhood? . . .

Q. You've said a couple of times that you wouldn't raise taxes. Are there any taxes that you would either cut back or abolish?

A. Well, I think -- there's 22 separate city taxes. And anything that doesn't bring in appreciable revenue, yes. . . .

Q. There seems to be a bit of a bandwagon among some of your opponents to take the World Trade Center tax revenue -- $100 million -- and put that into subsidized housing. Are you part of that steamroller?

A. I'm fundamentally opposed to dedicating any stream of revenue to any particular project. In a world where we just had a long conversation about how you were going to have cutbacks and make hard choices, you don't want to go and get around that through either the normal subterfuge of creating agencies so that you can borrow against revenues that may or may not be there.

Q. The city, to the extent that it's had an economic development strategy has been to give people like you large amounts of money to stay in the city. And I'm thinking of the New York Stock Exchange and thinking about your new building. Are you going to take the money? And should other people take the money?

A. They haven't given us anything. For 20 years they have offered us, every time we've redone a lease, tax incentives. And we have never taken them. I have instructed the guy who is running the company to postpone that decision till after the election because I don't want people to say he did or did not do it for political reasons. And from a practical point of view, remember, if I did walk away from $14 million, you'd write a story: Oh, Mike just spent another $14 million to become mayor. If I do it afterwards, it'll have absolutely nothing to do with it. Come on, you're not going to trap me into that one. . . .

Q. If you are elected mayor, speaking about your company, and the public doesn't know who the private partners are that own the shares that you privately, in your family, don't own. How will the citizens know whether or not there's a conflict of interest in the way that you ----

A. If the Conflict of Interest Board said we should disclose it, I would not have a problem. It's been in the papers. . . .

Q. In your disclosure forms it's not there.

A. I understand that, but I don't have an obligation to disclose what other people are doing. I have an obligation to disclose what I'm doing. But I believe the answer to your question is, it is public knowledge who the other partners are? They're all tiny, it's not going to be a conflict. And if the Conflict of Interest Board thinks it is, I'll tell them. . . .

Q. How much do you think you're going to spend of your own money to get elected in this race?

A. I don't know.

Q. What's an outer limit, do you think?

A. I've said that I will spend what I think is required to -- I think I'll spend what is required to get my message out. I think if you take a look at the history of self-financed candidates, three-quarters lose. There's no evidence that you can buy it and it's sort of insulting to the public to think you can buy an election. . . .

HEADLINE: Verizon Posts a Loss and Cuts 2001 Forecasts 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Verizon Communications lowered its profit forecast for the year yesterday, citing falling demand for business phone services, and it posted a second-quarter loss as the value of some investments dropped.
 Verizon, one of the regional Bell giants, said that before write-downs it expected a profit of $3.07 to $3.12 a share, down from the $3.13 to $3.17 it had forecast earlier. 
 It also cut its sales-growth forecast to a range of 5 to 6 percent from 7 percent in April. 
Verizon, based in New York, had 62.5 million phone lines in June, down 0.4 percent from a year earlier. It was the first time that Verizon, or the companies that merged to form it, Bell Atlantic and GTE, had such a drop in at least eight years, a spokesman, Peter Thonis, said.
The company's chief financial officer, Fred Salerno, said that job cutbacks by businesses, increased use of mobile phones and slowing American economic growth all reduced demand. Last week, BellSouth and Qwest Communications International trimmed their full-year forecasts, citing the weak economy.
Shares of Verizon fell $1.87 yesterday, to $54.15.
For the second quarter, the company reported a loss of $1 billion, or 38 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $4.9 billion, or $1.79 a share, in the period a year earlier.
Revenue, adjusted for the sale of wireless properties, rose 5 percent, to $16.9 billion, the company said.
The recent quarter's loss reflected $3.1 billion in special charges, including $2.9 billion in investment write-downs related to stakes in Cable and Wireless P.L.C., NTL Inc. and the Metromedia Fiber Network, and $162 million from consolidating billing systems and offices. In the period a year earlier, Verizon said it had a net gain of $2.9 billion. That included a gain of $1.9 billion from restructuring an investment and $1.5 billion from asset sales. The company also had $749 million in merger costs.
Excluding those items, Verizon's profit rose to $2.1 billion, or 77 cents a share, from $2 billion, or 72 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. On that basis, the company matched analysts' estimates.
Second-quarter sales of data-transmission services rose 25 percent, the company said. Verizon added 120,000 customers for fast Internet access, for a total of 840,000. The number of long-distance customers increased 804,000, to 6 million, as Verizon aggressively solicited business in New York and other states where it has been authorized by the F.C.C. to provide long-distance service. 
Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest mobile phone operator and a joint venture of Verizon and the Vodafone Group, added 808,000 subscribers, for a total of 27.9 million, up 13 percent from a year earlier.
After delaying its initial stock sale, Verizon Wireless said it might revise the terms of an agreement to buy a unit of Price Communications. Under a deal announced last November, Verizon was to acquire Price Communications Wireless for $2.06 billion.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE ART; 
Matching The Battery To the Task

BYLINE:  By David Pogue; E-mail: Pogue@nytimes.com

 BODY:
IF the F.B.I. ever singled me out for surveillance, its final report wouldn't hold much interest. "Wife, two kids, dog. Watches 'Survivor.' Aversion to mayo." Only one line at the end of the document might seem a little peculiar. "Buys AA batteries by the gross."
 These days, most gizmos -- digital cameras, palmtops, music players -- seem to have been designed in a conspiracy with Duracell: they guzzle batteries like Gatorade at the marathon finish line. And it's not just me. According to an Industrial Market Research survey, the average American has about 25 battery-operated gadgets in the house, up from only 7 in 1987. 
 The battery makers, of course, are delighted. All around us, we see ads for new kinds of batteries that "offer unsurpassed power for today's demanding devices," "last longer on high-tech devices" and have "longer service life." In the name of science, I decided to perform a few simple tests: I'd pop sets of each heavily hyped battery into, say, a Palm organizer and see how long they took to run down. What could be more scientific? 
As it turns out, almost anything. When I shared my plans with representatives of the Big Three -- Duracell, Eveready and Rayovac -- they told me, with the weary sighs of people who explain this point to journalists every day, that battery run-down tests are terribly misleading. For starters, a battery designed to excel in such a test would do poorly in the real world, where people play, pause and put aside their electronics for days or weeks. Who on earth actually runs a gadget continuously until it's out of power? (Game Boy owners, you can put your hands down.) Furthermore, the battery makers say, there is much greater inconsistency in the power consumption of supposedly identical devices than between two different batteries.
"We'd be delighted to help you design valid tests," one battery company representative said. "And we'll look forward to reading the results around Christmas."
When people conduct proper battery tests -- the repetitive, expensive, computer-controlled sort prescribed by the American National Standards Institute -- they find little variation across brands. One such test, published by Consumer Reports in March, offered a straightforward conclusion: When you need standard alkalines, ignore the marketing; just buy the cheapest ones.
Whatever size you're looking for, from tiny AAA's to fat C's and D's, the hard part is figuring out whether to buy the standard alkalines or some other type. Until 1980, you had only one type to choose: the silver "heavy duty" batteries, like the Eveready types with the black-cat logo. But that era is long over. 
What replaced those old "standard" batteries is a wide and confusing range of higher-powered battery types: alkaline, premium alkaline, rechargeable alkaline, nickel metal hydride and lithium. (All told, 92 percent of the batteries sold nationwide are alkalines, which offer from two to six times as much life at roughly the same price as the old "heavy duty" type.) 
It would feel glorious to declare one type the winner and then rent a movie to celebrate. Alas, batteries aren't that simple. 
In general, you can break down today's battery-operated devices into three categories. First, there are low-drain gadgets that sip power with all the gusto of an elderly aunt at afternoon tea: radios, clocks and flashlights that you keep on hand only for emergencies.
The vast majority of today's electronic gizmos fall into the moderate-drain category: tape recorders, Game Boys, music and CD players, electronic toys, pagers, boomboxes, smoke detectors, remote controls and flashlights that you'll use a lot -- when camping, for example. The third category, high-drain devices, has only a few occupants -- like digital cameras, palmtops, remote-control toys, portable televisions and photo flash units -- but is likely to see more arrivals in the next few years. 
Once you've grasped that much background, buying batteries is fairly simple: for low- and medium-powered equipment, standard alkalines offer the best power per penny. 
Battery selection for high-drain gear, however, is where the game gets interesting. In a typical digital camera, standard alkalines might last all of 30 minutes, as many a crestfallen consumer discovers. 
That's why some companies are touting something called premium alkalines -- reformulated batteries designed to last longer than standard alkalines in high-drain gadgetry. (The improvements include, as Duracell puts it, "proprietary separator material, enhanced cathode design and a high-power anode composition," just as you probably suspected.)
Duracell, for example, says that its premium battery, called Ultra, lasts up to twice as long as standard copper-tops in high-drain electronics. (Energizer's E2 line is also a premium alkaline, but Consumer Reports says it's not much more powerful than standard alkalines.) 
On the other hand, Ultra isn't as effective in medium- or low-drain electronics, offering an improvement of less than 50 percent, Duracell says, over standard alkalines. Any improvement is welcome, of course, but remember that Ultras cost about $1 apiece in a multipack, twice the price of store-brand regular alkalines. In other words, the convenience of Ultras is worth paying for in your Palm, television or digital camera but may be a waste of money in ordinary devices. 
But even premium alkalines can't power a digital camera for more than about 60 minutes of shooting, viewing and deleting pictures -- still not enough to last the whole day at Six Flags, let alone your two-week vacation. 
The final step up, therefore, is lithium batteries (not to be confused with lithium-ion laptop batteries) -- very expensive cells ($10 for four) that last five times as long as standard alkalines in high-drain electronics. Only Energizer makes AA lithiums. Duracell makes a lithium power pack called CV3 that looks like two AA batteries fused together, but it fits only certain digital camera models from Casio, Kodak and Olympus, for example, that have been designed to accept them.
If you use a high-drain device almost every day (this means you, palmtop and digital-photography addicts), the ultimate solution to the battery problem is nickel metal hydride (NiMH) batteries. Not only do they last even longer than premium alkalines, but for the ultimate in economy, you can recharge them 500 to 1,000 times by snapping them into a charger plugged into the wall. 
Rayovac's superb $30 charger (for AA, AAA and 9-volt sizes) rejuvenates drained NiMH's in one hour or less, a great improvement over previous chargers. (You'd think that engineers would have devised a shorthand for this battery's name, so they don't have to spend their days shouting, "Yo, Frank, should I put these nickel metal hydrides over on the nickel metal hydride shelf?" But they haven't.) 
The trouble with NiMH's is that they lose their charge over time -- about 15 percent per month. That makes them poor choices for long-term locations like remote controls, smoke detectors, digital cameras used only occasionally and, for that matter, the kitchen battery drawer. Some people keep one set in the charger and a second set in the camera, so they're always ready; but that's a lot of complication. At this point, rechargeables (including rechargeable alkalines, short-lived batteries that you can recharge only a few times) represent only 1 percent of battery sales. On the other hand, it's the fastest-growing battery category.
If you'd like to minimize complexity and maximize economy, then, the bottom line is this: Buy standard alkalines for everyday gadgets. Cheap store brands generally do just as well as big-name brands. In digital cameras, palmtops and other high-powered gizmos, buy rechargeable nickel metal hydrides (for gear you use daily) or Duracell Ultras (for gear you store between uses). 
Oh, and don't bother trying to conduct your own battery of tests.

When the Juice Runs Low (or Cold)
As it turns out, there's more to life with batteries than battery life. Here are some tips for smooth sailing:
* Don't put batteries in the refrigerator. Alkalines last at least seven years on the shelf at room temperature. A cold battery takes time to warm up before it's functional; worse, it sweats just like a can of cold soda. Do you really want moisture trickling into the guts of your $600 digital camera?
* They're still good. Just because a battery can no longer supply the power pulses required by digital cameras and flash attachments doesn't mean it's dead. Once removed from such high-drain devices, a battery still has plenty of juice for low-drain gadgets like clocks, remote controls and radios. 
* Don't mix old and new. Move those half-depleted cells straight into those clocks and radios. The problem with mixing old and new batteries in the kitchen drawer is that you risk inserting a mixed set into a device. Later, when the weakest battery dies, the electricity flowing through it from the newer batteries may make it leak, ruining both it and your appliance.
* Take them out for storage. If you won't be using a gadget for months, take out the batteries to avoid the same dying-and-leaking syndrome.
* It's O.K. to throw them away. Batteries haven't contained mercury since about 1993; Ric Erdheim, senior manager for government affairs at the National Electrical Manufacturing Association, says it is perfectly safe to toss them into your household trash. A few towns with incinerators still have battery collection days, a holdover from the mercury era, but they are fading away. Worn-out rechargeables are a different story, however. Take them to the collection buckets at chain stores like RadioShack and Circuit City. DAVID POGUE

HEADLINE: Phillips Group Shelves Plans For Gas Pipeline to Australia 

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
Phillips Petroleum and its partners will shelve plans to build a $500 million pipeline from gas fields under the Timor Sea to Darwin, Australia, because a tangle of legal and tax issues are unresolved, executives said today.
 The pipeline is considered crucial to development of the Bayu-Undan gas fields, whose estimated reserves of 3.4 trillion cubic feet of natural gas are by far the most economically important resource belonging to East Timor. 
Phillips, the lead partner in the group developing the field, planned to distribute the gas in Australia, where demand is strong, and to process condensates from the gas into bulk products for shipment to Asia and the United States. 
 The group decided 18 months ago to go ahead with the project, but Australia and East Timor argued until last month over how to divide revenue from gas fields under the waters that separate them.
The problem now, Phillips executives said, is that issues thought to have been clarified at the outset, like tax rates, are back in flux. "We began it on the basis that the legal regime would continue for the life of the project," said Jim Godlove, Darwin area manager for Phillips. But East Timor is now talking about raising tax rates, costing Phillips and its partners "a lot more than $500 million," he said.
Australia's foreign minister, Alexander Downer, expressed disappointment at the Phillips decision and frustration with East Timor. "It's important for East Timor's standing in the international investor community that commitments made by the leaders of East Timor are adhered to," he said.
Mr. Godlove said the project would not move ahead until all the legal and financial issues were resolved "as a package."

PERSON: Martin Stern Jr. 

HEADLINE: Martin Stern Jr., 84, Architect, Dies; Redefined Vegas Skyline 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Martin Stern Jr., an architect who pioneered the eye-popping Googie-style coffee-shop architecture of Los Angeles and then brought his exuberant vision to the skyline of the Las Vegas strip, died on Saturday at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 84.
 Mr. Stern designed three Ships coffee shops in Los Angeles in 1956 and 1957 that joined the pantheon of what came to be called Googie architecture -- an enthusiastic cocktail of neon, modern design principles and clever signage. Preservationists protested mightily when the shops -- featuring distinctive orange color schemes and looking like rocket ships about to blast off -- were demolished during the 1980's and 90's. 
 Mr. Stern went on to design a significant part of Las Vegas's skyline, including a skyscraper and convention center at the Sahara Hotel and the MGM Grand Hotel, which became Bally's. He also designed the 26-story Mint Hotel.
He was part of the second generation of Las Vegas architects. Space had become more expensive, and the sprawling motel-like developments of earlier years no longer made economic sense. He and contemporaries like Wayne McAllister adapted by building hotels with towers that replaced neon signs as the defining elements.
"Gone was the sleek and low-slung intimacy of lounges, manicured lawns with rambling motel wings with private box balconies overlooking the pool with its beauties, replaced with a bigger, bolder and self-confident look of a legitimate corporate business," Peter Michel wrote on the Web site of the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, to which Mr. Stern donated his architectural drawings. "There is much of the history of Las Vegas in the drawings of Martin Stern Jr.," Mr. Michel wrote.
Mr. Stern designed the Sahara Hotel's first skyscraper (14 stories) in 1959, its convention center in 1967, a 342-room high-rise addition in 1977 and a 625-room high-rise addition in 1979. He became known for his attention to the sort of details that make money. One trademark was the tower with the top floor wider than those below, to accommodate luxury suites with panoramic views. 
Steven Izenour, a Philadelphia architect and one of the authors of the 1972 book "Learning From Las Vegas," said Mr. Stern and his contemporaries "took the vocabulary of modern architecture and turned it into an ornamental style." He said Robert Venturi, who with Denise Scott Brown was a co-author of the book, called the approach "the architecture of the decorated shed."
Mr. Izenour argued that Mr. Stern's design has stood the test of time, calling it "wonderfully funky." He predicted that the Las Vegas style that succeeded that of Mr. Stern's generation -- huge theme parks modeled on New York City and other themes -- would fade, with Mr. Stern's style possibly making a comeback. He said, "In hindsight, it was a lot more sophisticated than people gave it credit for at the time."
Mr. Stern is survived by his wife, Chantal; three sons; a daughter; a sister; and four grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Designed by Martin Stern Jr.: left, a mid-1950's coffee shop in Los Angeles; the 1973 MGM Grand Hotel (now Bally's), right, in Las Vegas. (George Tames/The New York Times); (University of Nevada, Las Vegas)

HEADLINE: Pricewaterhouse Consulting Is Planning Further Layoffs 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
The consulting arm of PricewaterhouseCoopers warned employees of another round of layoffs yesterday, primarily in its United States offices, affecting as many as 800 people, or 5 percent of its consultants and support staff.
 The move by PricewaterhouseCoopers, one of the world's big accounting and consulting firms, is an effort to cut costs in response to sharply declining demand by clients for consulting services, Pricewaterhouse executives said. 
 Analysts said that while all consulting firms face difficult times, PricewaterhouseCoopers seems to be in a particularly awkward place. This is its second round of layoffs -- the first one in the spring affected about 1,000 employees -- and the direction of the consulting unit, which was almost sold to Hewlett-Packard late last year, is unclear. 
Mike Collins, managing partner of the Pricewaterhouse consulting arm for North America, said in a telephone interview yesterday: "Unfortunately, the costs of consulting have grown as a result of the strong economy of recent years, and have not yet been reset to reflect the current environment. We're basically doing the same thing we would tell our clients to do."
PricewaterhouseCoopers will reduce base compensation for both junior consultants and partners by 5 to 10 percent, Mr. Collins said. In addition, a greater portion of employees' salaries will depend on individual and team performance. The salary reductions and layoffs will take effect over the next few months.
The firm will also cut back recruiting efforts on college and business school campuses this fall, and has asked recent graduates who were to begin work in the fall to defer their starting dates. Pricewaterhouse will tell prospective employees by April 2002 whether and when they may start work, a spokeswoman said.
The changes are "reflective of PWC's position right now in the marketplace," said Tom Rodenhauser of Consulting Information Services in Keene, N.H. The PricewaterhouseCoopers consulting arm, he said, is not as big as Accenture or IBM Global Services, both technology services consultants, but is not a traditional division of an accounting firm, like Deloitte Consulting or Arthur Andersen's consulting business, either.
Some of the changes might also be preparation for a transaction involving the consulting business, several analysts said. Indeed, Pricewaterhouse's Mr. Collins said the firm still planned either a public offering for the consulting unit or a sale to an outside buyer, but he did not give a timetable. "We're not interested in doing a fast transaction if it's not the right transaction," he said.
Over all, the consulting business is suffering from the slowdown in the economy, which has led companies in a variety of industries to cut back spending. Growth in revenue at the 50 highest-grossing consulting firms fell last year to 11.7 percent from 19.7 percent in 1999, according to Kennedy Information, which tracks the industry, and consultants at several firms say privately that growth has fallen further this year.
"The big guys are all hemorrhaging," Mr. Rodenhauser said. "The business turned so sharply and they were caught with so much overcapacity that it was inevitable that they would have to cut."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Ferrer Accents Message With Appeals to Different Audiences

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
 Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and candidate for the Democratic nomination for mayor, is running two new television commercials -- one in English, one in Spanish. The English ad is scheduled to begin appearing today on English-language stations. The Spanish ad, which began yesterday, is being broadcast locally on Telemundo and Univision. 

English-Language Spot

PRODUCER -- Axelrod and Associates

ON THE SCREEN -- H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and Democratic candidate for governor speaking and then black-and-white photographs of boarded-up buildings and trash-strewn streets. Then Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former congresswoman, speaking, followed by photos of Mr. Ferrer attending a groundbreaking with Mayor Edward I. Koch and cleaning graffiti off a building. Then Mr. McCall and Ms. Ferraro applauding Mr. Ferrer, who is shown last, talking with children, lecturing a room full of people and hugging a child with Puerto Rican flags in the background.

THE SCRIPT -- "When he started off in the Bronx, it was in terrible shape," Mr. McCall says. "It was the poster child for urban blight."
Ms. Ferraro: "Burned out buildings, buildings boarded up. Freddy rolled up his sleeves and went in and worked hard to make this borough live again."

Mr. McCall: "Freddy came from a place that was hopeless and helpless and he made something of himself and his community. His purpose will be to unite the city and to make sure that everybody shares in the great benefits New York has to offer."
Ms. Ferraro: "Freddy Ferrer is going to be a mayor for all New Yorkers."

ACCURACY -- Mr. Ferrer grew up in a less-than-affluent household in the South Bronx, went to college and now lives in Riverdale. The Bronx endured a period of fires, abandonment and devastation, and it has made an extraordinary comeback. The rebirth involved immigration, private investment and a costly commitment of public money. As borough president since 1987, Mr. Ferrer participated in the recovery, but other city officials and community groups generally receive the bulk of the credit.

SCORECARD -- The ad effectively introduces Mr. Ferrer to voters as a man who came from common roots and participated in the Bronx's revival. It also pushes a central theme of Mr. Ferrer's candidacy, that he intends to speak for voters in those parts of the city -- like the Bronx -- that he believes have been ignored. Finally, the commercial makes a pitch to black and Hispanic voters, upon whom Mr. Ferrer's mayoral ambitions hinge.

Spanish-Language Spot

PRODUCER -- Axelrod and Associates

ON THE SCREEN -- This ad opens with the National Puerto Rican Day Parade and a banner bearing Mr. Ferrer's name. Then images of Mr. Ferrer walking in the parade and waving to a crowd. Mr. Ferrer is shown talking with students and then hugging children. A group of singing children appear. The ad ends with Mr. Ferrer in a crowd, clasping his hands with others and raising them into the air. Campaign promises flash throughout the commercial: "After-school programs for all neighborhoods," "A certified teacher in every classroom," and "150,000 new homes at moderate prices."

THE SCRIPT -- A drum beat followed by a narrator: "He is leading the march to put a qualified teacher in each classroom, because education was the road that lifted him from poverty to public service. He is leading the march so that our children have after-school programs, like those that once saved him from the dangers of the streets. He is leading the march to build houses at moderate prices. Fernando Ferrer is one of us. And he will be the mayor of all New Yorkers."

ACCURACY -- Mr. Ferrer is a product of Roman Catholic parochial schools and says he attended two after-school programs while growing up in the South Bronx during a time of economic hardship. Like most of the other candidates, Mr. Ferrer has promised to raise the qualifications of New York's public school teachers. He has promised to restore an income tax surcharge that was recently reduced and to use the money for after-school programs in middle schools. And he has promised to oversee the construction of 150,000 new homes.

SCORECARD -- With Puerto Rican flags waving in the background, this commercial makes a direct appeal to New York's two million-plus Latinos. Unlike Mr. Ferrer's English-language commercial, this one assumes that its viewers already know him. The sentence "Fernando Ferrer is one of us" is a blunt appeal for ethnic solidarity. "He will be the mayor of all New Yorkers" plays up one of Mr. Ferrer's main themes -- that many people in the city, particularly blacks and Hispanics, have not fully benefited from New York City's economic growth. HEADLINE: Vallone Asks Superintendents To Help Cut Board's Costs 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said yesterday that Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy had ignored an agreement with the Council to cut administrative spending at the Board of Education. As a result, he is personally asking school district superintendents their ideas for cost savings at the board and budget priorities for the coming year.
 Mr. Vallone's comments were in the unusual form of a letter to the 40 superintendents who oversee the community and high school districts that make up the New York City school system and who report directly to Mr. Levy. 
 The letter states that Mr. Vallone is "working together with the Chancellor," but even some members of Mr. Vallone's staff said it was was a not-too-subtle rebuke of Mr. Levy. The letter is scheduled to be mailed today.
Karen Finney, a spokeswoman for Mr. Levy, said he planned to offer details of his proposed administrative cuts next week. Over the last month, Mr. Levy has complained loudly and frequently that the budget adopted in June by the City Council and the mayor leaves the school system with $120 million less to spend on classroom activities in the coming school year than it had in the year that just ended.
Yesterday, at a news conference with union leaders and members of school boards at Intermediate School 131 on Manhattan's Lower East Side, Mr. Levy said the expected adoption of a stripped-down budget by the State Legislature could force the Board of Education to cut even more than the $120 million he has asked the district superintendents to prepare for. That $120 million shortfall is based on an allocation from the city and on the governor's budget, which was proposed in January.
In Albany, Joseph Conway, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, said that the Legislature's adoption of an austerity budget would make New York City's situation worse than it would have been if the governor's proposal had been adopted. He said the bare-bones budget that the Legislature is passing would give New York City only 16 percent of the governor's proposed $382 million statewide increase, rather than the 38 percent it would have gotten in the governor's original budget.
Mr. Vallone, as well as other City Council members and mayoral candidates, has expressed frustration that Mr. Levy has portrayed the Board of Education's budget as having been cut. In the letter, Mr. Vallone points out that the Board of Education's $11.5 billion budget actually includes a $183 million increase in city funds for the board.
Mr. Levy, however, has contended that because of inflation and mandated spending increases on salaries and other items, the school system is in fact left with $120 million less than it had last year. Mr. Levy has asked district superintendents to prepare plans for budget cuts should the Council or the state not increase financing for the school system later this year, which Ms. Finney said was part of the agreement with the Council to come up with cuts, which must be made by the end of the summer.
But Mr. Vallone said that "runs contrary to the Council's intent."
"In addition to the $183 million increase, the budget included a term and condition that requires the Board of Education to make a good-faith effort to generate administrative savings," Mr. Vallone stated in the letter. Once the board did so, "the Council would allocate additional funds for classroom instruction to supplement the original $183 million increase."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, at Intermediate School 131 in the Lower East Side, said the school board faces even more cuts. (Krista Niles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Experts on Mexican Trucking Say Safety Issue Is Misleading 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
About 1,500 miles from this border city, on Capitol Hill in Washington, the prevailing wisdom is that unsafe, badly maintained Mexican trucks are about to invade the United States unless Congress maintains a ban that has kept Mexican truckers from traveling more than a few miles inside the border.
 But experts on both sides of the border say opponents of Mexican trucking, including the Teamsters union, have marshaled safety statistics that on close examination are misleading or incomplete. 
 There appear to be little or no data to prove that Mexican long-haul trucks and truckers are far more dangerous than their American counterparts, experts say.
The trucks that make the crossings along the 2,100-mile border with the United States are purposely older and less well-maintained vehicles used solely to travel the short distances from terminals on the Mexican side to depots on the American side. They would never be used for long hauls into the United States. 
Those short-haul trucks are often forced to idle at clogged crossings and by law cannot travel more than 20 miles beyond the border. The American opponents of Mexican trucking have cited safety statistics on those trucks -- 36 percent failed safety checks last year, according to the federal government -- to block attempts to lift the 20-mile limit.
In approving a $60 billion transportation bill, the Senate voted today to continue limits on Mexican trucks and imposed new safety and insurance restrictions on Mexican trucking businesses. President Bush has threatened to veto the measure because it would block his plan for Mexican trucks. Page A8. 
People pushing to lift the ban on Mexican trucks said the fight would resume next month if the new rules were not changed in a compromise with the House. The White House, which wants the prohibitions lifted, said the Senate vote would hurt chances of improving ties to Mexico. 
Mexican trucking owners dismiss the idea that they would send fleets of long-haul Mexican trucks roaming American roadways if Congress relented and the mileage limit and other rules that the Clinton administration unilaterally imposed on the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1995 are eliminated.
"That's not reality," said Roberto Quintanilla, president of CenSeCar, a large trucking company here in Nuevo Laredo, the gateway for 40 percent of the overland trade between Mexico and the United States. 
"Neither Mexican nor American trucking companies have the wherewithal to make a buck on the other side of the border," Mr. Quintanilla said. "Someday, it might be good business to do it. But the politicians up there should come down here, spend a day on the border, see what's going on, learn a little about Nafta."
Manuel Gomez Garcia, president of a Mexican trucking association, Canacar, said: "It's never going to make economic sense to send Mexican trucks to New York or Chicago. No way. It would be more practical for us to close up all our operations and reincorporate in the United States" -- and that is a highly unlikely prospect.
Since Nafta took effect in 1994, fewer than 2 percent of the trucking companies in Mexico have applied to do business in the United States. Only the best-run best-financed and most professional could do so profitably, Mexican and American businessmen and officials said.
"This argument has nothing to do with safety," said Jim Giermanski, for many years an academic expert on cross-border commerce who is director of international business studies at Belmont Abbey College in Belmont, N.C. "It has everything to do with politics and money."
The image of Mexican truckers painted in Washington is overblown, with the threat posed by thousands of illiterate peasants barreling down Interstates, behind the wheels of 40-ton tractor-trailers with bad brakes.
"There is going to be blood on the highway," said Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon, one of hundreds of lawmakers who are trying to retain the mileage limit.
"Nafta is a trade pact," Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, said during a House vote five weeks ago. "It is not a suicide pact." 
The House voted to bar the Transportation Department from approving requests from Mexican truckers to operate in the United States.
In Mexico, as in the United States, there are two trucking businesses, long-haul companies that use newer, better-maintained vehicles, and short-haulers with more aged fleets who need to travel just short distances. "It's true that some of those trucks are in bad condition and that some of the operators don't have the best training," Mr. Gomez of the trucking group said. "But I know, and the Americans know better than to confuse the long-haul with the short-haul trucks."
Mexican products rolling into the United States arrive at a Mexican border depot on long-haul trucks. They are loaded onto short-haulers that go back and forth over the border between depots on each side. Finally, an American long-haul trucker takes the cargo from the American border depot to its United States destination. That makes at least three trucks to cross one line, although sometimes five are needed, experts said. The point of the Nafta provisions, Mexican and American officials said, was to streamline the process and cut costs.
"Everybody knows the movement of goods across the border today is immensely inefficient and so costly that it defeats Nafta's goals," said John Simpson, president of the Association of American Importers and Exporters and a former senior Treasury Department official.
In the Nafta debate in Washington, the foes of Mexican truckers relied on faulty Transportation Department figures that showed that 4.5 million Mexican trucks crossed into the United States in 1999. If a high percentage had safety problems, the opponents said, it stood to reason that great convoys of defective Mexican trucks would soon be crisscrossing the United States.
The Teamsters president, James P. Hoffa, said last month at a hearing that 36 percent of the Mexican trucks inspected on the American side of the border last year had something wrong with them, providing "a recipe for disaster." 
Because American trucks inspected throughout the United States, Mr. Hoffa said, have a 25 percent failure rate, Mexican truckers threatened the safety of American families, not to mention the jobs of law-abiding Teamsters.
In fact, the correct number of trucks that crossed the border in 1999 was 63,000, each making many trips across the border, the Transportation Department now says. 
They were short-haul trucks, making for an apples-and-oranges comparison with safety information. The one-quarter of American trucks that fail roadside inspections are overwhelmingly long-haul trucks, and not short-haul rigs, according to experts. 
By comparison, short-haul trucks that transport cargo to and from rail yards in Kansas City, Mo., have a failure rate of 45 percent, according to the Kansas City police.
The American trucking industry has its own safety problems. Accidents that involve heavy trucks have killed an average of 5,000 people a year for 15 years. Similar figures from Mexico are not available.
The Transportation Department has told Congress that "once the border is open to long-haul traffic, the number and percentage of safety-compliant Mexican trucks will dramatically increase, because long-haul trucks will be different from, and in better condition, than the shorter-haul trucks."
Even if the rules change to let long-haul Mexican truckers enter the United States, Mexican trucking companies would have to apply to the Transportation Department and meet United States legal standards to operate in the United States. 
Given the opportunity to apply, most Mexican trucking companies have declined. They would have to clear their practices with the Transportation Department, review their books with the Internal Revenue Service and pay federal, state, local and payroll taxes for the drivers.
"The fact is," Mr. Giermanski said, "if we open the border tomorrow, nothing will change. There's no way the Mexican long-haul trucker can drive willy-nilly around the United States."
Still, for Mario Galvan, a Mexican short-haul trucker who was waiting in the sun at Nuevo Laredo to cross the World Trade Bridge into Texas, the prospect of more open borders and open roads sounded enticing.
"It's a good idea," Mr. Galvan said. "I guess it all depends on whether the politicians in the United States see that we have the intelligence and cautiousness necessary to do the job."

HEADLINE: Blacks Hit by Housing Costs Leave San Francisco Behind 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
At 21 years old, Shanika Long is giving up on San Francisco, the city she was born and reared in and would rather still call home.
 Her mother tells her of a time when blacks owned certain parts of town, when the Fillmore District, for one, was a vibrant neighborhood with, she recalls, "a black-power-type mentality." 
 But, like the Fillmore's nickname, Harlem West, those days are history. And Ms. Long, a clerk at the Labor Ready agency for temporary workers who has a 3-year-old daughter, says she wants to live where black people can afford to buy houses and rear children. 
"I'm moving out and I'm feeling like I'm being pushed out of San Francisco," she said. "The community now is, like, dead." 
African-Americans, like Ms. Long, are leaving this city in droves. Over the last 10 years, as public housing and low-income projects have been torn down and as rents and house prices climbed to record levels, African-Americans have left San Francisco like no other city. 
Census figures show that while the city's overall population increased more than 7 percent in the 1990's, the number of people who list their race as black fell from 79,039 in 1990 to 60,515 last year (with an additional 6,561 reporting some black heritage combined with another race, the first time the census allowed people to check a mixed-race category). That leaves the city of 776,733 with a black population of 8.6 percent.
Other cities have had notable declines in their black populations over the last decade -- Washington, for example.
But blacks in other cities appear to be migrating to the suburbs in a pattern of upward mobility. In San Francisco, many are leaving because they have no choice. Gentrification during the dot-com boom gave the city the distinction as the most expensive in the country. 
Landlords in black neighborhoods, much like others, cashed in, raising rents and evicting long-term tenants. The recent technology bust has had little effect in lowering housing prices, real estate experts say. And since blacks have always been a relatively small minority here (13 percent of the population at its height in 1970) the consequences are striking.
The result, in one of the few major cities with a black mayor and a liberal political sensibility in sync with a majority of African-Americans, is a San Francisco with whole neighborhoods where it is rare to see a black person. It is a city where blacks have little clout, few cultural institutions and only one remaining neighborhood, the homely, lonely Bayview-Hunters Point, best known for a sewage treatment plant and radioactive Superfund site.
For many blacks here, San Francisco is the sweetheart who loved 'em and left 'em, who promised the moon and stars only to forget them when new blood came to town.
In the Fillmore, there has been much talk over the years of establishing a jazz district in honor of the jazz scene that emerged in the neighborhood from 1940 to 1950. It was the heyday of the community, when the black population of the city grew tenfold as thousands of blacks came to San Francisco looking for war jobs, many of them at the Navy shipyard at Hunters Point. But the jazz project has been in the planning stages for years with little action. 
In 1997, Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. promised to bring Bayview-Hunters Point thousands of jobs, a new stadium for the San Francisco 49ers and a megamall to go along with it. Voters approved the project in 1997, agreeing to finance it with $100 million in bonds. But the project was stalled when the 49ers owner, Eddie De Bartolo Jr., became embroiled in legal troubles and lost the team to his sister and her husband. The mall project is still in the talking stages.
Many blacks have little hope of things improving anytime soon. Even the black churches, the soul of the black community, have lost their influence. The Rev. Cecil Williams, pastor of the Glide Memorial Methodist Church, perhaps the sole remaining influential church, with more than 50 social and community programs, says that as blacks have moved, the churches have lost their base.
"Naturally, you're going to lose some of that vibrancy," said Mr. Williams, who blamed "economics, first and foremost -- the cost of living in this city" -- as the reason for the black exodus. His church is thriving, with more than 1,500 members of all races, many of whom drive from as far as Sacramento, 85 miles away. It also attracts busloads of tourists, drawn by the church's popular choir and band.
The mayor, through a spokesman, P. J. Johnston, said that not all blacks were leaving because they could not afford to stay.
"Those who would tell you it's simply a matter of poor people not being able to afford to live in this City obviously don't understand the black community, or the City of San Francisco,' Mr. Johnston said.
Some homeowners, he said, have sold their houses to cash in on the market and moved to more affordable cities. But, he conceded, lower-income renters "have had trouble keeping pace with this rise in housing costs, and many have moved to cheaper digs around the Bay Area."
Some are moving to working-class cities like Vallejo, Richmond or Fairfield, which have significant black populations and where it is still possible to buy a house for under $300,000. But census figures suggest that blacks appear to be bypassing Oakland, where African-Americans represent over a third of the population. In the last decade, that city, too, has seen a decline in its black population -- from 163,500 out of 399,500 residents in 1990 to 142,400 out of 372, 200 residents in 2000 -- as gentrification forced some low-income blacks to the further reaches of the area. 
Black-owned businesses in San Francisco have also left. Fred Jordan, a past president of the San Francisco Black Chamber of Commerce, said: "There used to be 138 African-American businesses along Fillmore Street. Last I heard there were 32 left and very hard to find."
One that remains is Perry's Joint, a coffee and candy shop, on Fillmore Street. Perry Bennett opened the shop eight years ago, hoping to buy into the neighborhood's history. But now only 15 percent to 20 percent of his customers are black, he said.
While the Fillmore has been losing blacks for decades -- federal urban renewal projects in the 1960's displaced thousands of blacks to make way for a boulevard and Japan Trade Center, shops and plazas -- Mr. Bennett started his business at a time when community leaders were talking revitalization. But even in the eight years that he has been around, Mr. Bennett said, he has watched dozens of businesses close and hundreds of customers move.
Like some other African-American business owners in the city, Mr. Bennett complains that blacks lack the unity and community spirit to achieve success here. "If we had that, in the Bayview-Hunters Point area," he said, "where blacks own all the homes, all the apartments and we had a black business district going all up and down Third Street, and we were a constituency that could put someone in office that is going to look out for our interests, we wouldn't be having this conversation." 
African-Americans do own most of the houses in Bayview-Hunters Point, but the prices of the modest starter house never kept pace with the rest of San Francisco's; homeowners who wanted to trade up were forced to leave the Bay Area to afford something better. 
Sophie Maxwell, a city supervisor who represents Bayview-Hunters Point, said projects in the works should improve the neighborhood. "Economic revitalization is what we're looking at," Ms. Maxwell said. "We're losing numbers so we're trying to identify and work on the assets in this community." 
The neighborhood's open space, parking places, vacant lots are all assets that developers are exploring, she said. 
Eric Martin, a 43-year-old salesman at the Record Shop in Bayview, said Asians, whose numbers are steadily climbing here, could teach blacks how to move forward.
"The Filipinos come in and they got five families living in one house," Mr. Martin said. "That's how they do it, how they can afford it. Then they buy the house, then they buy another house. They got unity. Brothers ain't like that. It used to be like that way back in the 60's and 70's."
The major obstacle to attracting new life has been the Navy shipyard, which brought so many thousands of blacks to San Francisco during the war. Since the Defense Department closed the shipyard in 1974, the neighborhood has been overshadowed by its aging hulking buildings, several of which are contaminated with radioactive waste.
Some see the toxic waste that has made Bayview-Hunters Point the subject of scorn and ridicule as the one reason the black population has not been pushed out of its stronghold. "It's what's killing this community and at the same time it may be preserving what we have," said Rebecca Logue Bovee, an organizer with the Housing Rights Committee.
Deborah Dean, a 41-year-old cashier at the Record Shop, sees the plans to redevelop Bayview as a plot to drive out blacks, because "blacks don't represent the white tourism image of the city."
"I live where you can hear the games from the new Giants ballpark and everything and you can see the lights," she said. "And it's just a beautiful view. If it wasn't for the toxic waste, they would have taken this hill a long time ago."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 3, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about an exodus of black residents from San Francisco gave an incorrect surname in some copies for the former San Francisco 49ers owner whose legal troubles stalled development plans in a black neighborhood. He is Eddie DeBartolo Jr., not Bartolo. A map with the article referred incorrectly in some copies to a neighborhood where a jazz district has been proposed. It is the Fillmore, not Filmore.

HEADLINE: America's New Take on the World 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "America on the Sidelines" (editorial, July 29): 
 America suddenly seems like a very foreign country to the majority of Western Europeans. 
There is a growing sense of dismay at the Bush administration's aggressively negative tactics regarding international treaties and agreements on arms, pollution, trade and criminal justice. 
The violence of a small minority at the Genoa summit meeting should not distract from the fact that many Europeans traveled to Italy to protest World Trade Organization, World Bank and International Monetary Fund strategies that are perceived as serving American interests at the cost of further indebtedness for the world's poorest countries, as well as accelerating the ecological disaster that confronts our planet. 
Your editorial offers hope that Americans will petition their president to drop his gung-ho stance and enter into dialogue with a world that, while willing to accommodate his views, will not be bullied into swallowing them.

ALIX SHARKEY
Paris, July 29, 2001

HEADLINE: An Old River Town Debates Modern Change 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: CATSKILL, N.Y. 

 BODY:
To contact a colleague, employees here at the hub of government in Greene County rely on couriers, since there is no e-mail and not enough telephone lines. To type reports, social workers in field offices drive nine miles to the nearest computer, then wait to use a pair of fax machines shared by 70 people. To make matters worse, they share their work space with skunks, raccoons and cockroaches who call the outdated government buildings home.
 Catskill is renowned as the longtime home of Thomas Cole, founder of the Hudson River School of landscape painting, and has been designated as a national historic district, but it may have too much history: it could be the most anachronistic county seat in the Hudson Valley. 
 But a potential solution to the problem, a new government office building, is encountering resistance from preservationists who fear that 21st-century amenities will obliterate 19th-century charms. 
The disagreement involves a proposed $14.7 million, four-story, 108,000-square-foot office building on Main Street and the 537 parking spaces it would require in several lots in the downtown area. According to county officials, the project would save taxpayers perhaps $2 million a year by consolidating more than a dozen offices under one roof and would generate millions more by rejuvenating a moribund downtown area. In addition, the project would, in one bold swoop, require the demolition of 11 existing structures that the project's advocates describe as eyesores that attract loitering youths.
"I think Main Street is like a medical patient," said William B. Lawrence, a Republican county legislator. "We're removing some discarded flesh, and we're putting in a new organ. But if they keep in the diseased organ, the patient is going to die."
In June, the County Legislature approved a $4.7 million bond issue for the project. Demolition was scheduled to start in the fall, and groundbreaking the following spring. But in July, a new citizens' group filed a lawsuit to block the project, arguing that the county did not adequately review the project's environmental and archaeological effect on the fragile historic district.
More recently, state conservation groups, including Scenic Hudson and the Preservation League of New York, have lined up against the project, too. 
"There aren't too many of these places left," said Scott P. Heyl, president of the Preservation League. "That's why this is so wrongheaded. Catskill is one of the more intact river towns in a very scenic area."
Located about 30 miles south of Albany and across the river from the reinvigorated city of Hudson, Catskill once served as a destination for weekenders from New York City, as well as a haven for artists. In the 1880's, a railway was built near the bustling dock to transport travelers to the Catskill Mountain House, the chief resort on the eastern slope of the Catskill Mountains.
As late as the 1960's, Catskill remained a modestly successful resort town, where residents could still shop for fresh food or clothing and find a decent restaurant meal. But like so many other upstate towns, Catskill lost industry -- its lingerie and thermostat factories -- and its downtown was eviscerated by the growth of bland shopping malls nearby. In a stunning symbol of the village's deterioration, New York State bought the Catskill Mountain House in 1963, which had been long since abandoned, and burned it down.
A few government offices that had been providing unemployment, legal, agricultural or social services left, moving across the river to Columbia County. The village remained the county seat, but the downtown became a lonely 9-to-5 place occupied by lawyers, the remaining government employees and nonprofit workers, who ate and shopped in malls. 
"You couldn't get a cup of coffee on Main Street," said Douglas J. Brewer, the Greene County administrator. "You couldn't get a tie or men's underwear."
During the 1990's, however, Greene County's population increased by 7.7 percent, one of the fastest rates in the state, fueled in part by commuters who make the trip to Albany or New York City on the New York State Thruway. And yet, anyone with official county business still confronted an inefficient infrastructure, Sisyphean in its futility.
The County Legislature, which occupies a former car dealership, has so little space that its main conference room doubles as the site for civil service examinations. To accommodate its different agencies, the county rents space in more than a dozen buildings. This means extra expenses for security, insurance, maintenance contracts and jobs, Mr. Brewer said.
In some offices, there are so many telephone wires and extensions criss-crossing overhead that the offices appear to be decorated with Christmas wiring, minus the lights. But the tangle of wires is deceptive. "Employees use personal cell phones because there aren't enough phones in the office," said Carol W. Wallace, the county's social services commissioner. "They're so frustrated."
So this year, the County Legislature approved a proposal for a new building that would house 350 employees on the site of the defunct Newberry's department store. Of the $14.7 million earmarked for the project, $7 million would come from New York's share of the national tobacco settlement, $3 million would come from the county budget and the rest from the bond issue.
In hopes of not violating the requirements for national historic districts, the building's architectural design would echo that of the downtown, and would not be a "glass and chrome" suburban box, Mr. Lawrence assured. 
While the downtown is dressed up with green banners that proclaim "Historic Catskill," many of its buildings, including some of those scheduled for demolition, are empty and rickety, their faded Italianate facades reminders of better days. Inside are dilapidated and overcrowded apartments that have attracted transient youths looking for cheap rents and minimum-wage jobs.
But these buildings also convey a sense of history. One, a former church built in 1841, was designed by Cole himself and remains one of his few extant structures. Most of the others scheduled for demolition are more than 100 years old, adorned by architectural flourishes like decorative roof cornices and curved pediments. 
David Seamon, a part-time resident who is an environmental psychologist at Kansas State University, supports a new county office building, in principle. But his new citizens' group, Save Our Main Street Buildings, has been troubled by the proposal's parking plans, which his group says would create an unappealing asphalt moat around the new building. And it is particularly unhappy that officials are proposing to tear down three buildings to create only nine parking spaces. So the group has urged the county to look at other empty lots and nonhistoric sites farther away from the downtown strip.
As a national historic district, Catskill is subject to extra requirements encouraging the preservation of all structures. But according to Mr. Seamon, the county has pushed the project through in a hasty and irresponsible fashion. In addition to doing a shoddy environmental review, it quietly managed to limit the time for public response to 20 days from 30, he said. His group found out in time to file its suit just before the deadline in mid-July. So far, the county has not responded to the suit, but a court hearing is scheduled for mid-August, Mr. Lawrence said. 
More than any legal particulars, however, Mr. Seamon is concerned that the parking lot would derail the village's nascent attempts to emphasize its past. These efforts include the refurbishing of Catskill Point, a riverfront museum and park about a mile from downtown. 
Even so, Mr. Seamon said, he couldn't escape a sense of dread during a recent celebration of the village's latest achievement: the restoration of a building where Thomas Cole lived, in honor of his 200th birthday. "It seems so ironic that we were all standing there, and the politicians were talking about how wonderful that Cole's building had been saved." 
Then, turning his attention to the former church Cole designed, Mr. Seamon said, "Yet here we are, about to destroy his building."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
GUARD, SARAH ("SALLY")

 BODY:
 GUARD-Sarah ("Sally"). Sally died peacefully July 28 at St. Vincent's Hospital with her husband, David Burger, at her side. Their daughters, Emma and Cameron, were at home nearby with Sally's mother, Gretchen, and her aunt, Sarah Ballard. Born January 26, 1963, near Sydney, Australia, Sally was the daughter of Gretchen, a painter currently of Santa Fe, NM, and the late David Guard, a founding member of The Kingston Trio. Along with her sister, Catherine, and brother, Tom, Sally grew up in Whale Beach, Australia, and in Palo Alto and Portola Valley, CA. She went to Woodside High School and spent spent summers at the Bar 717 Ranch in Trinity County, CA. In 1980, Sally headed to Middlebury College, where she would play varsity soccer, major in English, study French and Italian, and play saxophone in the Ripton Blues Band. After graduating in 1984, she became a reporter at Sports Illustrated in Manhattan, covering golf and the Winter Olympics, as well as soccer, the sport she loved most. She met David, now an economist and senior analyst at Moody's, in a guitar class at The New School in 1993, and they were married 2 years later. Sally was a senior editor when she left Sports Illustrated in 1995, shortly before Emma was born, then an editor at Bishop Books until Cameron arrived in 1998. After that, she devoted her time to her girls and to David, with whom she found enormous joy and fulfillment. 
She will be remembered for her wit, her artful turn of phrase, her letters, her love of music, language and arts, her honesty, generosity, and for her commitment to family and friends. She was a unique and loving soul, and will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held at The Orensanz Foundation for the Arts, 172 Norfolk St, NYC on Saturday, August 11, at 1PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Ave So., 21 Fl, NY, NY 10016. Please include Sally's name and that acknowledgement should be made to David Burger, 50 Walker St, Apt 4B, NY, NY 10013.
