HEADLINE: Harlem's Visible Man 

BYLINE:  By David Levering Lewis; David Levering Lewis is the author of "When Harlem Was in Vogue." He won Pulitzer Prizes this year and in 1994 for a two-volume biography of W.E.B. Du Bois.

 BODY:
The long-awaited second coming of William Jefferson Clinton happened on a day of splendid weather and general thanksgiving in Harlem. Current and former elected officials lauded him as the last legitimate occupant of the White House, and the Republican secretary of state of New York proclaimed the day "William Jefferson Clinton Day" in the name of the governor. Family matters detained the senatorial Clinton. Rare good judgment kept Mayor Rudolph Giuliani away. Harlem's adroit perennial congressman, Charles Rangel, praised the economic impact of the former administration's empowerment zone in language akin to that lavished on the Marshall Plan. The New Black Panthers and a few others sounded discordant notes about exploitative gentrification and the loss of community identity, but they were drowned out by thousands of others in the plaza fronting the state office building bearing the name of the original "king of the cats," Adam Clayton Powell. Bill Clinton, famously described by Toni Morrison as the first black president, had come home. 
 "I ain't dead yet," the former president told the delighted crowd. Although he was half-joking about playing his saxophone some night at the legendary Apollo Theater, his words inescapably invite speculation as to the larger meaning they may hold. For the politician whose favorite sobriquet is "The Comeback Kid," Harlem, idolizing and insular, may well prove to be the ticket to redemption, an expiatory stop among the needy and historically abused along the road to Damascus. It is surely not implausible that the quarter's reputed magic of release and renewal -- of renaissance -- can be expected to redound to its latest fallen idol. 
 Millions of Americans who regret the Clinton presidency as a prodigious squandering of talent by one of the most brilliant politicians to occupy the Oval Office find scant sympathy for their displeasure among Harlemites. This is true not only because of the almost ineffable loyalty that some Southern white politicians evoke in black people (Lyndon Johnson, Jimmy Carter and even George Wallace), but also because the moral outrage Bill Clinton's misdeeds have engendered among the American mainstream is seen by black Americans as part and parcel of the immemorial hypocrisy of the value system that has repeatedly victimized them. Like him, they too have been rebuked and scorned. The role of the African-American as surrogate for the troubles and malefactions of white people is as old as the Republic, a part carefully scripted in the antebellum South and archetypally acted out in American literature from Harriet Beecher Stowe to William Faulkner and beyond, and one whose present-day vitality was vividly displayed a few days ago north of Central Park.
Jazz Age Harlem was thought to put touring Caucasians in touch with their real selves, to be a place of primal authenticity where fingers could feel the pulse of life -- much as Harlem strikes President Clinton as a place "human and alive," as he said, "where there was a rhythm to life and a song in the heart."
Mr. Clinton knows that many who are singing today may not like the music they will be hearing in the near future. Harlem's famous commuter has promised to do his part to safeguard the community's "great diversity" and to keep the worst consequences of urban development from harming the community as property values spike and developers alight. "I don't want small business people to be run out because I'm coming in," he said to thunderous applause. But even with the former president's good intentions, we would be more than a little naive to think that large numbers of poor and working-poor families in Harlem won't have been displaced by increasing gentrification. Yet, barring a steep economic recession, who can doubt that the joyous welcome of this world figure signals a profound shift of the plates under the city's psychological and residential crust? Henceforth, the region above Central Park that survived riots, crime and special-interest politics and even defied the logic of the market is open for business to all comers.
The changes in store for Harlem may well pale beside the transubstantiation of the charismatic newcomer. After addressing AIDS, peace, poverty and other problems local and global from his bully pulpit on 125th Street, William Jefferson Clinton will, in all likelihood, emerge redeemed to an amnesiac American public. The former president could represent his people as mayor, city councilman or congressman; even the governor's office would not be beyond his range of choices. Whatever his remarkable future brings -- running a foundation called Hope or running a studio in Hollywood -- the last word must go to that Clinton spokeswoman who said of the Harlem advent, "The bottom line about today is . . . the former president had a wonderful time." 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 9, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An Op-Ed article on Aug. 2 misstated the party affiliation of Randy Daniels, the New York secretary of state. Mr. Daniels, who was appointed by Gov. George Pataki, is a Democrat, not a Republican.

HEADLINE: Green Stakes Out Positions Starkly Contrasting Giuliani's 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Mark Green said yesterday that if he were elected mayor, his administration would be profoundly different from the current one running New York City, even within the Police Department, where he would like to shift some of the overtime budget used for crime fighting to social programs for the police and for crime prevention.
 Even when Mr. Green, New York City's public advocate, was not offering policy proposals that differ from those employed by Rudolph W. Giuliani, he took numerous opportunities to criticize the mayor and the way he has run the city for the last eight years, in turn presenting a vision for City Hall that is in many ways antithetical to that of the current mayor. 
 His targets ranged from the Giuliani administration's record on education reform ("a failing grade," he said) to the Police Department ("mismanaged") to health care policy ("I don't see much of a policy") to the mayor's approach to economic development ("he squandered his bully pulpit"). 
He called Mr. Giuliani's administration secretive, saying: "For seven and a half years, there was an iron curtain between his government and the public when it came to distributing information to reporters and to citizens." Mr. Green vowed to create an administration that would be open to and would consult with the city at large. "The top-down government-by-enemies-list method of governing, I hope, subsides," he said. "And I want to have a far more small-D democratic, interactive, transparent, open government."
Mr. Green, who confidently predicts "when I am mayor," said his vision included a more efficient government that would rely more heavily on technology and a school system in which children in the early grades would be in classes with no more than 19 other students and in which teachers get raises.
He also said he would like to repair the relationship between the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, using tax revenues from the sale of the World Trade Center for transportation initiatives, in a departure from some of his competitors, who would like that money earmarked for new housing. Mr. Green said he would like to increase the morale of police officers and keep them from defecting to the suburbs. 
But in terms of actual policy proposals, Mr. Green also carefully sought to take the middle of the road during a 90-minute interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times yesterday, avoiding controversial initiatives and declining to commit to specific positions on a few occasions.
He said he was not sure whether he would pursue new tax cuts, nor would he rule out future tax increases; he selected no single agency for definite cutbacks during hard times, yet he deemed few impervious to budget trimming. He said he favored the current system for negotiating with the city's unionized workers, but added that he was the first to get behind an overhaul of that process a few years ago. Mr. Green mentioned that he believed teachers should be subject to the same disciplinary procedures that principals face, but then added that those terms would be negotiable.
In choosing to defer some tough policy decisions until after the election, Mr. Green said that he was not trying to keep from alienating voters who are already squeamish about the notion that he is a traditional old party liberal who will drag the city into a fiscal or public safety crisis with 1970's-style social policies. 
"I'm a proud progressive Democrat on issues like social justice, choice, gay rights -- without ever having to shift positions because of an election year," Mr. Green said. "I am very tough-minded on criminal justice issues and economic issues."
Mr. Green is most specific on his key goal for education: smaller classes for the youngest children. "It's not easy, it's not cheap," he said. "But all the pedagogical studies show that is the best way to convey literacy and numeracy skills at the biological moment kids are ready."
In terms of how teachers should be compensated and evaluated, Mr. Green said he would like to give principals more power, adding that he supported "bonus pay" for teachers who achieved further professional development or advanced degrees.
When crediting Mr. Giuliani in one area in which most New Yorkers do tip their hats -- fighting crime -- Mr. Green was consistent in spreading that praise to former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, who has endorsed him. "We're all thankful that because of certain national trends and Giuliani-Bratton strategies, crime is down in New York City substantially more than in other urban areas," he said.
But he added that he felt there was much work to be done in the area of how the police relate to black and Latino New Yorkers. "There is extraordinary anecdotal and statistical evidence that there is a level of racial profiling on the streets of New York," Mr. Green said. 
He added: "I don't believe the mayor or the police commissioner has ordered it. At the same time, communities of color in this city are furious at how their children -- they believe are -- how their children are being disproportionally stopped and frisked."
To that end, Mr. Green said he would, if elected, re-evaluate Operation Condor, a program in which officers are paid overtime to fight street crime. "I think Condor is largely responsible for the $300 million overtime budget," he said. 
Some money would simply be redirected. "I may want to spend some Condor money on tuition assistance for young cops, because all the data indicate the higher the educational level, the more productive and the less brutal officers are," he suggested. "I may want to spend some of that money on repairing decrepit precincts, because officers feel demoralized when they go into these awful -- when they work in these awful conditions. I may want to spend some Condor money on, as I said, to steal a phrase from Dennis Walcott, repeat midcareer tuneups so officers are better trained on when to stop and frisk."
As for added savings, he quipped: "I would substantially reduce police overtime by cutting Howard Safir's detail," referring to the former police commissioner.
Facing a slowing economy, Mr. Green laid out a modest, inexact proposal to raise new revenues apart from any change in tax policy. His ideas include more electronic government, building up downtown Brooklyn, investing in information technology training and pouring economic development dollars into small community-based industries and organizations.
Transportation initiatives could be earned, he said, through a new relationship with the Port Authority. "Instead of trying to blow them up," he said, "we have to have a cooperative relationship, which I believe I will have."
"We will have more lease payments for our airports," he said, "and they have billions of dollars that we need to invest in a cross-harbor freight tunnel, in an expansion of the Javits Center, in a Second Avenue subway. And they've all been stalled because of the personal animosity between the governor and the mayor, which will not exist between the next governor and the next mayor."
How will this be accomplished? In large part it seems through delegation. Mr. Green said he wanted to hire a chief technology officer to "look around the country and world for the smartest ways to deploy information technology to reduce the size and cost of city government." He also wants a "labor czar" who would help him to evaluate how the city negotiates with labor unions.
Mr. Green declined to outline a specific plan for housing. Instead, he said he would, if elected, convene a housing summit right away, "and have around it all the best, smartest, for-profit and not-for-profit builders, labor and management people, contracting people, churches that put up housing, poverty advocates to figure out where the revenue will come from and what the right mix of low- and middle-income housing is." 
In terms of transportation, Mr. Green said he longed for a multibillion-dollar cross-harbor freight tunnel to ship products and move solid waste now that Fresh Kills is shuttered, a regional MetroCard and an expansion of the E-ZPass. "I don't know of a -- other than getting rid of squeegee men -- I don't know a governmental advance more popular than E-ZPass," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Public Advocate Mark Green criticized Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's record on education, law enforcement, health care and economic development. He said that as mayor, he would run a more open government. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: As Whitman Deliberated Plan, the Pressures Mounted 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
The pressure faced by Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, on whether to proceed with the dredging of the Hudson River was enormous.
 On one side were General Electric and its chairman, Jack Welch, who were major contributors to President Bush's presidential campaign. Backing the company were many of the residents of the rock-ribbed Republican communities along the upper Hudson River. They opposed the dredging plan, which would cost General Electric half a billion dollars, saying it would do more harm than good and could destroy the river's recreational and economic life. 
 On the other side were a broad coalition of environmental groups and public officials, including some top Republicans, backed by years of the E.P.A.'s own scientific studies. They favored the dredging plan, which would be 10 times as big as any environmental cleanup undertaken in this country.
Mrs. Whitman, as the governor of New Jersey, had always supported cleaning up the Hudson and had favored the dredging proposal. But environmental groups grew concerned two weeks ago that under pressure from the Bush administration, she was brokering a deal with General Electric to soften the blow. Whether this was true remains unclear, but the perception galvanized the environmentalists and prompted Gov. George E. Pataki of New York to call Mrs. Whitman and declare his support for the dredging plan.
The environmental groups met with Mrs. Whitman on Thursday. In an otherwise scientific discussion, they told her that General Electric had spent perhaps $60 million on its antidredging campaign. Mrs. Whitman joked in response: From what she had seen, she said, the company must have spent $75 million.
The exact amount of the company's extensive antidredging media campaign, including television commercials, a half-hour infomercial and intensive lobbying efforts, is not known. What is known is that it seems to have come to naught.
The Bush administration, torn between the pro-business wing of the Republican Party and the moderate environmental wing, has sided -- this time -- with the environmentalists.
The White House today placed responsibility for the decision squarely on Mrs. Whitman, but added that Mr. Bush had supported her decision.
"This was an E.P.A. decision that E.P.A. made on the merits," said Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman. "E.P.A. decided to move forward cleaning up the river in a way that is environmentally sound and also responsive to the concerns of the people who live in the affected communities. The president, of course, supports E.P.A.'s decision."
At the E.P.A., Eileen McGinnis, Mrs. Whitman's chief of staff, said the agency's staff had briefed not President Bush but other White House officials, including those at the Council on Environmental Quality and the Office of Management and Budget, at least three times.
Ms. McGinnis said that Mrs. Whitman had considered four broad categories of questions as she examined the issue: the science of the plan, the economic effect on the local residents, whether a government agency could pull off a project of this magnitude, and whether a decision to dredge would be litigated.
But advocates of dredging said there were unmistakable signs that the administration was trying to find a way to soften the blow on an important corporate ally and also to signal to other companies that this would not be a precedent-setting decision that would force them as well into costly cleanups.
At the same time, the political implications of the decision were undeniable. As Lisa Guide, a deputy assistant secretary for policy in the Department of the Interior under President Bill Clinton, put it, "Environmental issues are sapping the life out of Bush's political viability, and the White House is trying to stop the bloodletting by allowing dredging in the Hudson."
Representative Maurice Hinchey, Democrat of New York, who favors dredging, met with Mrs. Whitman in his office two weeks ago. "She said some things to us that were encouraging, but she also said, and I'm quoting, 'What's proposed by the region is way out there, it's something that's never been done before, it's a very aggressive plan.' We took that to mean she was hedging."
Mr. Hinchey added that Mrs. Whitman said she was concerned that the decision would affect other sites by setting a precedent. "She was concerned about the scope of it," he said.
Environmental groups became alarmed that the plan, first proposed by the Clinton administration, would be compromised, and key Republicans began pressuring the administration. Several environmental groups said today that they believed that Mr. Pataki's July 24 call to Mrs. Whitman expressing his concern signaled a turning point in her thinking.
Laura Haight, a senior environmental associate with the New York Public Interest Research Group, reminded Mrs. Whitman of the political consequences of her decision. She presented her with a list of five swing Congressional districts in which General Electric was at least partly responsible for toxic waste sites. The groups were planning news media campaigns in those districts and arranging for boycotts of General Electric products.
Ms. Haight said that Mrs. Whitman, while polite, seemed offended. "She said: 'I don't need this. This decision will be based on the science.' "

HEADLINE: Factory Index: A Year of Decline 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 

 BODY:
The slump in manufacturing extended its run in July to a year, but might be moving toward a rebound in coming months, a major purchasing survey suggested today.
 The survey, the National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index, dropped last month to 43.6 from 44.7 in June. 
 A reading of less than 50 signals contraction, and the 12-month stretch below that level is the longest since 1990-91, during the last recession. 
A separate report from the Commerce Department showed that construction spending fell unexpectedly sharply in June. Spending fell 0.7 percent, the biggest drop since July 2000, to $861.6 billion at an annual pace, after a more modest decline of 0.2 percent in May. Work slowed on schools, apartments, town houses and condominiums, outweighing an increase in construction of single-family houses.
Economists had expected a reading of 44.5 in the factory index. The new-orders index, which accounts for 30 percent of the total survey, fell to 46.3 in July from 48.6 in June.
Manufacturing is "bouncing along the bottom," said Neal Soss, chief economist at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York. The report showed that companies were eliminating excess inventory at a faster pace, which "is precisely why you would expect a rebound of production down the road," he said.
Other measures gave signs that manufacturing could rebound. The inventories index fell to 35.8, the lowest since December 1982, from 40.8. The index of production rose to the highest since November. The index of orders for export rose to 48.2, the highest since 50.6 in March. An index measuring backlogs of orders increased. The employment index rose to 37.2 from 36.3.
Price pressure eased. The index of prices paid for raw materials fell to 38.7 in July, the lowest since February 1999, from 42.3 in June. Among metals, slower demand has reduced the price of copper to its lowest level in more than two years.
A big problem has been the excess of telecommunications equipment that developed after a nine-month slump in capital spending began late last year. Producers of fiber optic equipment like JDS Uniphase and Corning are receiving fewer orders, with some of the largest customers of JDS, including Nortel Networks, saying that they will draw down inventories before ordering further.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 33

LENGTH: 4701 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* AFRICAN GALLERIES, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (on long-term view). The museum has one of the oldest and most important collections of African art in the country. Just a few years ago, 250 objects from the permanent collection were installed in revamped first-floor galleries; now two dozen pieces have been added and the space has been redesigned again, this time with multicolored walls, mural-size color photographs, documentary films and ambient sound. Added works expand the definition of African to include both Moroccon and ancient Nubian. And the overall selection, from familiar friends to treasures recently acquired, is thrilling. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

"MARC CHAGALL: EARLY WORKS FROM RUSSIAN COLLECTIONS," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Oct. 14). When Chagall returned to Russia in 1914 after four years in Paris, he intended to marry his beloved fiancee, Bella Rosenfeld, and hurry back to the French capital. Instead, World War I and the Russian Revolution kept him in his homeland for eight years, during which he did some of his greatest work. The 60 artworks here, most being exhibited in the West for the first time, form a series of intense Chagallian doses rather than a comprehensive overview. They are accompanied by nine paintings by Chagall's first teacher, the sensitive realist Yehuda Pen. The show culminates in the seven large, deliriously inventive murals Chagall made for the Jewish State Chamber Theater in Moscow during three feverish months in 1920. Hours: Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students and 65+ ($2 surcharge for "Chagall") (Roberta Smith).

* JACQUES AND NATASHA GELMAN GALLERIES, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (continuing). These glorious new galleries display 50 French modern works, almost all paintings, drawn from the Gelmans' collection. In addition to the paintings here, the collection includes five sculptures, more than 30 drawings and a major work on paper: a Matisse cutout, the Met's first, which will be shown in a subsequent hanging. The standouts installed here include Matisse's Fauve masterpiece "The Young Sailor II"; a matched set of small, classic Cubist paintings, one by Picasso, one by Braque, both from 1911, arguably the high point of their collaboration; and a fantastically refined, sexually fraught 1929 Dali, "Accommodations of Desires." It makes the museum a modern art destination in a way that it has never quite been before. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Smith).

"LEON GOLUB: PAINTINGS, 1950-2000," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 19). Now 79, Mr. Golub is best known for paintings done in the 1970's and 80's, raw, awkward figurative works that seek to illuminate his basic theme, man's inhumanity to man. They include huge, engulfing canvases of Vietnam War scenes, riots, interrogations, death squads, racial face-offs and other grim tableaux in which power confronts the powerless. The set piece here is the enormous "Vietnam II" (1973), whose cinematic-scale canvas depicts two groups of figures, a trio of soldiers and a tank pointing guns at a scraggly group of terrified Vietnamese, led by a young man screaming. As a graphic rendering of might asserting its rights over weakness, it delivers its message with impact. Recently he has dwelled with wit more on philosophical themes, referring often to the frailty of the individual and the inevitable end. Whatever the infelicities of his style, he has steadfastly stuck to his role as witness to the world's evil workings. Hours and admission: See above (Grace Glueck).

* WILLIAM KENTRIDGE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 16). By way of drawings and film animations, Mr. Kentridge uses searing images to address South Africa and its racial problems, along with the longings and frustrations of bourgeois lives played out in the country's deeply dysfunctional setting. The exhibition begins with his jarring "Shadow Procession" (1999), a ragtag parade of silhouetted moving images projected on a big screen, which evokes the displaced and dispossessed who haunt not only South Africa but also the history of the world. At the heart of the show are his drawings and the short animated films he makes of them, in which the process shares importance with the content. Many of the films contrast the lives of two antiheroes, one a crude rapacious businessman, the other a sensitive artist, in compelling medleys of images that touch on the personal and the political. Departing from this format is "Ubu Tells the Truth" (1997), a highly charged satire based on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, set up in 1995 to investigate human rights abuses in the apartheid era. It's not often that good art is shaped from such raw angry material, but Mr. Kentridge's powers of invention are equal to the challenge. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and 65+ (Glueck).

* "MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF ART," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Aug. 19). From Michelangelo to Louise Bourgeois, from Rembrandt to Franz Kline, this cornucopia of drawings from one of the most important collections in the United States bristles with the work of stellar talents. A standout is a double-sided drawing in red chalk by Michelangelo, probably done around 1510-11. One side reveals the trouble he had sketching a foot that fits the position of a youthful male nude on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; the other shows the headless nude, a powerful, ingeniously posed figure that emphasizes the sculptor's magnificent grasp of anatomical rendering. A rare compositional drawing by Fra Filippo Lippi, a subtly toned landscape by Claude Lorrain, a scene of battling horses by Gericault, a stately portrait by Ingres, one of Seurat's brilliant black crayon drawings of a French vaudeville scene and works by Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec are among the highlights. The 20th-century American group is something of a disappointment, but there are enough great things from other eras to make this a masterpiece of a show. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Glueck).

"MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE SMITH COLLEGE MUSEUM OF ART," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Aug. 12). This selection of drawings spanning six centuries has compelling works on paper by some of the more resonant names in Western art history, names like Tiepolo, Boucher, Ingres, Gericault, Beardsley, van Gogh, Mondrian and others. There are works of only academic proficiency, but in far more cases the drawing sings: in the 15th-century Italian Rosso Fiorentino's near-orgiastic vision of a double martyrdom made with urgent sensuousness in red chalk, for example, or Seurat's studies for "La Grande Jatte," in which broad, deft swipes of a black crayon evoke the silhouettes of women who seem almost dissolved by watery light. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 62+ (Ken Johnson).

* "MIGRATIONS: HUMANITY IN TRANSITION," photographs by Sebastiao Salgado, International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Sept. 9). The show (there are two accompanying books) is the product of seven years in more than 35 countries documenting what Mr. Salgado calls "the reorganization of the human family," partly because of the shift from "majority rural to majority urban." His subjects are refugees, exiles, orphans, landless peasants, homeless families, boat people, internees and others. This is a sprawling, frequently gruesome story -- the scale and gravity of it should speak for themselves -- and if the suffering doesn't prompt guilt, indifference to it will. That's how emotional blackmail and effective moral photojournalism work. Mr. Salgado practices both as well as anyone does these days. Of course, the pictures are also exploitative, but that's also a feature of photojournalism. We respond despite the voyeurism and the manipulation because of the formal beauty. The good photographs are so stupendously gorgeous that, for better and worse, they can make you forget everything else while you are looking at them. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* WAYNE THIEBAUD: A PAINTINGS RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Sept. 23). The world not being a perfect place, this show will be around only through the summer, so consider yourself forewarned. At the Whitney, as in life, happiness is fleeting. Meanwhile, you are free to bask in these pumpkin pies, meat and cheese deli counters, lipsticks, hot dogs and gumball machines, which, as Mr. Thiebaud has painted them for the last 40 years, have the aura of loves lost and too fondly recalled. Joy yielding to melancholy then yields to the less jolting but more durable satisfaction of being in the presence of pictures so lovingly and wittily made. These pictures provoke happiness if for no other reason than that they are content to be what they are, which is enough, this being the same message they convey about the modest objects and people they depict. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

* "UNIFORM: ORDER AND DISORDER," P.S. 1 Center for Contemporary Art, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sept. 3). Originally shown in Italy, this exhibition traces the changing forms and symbolism of the modern military uniform as it progresses through the larger culture and is transformed by it: alternately respected and violated, examined and absorbed, abbreviated and exaggerated. The perpetrators include artists like Wolfgang Tillmans, Vanessa Beecroft and Maurizio Cattelan; fashion designers like Prada, Versace and Donna Karan; and scores of terrorists, punks and nameless teenagers. Eight well-stocked vitrines present a plethora of supporting material, much of which is also reproduced in a stylish catalog. The exhibition ends with the real thing: a gantlet of the uniforms and head gear -- from fatigues to parade dress -- worn by members of the different Italian military services. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2, students and 62+ (Smith).

Galleries: Uptown

"MINIMAL," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Aug. 10; reopens Aug. 27 to 31). This elegant show includes works of classic Minimalism like a box made of stainless steel and fluorescent red Plexiglas by Donald Judd; an iconic arrangement of red, pink and yellow fluorescent lights by Dan Flavin; and a gorgeous, glossy red, thick plank shape by John McCracken. It also embraces more conceptually motivated works, like words on the wall by Lawrence Weiner that say "Around the bend"; a square of typewritten concrete poetry by Carl Andre; and photographs of framework houses by Bernd and Hilla Becher (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Aug. 31). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop Art by the movement's stars. The 26 objects shown here are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. (Glueck).

"SALT OF THE EARTH," Bettina Werner, Winston Wachter Mayer, 39 East 78th Street, (212) 327-2526 (through Aug. 15). With unabashed grandiosity, Ms. Werner calls herself the "Queen of Salt." Since the 1980's she has specialized in making abstract paintings using colored salt crystals in various grades, from sandy to chunky, as her primary medium. She evidently wants to be some kind of 21st-century alchemist, but her multipaneled pictures are formally generic. Maybe they should be saltier (Johnson).

"SERIAL THINKING," Kouros, 23 East 73rd Street, (212) 288-5888 (through Aug. 31). Zeuxis, an organization of still-life painters, presents works by more than two dozen artists, most represented by multiple versions of a single motif. Some impressive works stand out against the earnestly academic background, including Victor Pesces's iconic, subtly humorous pictures of isolated cups; Suzanne Biggins's small close-up studies of matches, which verge on grid-based abstraction; and Lucy Barber's hazy images of objects that seem almost dissolved by light and heat (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

MORRIS GRAVES, "Still Life," Schmidt Bingham, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-1122 (through Aug. 17). This small retrospective honors a great American original who died in May at 90. Ranging from vigorously palette-knifed paintings of drinking fountains from the 1930's to exquisitely delicate pictures of flowers in transparent bottles from the 90's, the show gives a fine taste of Graves's craftsmanlike versatility and his modest yet intense poetic sensibility (Johnson).

"MINIMALISM PAST AND PRESENCE," Galerie Lelong, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 315-0470 (through Aug. 15). For its final exhibition before moving to Chelsea, Lelong presents a retrospective of Minimalist or near-Minimalist artists who have exhibited here over the years, including Robert Ryman, Robert Mangold and Donald Judd. Alfredo Jaar's lightbox-lighted Social Realist photograph, Sean Scully's loose stripe paintings and Ana Mendieta's photograph of an earthwork undermine the show's coherence, but being definitive seems not to be the point (Johnson).

"NO BIG PICTURES," Pace/MacGill, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7999 (through Aug. 29). Tired of oversized, overproduced, conceptually coy contemporary photographs? This show of small-to-tiny vintage prints is for you. It includes William Christenberry's beautiful image of a red truck trailer in a green field; Harry Callahan's serene image of a volleyball net on a deserted Cape Cod beach; zany, slightly creepy "auto-Polaroids" by Lucas Samaras; an absorbing short story told in four color Polaroids by Philip-Lorca DiCorcia; and Diane Arbus's touching portrait of a young waitress at a nudist camp wearing only an apron (Johnson).

* CARLO SAMMARCO, Franklin Parrasch, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 246-5360 (through Aug. 31). Richly glazed and textured, Mr. Sammarco's pedestal scale compositions of elemental geometric shapes have a coolly refreshing beauty. "Subscape," an architectonic complex of square-walled circle sections glazed in smooth red brick, matte moss green and granular charcoal gray, shows off this promising young artist's consummate craftsmanship and suave way with color (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

MEREDITH ALLEN, Gracie Mansion, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 505-9577 (through Aug.31) In each of Ms. Allen's silly but charming photographs, someone's hand holds up a melting Good Humor bar in the barely recognizable form of a cartoon character like Tweety Bird or the Tasmanian Devil. In the distance are blurred Long Island landscapes, setting up a dialogue between culture and nature and, possibly, between painting -- represented by the gooey, drippy, brightly colored ice cream -- and photography (Johnson).

"CAMERA WORKS: THE PHOTOGRAPHIC IMPULSE IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Marianne Boesky Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9889 (through Aug. 10). Despite the encompassing title, this show focuses almost exclusively on photographs by 31 established artists, mostly in their 30's and 40's, who are not known primarily, if at all, for working with the camera. Usual suspects are in the majority, from Ross Bleckner to Lisa Yuskavage, with Peter Doig, Jessica Stockholder, Rachel Whiteread and Gregor Schneider in between. But there are still plenty of surprises and revelations, especially when you find yourself thinking that some of the assembled should stick to photography (Smith).

"ELECTRIFY ME!" Friedrich Petzel, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9467 (through Aug. 10). This judiciously selected (by the curator Mark Fletcher) and beautifully installed exhibition of sculptures that use electric light includes a heart-shaped neon sign with a funny but unprintable message by Tim Noble and Sue Webster; a window of cool light by James Turrell; Jorge Pardo's lamps of thick glass scattered on the floor and looking vaguely like collapsing squashes; an elegiac string of bulbs by Felix Gonzalez-Torres; and a neon palindrome by Bruce Nauman. Only Rachel Whiteread's aluminum cast of an electrical switch box doesn't light up (Johnson).

ENEAS, "Thriller," Esso, 211 West 28th Street, (212) 560-9728 (through Aug. 16). Every canvas in this empty but archly sophisticated display of insider gamesmanship has the name Michael Jackson stenciled across the top above a skillful simulation of gesture or drip painting by Jackson Pollock, who shares a name with the mercurial pop star. These works so closely resemble George Condo's jazz album cover paintings that you can't help suspecting the sly Condo might have invented Eneas (Johnson).

"50'S PHYSIQUE: VINTAGE BODYBUILDING PHOTOGRAPHY," Wessel & O'Connor Gallery, 242 West 26th Street, (212) 242-8811 (through Aug. 24). This is a kind of summer idyll from yesterday, with beaches and mountains for settings, sun-tanned bodies galore, and everyone having good, clean, fabulous fun. The young men seen in the 90 photographs were posing for discreetly distributed, small-format physique magazines that had an ardent gay following in the pre-Stonewall 1950s. Among the masters of the genre were Bruce of Los Angeles (Bruce Bellas, 1907-1974) and Bob Mizer (1922-1992), both well-represented here. For students of popular culture, the material is a gold mine. For everyone else, its a chance to stare, smirk and swoon the summer away (Cotter).

"FOUR ABSTRACT CLASSICISTS," Gary Snyder, 601 West 29th Street, (212) 871-1077 (through Aug. 25). This punchy time capsule of a show features works from the 1950's and 60's by four West Coast painters of hard-edged abstraction -- Karl Benjamin, Lorser Feitelson, Frederick Hammersley and John McLaughlin. The exhibition recalls a generational shift away from Abstract Expressionism toward the cooler aesthetics of the 1960's. Its title invites reflection on the tension in reductive abstraction between historical avant-gardism and timeless formalism (Johnson).

RICHARD HAMILTON, "Prints, 1968-1998," Charles Cowles Gallery, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through Aug. 17). James Joyce's "Ulysses" and tabloid subjects like Mick Jagger's arrest for drug possession are part of the huge print repertory of the English painter Richard Hamilton. Mr. Hamilton is wide-ranging not only in subject matter but also in print technique; while not dispensing with venerable practices like etching and engraving, he sets no limits on technical possibilities, fooling around with contemporary techniques from silk-screening to computer manipulation of digital images, sometimes using several in the same print. This wonderfully animated show illustrates his belief that images will always be more important than the manner of their execution. But it also reveals the role that technical innovation plays in the impact of his graphic work (Glueck).

CRAIG KAUFFMAN, Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, (646) 336-7183 (through Aug. 31). This Fetish Finish artist of Los Angeles is still producing Minimalistic, super-slick, vacuum-formed plastic wall reliefs. Each piece in this show is shaped like a bottom-heavy doughnut and spray-painted from behind in frosty, pearlescent colors that call to mind fingernail polish. Possessed of a weirdly artificial, vaguely erotic and futuristic beauty, they could be props for a "Clockwork Orange" milkbar (Johnson).

"LARGER THAN LIFE," Center for Figurative Painting, 115 West 30th Street, (212) 868-3452 (through Sept. 28). The standouts in this five-artist show are two painters of opposite but equally ambitious sensibility: Leland Bell, whose large, perfectly composed figure compositions project an Apollonian love of order and clarity, and Paul Georges, a passionate hedonist whose big, recklessly vigorous painting of wild pink roses under a bright blue sky evokes a summer day to almost unbearably delightful effect (Johnson).

"PHOTOPLAYS FROM THE 60's," James Bidgood, Paul Morris, 465 West 23rd Street, (212) 727-2752 (through Aug. 17). Creator of the cult film "Pink Narcissus" (1971), Mr. Bidgood made dreamy, homoerotic photographs in the 1960's. Using colored lights and cheap materials, he staged blatantly fake scenes in settings ranging from the boudoir to the beach. They featured partially unclothed youths playing characters like a toreador or a faun. Seen here as new digital prints, the images are less shocking than you might wish; still, Mr. Bidgood deserves credit for being a brave pioneer (Johnson).

PETER PINCHBECK, "A Memorial Exhibition," Greene Naftali, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 463-7770 (through Aug. 10). Mr. Pinchbeck, a British-born New Yorker who died a year ago, began as an Abstract Expressionist painter in the 1960's, turned to Minimalist sculpture and then went back to painting. The recent pictures on view here have sensuously textured, chromatically intense surfaces and, hovering in ambiguously illusory space, bulbous forms made of generously slathered paint. These works are hedonistic, a little comical and mysteriously elemental (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"INTIMATE: A GROUP EXPERIENCE," Scalo, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 334-9393 (through Aug. 30). Contrary to the title, the pictures in this show could just as well be used to demonstrate photography's distancing effects. They include blurry, surveillance-style pictures of a man sleeping, by Marianne Muller; Social Realist family pictures shot in Kentucky, Morocco and Colombia by Wendy Ewald; male odalisques by David Armstrong; compositions of bed sheets and parts of naked bodies by Jeanette Montgomery Barron; and, most arresting, Edward Quinn's picture of a baby-faced Warren Beatty helping a transcendentally sexy Natalie Wood with her coat in Cannes (Johnson).

"STRUCTURES," Work Space, 96 Spring Street, (212) 219-2790 (through Aug. 31). This gallery in a law office presents yet another interesting guest-produced group show. Organized by Linda Francis and Marjorie Welish, and featuring artists variously preoccupied by geometry, it includes a lumpy, hovering box with a gridded surface by James Hyde; a glossy black spot on a mossy green field by Thomas Nozkowski; a spare, emblematic diptych by Ms. Francis; and diverse approaches to the grid by Ms. Wellish, Michael Brennan, Nancy Haynes and Kes Zapkus (Johnson).

"SURF'S UP! SURFING PHOTOGRAPHY FROM 1922 TO 1942," by Tom Blake and Don James," Ariel Meyerowitz, 580 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 625-3434 (through Aug. 10). Blake and James got into surfing and photographing surfers long before the Beach Boys made it a national craze. Blake's pictures from the 1920's and early 30's and James's from the late 30's and early 40's are shown here in the form of poster-size digital prints made from original negatives. The warm-toned, often blurry images of men riding waves on long boards look at once nostalgically antique and fashionably contemporary (Johnson).

Other Galleries

TONY CRAGG, "Turbo-Ferryman," Doris C. Freedman Plaza, Fifth Avenue and 60th Street, (212) 980-4575 (through October). This year's Public Art Fund installation here consists of two bulbous bronze sculptures by a consistently interesting British sculptor. One is a perforated, biomorphic bottlelike form with wiggly arms going in and out of its body; the other is a big, asymmetrical shape, like a toy top with odd lumpy places. In a gallery either would be fine; outdoors they look too small. If one or the other were five times larger, it would be terrific (Johnson).

Last Chance

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Wednesday). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by an elegance, an economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Smith).

ALEXANDER LIBERMAN, "Maquettes for Monuments," Ameringer/Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through today). In the late 1960's, this Modernist sculptor and Conde Nast editorial director produced gigantic abstractions using old, unearthed gas pipes. On view here are sleek little copies of those monumental works, compositions of standing, leaning or tumbling cylinders finished in glossy red or matte rust-colored patina. Though not deeply consequential, they are appealingly precious (Johnson).

"VOICE, IMAGE, GESTURE: SELECTIONS FROM THE JEWISH MUSEUM'S COLLECTION, 1945-2000," Jewish Museum, 1195 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Sunday). Though not by any means an exhibition of great art, this show offers a thought-provoking occasion to meditate on relations between contemporary art and Jewish identity. The 60-odd works include Abstract Expressionist paintings by Adolph Gottlieb and Robert Motherwell; Andy Warhol's Pop-style silkscreen series "10 Portraits of Jews in the 20th Century"; a campy contemporary skullcap by Cary Liebowitz and a deconstructed menorah made of low-tech electrical hardware by Michael McCaslin. Television and movie clips feature Jewish luminaries like Woody Allen and Sandy Koufax. A painting by R. B. Kitaj based on a 15th-century depiction of an antisemitic myth is the show's most suggestively allusive work. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson)

"VOYAGES: A SMITHSONIAN LIBRARIES EXHIBITION," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through tomorrow). Mostly a selection of mostly rare books with some curious objects also, "Voyages" offers a miniature cross section of the vast holdings of the Smithsonian Institution Libraries. Contents range from remarkable antiquities like "Mundus Subterraneus" by the 17th-century Dutch scholar Athanasius Kircher, thought to be the earliest printed study of geophysics and vulcanology, to a copy of Neil Armstrong's "Stroll on the Moon," which is signed by the author and the fellow astronauts Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins (Johnson).

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Lumumba, the African Castro or a Dazzling Ray of Hope?

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
THE ASSASSINATION OF LUMUMBA
By Ludo De Witte
Translated by Ann Wright and Renee Fenby.
Illustrated. 224 pages. Verso. $27.
 Patrice Lumumba was one of those charismatic figures -- martyrs, in the view of their supporters -- who stood on the public stage during that moment of ferment when colonialism was dying and a new force on the global scene, third world nationalism, seemed poised to replace it. Lumumba, who was assassinated in January 1961 during the terrible Congo civil war, was like Che Guevara in this sense, or perhaps Sukarno (overthrown but not assassinated in Indonesia), or maybe even the American Black Muslim Malcolm X. He was a fiery, commanding figure with a revolutionary aura about him, cut down before he was able to exercise power long enough for anybody to be sure how he would have reshaped the world. 
 In one view, the view that has predominated in the seats of Western power, Lumumba was a dangerous figure who would have taken the newly independent Congo either into social chaos or into the Soviet camp. The director of central intelligence at the time, Allen Dulles, called him an African Castro. By contrast, Ludo De Witte, a Belgian sociologist and writer, takes a very different view in "The Assassination of Lumumba."
For Mr. De Witte, Lumumba was a dazzling ray of hope for a successful postcolonial future in Africa, a man who might have led Congo, reluctantly granted independence by Belgium after a century of rapacious control, into a hopeful future. Mr. De Witte's thesis is that Lumumba's murder was not, as many have previously written, an internal Congolese affair, a kind of panicked overreaction among African factions fighting it out after the departure of the Belgians. Lumumba was murdered, in Mr. De Witte's account, by a kind of unholy alliance led by the Belgian government acting through well-paid Congolese stooges and enjoying the connivance of the American Central Intelligence Agency and the United Nations.
Mr. De Witte's book, translated from the Flemish by Ann Wright and Renee Fenby, is an important and flawed examination of the persecution and murder of Lumumba. Mr. De Witte makes no pretense of being an impartial investigator. His book is full of a kind of impassioned boilerplate more common to the leftist intelligentsia in Europe than in the United States, phrases like "the Western ruling classes" and "the fight for national liberation" abound. At one point, after he has taken the reader through a gripping, minute-by-minute account of Lumumba's execution, Mr. De Witte laments: 
"Patrice Lumumba was not yet 36 years old, the same age as Robespierre, that other great defender of the modern nation state, when he died." To put Lumumba into the same category as the man who invented revolutionary terror seems at best tactically unwise; it does not inspire confidence in Mr. De Witte's political judgment.
Still, whatever eccentric political ideas he may have, Mr. De Witte has written a compelling account of the tireless efforts by the West to eliminate Lumumba. When this book was published in Europe in 1999, it prompted the formation of a Belgian parliamentary inquiry into Lumumba's death. (Its findings are to be announced this year.) Mr. De Witte makes his case, and he has documentary evidence to make it stick.
Lumumba was the first prime minister elected in Congo before a reluctant Belgium granted it independence in July 1960, but matters began to deteriorate almost immediately. Lumumba made an inflammatory speech at the independence ceremony, attacking Belgium for its years of colonialist exploitation and humiliation while King Baudouin stood nearby. Lumumba's attack was historically accurate but politically foolish. It aroused fears among Europeans that antiwhite vengeance would be a main theme of his regime.
Within a couple of days, when the Congolese army revolted, beating European men and raping some women, Belgium intervened militarily, and though Belgian troops were soon displaced by a United Nations multinational force, Lumumba was soon dismissed by President Joseph Kasavubu. When he tried to escape house arrest in Leopoldville and join supporters in Stanleyville, he was arrested by troops controlled by the future dictator, Joseph Mubutu. A few months later, in the presence of several Belgian police and army officers, he was beaten, tortured and executed by a firing squad.
It is a seedy story, and the essential fact of it is indisputable: that the legally elected prime minister of a newly independent country was murdered, to the evident satisfaction both of Belgium and the United States. Much of what Mr. De Witte says in his detailed reconstruction of the crime has been known for years, including the almost comic-opera plot concocted by the C.I.A. to have Lumumba assassinated by injecting poison into his toothpaste.
Mr. De Witte mines the Belgian archives for a good deal of new information, especially on the role of ranking figures in the Belgian government in fomenting opposition to Lumumba among alternative Congolese leaders. Once Lumumba was arrested, Mr. De Witte's reconstruction of events says, Belgium pressed for what a senior Belgian official called his "definitive elimination." Mr. De Witte and his translators maintain the original French phrase: "elimination definitive."
But De Witte also slides quickly over the breakdown in order after the independence-day celebrations. In this book you won't read about the rape of European women, for example, or of Lumumba's inability to control the situation, or of his tendency to make inflammatory declarations. While Mr. De Witte meticulously describes Belgian economic interests in its former colony, he does not talk much about the Congo's powerful tribal and personal rivalries, which other commentators have stressed. You would almost think, reading Mr. De Witte's account, that the murder of Lumumba was unusual in Africa at the time. In truth, throughout the continent, corrupt and brutal army officers of the Mobutu stripe were taking power from the Western-trained intellectuals that the departing colonial powers had left behind to run things.
But it is also true that Congo was different in some ways, different because of the unusual cruelty of Belgian colonialism (grippingly recounted in Adam Hochschild's recent book "King Leopold's Ghost") and because of the exceptional brutality and corruption of the Mobutu regime after Lumumba's fall. Mr. De Witte's book, politically passionate as it is, is an unignorable effort to bring the West face to face with its culpability in this entire sad and sanguinary tale.
