HEADLINE: WATCHING MOVIES WITH: WOODY ALLEN; 
Coming Back To 'Shane'

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

 BODY:
HE came into his screening room walking that Woody Allen walk, slightly hunched, a little distracted, his vigorous fingers carving the air as he spoke. "I hope you don't mind," he said, "but I have prepared a statement."
 And he pulled from his pocket a folded sheet of canary-colored paper, the double-spaced letters overlaid with black-ink editing that spilled into the margins. Mr. Allen said he wanted to make completely clear why he had chosen George Stevens's "Shane" as the film he wanted to watch. 
 "I'll just read this into your tape recorder, if that's O.K., and then you can do whatever you want with it after that," he said, settling himself in a plush chair in the back corner of the screening room. "Is it on? Can I start talking?" 
He held up the canary sheet and began. "When I was invited to pick a film to view and discuss with The New York Times, I wanted to select an American one," Mr. Allen said. "This is unusual for me, because my affection for foreign movies seems to be much deeper. If I were, for example, to list my 10 or even 15 favorite movies -- and I don't say best movies, because these lists are always completely subjective -- aside from 'Citizen Kane,' all of the films would be foreign. A sampling might be, 'Rashomon,' 'The Bicycle Thief,' 'Grand Illusion,' 'Wild Strawberries,' 'Seventh Seal,' 'Throne of Blood,' 'The 400 Blows,' 'Los Olvidados,' you get the idea."
He cleared his throat, took a deep breath and continued: "But I didn't want to do that for this, because I wanted to make sure that the people who read this, at least a portion of them, have seen the movie, so I thought I would stay with an American movie. I hesitated, too, about viewing a comedy, because on a list I might make of, let's say, the 10 or 15 great American films, there'd be almost no comedies. Certainly not from the talking era. And I wouldn't include the silent era, because that is a completely different entity. Silent films to me are a completely different kind of thing. If you were to count silent films, of course, between Chaplin and Keaton you could probably get 10 great movies. But if you take films only from the start of the sound era, I don't think that there are too many great sound comedies." Mr. Allen, 65, hunched forward and spoke slowly into the recorder, never looking up from the typewritten sheet. (And it had indeed been pecked out on a typewriter, not printed from a computer.)
He wore khaki pants and a button-down blue shirt, long-sleeved and fastened at the wrist, and despite the sweltering summer afternoon he was perfectly dry, pressed and unruffled.
"I have a very idiosyncratic view of sound comedies that I wouldn't want to interfere with this," he said. "For example, I wouldn't count the Marx brothers or W. C. Fields films, I wouldn't put them on my great list, as I don't consider their films great. But they are records of performances by these stupendous comedians, and any five minutes of Groucho or Fields is funnier than most purported or even venerated comedies. And still I wouldn't rank their movies, which I find, you know, choppy and even silly, as great comic filmmaking. I would say my personal view of most sound era comedies would be considered harsh, and I certainly include my own films in that appraisal. None of them would be on any of these great lists, certainly."

'A Great Movie'
There is a scene in Mr. Allen's "Manhattan" in which Isaac, the character he plays in the 1979 film, reclines on a sofa in his New York apartment and recites into a tape recorder a list of what he holds most dear in the world, from city landmarks to creative works like Flaubert's "Sentimental Education." It is difficult to watch Mr. Allen read his "Shane" statement into a similar tape recorder without catching at least an echo of Isaac's streaming, punctilious manifesto.
"For whatever reason, I am not enchanted by a huge number of highly respected comedies, whose names I would rather not mention and hurt anybody's feelings," Mr. Allen said. "I do consider 'The Shop Around the Corner' a great comic movie, also 'Trouble in Paradise,' also 'Born Yesterday.' Speaking of 'Born Yesterday,' I considered the British version of 'Pygmalion' with Leslie Howard and Wendy Hiller, and also the Fellini masterpiece 'The White Sheik.' Since I spent most of my life in comedy, in one medium or another, I am not a clean, objective judge. I would prefer not to harp on my highly special preferences and distastes. As musical comedy goes, I do consider 'Singin' in the Rain,' 'Meet Me in St. Louis' and 'Gigi' great, and probably 'My Fair Lady' would have to be ranked up there.
"In the end, looking over my list of great American films, which include, among others, for final consideration, 'The Treasure of the Sierra Madre,' 'White Heat,' 'Double Indemnity,' 'The Informer' and 'The Hill' by Sidney Lumet, I finally settled on 'Shane.' This is an odd choice in one sense, because I don't like westerns. I like 'The Ox-Bow Incident' and 'High Noon' and care a bit but considerably less about a few others, but 'Shane,' I think, is a great movie and can hold its own with any film, whether it's a western or not."
Mr. Allen looked up from the piece of paper. "That's the only statement I wanted to make," he said, handing over the typewritten sheet along with the still turning recorder. His editing marks cover the entire statement, words are crossed out, entire clauses inserted from the margins.
He nervously cleared his throat again and stood up, peering back into the projection booth where someone was waiting to crank up the first reel of "Shane." The cluttered suite of Park Avenue offices where Mr. Allen edits his films and maintains a screening room is completely free of the kind of blinking high-tech gizmos with which other directors surround themselves. The editing equipment, the upholstered furniture, even the copious collection of vinyl jazz albums that line one entire wall all seem like throwbacks to an earlier, analog era, as well worn as the love seat where Mr. Allen finally came to rest facing the screen.
"I saw 'Shane' when it first came out in theaters," Mr. Allen said. That would have been in 1953, when he was just getting out of high school in Brooklyn. "I didn't rush off to see it," he said, "because there's no western film that I ever rush off to see. I'm not really that interested -- and, again, this is purely personal -- by rural atmospheres. So when a film begins in a farmhouse or something, it's not the same for me as if it begins in a penthouse. I just like an urban setting."
So just why, then, did he choose "Shane"?
"I thought 'The Ox-Bow Incident' was wonderful when I saw it, and 'High Noon' is a good western, for me," he said. "But none of them hold a candle to 'Shane.' 'Shane' is in a class by itself, because if I was making a list of the best American movies, 'Shane' would be on it, and none of these other movies would."
The reason, in large part, is the great skill of Stevens, Mr. Allen said. "I rank him very high. And this is on the basis of a very few things, really. The few of his films that I've liked, I've liked very much. 'Shane,' I think, is his masterpiece. I do think he would be right up there with my very few favorite American directors -- of the era that I grew up in. Orson Welles is in a class by himself, but then, you know, John Huston and George Stevens and William Wyler."

A Score of Viewings
Mr. Allen remembered enjoying "Shane" from the first time he saw it, but he said his appreciation had deepened over the years. "I've seen it many, many times," he said. "Certainly more than 20. I've also taken people to see it, people who tell me that they can't stand westerns. Because it's more than a western. It's a fine movie. Oh, there are a couple of weaker spots in it, but they are so minor and forgivable, and what's great about it is so wonderful, that you'd really have to be carping to be annoyed at them. To this day, if it was on television this week and I happened to be tuning through the channels, I would stop and see it. I am always riveted."
Mr. Allen frequently describes "Shane" as a lovely film, or a beautiful one, and praises it for its poetry and elegant flow, words not normally associated with westerns. Two of his favorite westerns, it is pointed out, are essentially a long buildup to a climactic confrontation. In "Shane" it is Alan Ladd's reluctant gunfighter strapping his six-shooter back on to do battle for the beleaguered homesteaders; in "High Noon" it is Gary Cooper taking on the killer who has arrived on the noon train.
"Yes," Mr. Allen said, letting the notion sink in for a moment. "But if you were asking me, I would say that 'Shane' achieves a certain poetry that 'High Noon' doesn't. 'High Noon' is beautifully made, but you can see the message of it too plainly, you know, and it's just not as well done. For whatever reason, probably because Stevens himself had some of the poet in him, it infuses that material with a certain poetry that 'High Noon' doesn't have. 'High Noon' is more like a fine piece of work, you know, whereas 'Shane' is sort of a fine piece of poetry."'
Mr. Allen leaned over, twisted the volume knob on a console beside his seat and shouted back to the man in the projection booth. The familiar blast of Victor Young's classic score erupts behind the Paramount Pictures logo, pushing into the classic opening shot of the wandering gunfighter cresting a hill and passing down into the troubled valley where the drama will take place.
The colors in the print are a little bled out, which is a shame, because the images of the craggy peaks of northwest Wyoming, where Stevens shot the film, are among the most beautiful in any western. Did Mr. Allen have any idea where the film was shot? "No idea," he said in a crisp tone that discouraged further discussion. A subsequent question was cut off just as quickly. Was Mr. Allen going to be able to discuss the film as we watched it? "I can't talk and watch the movie at the same time," he said.
Oh.
This was a bit of a problem, as the discussion is pretty much the idea of this series. But he was adamant -- polite but adamant. He suggested a compromise: we would watch the film for 20 minutes or so, then switch it off and discuss what we had seen before starting it up again.

Just Heading North
Shane glides across the bucolic valley to the remote homestead of the Starrett family, Joe (Van Heflin), Marian (Jean Arthur) and Joey (Brandon de Wilde). He asks to cut through their property, says he's just heading north to "someplace I've never been." When Little Joey absent-mindedly cocks his rifle, Shane snaps around like a gunfighter. When some rough-looking men ride up, Starrett at first thinks Shane is one of them. They are the Ryker brothers and their gang, open-range cattlemen who want to chase off all homesteaders. They threaten Starrett and roar off.
By this time, an embarrassed Starrett realizes that Shane was not with them and invites him to stay for supper. Shane, used to the gunfighter's violent life, is entranced by the gentle domestic scene. After dinner, the two men work to remove a stubborn tree stump in Starrett's yard, and Shane accepts a job on the ranch.
The next day, Shane rides into the nearby town to buy work clothes and is humiliated by one of Ryker's hired men, played by Ben Johnson. At a meeting that night, Stonewall Torrey (Elisha Cook Jr.), one of the homesteaders, and others shun Shane for his supposed cowardice. They decide to ride into town together in the future, and are seen doing just that, a glowering sky lighted by lightning foreshadowing trouble ahead.
"O.K., is this a good place to stop?" Mr. Allen asked. "It is? Fine." He called back to the projectionist.

In the Middle of Nowhere
"I think, first off, you take the film from the beginning, there's that beautiful scenic opening," Mr. Allen said. "The sense of this ranch house that's isolated out there, and then the town, which is one of the great images in American film. It's a town in the middle of nowhere, just a few buildings. I mean, it's just a little general store, a bar, a livery stable, just stuck out in the middle of the wild like that. You have a sense that this is what those Western towns really looked like."
Mr. Allen noted the complex tangle of relationships that are economically sketched out, one by one, in the opening scenes. "From the first, because of the way Stevens shot it, you can tell that there is this intense fascination between the kid and Shane; it's almost love at first sight or something," he said. "And it's wonderful the way he snaps around when the kid cocks his gun, because you know, immediately, that you're dealing with a tough guy. It's done so offhandedly. There are certain things that you don't think in words, that you think emotionally. You know, it clicks in some subliminal way. Here, you think to yourself, oh, I would like to have this guy on my side. So that then later, when he does go on Starrett's side, it's so wish-fulfilling.
"And the bad guys are handled in a great way, too. The first word out of Ryker's mouth is that he doesn't want any trouble. At several points during the movie, Ryker tries to be reasonable. So it's not just a bunch of bullies. It's more complex than that."
The connecting threads of the relationships are built one strand at a time. Even the tough guy who humiliates Shane in the bar comes back into play, later, redeemed and nuanced. But through it all, the overriding mystery is the character of Shane himself; quiet, calm, utterly competent and yet yearning for something. "This guy is not a pushover," Mr. Allen said, "but you have also seen this goodness of spirit that he has. Alan Ladd is an interesting choice for the part because Shane is such a passive character in the whole thing. He's just quiet and passive and nonassertive. And he's a small guy, not a big, beefy cowboy star."

Evil Arrives in the Town
The movie starts up again. Shane and the homesteaders are heading into town. The weather is glowering. Shane, now aware that the homesteaders consider him a coward, wanders back into the bar to confront Ben Johnson. They circle each other, then fight. At first, the homesteaders hang back, fearful. But finally Starrett wades in and the two men take on the entire gang. The Ryker brothers, sensing that the time has come to raise the stakes, send off for a gunfighter. Shortly afterward, Jack Wilson (Jack Palance) rides into town, a reptilian, thoroughly malevolent desperado.
"Watch this," Mr. Allen said, breaking his own rule.
Mr. Palance enters the saloon. A dog looks up, sees him and slinks across the barroom floor. Mr. Palance begins to walk across the room. We see him only from the waist down. Gradually, he dissolves out of the frame and, almost instantly, dissolves back in a few steps further along. It's beautiful, but ghostly. He's like an apparition.
"It's one of the most puzzling dissolves I've ever seen," Mr. Allen said. "I can't imagine what it was for. It must have been to cover up a mistake. I can't think of any other reason for it."
Once Mr. Palance is introduced, the film returns to the farm. Shane is trying to teach Joey how to shoot until Marian comes out and stops it. She doesn't want her boy to have anything to do with guns. It's clear, too, that the unspoken relationship between Marian and Shane is deepening, though nothing ever happens between them that's more physical than a handshake.
"So, when we last left off, they were riding into town, and you could tell that Shane had his own agenda to settle the score with these people," Mr. Allen said. "And then they go home and you get the scene of Marian fixing up the two men, Shane and her husband, and it's so obvious that she's attracted to Shane, and it's starting to bother her. When Shane leaves, she asks her husband to hold her. She's getting to where she can't trust her feelings. This is wonderful stuff for a cowboy movie because it's not heavy-handed. It's a relationship that develops with the same subtlety that it would in the most sophisticated kind of urban movie."
And then there is Jack Palance.
"If any actor has ever created a character who is the personification of evil, it is Jack Palance," Mr. Allen said. "We've all read about the size of the horse, how Stevens put Palance on a smaller horse so he'd look even bigger. But when he arrives -- the music is great -- he's all in black; he's so poetically evil. He looks like he'd gladly kill the guys who hired him if they looked at him wrong. He's just bad news. Serpentine. In our minds, he's set off against Shane, one particularly good, almost too good to be true, and the other is totally evil."
By this point, too, we have come to know Starrett a little better.
"Shane is more sophisticated," Mr. Allen said. "Shane has traveled more. He's drifted around more, seen more different sides of the world. Starrett is more plain. But they're both very nice men, both brave men. The only difference is that Shane is so amazing with a gun. He's got the gift of God or the artist or something."
The homesteaders, hoping to buck up their confidence, organize a Fourth of July celebration. Starrett notices Shane dancing with Marian, and an odd look crosses his face. After the party, Shane and the Starretts head back to their homestead. It's dark. When they arrive, the Ryker brothers are waiting for them. So is Wilson.

'One of the Best'
"This is a great scene," Mr. Allen said. "Really, from here on until the end of the picture are some of the best scenes I've ever seen in an American movie. And this is one of the best. You have so much going on at the same time, but it's never forced. All these relationships are working at the same time, and Stevens is able to make you feel and understand all of it because he has laid the groundwork so carefully in the earlier scenes. You've got the Rykers, talking reasonable again. You've got the wife worrying about her husband, about their boy. You've got the boy watching this. And then, in the background, without a word, really, you've got Shane and Wilson sizing each other up. And the boy watches this, too. It's directed in the most brilliant way. And when, at the end, Jack Palance backs his horse out of the yard, it's just an amazingly wonderful moment."
The next day, Torrey, the hot-headed homesteader, heads into town. It's too much of a temptation for Wilson. With the Rykers' permission, he picks a fight with Torrey. Standing on the raised wooden sidewalk outside the saloon, looking down at the diminutive Torrey slogging through the mud, Wilson belittles him with a hissing voice, casually puts on his gunfighter's gloves and outdraws Torrey. There is a moment's pause, Torrey standing there with his useless gun in his hand, until Wilson blasts him in cold blood.
"This may be the best shooting confrontation scene in a cowboy movie ever," Mr. Allen said. "First, it's so beautifully filmed, these guys riding into town, the camera going along with them, and then you get the side view of the town with the mountains and the weather. And then Palance, the personification of evil, lures him into this fight. It unfolds so slowly. And then there's the ritual of it, with Palance putting on that glove. It's just his eccentricity, or something, a part of his artistic process, in a sense. It isn't a simple thing, where he just shoots Torrey. There's this whole ritual that goes with it. And it's always so shocking when you get this three- or four-second pause before Palance pulls the trigger, because it's clear that he doesn't have to shoot. He's already beaten him. There's never been a shootout in a cowboy movie to equal it, in terms of evil against innocence."

Violence vs. Violence
Torrey is buried at the graveyard on a hill overlooking the town. Some of these shots are the most stunning in the film: the small cluster of mourners around the open grave, the tiny town in the distance, the towering mountains all around. That night, back at the homestead, the Rykers pass word that they want to meet with Starrett back in town. He knows it's probably a trap, but he also knows he has to go. His chances are slim, but he has come to realize that the Rykers' increasing violence can be defeated only by more violence.
Shane appears. He has his gunfighter's clothes on again, his six-shooters strapped on his waist. He announces that he, not Starrett, is going into town. They quarrel, then fight, tumbling all over the dusty yard until, up against the remains of the stump over which they labored in the opening scenes, Shane knocks Starrett unconscious, says goodbye to Marian, suffers Joey's withering disdain and heads into town.
"Shane doesn't want to get back into gunfighting," Mr. Allen said. "He's been trying the whole movie to put it behind him. But he knows that the only way to put an end to the violence in the valley is for him to do it. That's what makes the film great in my eyes. He knows. He's got to go in there and kill them. And sometimes in life -- it's such an ugly truth -- there is no other way out of a situation but you've got to go in there and kill them. Very few of us are brave enough or have the talent to do it. The world is full of evil, and rationalized evil and evil out of ignorance, and there are times when that evil reaches the level of pure evil, like Jack Palance, and there is no other solution but to go in there and kill them."

He's Not Coming Back
And so the famous climax plays out. Shane makes his long ride into town, Joey running after him. Shane confronts Wilson, pure good versus pure evil, and outdraws him. Then, when the Ryker brothers pull guns on him, Shane shoots them, too, but not before one of them wounds him.
Afterward, Shane gets on his horse and tells Joey that he's not coming back to the ranch. Shane realizes that the era of the gunfighter is ending, but he also knows that he can't be anything else. And so he rides off. "Come back!" Joey calls. But Shane does not come back. The last shot, a mirror of the opening image, has Shane riding over the crest of a hill. Except this time he is heading out of the valley. And it is twilight. And he is hunched over in the saddle. Wounded? Dead? Or simply sorrowful?
"I don't like to think that he's dead," Mr. Allen said. "Just that he's wounded. I hate to think that he dies in the end. I think they probably are pointing to the fact that he's dying because, you know, he's ascending. But I don't like to think that he's dead yet."
And Mr. Allen stood, stretched, turning the lights on one by one.
"Everything pays off," he said. "The relationship between Shane and the kid pays off in spades. But also between Shane and Marian, between the husband and wife. And when Alan Ladd takes control and tells Starrett that he's not letting him go into town, it's like, you know, you always hope in life that there's somebody who will take that kind of control, who will fight your battles. It's really only in the movies that it happens, though. The moment you really want to see, and that you can never see, is the next morning when the people come into town and see that both Ryker brothers and Wilson are dead. You don't get to see that. And you want to. You want to see how they react when they see what Shane has done for them.
"Because the truth is, most people are not comfortable with violence. So they find themselves at the mercy of armies or groups of policemen or vigilantes. You always hope, in that situation, that either a Shane will appear or that you will somehow become like Shane. I use the example of Michael Jordan. He's the guy who knows that the ballgame has to be won in the last six seconds, so he goes out there and quietly wins it. That's what had to happen here. I keep referring to Shane as the artist. You see, that's what he is. Shane is the guy who has brought this gunfighting to the level of art."

An article in Weekend on Friday about watching movies with Woody Allen misstated the number of six-shooters worn by Alan Ladd in the film "Shane." It was one, not two.

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION; 
Rochester, Still a Cradle Of Invention

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
"Race a boat! Help a good cause!" shouted a man in yellow boots, waving a pair of footlong toy boats, as we walked down the cobblestone street toward Brown's Race in Rochester, a relic of America's early industrial years that once powered mills grinding wheat into flour for New York City bakeries. For a $5 donation to Big Brothers/Big Sisters, you could watch your toy boat, captained by a rubber amphibian, bob a few dozen feet down the sloping rectangular box that for nearly two centuries has drawn water from the Genesee River at High Falls, the spectacular 90-foot cascade in the heart of downtown Rochester.
 Only a dozen or so of us watched our little boats, nothing like the thousands who gathered along the river gorge here in November 1929 to watch a daredevil named Sam Patch make his second, and fatal, leap over High Falls. Sam Patch's "leap into history," as the folk song gently puts it, parallels the leap we found as weekend tourists in a town that has built on its assets, recycling a rich history of the tools of industrial innovation that helped America prosper into new uses for a new era. 
 For those interested in the economic history of the great, and very uneven, wealth of America, Rochester is a great place to see how our political and social systems create a culture of mass affluence, built on innovation, hard work and investment, and how our ideas about America change with time. I live here on weekends and, with our daughters away at college camp, it was a great time to play tourist at home with my wife, Jennifer Leonard, president of the Rochester Area Community Foundation.
Rochester was the original boomtown. From 1820 to 1830 its population grew sixfold as the power of the Genesee was harnessed to trim logs into lumber and then to grind into flour the wheat grown in the vast flat fields that had been primeval forests. When the Erie Canal reached town in 1823, everything fell into prosperous place.
For more than a century Rochester was to industrial America what Silicon Valley is to the digital age. Western Union made telegrams cheap and reliable. George Eastman's Brownie camera let anyone take photographs. The signals that let trains run on time without crashing head on came from here.
So did Xerox's copiers. As well as new ways to move earth and improve underwater cement.
Today Rochester and surrounding Monroe County remain a center of invention (second, after Silicon Valley, in patents per capita), biotechnology (third per capita in graduate bioscience degrees) and exports (first per capita). The golden handshakes from a decade of downsizing at Kodak, Xerox and Bausch & Lomb have financed new enterprises that use fiber optics and organic molecules to create the digital and biotechnology products of the future.

From Mill to Museum
We began our weekend, as Rochester began its past, on the banks of the Genesee at the Centers at High Falls, a long-ago grain mill that today is a multistory family entertainment center with history museum, art gallery, restaurants and a jazz club. Through the glass floor of the history museum the original flood-control gates of the mill race can be viewed. An interactive computer exhibit models the making of the Genesee River gorge, beginning 10,000 years ago; the falls formed when the river, having failed to break through hard limestone, abruptly burrowed deep into layers of softer shale. The scions of Rochester history tell their stories on demand in a clever, compact exhibit.
Throughout the Centers, tiny horses decorated by schoolchildren stand atop exhibit cases, on window ledges and stair landings. They are part of the "Horses on Parade" public art sculptures of high-stepping and rearing ponies placed around Rochester with the sponsorship of the High Falls Brewing Company, which is also reinventing itself under new ownership for a new era of competition. The brewery dominates the other side of the river at High Falls, connected by a footbridge called Pont de Rennes, named for Rochester's sister city in France.
The waterways that drove the grist mills and moved the grain now move kayaks, crew teams, fishing dories and tour boats; "lake liners" sleeping 84 come in from the St. Lawrence Seaway by way of the locks of the Erie Canal and tie up at Corn Hill Landing, just south of the falls. At the far end of the city, where the north-flowing Genesee River empties into Lake Ontario after rushing over three sets of falls, a fast ferry to Toronto is to start service next year.

Lasers and Fireworks
After the public opening of a painting, sculpture and fiber art show in the High Falls Gallery, we visited the Empire Brewing Company, a microbrewery in a rehabilitated button factory with sleek Art Deco touches in its wood-paneled interior. It was hard to say which was better: the cheeky beers, which included a German wheat beer that tasted like iced tea, lemonade and pilsner, or the lobster egg rolls made with a soft, yeasty wrap. We knew it was time to get going when the crowds from Frontier Field, the new baseball park that is even more intimate than its architectural parent, Camden Yards, started passing our table on the way to the Pont de Rennes. The laser light show was fast approaching.
Now in its eighth year, the laser light show in the High Falls gorge has fine-tuned its virtuoso son-et-lumiere displays to please baby boomers, Generation X'ers and the latest generation, which some are calling "echo tots." A once-interminable history of the gorge from Ice Age to Space Age has shrunk to a charming few minutes of vignettes, followed by riveting lights and fireworks set to song, from the Beach Boys to James Brown. This may have been the first time in our lives that fireworks exploded at our eye level -- a thrill worth going to the Pont de Rennes early enough to get one of the coveted first-row spots at the rail.
We drifted away with the mellow crowds, past a life-size Horse on Parade called "All Keyed Up," in which computer keys had been recycled as body armor and colorful cable wires became mane and tail.
Our destination was the Inn on Broadway, an elegant 23-room bed-and-breakfast built in the former University Club of Rochester and within walking distance of theaters, restaurants and museums.
We arrived as crowds of young people drifted away from the monthly East End Festival, with music acts on street stages, clubs open late and a vibrant gaiety beyond the energy of us midlifers; it was (we hate to admit it) more fun to imagine than to partake in. (In winter, the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra or Eastman School of Music recitals would be the local music of choice, a block away at the 3,000-seat Eastman Theater with original Maxfield Parrish murals.)

A Featherbed Feeling
Our room's evocative decor featured old travel gear, a grand armoire, even century-old Harvard Club of New York registers (in keeping with the open chess set and World War II history by the breakfast coffee service on our floor). The featherbed feel of the bed and the three-jet shower completed the luxurious "just for us" getaway feel, augmented by the jazz radio that played softly from a modern but welcome combination CD player and alarm clock.
Later we found that our charming Canadian hosts were also handy with a griddle, and their lemon blueberry pancakes were a great start to the next day. Cohabiting with the catering company Gatherings, the inn continues the University Club's tradition of handling weddings and banquets in the landmark living room, the library, the College Room and the main ballroom. The last of these features two magnificent crystal chandeliers as well as murals of the Erie Canal, High Falls, Kodak and the University of Rochester -- home of an exciting new biotechnology research thrust, which has the whole city talking.

Kitsch of Every Era
In the morning we strolled two blocks from our hotel to the Strong Museum, named for an eccentric and single-minded benefactor, Margaret Woodbury Strong, whose family invested early in Kodak stock but could never get her to appreciate the benefits of regular bathing. Her fortune allowed her to build the largest doll and toy collection in the world, which she left to the museum, along with an endowment.
You can visit Mrs. Strong's collection, and many scholars do, on the second floor, where row upon row of glass cases display porcelain, wood, fabric and animated dolls, as well as porcelain tea sets and even Burma Shave signs. There are also Kewpie dolls and Ninja Turtles, giving a sense of the continuum of time as well as a reminder that kitsch is part of every era. There are also dozens of dollhouses. Our favorite featured a wood-paneled dining room with sterling silver chandelier and real brass fire implements.
The Strong Museum, which has plans to become one of the largest children's museums in the country, has already transformed itself from a dull warren of glass display cases into a lively, family-oriented interactive educational center. It has the first permanent "Sesame Street" exhibition in a museum and a child-size model of Rochester's renowned Wegmans supermarkets, which are often the first stop for visitors. On any weekday morning, preschoolers crowd the exhibits and the historic diner and an indoor carousel.
Our favorite exhibit takes a jaundiced look at the role of toys in fighting the cold war. "When Barbie Dated G.I. Joe" brings into sharp focus how toys served political purposes. A video loop of black-and-white commercials for toy six-shooters, a girl's board game called "Mystery Date" and other products offer reminders of how gender stereotyping was the norm in the days before a gleam in Gloria Steinem's eye became Ms. magazine. And how times change. Twice we heard children, reading from the display cards, ask their parents what the U.S.S.R. was.

The Eastman Legacy
A half-hour's walk away was George Eastman House, which combines the best of a mansion cum photographic museum. Aficionados worldwide also know that its archives house the original of many 35-millimeter movies and a treasure of historic photographic prints and negatives. We spent the afternoon at an Ansel Adams show, which examined how he took the images of photographers who had come along years or decades before and, with Eastman's improved technology, made even more compelling images. For many visitors it provides the first inkling that many other photographers captured Yosemite's Half Dome before Adams. The breadth and depth and longevity of Adams's photography stand out clearly in this exhibition, illuminated by a fine feel for his artistic imagination and technical genius, which results in a Platonic image of the natural world.
Eastman, who built the Eastman Theater and endowed the Eastman School of Music, also built his house for music. He held regular musicales in his enormous front living room. But the astounding history is that of the sunlit conservatory, built with a pipe organ in the wall. The organ music played as he came down to breakfast each morning (a breakfast setting is still seen by visitors), but alas, soon after moving into his new house, he declared its acoustics inadequate. To ensure a better sound, he had his house sliced in two and widened by 10 feet, a job that cost more than building the original mansion. 
The conservatory also reminds visitors of changing views of propriety. It is dominated by a cast made from the head of a giant elephant, which Eastman shot in the days when shooting on safari did not refer to a Kodak moment.

Cannons Out, Artworks In
After a stroll back past the East Avenue mansion and a break at Spot Coffee, a delightfully eclectic coffeehouse inside a 1930's Art Deco car showroom a block from the Inn on Broadway, we decided to visit another example of how an old industrial enterprise has found new life.
We drove to what had been a factory that turned out cannons in World War II and is now home to the Elizabeth Collection and its companion M.E.T.A.L. Arts, a cornucopia of modern art hung in an occasionally baffling richness of styles and mediums. A collector for more than 30 years, Louis Perticone rented the place to display his objets d'art. His father, William, an artist now in his 80's, painted major murals as part of the meandering vistas of this massive project. In a typical setting, a Frederic Remington bronze sits next to a miniature "Last Supper" tapestry table runner, not far from a Fantasy Art chair of giant lips beckoning the weary.
The M.E.T.A.L. museum (the letters stand for Museum at the Elizabeth Collection for Twentieth-Century American Laborers) offers a nonprofit and more thematic side to the collection (although almost everything is for sale). Modern versions of monumental worker murals serve as backdrops for six-foot wooden models of staplers, soda fountains and 1920's telephones. A recent Parisian street scene features several of the 25 artists' studios that are integral parts of the site; a Japanese tearoom (which can be rented for special dinners, as can many of the parts of the gallery and museum) features Oriental art treasures and books; a "Living With Art" exhibit displays art in a home setting to show its integration into decor.
We could have eaten nearby at the former propeller factory turned lively Italian restaurant and patio bar called Pomodoro, but we chose to return to our hotel neighborhood and walk three blocks to a former car detail shop turned French bistro. 2Vine (named for the detail shop's address on an alley that is now its parking lot) has become so popular that our hosts at the inn suggested we order one course at a time to ensure a leisurely dinner. We did, and we enjoyed fabulous food right down to the chocolate-wrapped creme brulee. By that time it was dark and we could happily wander back, sated, to our hotel. We ferreted our way through a wedding party and a crowd of fans of the Little Theater, a nonprofit art film house next door to the restaurant, and once more settled cozily into our home away from home.

Canoeing on the Erie Canal
On Sunday morning we went to canoe on the Erie Canal in Pittsford, a 1789 village that has preserved much of its charm and many of its vintage buildings. We rented a canoe at State Street and put into the water off a floating dock that put the first scent of fear into our landlubber souls. Strong canoeing skills would have been helpful because of pleasure boat traffic, which can leave large wakes that rock canoes. But the overhanging trees and smooth waters were a pleasant excuse for exercise. More athletic folks can rent kayaks at the same place, and many residents as well as visitors use the canal path for bicycling; there are convenient rentals right at dockside.
We took lunch at Aladdin's, where you can enjoy octopus salad and hummus on either of two small decks while watching children feed the mallards in the canal and watch power boats glide past.
We left as a gentleman angler on the promenade parried and tugged with something on the end of his line. Each movement drew another set of eyes as people rested their bikes, licked their cones and murmured "Ah-h-h!" as the fish bent the fisherman's slender rod into an arc, which, like the gathering crowd, slowly tightened. The big fish broke the surface for a moment, to gasps from the crowd, before plunging into the murky water, tugging at the taut line until it went limp, and the fish, like the crowd on this lazy Sunday afternoon, moved on.

In a City Renowned for Water Power

Rochester is 333 miles from New York City.

What to Do

CENTERS AT HIGH FALLS, 60 Brown's Race, (716) 325-2030 or Web site: www .artsrochester.org. The visitor's center includes interactive exhibitions, laser shows and programs on city highlights. Open Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Saturdays, noon to 10 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission is by donation. Laser and fireworks at 10 p.m. nightly in August, 9 p.m. in September.

FRONTIER FIELD, 1 Morrie Silver Way, (716) 454-1001 or (716) 423-9464 or www.redwingsbaseball.com. The baseball stadium for the minor league Rochester Redwings, the farm team for the Baltimore Orioles. The playing season is from April 1 to Sept. 1. Tickets: $5 to $9.

EASTMAN THEATER, 60 Gibbs Street, (716) 454-2100 or www.rpo.org for Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra; (716) 222-5000 for all other events. The season begins on Sept. 29.

GEORGE EASTMAN HOUSE, 900 East Avenue, (716) 271-3361. "In Praise of Nature: Ansel Adams and Photographers of the American West," through Sept. 16. HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Rise Warily on Upbeat Statements From Intel

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday after Intel signaled that the beleaguered personal computer industry might turn the corner, but memories of this year's false rallies kept investors cautious.
 "A lot of money has been burnt up, and it is going to take time for investors to heal, to resave and redeploy," said Tom Sparico, managing director of equities at the broker-dealer Bengal Partners. "It is going to take time for us to work our way back to the confidence levels that business investment will grow at a fast enough pace to add to earnings growth of something more than single digits." 
 Upbeat comments from Intel ignited a modest early-morning rally, but stocks started to weaken at mid-session. It was the third consecutive day an early rally fizzled. Investors remain skittish after a dismal second-quarter reporting season offered few hints that a profit recovery was in sight. 
"I keep asking, 'Is this for real? Is there any chance six months from now we are going to see a better economy?' People I know say this is a phony rally and don't be sucked in," said Ned Collins, a trader at Daiwa Securities America. 
"I have been negative for a while. I have been trying my best to switch my position and get a little more positive, but it sure is tough," he added. "I keep wondering where is the earnings turnaround going to come from?"
The Nasdaq composite index rose 19 points, or 0.9 percent, to close at 2,087.38, after climbing more than 1.6 percent early in the session and then dipping into negative territory.
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average gained 41.17 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,551.18. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended up 4.82 points, or 0.4 percent, at 1,220.75.
Investors took heart in government data showing claims for unemployment benefits dropped for the third consecutive week last week. But another report kept optimism in check by suggesting the manufacturing sector is still struggling to climb out of a painful recession. Wall Street is hoping today's employment numbers for July will offer a better read on the economy.
Craig R. Barrett, president and chief executive of Intel, said the personal computer industry had bottomed out and demand for personal computers should rebound in the second half of the year. But he noted that a full-blown rebound depended on a global economic recovery.
Intel, one of the 30 stocks in the Dow average, rose $1.36, to $32.11. The company, the world's largest maker of chips for personal computers, was the most active Nasdaq issue.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index advanced 3.15 percent, reflecting gains in other computer chip makers. The index continued its trek above its 200-day average, which it first broke above on Wednesday after a bullish call from Merrill Lynch on chip makers.
Dell Computer climbed $1.25, to $28.43, while I.B.M. advanced $1.74, to $108.80.
Microsoft, a Dow component and Nasdaq heavyweight, gained 98 cents, to $67.45. A federal appeals court rejected the company's request to re-examine part of its ruling in the landmark antitrust case against the company and also declined to speed the case's passage back to a lower court, a move sought by the federal government.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Drop
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices fell yesterday after a decline in jobless claims suggested that the economy might rebound without further Federal Reserve interest rate reductions after this month.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 21/32, to a price of 98 27/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.16 percent from 5.07 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 25/32, to 97 2/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.58 percent from 5.52 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
356 Units Under New City Bond Plan

BYLINE:  By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
A 356-apartment rental complex at Seventh Avenue and 26th Street, part of a spurt of residential building in Chelsea, is the first to be financed under a city-sponsored taxable bond program that offers developers quicker, if somewhat more expensive, access to financing.
 In return, the developers make some of the apartments available to people whose incomes, though moderate, are too high to qualify for traditional city housing programs. 
 The 340,000-square-foot complex, known as Chelsea Centro, consists of two adjoining properties: 200 West 26th Street, which has 17 stories and 231 apartments, and 220 West 26th, which has 11 stories and 125 apartments.
Eighty percent of the apartments will be rented at market rates, while the remaining 71 apartments have been set aside for low- and moderate-income households that earn up to 80 percent of the median income in the New York City area. The usual cap on income to qualify for such apartments under what are called 80/20 programs is half of the area's median income. 
Kevin P. Singleton, a senior vice president at the Rockrose Development Corporation, said that his company was prompted to build Chelsea Centro because of the success of its nearby Chelsea Mercantile luxury condominium at Seventh Avenue and 24th Street. Since that building began selling apartments in May 1999 -- its last apartment was sold about three weeks ago -- five new rental buildings, with a total of 1,500 apartments, have sprouted in the area north of West 23rd Street, said Charles Singer, the director of market research at Rockrose.
To develop Chelsea Centro, Rockrose bought a parking lot in June 1999 that bordered both West 25th and West 26th Streets and that used to house flea markets. The company took advantage of a new taxable bond program that was rolled out by the New York City Housing Development Corporation in February 2000.
The program gives developers relatively fast access to financing if they agree to devote a fifth of their buildings to apartments for those families that because of income caps do not qualify for more traditional housing programs. At Chelsea Centro, that translates into income of no more than $33,100 for a one-person household up to $47,250 for a family of four.
Most such "affordable housing" programs in New York City are financed through the sale of city-backed tax-exempt bonds, which currently pay about 1.5 percentage points less in interest than their taxable cousins might. But because sales of the bonds are limited during any particular year and also because developers have no control over when they will actually get the proceeds, last year the Housing Development Corporation introduced a more flexible financing alternative, said to be the first of its kind in the United States.
"With interest rates so low in general, these bonds are still attractive" compared with tax-exempt offerings, said Russell A. Harding, the president of the Housing Development Corporation.
The new city-backed bonds provided Chelsea Centro with more than $74 million in financing. But according to Mr. Singleton, they also helped his company bring the development to market about a year sooner than it might have otherwise.
For market-rate apartments at Chelsea Centro, which is now about 90 percent leased, Rockrose is asking $2,125 monthly for a 408-square-foot studio to $5,045 for a 1,164-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment.
The 20 percent of the apartments reserved for people with moderate incomes have all been rented to tenants who were selected, after first qualifying for the apartments, on a first-come-first-served basis. The apartments have monthly rentals of $747 for a studio to $961 for a two-bedroom unit.
The future of the 45,000 square feet of retail space at Chelsea Centro is uncertain, mostly because the largest prospective tenant, Lechter's, the housewares retailer, filed for bankruptcy protection before it could move into its 39,000-square-foot space.
If all goes according to plan, more developers may be coming to Chelsea soon. Mr. Harding said that the Housing Development Corporation was working with three other developers who were interested in using the taxable bonds to develop properties in both Chelsea and Clinton. "We think the bonds have been highly successful," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Chelsea Centro rental complex at 26th Street and Seventh Avenue used $74 million in financing from a new city-backed bond program. (Krista Niles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Public service ads had a record year in 2000, and the ad council has high hopes about 2001.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
IN 2000, the strongest year ever for advertising spending, the time and space donated to public service campaigns created by the Advertising Council also reached a record.
 The council received about $1.55 billion in donated media time and space, a 38 percent increase from the $1.12 billion in 1999. And with advertisers spending less in a sluggish economy, the council hopes to do better this year. 
 "We hope to grow it, of course, and I think there is plenty of room to grow" even if overall public service advertising does not increase, said Peggy Conlon, president and chief executive at the 59-year-old council in New York, which produces campaigns to educate viewers about issues like crime, drunken driving and seat-belt use. 
"It's definitely an opportunity for us to get our P.S.A.'s out there," Ms. Conlon added, and the slowing economy "certainly has been a factor in the increase that we've seen in media in the first quarter." 
Donated media time and space increased 23 percent in the first quarter, to $323.9 million from $262.9 million in the quarter a year earlier. Radio, the Internet and television were the top three donors in the first quarter, as they were in 2000.
Donations by radio in the first quarter rose 34 percent, to $159 million from $119 million; Internet donations were up about 13 percent, to $77.1 million from $68.5 million. Donated television advertising fell about 3 percent, to $61.6 million from $63.2 million.
"We're not looking for a huge increase in television inventory going to P.S.A.'s," Ms. Conlon said. "We know that they have to generate revenue and that may actually work against us because if they're getting a lower rate, they have to sell more ads in order to meet their revenue projections."
The donated time and space last year had the largest percentage increase since 1994, and 2000 was the third consecutive year that the value exceeded $1 billion. It was fueled by the sharp growth on the Internet and by continued support from radio.
And it was not just because of altruism. Ms. Conlon attributed the council's success in 2000 to three things: compelling campaign topics, emphasis on the importance of creative work and an increase in media outreach.
Radio was also the largest donor in 2000, providing $707 million of time, an 18 percent increase from $597.7 million in 1999. After radio was the Internet, whose donations jumped 499 percent, to $391.6 million from $65.4 million. Television was again third, up 0.5 percent, to $316 million from $314.6 million.
"I don't have any empirical evidence that the whole category of public service advertising grew," Ms. Conlon said. "We just look at what our part is in it, and I think what we experienced was probably a better share of market of that piece of the pie that is public service advertising."
She acknowledged that the Internet, the medium that had the largest increase, was also one that attracted cynicism because of skepticism about the effectiveness of banner advertising. But, she said, the council had found that the largest source of traffic to sites operated by Environmental Defense in New York was from Internet users clicking on donated banner ads.
Of the council's 40 or so campaigns, the two that earned the most donated support in 2000 did so because of the Internet. They were the campaign for Environmental Defense, at $169.5 million for the year, followed by one for the National 4-H Council in Chevy Chase, Md., with $117.3 million. 
The campaign for the National Crime Prevention Council in Washington, which traditionally attracts the most in donated time and space, was third with $75.4 million. The council said that if the Internet was excluded, the crime prevention campaign would be No. 1, and it attributed the change to preferences among people who make decisions about online advertising.
The council said it had been working to make sure its campaigns were being brought to the attention of the public service directors who decide whether to donate time and space, and it had been doing so by acknowledging the contributions of the media; educating agencies, advertisers and outlets; and attending media conferences, among other things.
The council is also trying to work more closely with regional markets and is providing more information about local associations and groups that are a part of a campaign. For example, the council is offering TV spots that can be "tagged" by local networks featuring their anchors, weather forecasters or sports figures.
To increase awareness and make the content more relevant, the council has started partnerships with organizations like the Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies in McLean, Va. (about six campaigns now have a separate Spanish-language component); Mediascope in Studio City, Calif., which promotes media responsibility; and Promax in Los Angeles, an organization for promotion and marketing executives.
"We're also going to put together a media advisory committee this year that will help us look at the issues that come before us," said Ira B. Tumpowsky, executive vice president for media at the council, "and maybe there's somebody out there that has a creative idea that we haven't tapped yet that we can look at and see how it works in the marketplace."

HEADLINE: A Cloudy Future for Policing 

BYLINE:  By William J. Bratton; William J. Bratton, a senior consultant to Kroll Associates, served as police commissioner in Boston and New York.

 BODY:
In Washington next week, many of America's most senior and experienced police leaders will gather at a conference sponsored by the Justice Department to discuss the current state of American policing. They will have a lot to talk about.
 Despite the historic crime reductions in the 1990's, for which police can justifiably claim much of the credit, American policing has become a deeply conflicted profession. Instead of being praised for the continuing declines in crime, police are increasingly criticized on a number of issues and for a wide variety of failings. As Gilbert and Sullivan put it more than 100 years ago: "A policeman's lot is not a happy one." 
 From Los Angeles to New York City, from Cincinnati to Miami, many of the nation's police forces face intense scrutiny and criticism for corruption, racial profiling, racial insensitivity, brutality, unresponsiveness to community concerns and professional incompetence.
This image of a troubled profession is a major contributor to the growing recruitment crisis for American police departments, which are having difficulty attracting qualified recruits, particularly from inner city neighborhoods and minority communities.
As reported in The New York Times earlier this week, the problem has spread to the top ranks of the profession. John Diaz, an assistant police chief in Seattle who does not plan to seek a top chief's job, said, "The politics of being police chief have become so insane no one wants the job." He may not be alone in that sentiment.
The causes of the current recruitment crisis, both at the entry level and at the top of the profession, are fairly clear. Starting pay of officers is relatively low in the current full-employment economy, and younger people don't see beyond the starting pay to weigh the advantages of a job with generous medical and retirement benefits. Even salaries for experienced officers remain low in cities like New York, where these officers can seek other opportunities. Policing has also become less a family tradition than it was a generation ago. And there is little appreciation among young people of the complexity and variety police work can offer or of the skills developed in policing that can be transferred to other arenas. The perception that policing offers limited opportunities, coupled with steady reports about police abuses -- which represent a very small percentage of police actions -- is more than enough to discourage a lot of people from even considering becoming police officers. It will require leadership and significant changes in police policy to reverse these perceptions.
For example, by providing the public detailed information about arrests and stop-and-frisk activities (as the New York City police department has recently agreed to do), departments can build greater trust in the community and therefore improve the climate for recruitment. 
We don't have all the answers about what must be done. What is clear, however, is what must not be done. We cannot, under any circumstances, reverse efforts to improve the qualifications, educational standards, diversity, training and accountability of officers or chiefs. Lowering standards to meet a short-term crisis would be counterproductive. Departments that go on hiring binges soon face even bigger problems when recruits unsuited to police work begin to work on city streets.
In 1994, when I was the New York City police commissioner and we were raising hiring standards for police officers, we did a study of officers who had been arrested as a direct result of the Mollen Commission investigation into police corruption and brutality. We found that not one of the officers who had been involved in that scandal would have been hired had our new standards been in place.
If we are going to sustain police successes against crime and expand efforts to work closely with communities, police departments must be able to attract the best from all segments of the population. We need individuals who see policing as a calling, not just as a job; who see the community as a partner, not as the problem; and who can be trusted to enforce the law without violating it themselves. Law enforcement needs to look at the recruitment crisis as a challenge -- like the challenge of reducing crime. Police departments systematically improved their crime-fighting techniques in the 1990's. I believe that with the right leadership and incentives, they can have the same type of success in recruitment. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Liability Insurers Pushing Companies to Share Risks 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Americans have had to get used to making bigger co-payments when they go to the doctor, as a result of changes in health insurers' policies. Now, a wave of shareholder lawsuits is prompting liability insurers to impose larger co-payments on corporate clients, too.
 The focus is on policies written to protect corporate executives and board members against suits charging that they did not act in the interest of shareholders -- by, for example, hiding losses or turning a blind eye to overstated revenue. 
 For the last five years or so, these insurance policies have paid 100 percent of a settlement or an award by a court after the company paid a deductible. But now, some companies will have to share more of the burden -- at least 15 percent and probably closer to 25 percent of any amount paid, insurers say. 
By forcing corporate clients to share more of the cost, analysts say, these new policies are intended by the insurers to discourage settlements. The shift is coming as such claims mount -- and, some insurers say, as shareholders are increasingly well armed with earnings restatements that support accusations of wrongdoing.
It could thus mean more litigation of securities claims, bigger legal bills and greater uncertainty about the outcome of lawsuits. 
The problem with current policies, said John Keogh, president of National Union Fire Insurance of Pittsburgh, is that they encourage companies to treat coverage as free settlement money. Companies may agree to pay the full amount of coverage for relatively weak claims, he said, because they have no incentive to reduce settlements. 
Mr. Keogh, whose company is a subsidiary of the American International Group, one of the largest underwriters of corporate liability insurance, added, "It's dysfunctional to have a product where all the responsibility is on the insurer financially, and none of it on the insured."
Liability insurance for directors and executives could start around $200,000 a year for $25 million of coverage, he said, and be affected by how likely it was that the company would face strong lawsuits. 
Businesses, of course, are not eager to share in the cost of settling securities claims against them, and argue that part of the reason to buy insurance in the first place is to protect them from having to pay. 
But Randy Thurman, director of risk management at Gaylord Entertainment, based in Nashville, and a vice president of the Risk and Insurance Management Society, saw matters as more uncertain. "If the co-insurance percentage that they were interested in negotiating was 10 percent," he said, "I wouldn't see a serious problem with that. If it were 25 percent, or a third, or a half, that would worry me a great deal."
Such a change would prompt his company to seek another insurer, Mr. Thurman said, adding that its current liability insurer had not announced changes to its policy.
Not all insurers have said so far that they will adopt a co-insurance system, and some may well hold out in an effort to frustrate this developing trend. But some of the largest, like A.I.G. and Chubb, which together account for more than a third of the market for corporate directors' and officers' insurance, have said that they are making the change. More clients may begin to see the changes as their policies come up for renewal, usually once a year. 
Behind the insurers' plan is concern about a sharp recent increase in the number and size of lawsuits filed against executives and board members. So far this year, 223 securities class-action suits have been filed in federal courts, compared with 211 in all of 2000, according to the Securities Class Action Clearinghouse at Stanford University Law School.
The size of settlements has also increased, rising to $14 million last year -- excluding a billion-dollar settlement by Cendant -- from $12.9 million in 1999, according to National Economic Research Associates, a consulting firm. Some prominent securities settlements recently include one by Procter & Gamble for $49 million in June, by Rite Aid for $200 million last November, and by 3Com for $259 million, also in November.
Lawyers for corporate directors and executives said that larger claims and larger settlements might be inevitable consequences of generally rising stock prices in recent years. The higher a stock's price, the more money investors may lose if the market value of the stock plummets.
But the claims that shareholders are filing against companies may also seem stronger, said Tony S. Galban, vice president and underwriting manager of directors' and officers' coverage at Chubb. 
"There are more claims with teeth," he said, because the kinds of mistakes that some companies have made are highly visible. "There's not a lot of defense when you have to restate your financials. What are you going to argue: 'We didn't blow it?' "
A greater risk to insurers could also be dealt with through higher premiums rather than co-insurance, said Robert Rabin, a professor at Stanford Law School. "Insurance itself can have a deterrent effect," he said, "if the insured recognizes that claims against it will result in higher premiums," adding that might discourage too-easy settlements.
The changes may also lead, lawyers say, to two tiers of insurance for directors and corporate executives: one type for those paying smaller premiums but sharing more risk, and the other for those paying more for full coverage.
The adoption of co-insurance is in some ways a return to a system in the early 1990's of allocating the burden of paying claims, said Michael D. Torpey, a partner in the law firm of Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison in San Francisco. Then, insurers sold policies covering only directors and officers, and after a claim was settled or a judgment issued by a court, the insurer and the company would dicker over how to divide the payment obligations.
"There was always a fight over allocation," Mr. Torpey said. But in the wake of court decisions hostile to insurers, and as the market for directors' and officers' coverage softened, insurance carriers began to offer so-called entity policies that would cover claims against directors, officers and the company itself.
"One of the side effects was that when you have entity coverage, after you get past the deductible, it's all on the carrier," he said. "Carriers didn't like that."

HEADLINE: June Factory Orders Fell Farther Than Expected 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
Factory orders fell 2.4 percent in June, a steeper drop than expected, led by declines in demand for computers and transportation equipment, a government report showed today.
 The decline in orders came after a 2.2 percent increase in May, the Commerce Department said. A 4 percent increase in orders for semiconductors, after a 34.6 percent surge in May, was not enough to outweigh the declines in computers and transportation equipment. Analysts expected an overall drop of 1.3 percent. 
 A separate report showed that the number of workers filing new claims for unemployment benefits declined last week to the lowest level in almost five and a half months, a sign that the worst of the job reductions may be over.
Initial jobless claims fell 23,000, to 346,000, in the week that ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. The drop, to the lowest level since Feb. 17, may reflect the return of furloughed workers after temporary shutdowns at auto plants.
Claims have fallen in each of the last three weeks, the longest string of declines since July 1998.
"There is a glimmer of hope that companies aren't firing workers as aggressively," said Richard Yamarone, the chief economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. Even so, "until the economy begins to pick up, companies will be less likely to add workers," he said.
A Labor Department report due out Friday is expected to show that the unemployment rate rose to 4.7 percent in July from 4.5 percent in June, analysts said. That would be the highest jobless rate since March 1998.
"It is more likely that labor markets are groping for a bottom than actually improving," said Steven Wood, the chief economist at FinancialOxygen in Walnut Creek, Calif.
This year, weekly jobless claims have averaged 382,800, up from the weekly average of 302,800 last year and the most since 407,800 in 1992. The government's statistics are based on requests for financial assistance administered by state and territorial employment service agencies. The number of people collecting unemployment benefits fell to 3.002 million during the week ended July 21 from 3.082 million in the previous week.
Companies are cutting costs to bolster profits as business slows with a sluggish economy. The bulk of recent job losses have been in manufacturing, especially at makers of business equipment. The economy grew in the second quarter at the slowest rate in eight years as business investment slumped and consumer spending cooled.

HEADLINE: The Mayoral Race and the Poor 

 BODY:
The signs are multiplying. New York's shelter system is reeling from the rise in homeless families. Food pantries are reporting a spike in the number of elderly people and children standing in line for their next meal. 
 Everyone hopes that the next mayor New York City elects will be confronted with problems such as which tax to cut or how to best improve the parks. But an economic downturn raises the possibility that his first big challenge will be a surge in the number of dislocated poor people who will turn to the city for food and shelter. 
 Right now, applications for shelter are running 30 percent higher than last year. The homeless population could grow even greater when the weather turns cold this coming winter. Food pantries and soup kitchens around the city serve 500,000 people a month -- and requests for emergency food are said to have risen dramatically. At the end of the year nearly 39,000 families, or roughly 75,000 people, reach the five-year lifetime limit on federal welfare aid and are removed from the rolls. The state will provide more restrictive assistance under a new and still evolving program. But families will have to reapply in order to get the state aid, a procedure that always leads to confusion, with people falling through the cracks and applicants who are actually qualified for aid being rejected.
The candidates for mayor have not, in general, attempted to duck the issue of what they would do about the homeless and hungry. But for the most part their campaigns address people who are concerned about other things, like neighborhood services and how to consolidate the Giuliani administration's crime-fighting successes.
The growing number of distressed poor families has to become one of the main points of discussion in this campaign. Voters who do not ask about it now may find themselves demanding answers later, especially if desperate New Yorkers begin to spill out of the shelters and back onto the sidewalks and streets.

HEADLINE: AOL Time Warner Reverses Itself on Cable Shift After Pressure by NBC 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
After deciding to move the financial news network CNBC to a less desirable, higher-numbered cable channel in New York City, AOL Time Warner reversed itself yesterday afternoon under pressure from NBC.
 Time Warner Cable of New York City, a division of AOL Time Warner, sent a letter to its 1.1 million customers in the city last week saying that it would move CNBC to Channel 64 from Channel 15 on Sept. 5. That raised antitrust concerns because the network would have been further back in the rotation than its chief rival, CNNfn, on Channel 27, which is owned by AOL Time Warner. 
 On Channel 64, CNBC would have been behind nearly every major cable network, nestled between Home and Garden Television and the Spice Channel, which shows pay-per-view sex movies. Officials at CNBC's parent company, NBC, and others said that such a move would be a realization of the fears they had when AOL's acquisition of Time Warner was approved earlier this year. 
Many critics of the merger said that the resulting conglomerate, AOL Time Warner, would have an unfair advantage by having its own television networks while controlling cable and Internet pipelines into millions of customers' homes.
CNBC would have been replaced on Channel 15 by Bravo, a film and live entertainment network that had paid Time Warner Cable to get better placement on its lineup. But NBC has a 20 percent financial interest in Bravo, and officials there said yesterday that they were unaware that they would be replacing CNBC, the dominant financial news network.
Throughout the day, NBC executives negotiated with Bravo officials to get them to agree to flip the two channels back. NBC said those talks were an attempt to avert filing a costly and difficult antitrust claim against AOL Time Warner.
A little before 5 p.m., the three sides reached an agreement to keep Bravo and CNBC where they were. "They brought that proposal to us," said Barry Rosenblum, the president of Time Warner Cable, "and we went ahead and agreed with them." 
Last year, before its acquisition by AOL, Time Warner came under criticism for a decision to black out ABC stations in several cities during a dispute with the network's parent, the Walt Disney Company, over payments for carrying ABC stations. Time Warner, which eventually came under enough public pressure to reverse its decision, was viewed as using the reach of its cable system to play hardball with Disney.
Yesterday, Corey Shields, an NBC spokesman, said officials were happy that this did not become similarly contentious. It was unclear whether Bravo got any concessions from NBC for giving up what would have been a prime spot.
If Bravo and NBC had not been able to come up with a deal, or if AOL Time Warner had not cooperated, the dispute could have led to what antitrust experts called the first legitimate challenge to a cable company's channel placement.
There are no provisions in federal antitrust law that regulate where cable companies place many channels, including networks like CNBC. But antitrust experts said that this situation could rise to the level of violating the Sherman Antitrust Act because AOL could have been construed as using its monopoly position as a cable company to benefit CNNfn at the expense of CNBC.
"Typically, you don't see a company like NBC having to go so far as filing a lawsuit to have their concerns addressed," said Christopher M. Mason, an antitrust and securities partner at Nixon Peabody, a Manhattan law firm. "NBC itself is a large and economically powerful company that has other broadcasting that Time Warner carries, and I was sure they would get Time Warner to listen to them."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Agency Layoffs And a Closing

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
Two agencies have announced lay-offs, while another is closing.
 Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, is laying off about 30 employees, or about 2.7 percent of its 1,100 employees in the United States, at offices in McLean, Va., San Francisco and St. Louis and at regional field offices. 
 Rebecca Sullivan, a spokeswoman for Arnold, said the layoffs were in response to the slowing economy. "I think everyone's tightening up all over the place," she said.
Last month, Arnold closed its design unit, Cipriani Kremer Design in Boston. Ms. Sullivan said the agency still planned to absorb most of the 18 employees from Cipriani. In January, the office in San Francisco, Arnold Ingalls Moranville, laid off about 12 of its 75 employees.
The New York office of TBWA/ Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, is laying off 8 from its staff of 216.
"We're just realigning and restructuring staff to accommodate the current production and service needs of our clients," said Jeremy Miller, a spokesman for TBWA/ Chiat/Day, confirming a report in the online edition of Adweek.
In May, the TBWA/Chiat/Day New York office laid off 17 of its 233 employees. The agency has laid off about 10.7 percent of its staff. 
Also, Robaire & Hogshead, a small agency in Venice, Calif., is being closed after three and a half years for what was described by its executives, Sally Hogshead and Jean Robaire, as philosophical differences and not economic conditions.
"While Sally wants very much to grow an ad agency in a traditional sense, I'm more focused on continuing to really focus on the creative end of things," said Mr. Robaire, co-creative director.
Robaire & Hogshead has eight employees.
The wants of Ms. Hogshead, 31, co-creative director, include managerial as well as creative duties in her next post. Mr. Robaire, 43, plans to continue creative work for projects in conjunction with agencies.
