HEADLINE: Defiant Legislators Proceed on Budget Spurned by Pataki 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
The State Legislature passed a stripped-down budget early this morning, four months overdue, defying Gov. George E. Pataki only hours after he declared that the spending plan was unconstitutional and would cause many government programs to run out of money.
 The 11th-hour clash between the governor, who has blamed the Assembly Democrats for the budget impasse, and Democratic and Republican leaders staying past midnight to vote on the lean spending plan tossed the state's fiscal house into confusion. As the last votes were cast just before 1 a.m., it was unclear whether the governor would turn around later today and challenge the budget plan in court. 
 Last week, the Democrats who control the Assembly and the Republican-led Senate put aside partisan differences and agreed to pass an austere budget intended to make it hard for Mr. Pataki to govern. Their aim is to force the governor into three-way negotiations over a supplemental budget, in which they hope to add some initiatives that the governor is resisting. 
For months, the governor and Assembly Democrats have been unable to reach agreement on revenue estimates because of a disagreement about the economy's future. Mr. Pataki has accused the Democrats of proposing irresponsible spending increases, while the Democrats have refused to pass a budget without the governor's participation. Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, has balked at passing a budget with the Senate unless the governor agrees not to resort to widespread vetoes, as he did in 1998.
Thursday began almost uneventfully, with lawmakers gathering in the Capitol as they faced yet another deadline: at midnight the government would lose its authority to spend money without a budget or an extension. They also faced the possible embarrassment of setting a new record for late budgets if their stalemate had lasted until Sunday. New York has not passed a budget on time in 17 years.
Like most days when legislators have been haggling over budgets, the governor seemed to be ignoring them on Thursday. He had plans to leave Albany and go to Syracuse to settle a football bet with Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota with a fishing trip this morning on Onondaga Lake. 
Then Mr. Pataki surprised lawmakers with a news conference Thursday afternoon and warned that the state might stop functioning if the Legislature passed the bare-bones budget it was considering. He said the legislators' $79.6 billion budget, which cuts about $4 billion from his original plan, would cause many programs, among them Medicaid, to run out of funds before the end of the fiscal year in March. 
"It does not come close to constituting what, by any reasonable definition, would allow for the continuance of governance for the balance of the fiscal year," he said. "This budget does not meet the needs of the people."
The governor and his aides also argued that the legislators had violated the State Constitution by changing language in the budget spending bills. They also held out the possibility that they would take the matter to court if the Legislature did not accept 800 pages of amendments to restore cutbacks.
The Democrats who control the Assembly and the Republican majority in the Senate stood their ground, however, and refused to consider the governor's amendments. They maintained that their spartan spending plan would provide enough money to meet legal requirements. That decision is ultimately up to the Democratic state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, who had not made a determination early today. Mr. McCall plans to challenge the governor in next year's elections.
Because the Legislature acted on the governor's bills without adding money or changing clauses, lawmakers argue, the parsimonious budget will become law immediately. The governor's counsel, James McGuire, however, said the governor might challenge that idea in court, because the Legislature deleted many changes to law that the governor had included in appropriations bills. 
Mr. Silver said the stripped-down plan "provides a complete, solid and balanced framework for meeting all state financial obligations and responsibilities for the entire fiscal year." Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader, acknowledged that the budget would cause some programs to run short of money in early September, but defended the tactic as the only way to break the stalemate with the governor. "We are trying to get some momentum," Mr. Bruno said. 
The budget essentially holds spending for most departments at last year's levels. It also cuts out any new programs or spending increases the governor proposed in January, except for a $382 billion increase in aid to schools, a figure school officials across the state are complaining is inadequate.
But the plan also omits several programs near to Mr. Pataki's heart. It eliminates, for instance, a $150 million fund for conservation and the acquisition of new parkland. It also effectively shuts down the state's economic development corporations, by not authorizing them to spend about $300 million on various projects.
The budget also holds hostage much of the $2.4 billion in federal money the state receives for welfare each year. It allocates $937 million for welfare payments, but puts the rest in a reserve fund. That means many important programs that help people move off the welfare rolls will not receive money in this budget. Among them is a $300 million program to provide 71,000 day care slots to single mothers and $323 million to pay for an earned-income tax credit. 
"It would be devastating," said Anne Erickson, the director of the Greater Upstate Law Project. "This has to be the beginning, not the end." 
On Medicaid, the Legislature has also created a headache for Mr. Pataki. The leaders eliminated changes the governor proposed that would have saved about $113 million in Medicaid spending on nursing homes and home care, ensuring a shortfall in those programs before the end of the year.
After Sept. 15, the budget would also eliminate about $54 million worth of appropriations, most of them for social services, approved in previous years, severely crimping many nonprofit organizations that depend on state grants.
Mr. Pataki predicted that many entitlement programs would run short of money. "We are looking at a so-called baseline budget that in fact, within a very short period of time, creates enormous difficulties for the government," he said. 
Still, Mr. Pataki vowed to keep the government running, by tapping reserve funds. "We'll look into this pool and that pool to try to keep the government running," he said. Senior lawmakers, however, said they hoped that the minimalist budget they debated would be a starting point for negotiations with the governor. 
"We have made this a bare-bones budget deliberately because we want to get the governor to participate," Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. said during the debate.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Discrimination Claimed 

BYLINE:  By Alan Feuer (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Federal regulators filed a discrimination lawsuit yesterday on behalf of three female construction workers who claimed that they were sexually harassed and forced to pick up after their male colleagues while working at a job site in Brooklyn. The three women complained last year to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that they were subjected to a hostile work environment while working for Tratoros Construction Inc., a general contractor hired by the New York Housing Authority to renovate the Williamsburg Houses in northern Brooklyn. 
After investigating their claims, the commission filed a sexual discrimination suit on their behalf in United States District Court in Brooklyn. In its formal complaint, the commission said, "Offensive and unwelcome comments were made regarding women's menstruation and sexual activity." The complaint accuses one of the company's male supervisors of telling his male colleagues to leave the women alone "because they had cramps" and ordered the women to "change their Pampers." The supervisor also asked the women if they had recently had sex and publicly accused two of them of having an affair, according to the complaint. The three women say they were forced to clean bathrooms and kitchens and wash windows while the men did demolition and paint jobs. Chris Curis, a spokesman for Tratoros, said the company denied all of the allegations and he could not discuss continuing litigation. Alan Feuer (NYT)

HEADLINE: The Crucial Votes in the House on the Energy Bill 

 BODY:
 Following are the roll-call votes in the House on Wednesday and early yesterday passing an energy bill, defeating significant increases in motor vehicle fuel economy standards and rejecting an attempt to ban drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The vote on the full bill was 240 to 189, with 36 Democrats, 203 Republicans and 1 independent voting for the bill and 172 Democrats, 16 Republicans and 1 independent voting against it. The vote on fuel standards was 269 to 160, with 123 Democrats, 36 Republicans and 1 independent supporting high standards and 86 Democrats, 182 Republicans and 1 independent opposing them. The vote on drilling in the refuge was 223 to 206, as 171 Democrats, 34 Republicans and 1 independent supported the ban, while 36 Democrats, 186 Republicans and 1 independent opposed it. There is one vacancy in the House.

HEADLINE: Bank of England Unexpectedly Cuts Benchmark Rate 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
The Bank of England unexpectedly trimmed its benchmark interest rate one-quarter point today, to 5 percent, responding to worsening economic tidings from the United States and Europe.
 The move surprised economists, who had expected the bank to hold rates steady. The European Central Bank, which sets rates for the 12 nations that have adopted the euro but not for Britain, decided separately today to leave its benchmark rate unchanged at 4.5 percent. 
 The Bank of England's move, its fourth reduction this year, pumped life into the stock market here, with the widely followed Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index closing at a four-week high, up 37.6 points, to 5,584.5. The bond market was mixed. Yields on the two-year government bond, which tracks central bank rates, fell to 5.12 percent from 5.18 on Wednesday. 
"Indicators of world economic activity have been weaker than expected over the last few months," the bank's Monetary Policy Committee said in a statement today. Minutes of the meeting will be released Aug. 15.
Economists pointed to rising unemployment and deteriorating business confidence in Western Europe and North America as important factors in the bank's decision. In Germany, the largest economy in Europe, executives are more pessimistic than at any time in five years. Worrisome statistics released in the United States recently included slowing orders for durable goods, less robust economic growth and an uptick in unemployment.
"The Bank of England is worried about the effects of the global slowdown on the U.K. economy, and they are willing to fight that by boosting domestic demand" through looser monetary policy, said Michael Taylor, a Merrill Lynch economist.
Analysts still expect Britain's economy to grow 2.2 percent in 2001, faster than either the United States or the big economies of Europe.
Inflation in Britain has remained below the bank's target of 2.5 percent for more than two years, leaving room to use monetary policy to stimulate the economy. While the inflation rate has crept higher lately, reaching 2.4 percent in the 12 months through June, the bank attributed the rise to "erratic factors," like food prices and said that "underlying price and cost pressures are expected to remain subdued."
The European Central Bank has had less maneuvering room, because inflation in its bailiwick has been running above its target for more than a year. But price rises have slowed somewhat in recent months, leading many analysts to predict a rate cut in August.
The move by the Bank of England today was especially surprising given past statements by bank leaders like Mervyn King, the deputy governor, who has championed predictability as the best recipe for stable markets.
Mr. King has also expressed concern about what he deems an "unsustainable imbalance" in Britain's economy -- domestic demand, as signified by retail spending and house prices remaining robust while export-driven industries like manufacturing falter. Exports now account for one-quarter of Britain's total output of goods and services.
Some economists echoed his concern today. "If the Bank of England is trying to stoke the domestic economy by throwing fuel on the fire, it might get out of hand later this year, especially if the global economy improves," said Peter Dixon, a Commerzbank Securities economist.
Spending by British consumers, equal to about two-thirds of gross domestic product, has been buoyant lately. Retail sales rose at their fastest pace in more than a year in July. Major store chains have been reporting robust gains: an 8.6 percent rise in sales at Carpetright, Britain's largest carpet retailer, in the three months ended July 31; a 19 percent jump at Hamleys, the toy store, in the 16 weeks to July 20; a 5.6 percent rise at J. Sainsbury, the No. 2 supermarket chain, in the 12 weeks to June 23.
Manufacturing, on the other hand, contracted for the fifth consecutive month in July. Invensys, a factory-controls maker; Marconi, a phone equipment manufacturer; and the Corus Group, a steel maker, have all announced major layoffs recently involving thousands of jobs.
The Confederation of British Industry had been lobbying for a rate cut, and Douglas Godden, the group's head of economic policy, praised the move today. "Interest rates are now at the appropriate level," he said.
Economists said lower rates alone would not bring fast relief to manufacturers, whose export sales continue to suffer from the strength of the pound, which fell to $1.4316 from $1.4345.
But homebuyers will see some benefit almost immediately. Three major mortgage lenders -- Halifax, Lloyds TSB and the Nationwide Building Society -- quickly followed the Bank of England's move with quarter-point reductions in their rates, making mortgage money cheaper here than at any time since 1963.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
Cost-Cutting Helps Disney Exceed Earnings Forecast

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company announced quarterly financial results yesterday that modestly exceeded analysts' expectations.
 But expectations were fairly modest to begin with. Whether because of the nation's generally slow economy, the weak advertising market or the company's own missteps, none of Disney's operations are performing spectacularly these days. 
 When times are tough, however, the tough cut costs. Or at least that is what they do in Burbank, Calif., home to Disney, the world's second-largest media company after AOL Time Warner. Disney's recent cost-reduction moves have included the planned elimination of 4,000 jobs. 
The cost cuts helped the company generate earnings of 23 cents a share, excluding special charges, like those for job cutting, and adjusting for the effect of acquisitions. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call predicted earnings by that measure of 21 cents a share.
In addition, the company posted revenue of $5.98 billion. The analysts predicted revenue of $5.9 billion.
The results, for Disney's third fiscal quarter, which ended in June, were announced after the major financial markets closed. In after-hours trading, however, the company's shares rose as high as $27.35 from a 4 p.m. close of $26.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"The third quarter of fiscal 2001 says a lot about our company," Michael D. Eisner, the company's chairman, said in a conference call.
Disney's revenue in the quarter, $5.98 billion, was down about 1 percent from $6.05 billion during the period last year.
The earnings of 23 cents a share were the same as in last year's third quarter. But overall earnings before charges -- and adjusted for acquisitions -- declined to $479 million from $495 million a year earlier.
The weak advertising market has not helped matters. Advertising supplies almost one-quarter of Disney's revenue.
Most of Disney's advertising revenue is generated by the company's media networks unit, which includes ABC and ESPN, as well as local television and radio stations. The unit's revenue declined almost 6 percent, to $2.14 billion from $2.27 billion in last year's third quarter. The division's operating income fell more sharply, by 29 percent, to $470 million from $662 million.
In addition to the weak advertising market's role in the declines, ABC's ratings have recently tailed off as well.
Revenue at Disney's parks and resorts was essentially flat, while revenue fell at its consumer products and Internet divisions.
Surprisingly, perhaps, the brightest spot in the company's results might have come from Disney's studio entertainment business, which is dominated by the film unit. Despite the failure of "Pearl Harbor" to achieve blockbuster status, the studio operation reported a 7.7 percent increase in revenue, to $1.34 billion from $1.25 billion.
Including the effect of charges, acquisitions and changes in capital structure, the company reported earnings of 19 cents a share, or $392 million. In the period last year, the company reported earnings of 21 cents a share, or $361 million.
In an interview, Thomas O. Staggs, Disney's chief financial officer, said the company was still on track to meet its financial target for the fiscal year of generating per-share earnings growth "in the high single digits."
Disney executives spent a fair amount of time yesterday citing their company's policy of refusing to comment on potential merger or acquisition activity.
Disney is one of a number of companies that appear to be considering whether to bid for all or a part of AT&T's cable television operation, the nation's largest. AT&T has said that a number of companies have signed confidentiality agreements as a precursor to negotiations.
AT&T has not said which or how many companies have signed the agreements. The Comcast Corporation, which set this process in motion last month with its unsolicited $44.5 billion bid for the AT&T cable unit, does not appear to be one of them.
"I can't comment on any of the things that are being rumored in the press now, but we certainly are keeping our eyes open," Mr. Eisner said on the conference call. "We keep looking, but we're not going to do it just to get a good headline in the media and then have to bear an unpleasant reality a year later. So we're going to do something, if we do anything at all, that we think really enhances our company."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
The Item You Ordered May Be Sneaky

BYLINE:  By ELVIS MITCHELL 

 BODY:
It's safe to say that Antonio Banderas is the campiest heterosexual left in show business, if not on the planet. Pedro Almodovar often exploited the actor's luscious Iberian looks, musical vocal delivery and sexy caterpillar eyebrows, and Mr. Banderas was in on the joke. (He probably laughed at the semaphore-broad impression of him that Chris Kattan brandished before the cameras on "Saturday Night Live.")
 Mr. Banderas's awareness of his beauty and his sense of humor about it, as well as his swift reflexes as an actor, can often keep him from being absurd. When his falcon's-wingspan lashes start fluttering, you're laughing with him. But few directors have figured out a way to use him well in serious pictures, and Michael Cristofer, the director of the earnest romance "Original Sin," won't make that list. 
 As Luis, a worldly late-19th-century Cuban aristocrat who learns that he is naive after all, Mr. Banderas is shoved into a familiar position: the butt of the joke. But in "Original Sin" (and the most original thing about the picture is the use of that word in the title), he's not alone as the laughing stock. His co-star is Angelina Jolie, whose sultriness is so overwhelming that she's a real-life caricature as drawn by Mad magazine's Mort Drucker, with her sofa-cushion lips and a chin cleft so deep that mushrooms could grow in its shadow. And then there's her fearless avidity for acting. "You have no shame at all," Mr. Banderas murmurs incredulously.
It seems ridiculous to put these two in a romantic melodrama; their faces alone are melodramatic enough. It's hard to keep a straight face just thinking of Mr. Banderas and Ms. Jolie in the same shot, but "Original Sin" will bore the giggles right out of you.
Luis orders a bride via mail from the United States. "Love is not for me," he confesses to his housekeeper (Joan Pringle), who roars with laughter. All he asks of his potential bride is that she be kind and "young enough to bear children." Those are the qualifications stated by the plain Jane, or rather, plain Julia, who answers him, enclosing a photo so he won't get the wrong idea.
When the Julia who shows up and purrs at him doesn't resemble the photo, he is lost. "I deceived you," admits Julia (Ms. Jolie), but only because she didn't want a man to fall for her just because she's a pretty face. He'll forgive her just this once because it turns out he has also lied. He doesn't just work at a coffee plantation; he's one of its owners.
The story plunges more precipitously than Ms. Jolie's neckline. Luis does fall for her, despite his detachment. And when Julia walks out with his money, the only shock is that he is caught off guard. She has left him plenty of clues in her portentous rambling about love and lying.
After taking some time out for a debauch that hardly serves the healing purpose he had hoped for, Luis dedicates his life to finding Julia, joined by a private investigator, Walter Downs (Thomas Jane). Luis is always a couple of steps behind the plot, which leaves the audience in the position of stealing a couple of steps closer to the exit.
"Original Sin" -- adapted from Cornell Woolrich's novel "Waltz Into Darkness" (the basis also for Truffaut's "Mississippi Mermaid") -- drops the businesslike, detail-laden distance of the original material for an infatuation with heartbreak much closer in spirit to melodramas like the ravishing and unforgettable "Letter to an Unknown Woman." But everything in this film is forgettable, right down to bongos pounding on the soundtrack to indicate a quickening of the pulse, or characters closing the doors before the camera.
In one case, Mr. Banderas registers emotion by lifting his head in slow motion, a move right out of "The Young and the Restless."
Such recycling is appropriate because no one in the film is above lifting tricks from the recent past. As Luis's hearty-back-slap partner, Jack Thompson dusts off the accent he used in "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil."
Ms. Jolie seems to be working out the one she used in "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider" for the Fruity Pebbles lines that pop up, to much hilarity, in the trailer for "Original Sin." Unfortunately, these lines are parsed out with sad economy in the movie itself; they could have been bits of flavor in the gruel of run-on and predictable exposition. Students of such junk will have to limit themselves to the stars' exhibitionistic displays of sweat and skin: not many actresses will follow an Oscar by starring in soft-core nonsense like "Original Sin." The beautiful and lurid cinematography by Rodrigo Prieto accentuates every jawline; it's lighted like the hallways of a Philippe Starck hotel. 
Mr. Cristofer knows what an open actress he has in Ms. Jolie, whom he directed in the race-with-deterioration melodrama "Gia" on HBO. In "Original Sin," it's Mr. Banderas's Luis, emotionally and financially in ruins, who disintegrates on-screen: his skin becomes as pallid as mottled, gray parchment. (Jolie is willingly tortured here, just so Mr. Cristofer can show his taste for perversity.)
"This is not a love story, but a story about love," Julia says in one of the flashbacks that frame "Original Sin." You'll probably just end up wishing that this middlebrow potboiler were about something, other than about two hours.
"Original Sin" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes violence, strong language, luxuriant scenes of sexuality suited to its eventual run on pay-per-view, and a few other baroque and piquant instances of garish behavior.

ORIGINAL SIN

Directed by Michael Cristofer; written by Mr. Cristofer, inspired by the novel "Waltz Into Darkness" by Cornell Woolrich; director of photography, Rodrigo Prieto; edited by Eric Sears; production designer, David J. Bomba; produced by Denise Di Novi, Kate Guinzburg and Carol Lees; released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures. Running time: 110 minutes. This film is rated R.

WITH: Antonio Banderas (Luis Antonio Vargas), Angelina Jolie (Julia Russell), Thomas Jane (Walter Downs), Jack Thompson (Alan Jordan), Allison Mackie (Augusta Jordan), Joan Pringle (Sara), Pedro Armendariz (Jorge Cortes), Cordelia Richards (Emily Russell), Gregory Itzin (Colonel Worth) and Daniel Martinez (Rafael).

HEADLINE: A Call for Broadband 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Shakeout in Fiber Optics" (editorial, July 29): 
High-tech industry leaders believe that rapid and widespread deployment of broadband is key to the future of their industry and the United States' economy. 
Unfortunately, outdated government policies lack the right incentives for companies like Verizon to invest in broadband.
Congress can revive the economy and the high-tech sector by passing the Internet freedom and broadband deployment act, which promotes broadband growth by lifting rules that suffocate investment, innovation and competition.
New Yorkers are saving up to $700 million a year on local and long-distance services as a result of intense competition. Opening long-distance data markets to all comers can achieve similar results.

IVAN SEIDENBERG
New York, July 31, 2001

The writer is president and co-C.E.O. of Verizon.

HEADLINE: A Top Treasury Official Favors Quick I.M.F. Aid to Argentina 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
The Bush administration signaled support today for accelerating an international loan to Argentina, which is struggling to contain a financial crisis. 
 The Treasury Department's top international official, John B. Taylor, headed to Argentina on an emergency fact-finding trip. Mr. Taylor, who is under secretary for international affairs, said before his departure for meetings in Buenos Aires on Friday and Saturday that he thought there was a good chance that the payment of new loans to Argentina by the International Monetary Fund would soon be approved. 
 He said officials were also considering a range of other options to help the Argentines, though he declined to say what ideas were on the table. 
Argentina is scheduled to receive an additional $2.4 billion in I.M.F. loans this year, and the next installment had been expected to be approved in September. 
Mr. Taylor spoke to reporters after the White House said President Bush had phoned President Fernando de la Rua of Argentina to express support for his efforts to stabilize the country's finances by imposing a government austerity program. 
On Monday, the Argentine Senate adopted a plan to cut spending and balance the budget, aiming to calm the fears of investors that the nation would default on its debt payments. Those fears have made credit markets wary about the debt of some other developing economies. 
Mr. Bush called Mr. de la Rua on Wednesday, and in a 10-minute conversation they exchanged views on Argentina's financial situation, an administration spokeswoman, Mary Ellen Countryman, said. 
Mr. Taylor said that Washington favored releasing the $1.2 billion September loan installment to Argentina early. That money, and another $1.2 billion scheduled for November, are part of $7 billion in I.M.F. resources available to Argentina under an existing loan program. 
There have been reports that the Argentines may request a larger loan, and Mr. Taylor would not say whether the United States would support increasing the size of the I.M.F. package. 
"There are a whole range of discussions going on," he said, adding that "we will be discussing all of these things" in the meetings with government officials, the Argentine central bank and Argentine business executives over the next two days.

HEADLINE: The Dangers of Voting Outside the Booth 

BYLINE:  By Norman J. Ornstein; Norman J. Ornstein, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, led the voting procedures group of the Constitution Project's Forum on Election Reform.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Major reports on election reform have come out in the past few weeks from scholars at the California Institute of Technology and M.I.T., a commission led by former Presidents Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, and the Constitution Project of Georgetown University's Public Policy Institute. Most reaction in the press has focused on the groups' varying proposals that seem related to last fall's Florida election, like eliminating punch-card voting machines; letting everyone who comes to the polls on Election Day vote, even though a lack of registration might disqualify ballots later; extending voting hours; and perhaps moving Election Day to a holiday or a weekend. Virtually unmentioned is something all three reports have in common: a concern about the explosion in voting that doesn't involve going to the polls on Election Day.
 Almost unnoticed last fall, in the frenzy over the close Florida results, was the startlingly large proportion of the votes in the presidential election -- about 20 percent -- that were cast by these alternative methods. All of Oregon's ballots and more than 50 percent of those in Washington State were cast by mail, for example; more than 25 percent of votes were filed early in states like Tennessee and Texas; and nearly 25 percent of voting in California was by absentee ballot. 
 The trend is both clear and alarming. One-fifth of our voters voted well before Election Day -- before we saw the candidates in action under the pressure of the final days of the campaign. They voted from a smaller base of knowledge than the rest of us had; it was the equivalent of deciding the winner of a basketball game at the end of the third quarter. Some of those voters, of course, could not get to the polls because of illness or travel, but this group is usually less than 5 percent of voters in any election.
Serious election fraud -- through forgery, chicanery and badgering of voters -- is all too possible when voters don't go to the polls. Judges have nullified results because of fraud in absentee ballots, for example, in the Miami mayoral race of 1997 and in some local elections in the past decade in South Carolina.
Alternative voting also delayed some states' 2000 election results -- and with them, the overall result for the whole country. Waiting for ballots to arrive and verifying and counting millions of ballots takes time.
Many state secretaries of state and local election officials who were contacted by the Constitution Project brushed off or bristled at these criticisms. They focused instead on the convenience for voters of filling out a ballot at home and sticking an envelope in the mail, the economies of using fewer poll workers and voting machines, and an assumption -- which the commissions on voting did not find to be borne out -- that alternative voting enhances participation in elections. For election officials in Oregon and Washington, the belief in the efficacy of voting by mail has taken on almost religious significance.
But the consensus of the social scientists, political philosophers, elected officials and others on the commissions that studied voting is in the opposite direction. The National Commission on Federal Election Reform, led by Presidents Ford and Carter, said it was troubled by the trend toward mail voting, early voting in person and absentee voting without requiring an excuse. "Though this trend is justified as promoting voter turnout, the evidence for this effect is thin," its report said. "Analysts have even noted the possibility that voter turnout in such states may eventually decline, as the civic significance of Election Day loses its meaning."
The report from Caltech and M.I.T. recommends: "Restrict or abolish on-demand absentee voting in favor of in-person early voting." And the Constitution Project report decries unlimited absentee balloting and votes by mail, strongly endorsing "the proposition that voting at the polls serves basic and historically rooted objectives" and adding: "The gathering of citizens to vote is a fundamental act of community and citizenship. It provides the greatest security for enabling voters to cast their ballots free of coercion. It facilitates prompt counting and verification of results."
To many, anything that makes it easier for people to vote is automatically a good idea. It will be a Herculean task to reverse this kind of thinking, especially in the West. But we should be doing everything possible to keep alternative voting from expanding until Election Day becomes a meaningless time. As Congress and the states prepare to move on election reform, they should keep in mind the consensus view of every major panel that has examined this issue.

HEADLINE: Dressing for 2, Buying for 1; 
Retailers Vie for More Fashion-Conscious Moms-to-Be

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
Tucked in the corner on the third floor of Barneys in Beverly Hills, past the $500 gowns by Dosa, across the aisle from the $1,000 Piazza Sempione jackets, a mannequin displays the latest by Diane Von Furstenberg. A cream-and-brick-colored dress is stretched tight across the belly -- which looks seven months pregnant -- and from the sleeve dangles a $325 price tag.
 With many expectant mothers older, wiser and more fashion conscious these days, merchants at all levels of the retailing hierarchy seem to be vying for the buying dollars of women dressing for two. And, reflecting the digital times, in the last year mainstream retailers like Gap and its Old Navy chain have begun selling maternity wear online. 
 Even Barneys New York, which caters to trendsetters from New York to Los Angeles, is wooing moms-to-be. Four racks here are crammed with velvety-soft hip huggers and enough silk shirts and cashmere sweaters to make a Vogue editor swoon. Last year Barneys introduced Procreation, its exclusive line of maternity wear. It is not ordinary fare, though. In its Beverly Hills store, a stylish leather jacket (with ample room for an expanding middle) sold for $600. 
"We cater to the woman who is aggressively fashion conscious," said Melissa Seay, a store manager.
Indeed. But it is retail stores and designers, dogged by years of sagging profits and a fickle customer trained to seek bargains, that have become more aggressive. In the nation's fashion capitals, upscale boutiques and department stores like Fred Segal, Liz Lange and Saks Fifth Avenue are packing stores with stretchy slim pants and body-hugging T-shirts, once the uniform of only the most trim.
At the same time, the retailers that have long specialized in maternity wear are fighting back, hoping to stem the competition by emphasizing their experience and devotion to the market.
Why all the interest in mothers-to-be now? For one thing, professional working women, many of whom have opted to have children in their late 20's and 30's, are demanding well-made, stylish clothes that fit not only their hectic lifestyles, but their bodies as well.
The birth rate among women in their 30's is at its highest level in more than three decades, according to the National Center for Health Statistics, which tracks births, while the rate for women in their 20's fell in the 1990's.
Older expectant mothers have money to spend, and a honed sense of personal style from years of dressing themselves. As a result, they are unwilling to trade in sleek pants and jackets for tent dresses or shifts with bow ties.
It is no surprise, then, that for its fall season the Gap has chosen the slogan "Gap Maternity. What you'd wear even if you weren't." Industry analysts are suggesting that the tiny market once dominated by a handful of players could reach $2 billion in sales in the coming year.
"It's really what I would call niche marketing at its most extreme," said Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Strategic Retail, a Manhattan consulting firm. "When the business started to get tougher, people began to look outside of their core business."
Recent history suggests that specialty sizes are big sellers. Clothing made for petite women is now an $8 billion business, a 31 percent increase since 1998, according to NPD Fashionworld Consumer, which tracks the women's clothing market. By contrast, sales of misses' clothing in the same period remained flat. Witness, too, the boom in sales of plus-size fashions, which last year, NPD said, totaled $19.7 billion -- a 10 percent increase in two years. 
But unlike shoppers buying misses, petite or plus-size clothes, pregnant women do not have the luxury of waiting for an item they adore to hit the sale rack. "When they need it, they need it now," said Faye Landes, an analyst who covers retailing for Sanford C. Bernstein. "If you see it in your third month, you only have a short window of time to wear it."
As a result, retailers have a captive audience who will pay any reasonable price -- or unreasonable, depending on how extravagant buyers feel -- for clothes they not only want, but need. "Who knows?" mused Ms. Liebmann of WSL. "Maybe La Perla will sell a really sexy nursing bra for $433."
Rebecca Matthias, president and chief operating officer of Mothers Work in Philadelphia, a leading maternity retailer for more than two decades, scoffs at the new competition. Her company, which owns three of the dominant maternity-wear chains, sells clothes in 765 stores and outlets. Its chains are A Pea in the Pod, which caters to affluent shoppers; Mimi Maternity, which sells midprice fare, competing with Gap and Old Navy; and Motherhood Maternity, which sells the least expensive brands.
Competitors, she said, come and go. The market is small; only about four million babies are born each year. Repeat shoppers are fickle. It is the inexperienced, and demanding, first-time mothers who tend to buy the most. "It's a very hard market to serve," she said. 
In mid-July, Mothers Work announced that although total net sales climbed in the quarter ended June 30, sales at stores open at least a year in the three chains' shops were down 2 percent from the year before. Michael Devine III, Mothers Work's chief financial officer, said sales were down most at A Pea in the Pod and Mimi Maternity, which he attributed to recession jitters. But it is these higher-priced stores, too, that are the targets of newer entrants. 
On the 27th floor of a downtown Los Angeles building, Laurie McCartney, chief executive of the online retailer eStyle, is cooing over a rack of clothes packed with some of the e-tailer's private-label offerings. "Look at these!" she said, holding a $138 pair of "pleather" pants (read: fake leather) in the air. She grabbed an eye-catching pair of flat-paneled gray pants, priced at $68 a pair, with enough stretch to accommodate a growing belly. Estyle even makes a versatile little black dress. The price? $78.
Estyle, through its Babystyle maternity collection, began selling maternity clothes online last year. Of course it helps that Cindy Crawford, the supermodel and fashion impresario, is not only a consultant for the collection but a pitchwoman, too. About half of all maternity sales come from its private-label offerings, Ms. McCartney said. (The company also offers a variety of styles from different clothing makers.) To broaden the private brands, the company plans to expand into select retail stores, too, she said. 
"As a new mom you feel bombarded," Ms. McCartney said. "From my standpoint it is great to have options. It's about feeling good about yourself. I mean, you can't take a break and let yourself go for a year. In places like New York and Boston you have to look presentable."
To help the company keep in touch with trends, a group of expectant mothers make the trek to the company's headquarters downtown each month to talk about maternity clothes. There they slip into private dressing rooms and are asked to try on skirts, pants, dresses and, yes, pleather. Then they discuss the clothes over lunch -- what they like (cotton and Lycra blends) and what they don't (scratchy seams that chafe the belly).
Such research is particularly essential with maternity clothes, analysts say, because a woman's body changes weekly. So, too, does the fit of the clothes. And that, Ms. Matthias said, is why she does not fear her online competitors. Women need to try on clothes to see how they will fit their particular shape. "The priority customer is a first-time mom," she said. "She doesn't know size. Women want to touch and feel."
But Ms. Matthias acknowledged that while more than two million women visit Mothers Work stores each year, the most marked growth the company has experienced recently is on the Internet. Web sales are up 50 percent from last year, she said. "We do a big business," she said. "I really believe e-commerce is all about brands."
That is exactly what mainstream retailers are betting on. The Gap, whose operating margins dropped 42 percent between 1998 and 2000, according to Sanford C. Bernstein, has no plans to sell Gap maternity clothes in stores yet. "Maternity is a unique business," said Cindy Capobianco, the vice president in charge of marketing the Gap brand. But the collection is growing. 
It includes not only long-time favorites, like paneled slim pants, but seasonal offerings as well. The company now sells 120 maternity pieces, up from 16 when the company introduced the line in May 2000. "It was our best opportunity to get it out quickly," she said. "We were concerned about accessibility."
But it also allows the company to test women's appetite for affordable maternity clothes without having to spend money to rebuild displays or take other favorite products off the shelves. Upscale and mainstream retailers have ventured into maternity clothing before, which concerns some analysts who question whether the recent trend is a passing fad.
"It is an efficient way for Gap to see how big the opportunity is without having to redo their stores," Ms. Liebmann said. With Gap, "you know what you are getting, making it easier to shop online."
Besides, she added, it is not as if shoppers are taking much of a fashion risk with a Gap T-shirt and pants. "If you said Versace maternity, you'd figure you want to go in and try it on," she said, laughing. "I mean, you may not be able to decide where the slit goes."

HEADLINE: Mexico Vows To Retaliate Against U.S. On Trucking 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
President Vicente Fox vowed today to bar American trucks from Mexico until Mexican truckers were allowed on American highways, raising the volume in a war of words between the two governments.
 Mr. Fox reacted strongly to a United States Senate vote on Wednesday to impose restrictions on Mexican trucks, which followed a House vote to bar Mexican trucking companies from seeking operating licenses in the United States. 
 "There currently aren't any American trucks in Mexico, and there won't be any unless we reach a mutual, equitable and well-thought-out agreement on the issue," Mr. Fox said during a news conference with Tony Blair, the visiting British prime minister. "If no agreement is reached, there won't be any Mexican trucks up there, because they don't want them, but there won't be any American trucks down here, either." 
Neither nation now uses its trucks to import and export goods more than a few miles past the border. Neither government wants that commerce to stop.
The narrow border zone is where the bulk of their $250 billion in annual trade is conducted. Long-haul trucks transfer their trailers to short-haul trucks, which ferry the goods across the border through the maze of customs officials and brokers.
Under the North American Free Trade Agreement, which took effect in 1994, Mexican long-haul trucks were supposed to be allowed into California, Texas, Arizona and New Mexico by the end of 1995, and then anywhere in the United States this year. President Bill Clinton blocked that provision from taking effect, largely at the behest of the Teamsters union.
President Bush promised to reverse the Clinton decision, and international long-haul trucking was to have begun.
That did not happen. Congress held hearings, focusing on the inspection records of the older, more decrepit short-haul trucks that shuttle back and forth at the border, rather than the more modern long-haul carriers used in Mexico. They raised the specter of unsafe trucks driven by poorly trained foreigners threatening American lives.
Despite a warning by the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, that a Congressional roadblock "violates the spirit of Nafta by holding Mexico to different standards than it holds Canada and the United States," the House and Senate passed separate restrictions.
But Mr. Bush has promised to veto them. 
If and when the trucking provisions take effect, it would be years before many Mexican trucks head north or American trucks head south, said Duane W. Acklie, chairman of the American Trucking Associations, which represents 3,000 trucking companies in the United States. Several other American and Mexican trucking executives concurred.
Their companies need bilingual drivers who can meet state and federal requirements on both sides of the border, they said. They will have to qualify in the Mexican and American states where they do business. They must pay federal, state and local taxes and fulfill insurance requirements. 
Mexican carriers would face federal safety and insurance audits, not to mention daunting competition from American companies for which every cost of doing business, except labor, is cheaper.
In time, Mr. Acklie said, American trucking companies may buy up Mexican carriers. Or they may begin exchanging drivers, rather than cargoes, at the border. But today, he said, few if any American or Mexican trucking companies could handle long-haul operations across the border.
Those practical concerns have been drowned out by a battle of politics and policy. And that battle could escalate.
The United States, by blocking Nafta's trucking provisions, has violated the accord, a five-member arbitration panel of two Americans, two Mexicans and a Briton unanimously ruled six months ago. Under Nafta's rules, Mexico could take retaliatory steps that would inflict far more economic pain than Mr. Fox's warning of today -- steps like blocking imports of American goods. 
But for now, that threat, like the argument over international trucking, is largely theoretical, though potentially dangerous down the road.

HEADLINE: Clinton Lays Out Future for Library, and Himself 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 2 

 BODY:
In a pep talk to a receptive hometown crowd, former President Bill Clinton said today that he would use his presidential library and policy center here to advance themes that were central to his presidency.
 Among them, he said, were spreading economic opportunity to the disadvantaged; improving schools, health care and the environment; fostering understanding of the world economy; and promoting peace and reconciliation across racial and religious lines. 
 Though Mr. Clinton, 54, did not say how he would translate those themes into specific projects, he made it clear that he intended to be an active former president, along the lines of former President Jimmy Carter. 
"I think I was given a phenomenal opportunity to serve as president," Mr. Clinton told about 1,000 well-wishers in the lobby of a science and technology museum here. "And I think that I should spend the rest of my life trying to give back out of a wealth of experience that no one could ever have unless they had been president. So I think I should try to focus on doing things that I can do just because of the life I had."
Mr. Clinton's appearance here served as a bookend to one of the most public weeks of his postpresidency. It began on Monday with something of a hero's welcome in Harlem, where the former president moved into his New York office. Characteristically, he chose not to arrive quietly, but with great fanfare and a full program of speeches.
While New York is his new home, because of the decision by his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, to run for the United States Senate there, Mr. Clinton's roots clearly remain in Arkansas. He decided during his presidency that he would have his library built here on the banks of the Arkansas River, making it the anchor of a continuing and largely successful redevelopment of the Little Rock riverfront.
Mr. Clinton said today that while some of his work would be conducted in New York and around the world, "the heartbeat will be here."
Mr. Clinton, who has been intimately involved in the planning for the library complex, has already approved plans by the New York architects James Polshek and Richard Olcott for a glass and steel structure that extends over the river. On Friday, he is to meet with the exhibit designer, Ralph Appelbaum, who worked on the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington among other projects, to review preliminary plans for displays. He is also expected to announce plans on Friday for a project on racial and religious reconciliation, which will be financed with a grant from SBC Communications.
It can be difficult, Mr. Clinton said today, to design an attractive presidential library because of the requirement that millions of documents be protected from natural light. He said that much of the archival material from his administration would be stored below ground. Exhibit space will be above ground and flooded with sunlight.
"I wanted to build a building that would last," Mr. Clinton said, "and that would be a great and lasting gift to the people of Arkansas who have been so good to me."
The library is intended to be the centerpiece of a 27-acre project that will include parkland, a policy center, a public policy school affiliated with the University of Arkansas and a restored pedestrian bridge between Little Rock and North Little Rock. A foundation hopes to raise $200 million to pay for construction and to establish an endowment for operating costs. Skip Rutherford, the president of the foundation's board, said fund-raising was going well, but he refused to discuss it in detail.
Groundbreaking has been delayed by lawsuits against the City of Little Rock. One suit challenged the city's use of revenue bonds to finance the $16.5 million purchase of land for the library. That claim was rejected by the Arkansas Supreme Court, but the plaintiff has since filed a second, slightly different suit. Another lawsuit objects to the city's use of its powers to condemn land for the project. The city won that case in the lower courts and is awaiting a decision on an appeal to the Arkansas Supreme Court.
"We're one Supreme Court decision away," Mr. Rutherford said.
Construction could begin as early as November and be completed in 2004, he said.
Mr. Clinton, who raised money aggressively for the project during and after his presidency, acknowledged today that it would be expensive. He was heavily criticized shortly after leaving office for granting a pardon to Marc Rich, whose former wife, Denise Rich, had contributed $450,000 for the library.
"You can't do this unless you're willing to spend some money," Mr. Clinton said. "But whatever it costs, when people are happy going into it 100 years from now, when our great-grandchildren are going in there and walking along the river and being a part of it and being proud of it, we will be very glad that we made this investment."

HEADLINE: Gephardt Launches an Attack on Bush's Foreign Policy 

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
Drawing clear battle lines with the White House on foreign policy, Representative Richard A. Gephardt accused the Bush administration today of an obsession with missile defense and of pursuing a unilateralist approach to world affairs that risks antagonizing Russia and undermining relations with Europe.
 Mr. Gephardt, the House minority leader, vowed to unite Democrats and persuade Republicans to forge a bipartisan majority in Congress to block any missile defense system that would violate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. He also defended formal arms control negotiations as essential to maintaining the nuclear peace. 
 On Russia, Mr. Gephardt sketched his version of a framework for new relations, one that would reject ultimatums on missile defenses and warhead reductions but never shy from complaining about Russian failures to protect press freedoms, ethnic relations and religious tolerance. Eventually, he said, the goal would be to "extend to Russia the prospect of NATO membership."
The Missouri Democrat, widely seen as an undeclared candidate for his party's presidential nomination in 2004, recently returned from a visit to Europe and Russia, and said NATO allies "are worried that America is on the sidelines."
"They think the Bush administration has embraced a go-it-alone policy that undermines international security, hurts our economic and environmental interests and prevents us from seizing a historic opportunity for engagement with Russia," he said.
When Mr. Gephardt's speech, given to the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace today, is added to recent statements from three Senate Democrats -- Carl Levin of Michigan, chairman of the Armed Services Committee; Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee; and Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader -- a consensus party agenda on international security comes sharply into focus.
While differences are inevitable, the Democrats generally unite in arguing that nuclear deterrence still works, even against Iraq and North Korea. They broadly agree that there is no need to rush deployment of missile defenses, although continued research and development, within treaty constraints, in pursuit of a limited system is a national interest.
The Democrats also hold that President Bush, by rejecting important treaties, is leading Americans into a new isolationism that will weaken their ability to pursue a broad range of global interests, and that the United States should return to negotiations on global warming and stick to peacekeeping commitments.
Mr. Gephardt focused his harshest criticism on the Bush administration's dealings with Moscow on arms control and missile defense.
Speaking of Russia, he said: "This is a country that is strapped financially in the most severe way. And they've got multiple thousands of warheads. How can they keep them in repair? How can they avoid accidents? Are we worried about their command and control, about something getting out of hand? So that to me is the major threat that we still face. And treating that in a sensible way is severely complicated by our obsession with going ahead with this missile defense plan, which we haven't proven can work, and we haven't developed, and that we certainly haven't worked out with the Europeans and the Russians."
The president's senior advisers say that the Bush administration will apply the standard of American national interest in determining whether to support or reject international accords. For example, in the case of the Kyoto Protocol on global warming, administration officials say, the pact would damage the American economy and harm global financial health.
And on relations with Russia, the administration has stated that the ABM treaty is outdated and stands in the way of moving rapidly toward both historic reductions in arsenals and building a defense against ballistic missiles launched by an enemy -- or accidentally by Russia.
Mr. Gephardt said the administration "has ratcheted up its unilateral rhetoric," which he said had led to "the largely symbolic, yet potentially destabilizing treaty between Russia and China, designed in part to counter U.S. global dominance." He was referring to a treaty of "friendship and cooperation" signed by the two countries last month. 
Mr. Gephardt said the president's policies had already resulted in Russian threats to place more nuclear warheads on its missiles and a Russian decision to block American efforts to strengthen international sanctions on Iraq.
"These examples, I think, demonstrate a simple yet profound fact of international relations," he said. "One nation, acting alone, cannot possibly build a lasting strategic framework to which all other nations submit."
After the speech, Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, tossed the unilateralist charge back at Mr. Gephardt, accusing him of working to shackle the president's authority to negotiate trade deals and saying that he and other Democrats were thwarting the tenets of the North American Free Trade Agreement by trying to keep Mexican truckers off American highways.
"Given his isolationist record on Mexico, on Nafta, on free trade, the president hopes that Mr. Gephardt will pursue a more internationalist course this fall on trade promotion authority," Mr. Fleischer said.
Mr. Gephardt had anticipated that charge in his speech, saying that in order to get a trade agreement through Congress, "it's got to have enforceable provisions on labor and environmental matters" and on human rights.

HEADLINE: Core's Split on Energy Is Costly to Democrats 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
President Bush won a lopsided victory on energy this week because the Republican package in the House split two of the Democrats' core constituencies: environmental groups and organized labor.
 In their votes on the energy plan late Wednesday and early today, many Democratic representatives, including Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, and David E. Bonior of Michigan, the minority whip, opposed big increases in automobile fuel efficiency. Moreover, three dozen Democrats, including at least five members of the Congressional Black Caucus, broke ranks to support drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge on the ground that it would create thousands of jobs. On both issues, Democrats provided the margin of victory. 
 The support came even though Democrats loudly opposed Mr. Bush's energy plan when it was unveiled in the spring. The party's House and Senate leadership vowed to promote conservation measures and oppose drilling in wilderness areas.
Many predicted that differing visions of environmental and energy policy would be a centerpiece of the 2002 Congressional campaigns.
Unions, however, including the United Auto Workers and the Teamsters, along with the powerful auto and energy industries, weighed heavily on some Democrats, overwhelming the influence of environmental groups that command less political loyalty and money. 
"I have no idea what they think they've accomplished," said Philip Clapp, president of the National Environmental Trust. "Democrats simply walked away from the public policy they endorsed all spring and handed the president a great victory."
Environmentalists and unions developed broad alliances on trade and globalization issues in recent years and were among Al Gore's most reliable supporters last year in the presidential campaign. But the jockeying in the final hours before the House vote exposed that bond as tactical and possibly temporary.
Influential unions abandoned environmental groups to support Republican leaders and industries on auto efficiency and drilling. The split assured that Democrats would lack unity on the issues as well.
"What environmentalists fail to realize is that we are not environmental organizations, we are labor organizations," said Jerry Hood, who headed the Teamsters' lobbying effort in favor of drilling in the wildlife refuge. "Our responsibility is to grow the work force." 
The Teamsters argued that opening the wilderness refuge to oil and gas exploration could create more than 700,000 jobs around the country, although environmentalists disputed those estimates as wildly inflated.
Mr. Hood said environmental groups had overplayed their hand by opposing numerous energy production measures rather than trying to ensure that oil exploration and production was environmentally sound.
"They could have helped write the rule book," he said, "but instead they just oppose everything."
The Senate, controlled by Democrats, is still expected to block drilling in the wildlife refuge and to push for stricter fuel efficiency standards than the ones approved by the House.
Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, has vowed to filibuster any bill that would open the wildlife refuge to drilling. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, has predicted that the Senate will reject drilling.
But the defeat for the environmentalists' two priorities in the House gives the White House unexpected momentum. The same unions that held sway over House Democrats have influence in the Senate, too, and the victory will give Republicans leverage when the two bodies reconcile House and Senate versions of the bill in committee.
"A lot of the pundits said we'll never get an energy bill out of the Congress," Vice President Dick Cheney said today, adding, "We had, I thought, a surprising strong vote over here last night."
Some of the 38 Democrats who supported the president against environmentalists on Arctic drilling and some of the 86 who supported his position on fuel efficiency appeared to do so sheepishly. Repeated phone calls to at least 20 Democrats who voted with the president were not returned today.
One decisive factor appeared to be support for drilling and opposition to substantially higher fuel efficiency standards among Democratic members of the Congressional Black Caucus. Representatives Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, Edolphus Towns of New York, Earl F. Hilliard of Alabama and James E. Clyburn of South Carolina were among Mr. Bush's supporters on both measures. Each refused to comment.
James Harris, an aide to Mr. Towns, said the congressman was persuaded by arguments -- made largely by the Teamsters' lobbyists -- that Arctic drilling would create jobs "for the native community in Alaska."
Environmentalists were also stung by the opposition of several senior Democrats. In addition to Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Bonior, Representatives James L. Oberstar of Minnesota, the ranking Democrat on the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure; Paul E. Kanjorski of Pennsylvania, the minority whip at large; and Martin Frost of Texas, chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, all voted in accordance with the president on at least one of the two major energy amendments.
Mr. Oberstar and Mr. Kanjorski, who voted to support Arctic drilling, did not return phone calls today. Environmentalists said their decision to vote in favor of drilling, along with the absences or abstentions of several other Democratic leaders, was crucial to the outcome. At 223 to 206, the vote to drill in the area would have gone the other way if nine Democrats had voted differently.
Environmentalists suffered an even bigger defeat on their push to raise fuel efficiency standards for automobiles, which have not been altered by Congress since 1975. Support for higher standards appeared to surge this spring as Democrats rallied to oppose Mr. Bush's energy plan, calling it skewed in favor of production measures over conservation. Many Democrats argued that higher fuel economy standards for cars could do more to help the nation meet its energy needs than the most optimistic estimates of what could be recovered from the Arctic refuge.
But that support evaporated in recent days. Auto makers and the powerful United Auto Workers union lobbied Democrats to oppose a bipartisan amendment. Environmentalists, who had once counted on the auto workers' remaining on the sidelines for the vote, said the union ended up lobbying aggressively after the Big Three car companies in Detroit threatened to cut jobs if they were forced to comply with tougher rules. 
"We had to fight the White House, the Republican leadership, the Teamsters union and, it turns out, the Democratic leadership" on the auto efficiency vote, said Dan Becker, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club. "It's surprising we did as well as we did."

HEADLINE: MEASURE DEFINING PATIENTS' RIGHTS PASSES IN HOUSE 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
The House of Representatives passed a bill tonight that would create federal rights for millions of Americans in managed health care plans, after revising the legislation to limit lawsuits against insurance companies.
 In approving the legislation by a vote of 226 to 203, the House handed an important political victory to President Bush, who had argued that earlier versions of the bill would encourage frivolous lawsuits. 
 Under the legislation, health insurance plans must provide patients prompt access to medical specialists, must allow women to visit obstetricians and gynecologists without a referral and must permit patients to obtain emergency care at the nearest hospital, even if it is not affiliated with a specific health plan.
The vote tonight followed a long, tumultuous debate in which Democrats denounced the legislation as a sham, providing less protection to patients than to health insurance companies. It was the third time in four years that the House had passed legislation to define patients' rights. Earlier bills died. Shortly after the vote the House recessed until Sept. 6. 
No Republicans voted against the bill tonight, and only five Democrats voted for it.
At the heart of the latest bill is a compromise negotiated by the White House and Representative Charlie Norwood, the leader of a six-year campaign for patients' rights, who unexpectedly made a deal with Mr. Bush this week. 
"This is a real victory for American patients," Mr. Norwood said. "We not only passed a bill tonight, we passed a bill that the president has agreed to sign into law."
Under the bill, patients could enforce their rights by suing H.M.O's in state court for medical decisions. But there would be limits on damages, including one of $1.5 million in punitive damages and another of $1.5 million for pain and suffering. Damages for economic losses if medical decisions were made improperly would be unlimited.
Mr. Bush welcomed the final vote, saying it "brings us an important step closer to ensuring that patients get the care they need and that H.M.O.'s are held accountable."
Mr. Bush had wanted to limit suits to federal court, where damages are often lower than in state court. Mr. Norwood had wanted higher ceilings on damages.
Before voting on final passage of the bill, the House approved the Bush-Norwood proposal as an amendment by a vote of 218 to 213. The tally seesawed, and the two sides were tied for a few suspenseful moments before the result was announced. 
This vote also generally followed party lines. Three Democrats joined 214 Republicans and 1 independent in supporting the Bush-Norwood plan. Six Republicans joined 206 Democrats and 1 independent in opposing it.
In today's debate, Democrats criticized the compromise, saying it would cripple the enforcement of patients' rights. But Republicans hailed the agreement as a victory for consumers and common sense over trial lawyers, and they said it would inoculate Republicans against political attacks on the issue.
Mr. Bush praised Mr. Norwood, a Georgia Republican, as "realistic and reasonable." But the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, and the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, were among the members of their party who said they had been betrayed by Mr. Norwood, their former ally. They denounced Mr. Norwood and the deal he struck with Mr. Bush to limit lawsuits against insurers and health maintenance organizations. 
Today's House vote sets the stage for negotiations with the Senate, which passed a similar bill in late June by a vote of 59 to 36. Patient protections in the two bills are nearly identical, but the means of enforcing those rights are different.
Under both bills, people with insurance are guaranteed access to clinical trials of new drugs and an independent medical review of decisions denying claims for health benefits. The Senate bill gives patients a much more extensive right to sue health plans for injuries caused by the denial of care. The only limits on suits in the Senate bill are those provided under current state laws.
Mr. Bush threatened to veto the Senate measure, saying it would permit a flood of lawsuits that would drive up insurance costs and increase the number of people without coverage.
Negotiations between the House and the Senate will probably be difficult.
"We are not going to give up or give in," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Senate Democrats want higher limits on damages than the House bill provides.
Democrats, believing that voters tend to trust them on health care issues, say they can hold out for concessions. Republicans may feel more pressure to make such concessions as the campaign season heats up next year. But Democrats also run a risk. Republicans could portray them as obstructing progress on the issue if the conference committee reaches an impasse, as similar negotiations did last year.
Negotiators from the House and Senate will come under immense pressure from consumer advocates, doctors, insurers and employers lobbying for or against the bill or some of its specific provisions. 
The Bush-Norwood compromise is embodied in an amendment to the original patients' bill of rights. Critics said the compromise would override many state laws and state court decisions that provided greater protection to patients.
Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, the chief Democratic sponsor of Mr. Norwood's original bill, said: "The president and Mr. Norwood propose creating a new federal law that applies to state courts just for H.M.O.'s. Under this proposal, H.M.O.'s retain a very special status and cannot be held accountable for their negligent and harmful actions in the same way your doctor or hospital is."
Representative Greg Ganske, the Iowa Republican who was chief House sponsor of the Norwood bill this year, said: "Charlie was freelancing. He did not have our authorization. This was Charlie's own deal with the White House."
Mr. Norwood said it was ridiculous for people to suggest that his bill had been written by insurance companies. "The insurance industry can't stand me," he said. "They have had me on their dartboard for years."
Under the compromise, patients could sue health insurance plans in state court for injuries caused by the denial of care. But most aspects of the litigation would be controlled by federal law and the amount of damages would be limited by federal law.
Mr. Dingell said this arrangement "wipes out state laws like those already in effect in California, Texas and New Jersey."
The American Medical Association, a strong supporter of the original patients' bill of rights, said the compromise would override the laws of 10 states that allow injured patients to hold H.M.O.'s accountable in state court. The states are Arizona, California, Georgia, Louisiana, Maine, New Jersey, Oklahoma, Texas, Washington and West Virginia.
Representative Marge Roukema, a New Jersey Republican who supported Mr. Norwood's original bill, arrived at the Capitol today with an open mind, saying she wanted to evaluate the compromise he had negotiated with the White House. Several hours later, she decided to vote against the compromise.
"This is absolutely an atrocity for New Jersey," Mrs. Roukema said of Mr. Norwood's latest proposal on H.M.O. liability. "It would deprive New Jersey patients and doctors of protections that have existed for several years and were just strengthened in the last few weeks."
Mr. Norwood said, "I am not completely satisfied with the provision in our bill that protects state law." He promised that in negotiations with the Senate, he would try to clarify that provision of his bill, which is meant to protect state laws regulating the quality of medical care.
In recent years, some courts have allowed patients to sue H.M.O.'s, but John E. Stone, a spokesman for Mr. Norwood, said the outcome of such lawsuits was always in doubt.
"You may win, you may not," Mr. Stone said, depending on the judge and the legal theories used by the plaintiffs' lawyers.
Texas Democrats like Representatives Lloyd Doggett and Jim Turner were particularly annoyed at the compromise.
"Mr. Bush now seeks to override the effective state guarantees that we got enacted over his objections in Texas," Mr. Doggett said.
Democrats complained that the Norwood proposal would give H.M.O.'s an unfair advantage in court. It would, they said, establish a legal presumption in favor of H.M.O.'s when they prevail in administrative appeals to independent medical experts but it would not give consumers the same presumption if they prevailed.
Mr. Gephardt captured the flavor of all the Democratic criticism, saying: "This bill is better for H.M.O.'s than for patients. It ought to be called the H.M.O. bill of rights. For the first time in the history of this country, we will have a federal tort law that applies to malpractice and injuries caused by H.M.O.'s and insurance companies." 
In many cases, Mr. Gephardt said, the new limits on damages -- $1.5 million for pain and suffering, $1.5 million for punitive damages -- "will be less than what you would get if you were under state law."
Before adopting the Norwood compromise, the House approved an amendment intended to help people obtain health insurance. The proposal approved by a vote of 236 to 194 would expand access to tax-free savings accounts used to pay medical expenses and would make it easier for small employers to band together and buy health insurance.
Republicans said Mr. Bush had gone a long way toward protecting Republican candidates against political attacks on the issue of patients' rights. Democrats agreed, with Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts saying that "Mr. Bush has substantially reduced the risk" to himself and other Republicans.
Business groups and insurers criticized the deal. They said it was better than the original Norwood bill, but would still allow far too many lawsuits against health plans and employers that provide health benefits to their employees.
Representative John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, said, "The president deserves a lot of credit for ending partisan gridlock on this issue." Despite all the Democratic criticism, Mr. Boehner said, the bill "goes far beyond what we have in law today."
The White House took pains to emphasize that Mr. Bush had been actively engaged in the fight for patients' rights legislation. 
Still, Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, said: "This is not a compromise. It's a victory for those who oppose a patients' bill of rights. We provide protections, but there's no enforcement, so H.M.O.'s can continue to deny reimbursement without any fear of repercussions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representatives Greg Ganske of Iowa, a Republican, and Marion Berry of Arkansas and John D. Dingell of Michigan, Democrats, stuck with their patients' rights bill yesterday, opposing a compromise amendment. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. A18) Chart: "COMPARE AND CONTRAST -- 2 Versions of Patients' Rights"The House and Senate versions of the patients' bill of rights are almost identical in the protection they offer people with insurance. DENIAL OF CARE -- Patients can appeal the denial of care by seeking an independent medical review. Ob-Gyn -- Women can visit obstetricians and gynecologists without a referral or prior authorization. Emergency care -- Patients can get emergency care at the nearest hospital regardless of whether it is affiliated with their health plans. Specialists -- Health plans must provide prompt access to medical specialists. Drugs -- Doctors can prescribe any medically necessary drugs regardless of whether drugs are on the insurer's list of preferred medications. Clinical trials -- Health plans must provide access to clinical trials of experimental therapies if no standard treatment is effective. The bills differ in the way patients would be allowed to enforce their rights. Under the House bill:Injured patients could sue H.M.O.'s in state court for medical decisions. The bill allows unlimited damages for economic losses, but it sets a limit of $1.5 million on damages for pain and suffering and a separate $1.5 million limit on punitive damages. Under the Senate bill:Patients could sue insurers in state court for medical decisions or in federal court for administrative decisions. In federal court, there would be no limits on damages for economic loss or pain and suffering. Patients could win up to $5 million in civil penalties resembling punitive damages. In state court, damages would be subject to the limits of state law, if any such limits exist.(pg. A18) Chart: "Coming to Terms on Differing Bills"After the monthlong Congressional recess in August, House and Senate leaders will pick lawmakers to meet in conference to work out differences between the two versions of the patients' bill of rights legislation. Republicans have criticized the Senate bill, saying it would allow a flood of litigation that would ultimately drive up the price of health insurance to the point that many people could not afford it. Democrats have said the House bill protects insurance companies, not patients. Polls show that many voters are more likely to trust Democrats on the issue, a finding that Democrats say makes them want to push hard for concessions. The risk for each party in not moving toward compromise is that the voters could view it as obstructionist. Similar legislation passed both houses in the last Congress, but died in the conference committee. In that case, Republican leaders in the Senate passed a more restrictive bill, and the House version offered patients a broader set of rights. House Republican leaders picked representatives for the conference committee who had voted against the bill, an unusual tactic that set off an uproar among supporters. This year, such a step is unlikely. The conference discussions are still likely to be tense, but there is a possibility that most House and Senate conferees, voting separately, can agree on one bill. (pg. A18)
