SECTION: Section C; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 560 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Senate Committee Rejects Consumer Panel Nominee
The Senate Commerce Committee voted along party lines to reject President Bush's choice to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, handing him his first nomination loss.
 By a 12 to 11 vote, Democrats rebuffed the nomination of Mary Sheila Gall, saying her record as a current member of the commission showed an alarming disregard for children's safety and warning that her elevation to chairwoman would benefit manufacturers, not consumers. Page A1. 

House Passes Patients' Rights Bill
The bill would create new federal rights for millions of Americans in managed health care plans and was revised to limit lawsuits against insurance companies. A1.

Microsoft Suffers Legal Setback
A federal appeals court refused to reconsider its finding that Microsoft illegally blended Internet browsing software with its monopoly product, the Windows operating system. The move could open the way for courts to second-guess Microsoft's product designs. C4.

Companies Sharing Liability Risks
A wave of shareholder lawsuits is prompting liability insurers to make corporate clients share more of the cost of settlements or awards in cases where corporate executives and board members are accused of not acting in the interest of shareholders -- by, for example, hiding losses or turning a blind eye to overstated revenue. Now, some companies will have to pick up more of the tab -- at least 15 percent and probably closer to 25 percent of any amount paid, insurers say. C3.

Intel Spurs Rally in Tech Stocks
Stocks rose after Intel signaled the beleaguered personal computer industry may turn the corner. The Nasdaq composite index rose 19 points, or 0.9 percent, to 2,087.38. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 41.17 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,551.18. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended up 4.82 points, or 0.4 percent, at 1,220.75. C5.

Factory Orders Fell 2.4% in June
Factory orders fell 2.4 percent in June, a steeper drop than expected, led by declines in demand for computers and transportation equipment, a government report showed. The decline came after a 2.2 percent increase in May, the Commerce Department said. A separate report showed that the number of workers filing new claims for unemployment benefits declined last week to the lowest level in almost five and a half months, a sign that the worst of the job reductions may be over. C5.

Disney Results Beat Expectations
Walt Disney announced quarterly financial results that modestly exceeded analysts' expectations, helped in part by cost-cutting, including plans to eliminate 4,000 jobs. C4.

CNBC to Stay Put in Cable Lineup
After deciding to move the financial news network CNBC to a less desirable cable channel in New York City, AOL Time Warner reversed itself under pressure from NBC. CNBC, on Channel 15, was to have swapped spots with Bravo on Channel 64. B6.

Banks Avoiding Overhaul in Japan
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan has promised to take on the special interests that have long supported his ruling Liberal Democratic Party and in turn won privileges, protection and subsidies that have bloated the national budget and stalled the economy. But one seems to have slipped out of his cross hairs: Japan's troubled banks and the bad debts that have plagued them for a decade. News Analysis. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: A Difference A Day Made 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 

 BODY:
Just when Congressional Republicans had seemed in dangerous disarray, President Bush in a gratifying 24 hours won House passage of his comprehensive energy plan and eked out a victory on a patients' bill of rights.
 Mr. Bush's back-to-back successes changed the mood in the capital overnight, giving ebullient Republicans a set of issues to carry to the public over the August recess. At a rally on the East Front of the Capitol, party leaders took turns proclaiming that the president had made good on his signature campaign pledge to provide a new kind of leadership. 
 Vice President Dick Cheney spoke of "one of the most remarkable six months, I think, in any administration." And Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader, said, "This is a president that has changed the tone in Washington." 
Still, the change in tone has come about only in the Republican-run House, where Mr. Bush proved able to negotiate within his own party. And even there, his win on a patients-rights bill was perilously narrow.
He has yet to master relations with the Democratic-run Senate. There, a committee voted today to reject a Bush nominee for the chairmanship of the Consumer Product Safety Commission. And on Wednesday, the full Senate defied Mr. Bush's veto threat and voted to require Mexican trucks to meet strict safety standards on American highways.
In fact, what was most evident today was that the two parties are developing distinct agendas. The Republicans waved tax-refund checks in the air at their rally to showcase the $1.36 trillion tax cut that Mr. Bush pushed though Congress in the spring. Under the rubric "securing America's future," they also emphasized the president's energy plan, his education initiative and the Republican version of a patients' rights bill.
An hour later, House Democrats, on the West Front of the Capitol, focused on a different set of issues that they said were languishing in a "G.O.P. junk yard," among them the overhaul of the campaign finance law, "quality education," a more robust patients' rights bill, prescription drug benefits and fiscal discipline.
This could all lead in the autumn to a season of grand compromises should both parties decide that they need legislative achievements to bring to the voters in 2002. President Bill Clinton and the Congressional Republicans had just such periods of shared accomplishment for parts of 1996 and 1997 when they judged it to be in their mutual interest.
But it could just as easily lead to another period of gridlock judging by the sharp partisan divide that the House showed on the patients' rights bill tonight. In that case, each party would try to brand the other as the obstructionist as Republicans and Democrats take their competing agendas to the voters next year.
Already, the parties are starting to lay blame. Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, slammed the "purely partisan nature" of the Senate committee vote against Mr. Bush's nominee to head the safety commission. And of patients' rights Mr. Fleischer said, "At the end of the day there will be a bipartisan majority and there will be a more partisan minority."
The Democrats in turn accused House Republicans of scuttling popular measures sent forward by the Senate.
"Since Democrats took control of the Senate a few months ago," said Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Texas, "the mantle of partisan obstructionism has passed largely into the hands of Republican leaders in the House of Representatives."
Adding to the possibility of gridlock is that government analysts are expected to release new projections this month showing that the federal surplus will be far less than previously projected because of the sagging economy and the Bush tax cut.
That means there will no longer be a windfall of cash to help the parties avoid hard choices as the new fiscal year approaches. Instead, lawmakers will have to put much of their energy into finding a way to pass the annual spending bills and still finance the president's call for a national missile defense system, a more robust Pentagon budget as well as expanding education aid to levels Democrats want.
"It's going to be hard to accommodate all of these promises," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
Still, no matter how touch-and-go it was at times, for Republicans today was a day to be savored. A month ago, the president appeared on the defensive. Winning House support for drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge seemed a lost cause, and few could see how the Republicans could beat back the Senate's version of the patients' rights bill.
But on the energy issue, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, was particularly instrumental. He sought allies wherever they existed, even meeting quietly with the Teamsters president, James P. Hoffa.
And Mr. DeLay exploited the differences between the Democrats' core constituencies of labor and environmentalists. Crossover Democrats gave him the votes he needed to secure the drilling plan even as moderate Republicans defected.
Republicans credit Mr. Bush personally with defeating the Democrats' version of a patients' rights bill after early months when he seemed off balance on the debate, surprised by how entrenched all sides were on an issue fought over for six years. 
He threatened to veto the version of the bill approved by the Senate even though it is popular and he had campaigned in favor of a national bill of rights. The stand put him in some personal political peril. But it also gave him an argument to use with wavering Republicans who had supported the Democrats' version of the measure in the past. If they voted for the Democrats' bill, he said, they would never see it become law.
Republicans said that Mr. Bush lobbied with an intensity he had not shown on any other issue -- even his tax cut -- and that as the stakes rose for him, so did his mastery of the issue. Representative Peter T. King, a New York Republican who had voted with the Democrats in the past, had two meetings with Mr. Bush at the White House.
"I felt, at the first meeting in the Cabinet room, he did not make that good a case," Mr. King recalled. "I almost got the impression he was going through the motions. The second meeting in the Oval Office it almost reminded me what I'd heard of Lyndon Johnson. He totally dominated the meeting."
Then Mr. Bush entered negotiations with Representative Charlie Norwood, a Georgia Republican and a leader of the bipartisan coalition supporting the bill Mr. Bush opposed.
The very fact that Mr. Bush was negotiating helped him within his party. As Mr. Norwood's coalition rejected White House ideas, more Republicans came back into their party's fold, suspicious that the Democrats simply wanted the president to capitulate.
Finally Mr. Norwood, too, came back into the fold, striking a compromise with Mr. Bush that he did not run by his co-sponsors and breaking their coalition. 
The issue now goes to a House-Senate conference committee to become Exhibit No. 1 in the tug of war over whether the parties will compromise or take an issue to the polls. Democrats who have long been the driving force behind the movement to regulate H.M.O.'s believe they have the public well on their side, giving them confidence that they can hold out for further change.
Today they asserted that the compromise would in some cases override state laws that give patients a broader right to sue H.M.O.'s. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said, "We are not going to give up or give in."

HEADLINE: To Butt In or Not In Human Rights: The Gap Narrows 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Given all the interest these days in the founding fathers, especially John Adams, it shouldn't be surprising that some writers are citing different Adamses as they wage one of the longest-running debates in American history. What are the respective roles of human rights and the national interest, or morality versus power, in formulating foreign policy?
 In one recent book, "In Our Own Best Interest" by William F. Schulz, the executive director of Amnesty International USA, the Revolutionary leader Samuel Adams is cited to support the argument that human rights should be the essential ingredient of the American national philosophy. "We may look up to armies for our defense, but virtue is our best security," Adams wrote. "It is not possible that any State should long remain free, where virtue is not supremely honored." 
 In contrast, another recent book, "Does America Need a Foreign Policy?" by Henry A. Kissinger, cites a later Adams, John Quincy, who, as secretary of state, asserted that the United States "goes not abroad in search of monsters to destroy." Writing in 1821 in response to calls to help Greece in its war of independence against the Ottoman Turks, he elaborated on the reasons for this caution: the country "well knows that by once enlisting under other banners than her own . . . she would involve herself beyond the power of extrication in all the wars of interest and intrigue, of individual avarice, envy and ambition, which assume the colors and usurp the standards of freedom." 
Much has been written in recent years about human rights and foreign policy, but the books by Mr. Schulz and Mr. Kissinger -- one a professional human rights advocate, the other the world's most famous foreign policy "realist" -- set out each side of the debate in its most modern guise. Mr. Kissinger's is the broader book, a series of recommendations on many foreign policy questions, including some related to human rights, especially the effort to create an International Court of Justice to deal with human rights crimes. Mr. Schulz's only concerns are human rights and a foreign policy that gives it priority. Together the two books demonstrate the many differences between the two sides in this debate, but they also disclose at least a small degree of convergence as well, one that has been reflected in other writings.
"I would argue that you can pay attention to real concerns and still see human rights as an important part of foreign policy," Joseph Nye, the dean of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, said in a telephone interview. "But while human rights is part of foreign policy, it isn't foreign policy in itself, because a foreign policy is an effort to accomplish several objectives: security, economic benefit as well as humanitarian benefits.
"In the past, the realistic tradition excluded human rights as idealism. But realists thinking only of power and idealists thinking only of morality create a false dichotomy. The question is not an either/or one; it is one of implementation; how do you do it?"
In fact, ever since President Jimmy Carter re-established human rights as a priority in American foreign policy, it has been a part of every administration's foreign policy arsenal. Even Ronald Reagan, deemed generally a realist in foreign policy, often resorted to the language of human rights -- the concept of democracy versus tyranny -- in waging the cold war. Recent American military interventions, from Somalia to Haiti to Kosovo, have been undertaken primarily for humanitarian reasons, to stop or to try to avert atrocities, and President Bill Clinton apologized for not taking action to stop the slaughter in Rwanda.
Meanwhile, actions in the name of human rights have become regular occurrences. President Bush recently appealed to China to stop the prosecutions of Chinese-Americans on what appear to many in the United States to be spurious charges of espionage. A Spanish judge got the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet detained in England for 18 months in what turned out to be an unsuccessful effort to put him on trial for atrocities committed in Chile during his reign.
Meanwhile, one of the world's most infamous human rights violators, former President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, was given over to The Hague to be put on trial. And on Thursday, a former Bosnian Serb general, Radislav Krstic, was convicted of genocide by the United Nations war crimes tribunal and sentenced to 46 years in prison.
Human rights, in other words, is on the agenda, and neither realists nor idealists would remove it.
Mr. Schulz accuses American policy makers of being myopic, for example, in providing arms and training to governments in South America and elsewhere that have been guilty of human rights atrocities. But the main point of his argument is that paying attention to humanitarian considerations is consistent with rigorous concepts of the national interest. In his view, they advance it.
" 'Realists,' " Mr. Schulz argues in his new book, "regard the pursuit of rights as an unnecessary, sometimes even a dangerous extravagance, often at odds with our national interest. What they seem rarely to garner is that in far more cases than they will allow, defending human rights is a prerequisite to protecting that interest." 
Mr. Kissinger, though probably the kind of realist that Mr. Schulz has in mind, does not seem to fit that description, since, in his new book, he allows that human rights is a legitimate goal of foreign policy. "The growing concern with human rights is one of the achievements of our age and is certainly a testament to progress toward a more humane international order," Mr. Kissinger writes.
But Mr. Kissinger, distinguishing himself from those he unfavorably views as moralists, also writes that "humane convictions" have become "so integral a part of the American tradition that both treasure and, in the extreme, lives must be risked to vindicate them anywhere in the world." And this, Mr. Kissinger says, is going too far.
As the contrast between each writer's favorite Adams shows, both are well within a long American tradition. For most of its history, the United States played the international game in accordance with principles laid down by the coolly calculating Alexander Hamilton, whose policy was to encourage a balance of power in Europe so as to keep the countries there too preoccupied to become involved in the affairs of the American continent.
This changed with American entry into World War I, when President Woodrow Wilson asserted what he saw as new and better principles: not merely maintaining a balance of power but also creating a cooperative world order based on the universal applicability of democratic institutions.
In his book, Mr. Schulz, who would seem very much to be in the Wilsonian tradition, lists the many ways he says the national interest would be served by paying greater attention to human rights. His main reason is very similar to one of Wilson's: namely that democracies almost never wage war against each other, and if avoiding war is a primary goal of diplomacy, then, he argues, a foreign policy divorced from human rights is less likely to succeed.
"The conclusion is inescapable," Mr. Schulz writes, "that the more respect for human rights we can help engender in a country, the less likely that country is to go to war with us or other like communities." 
Mr. Kissinger, squarely in the Hamiltonian tradition, argues that the modern-day impulse toward humanitarian intervention is in some ways a return to an old pattern of behavior that preceded the Treaty of Westphalia in 1648, after which noninterference in the internal affairs of other countries came to be the first principle of foreign affairs. In what Mr. Kissinger treats as a revolutionary change, this principle has been replaced by another: "The proposition that certain universal principles are deemed enforceable, either by the United Nations or, in extreme situations, by a group of states (for example, NATO in Kosovo)."
The effort of a Spanish judge two years ago to have Mr. Pinochet extradited to Spain for his crimes in Chile, even though Chile's parliament had decided not to prosecute Mr. Pinochet, is a striking example of what Mr. Kissinger calls the international enforcement of "universal principles." That was an effort that pleases Mr. Schulz and that distresses Mr. Kissinger.
Indeed, Mr. Schulz says, "If you commit a crime, you should do the time," meaning that the international community should set up more tribunals like the ones created to deal with war crimes in the former Yugoslavia, so that the worst human rights violators can be held accountable for their acts. He adds, "It is breathtaking to think that it is in the national interest of the United States to isolate itself from an unprecedented global attempt to hold human rights criminals accountable for their crimes." 
Mr. Kissinger finds it "breathtaking" as well, but for a different reason. He is in favor of holding war criminals accountable, but he says the courts that try them must serve clearly stated, limited purposes. For Mr. Kissinger, the Pinochet case was a warning signal of the dangers that could emerge as the concept of universal jurisdiction gains strength. It could mean essentially that any judge in any country could indict any person for any crime, ignoring the mechanisms for justice or for reconciliation established in the country where the crimes were committed. Indeed, one of the objections that has been raised about the treaty that would set up the International Criminal Court is that Mr. Kissinger could be indicted for the role he played as a member of the Nixon administration both in the 1968 bombing of Cambodia and in the overthrow of the Chilean government that brought Mr. Pinochet to power.
"Should any outside group dissatisfied with the reconciliation procedures of, say, South Africa be free to challenge them in their own national courts or those of third countries?" Mr. Kissinger asks rhetorically. "Any universal system," he writes, "should contain procedures not only to punish the wicked but to constrain the righteous."
Yet in the end, the difference is, as Mr. Nye put it, not between two mutually exclusive goals but between two visions of attaining the same goal: more justice in a better world.

HEADLINE: Index of the Service Sector Shows a Slumpin July 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
A gauge of service activity slumped in July, pressed by declines in new orders and prices and weakness in employment.
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its monthly nonmanufacturing index fell to 48.9 in July from 52.1 in June. Any reading below 50 suggests activity shrank in the services sector, which includes everything from transportation to legal and financial services. The nonmanufacturing index also fell below 50 in May and April. 
 Economists caution that the four-year-old index has yet to prove itself as a reliable economic indicator. 
 Jim O'Sullivan, an economist at UBS Warburg, said, "When you go through the numbers, it's hard to say we're getting any clear pickup yet." The economy still looks fairly weak, he said, and everything is on track for the Federal Reserve to ease again in August.
 But Mr. O'Sullivan said the economy "is not getting worse than what it was, and it will get better over the second half of the year."
 Economists expect that the Fed's rate cuts so far this year, $38 billion in tax rebates landing in mailboxes nationwide, and a sharp drop in energy prices will help revive growth later in the year.
 The Fed has cut short-term interest rates six times this year in a bid to bolster growth, and it is widely expected to trim rates another quarter percentage point at its next policy meeting on Aug. 21.
 The survey's employment index rose slightly, to 46.4 in July from 45.1 a month earlier, but it indicated that the services sector has shed jobs for five consecutive months.
 The nonmanufacturing new-orders index, seen as a leading indicator of future activity, tumbled to 48.6 in July from 53.1, erasing June's gains. In another sign that demand has fallen off sharply, the backlog-of-orders index fell to its lowest level in five months, to 42.5 from 49.0.
 Prices paid by companies fell for the first time since February 1999 as the slowdown eroded pricing power, with the prices index falling to 49.0 in July from 55.5 in June.

HEADLINE: Back in Hong Kong, Accused Spy Himself Is Being Spied On 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
Security guards stand watch at either end of the long corridor outside Li Shaomin's cramped office here. When visitors drop by, the guards, who wear university badges, track their comings and goings on cellular phones.
 They are there to shield Mr. Li from the sudden notoriety that comes from being a convicted spy who was deported to the United States by Beijing and has returned here to reclaim his teaching job. 
 But they could just as well be watching Mr. Li, a Chinese-born American scholar who was told today that he could keep his position at City University, where he is a marketing professor.
For Mr. Li, 45, the decision puts an end to a painful, frightening chapter in his career. After being convicted of spying for Taiwan, however, he is likely to face continued scrutiny by his employer and his adopted city.
"I never wanted to become famous for something like this," Mr. Li said in a surprisingly relaxed interview as he waited for the decision of the university's executive council.
It is not clear that he can even continue his work. When Mr. Li was detained by the Chinese police on Feb. 25, he had been trying to visit Shenzhen, which borders Hong Kong, to research several companies as examples of economic development.
Now Mr. Li's ties to those companies are severed. And though his office, in a suburban part of Kowloon, is only a few miles from the border, he may never be allowed to set foot in the land of his birth.
"They told me, 'You hate the Chinese government,' " Mr. Li said of the officials who interrogated him four hours a day during his five-month detention. "But I love my native country. It was because of my concern for China's future that I got involved in activities that got me into trouble."
Mr. Li denies he spied for Taiwan. He believes the charges stem from the fact that his research in the late 1980's and early 1990's was financed by foundations on the island. Mr. Li has written about many aspects of Taiwan-China relations, ranging from economic ties to the growing number of cross-strait marriages. One of his articles is titled "What China Can Learn From Taiwan."
As part of this research, Mr. Li said, he asked another China-born scholar, Gao Zhan, to collect articles for him on a trip to China in the early 1990's. Ms. Gao, a sociologist at American University in Washington, was detained in Beijing on Feb. 11 and accused of passing documents to Mr. Li. She was also tried, convicted and deported. 
Mr. Li said he did not even use the documents in his research, and lost them in moving from the United States to Hong Kong in 1996. "To be honest with you, I don't even remember what they are," he said. "They were so insignificant."
Mr. Li said his research did not involve state secrets. Given China's elastic definition of secret, however, he said it was possible he had used restricted material. "As a scholar, you try to get as much information as you can, regardless of the sources," he said.
Looking back, Mr. Li believes his troubles had less to do with documents than with his politics: as a doctoral student at Princeton, he became involved in the democracy movement that sprang up after the dismissal of Hu Yaobang as Communist Party chief in 1987, and signed an open letter criticizing Beijing.
Mr. Li said he still dreamed of teaching in Beijing. And, as he said he told his interrogators, his criticism of China's government does not make him a spy.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Dow and Nasdaq Both Fall Amid Conflicting Reports

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks declined yesterday after a government report showed that employment in July was not quite as weak as many on Wall Street had forecast.
 A slowdown in the number of job losses, to 42,000, and the unchanged unemployment rate of 4.5 percent indicated that economic deterioration might be turning into stagnation. 
 But the report led some investors to think that this, in turn, might discourage the Federal Reserve from continuing its aggressive campaign of cutting interest rates in an effort to avoid a recession. Moreover, the continued economic weakness offered no promise for a rebound in corporate profits any time soon. 
"The employment report creates confusion," James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, said. "It wasn't good enough to say there's going to be an imminent turnaround. On the other hand, it wasn't so terrible that you could say at least the Fed is going to ease."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 38.40 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 10,512.78. For the week, however, it was up 0.9 percent.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index dropped 21.05 points, or 1 percent, to 2,066.33, but it rose 1.8 percent for the week.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 6.40 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,214.35. It was up 0.7 percent for the week.
Based on yesterday's employment figures, there was a growing consensus among analysts that the Fed's policy makers were unlikely to cut interest rates more than a quarter of a percentage point when they meet on Aug. 21 and that this might be the last rate cut for a while. That belief weighed on bond prices, although they cut their losses from an early sell-off.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note was unchanged at 98 27/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was also unchanged at 5.16 percent. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1/32, to 97 1/32. Its yield was unchanged at 5.58 percent. 
A further sign emerged that corporate profits might not improve any time soon. Thomson Financial/First Call, a research firm, said analysts were now expecting earnings to be flat in the fourth quarter instead of turning around. In July, earnings had been expected to grow 5.5 percent in the quarter.
Still, some investors seemed to be largely engaged in taking any recent profits from the stock market, analysts said. "Chips are giving back their gains, and we have the Friday factor at work, which means reasonably light volume," said Alan Ackerman, chief market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. "We have a market that's still within a tight trading range and no indication that it's likely to break out of that range in the immediate term."
Semiconductor stocks -- which jumped after Merrill Lynch upgraded the sector earlier this week and Intel said the worst was behind it -- were among the day's notable losers.
Intel fell 41 cents, to $31.68; Xilinx lost $1.89, to $41.45; Advanced Micro Devices dropped 51 cents, to $19.25, and Altera lost $1.36, to $31.24. 
Noven Pharmaceuticals, a maker of drug delivery products, tumbled $14.34, to $18.98, after warning that its earnings this year would fall short of expectations because of a drop in orders. 
Cisco Systems fell 20 cents, to $20.05, as investors awaited its earnings report on Tuesday. 
Among the stocks weighing on the Dow were American Express, which dropped 97 cents, to $40.45; Procter & Gamble, which fell $1.24, to $70.22, and Philip Morris, which fell 67 cents, to $45.17.
Sensormatic Electronics, which makes anti-theft equipment, soared $8.18, to $23.12, after Tyco said it would spend $2.3 billion to acquire it. Tyco fell 51 cents, to $53.29. 
Walt Disney rose 10 cents, to $26.60, after it reported quarterly earnings that were at the high end of Wall Street's expectations. 
Lucent Technologies gained 29 cents, to $6.60, after it said Thursday that it had raised nearly $2 billion in a sale of convertible stock that would be used to pay down its debts and for revamping purposes.
Despite yesterday's somewhat disappointing economic data -- the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its nonmanufacturing index fell to 48.9 in July from 52.1 in June -- investors appear to be having more muted reactions to such news.
"Industries and companies are starting to talk about having the worst behind them in their business; and maybe the pickup in orders isn't quite there yet, but there's a growing chorus of, 'Yeah, we think the worst is behind us,' " said Joseph Battipaglia, the chairman of investment policy at Gruntal & Company.
"The statistics that bear out the weakness don't have the same impact that they did 12 months ago," he added.

HEADLINE: Treasury Nominees Confirmed After Trade Protest by Helms 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
The Senate confirmed eight nominees to top Treasury Department posts today, including Kenneth W. Dam as deputy Treasury secretary, after the Bush administration agreed to address an unrelated issue raised by a Republican senator who had blocked action on the appointments.
 The Senate approved the nominations without a roll-call vote after the administration agreed to work out a compromise with Senator Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina on a trade dispute involving textile imports. 
 Senator Helms had held up a vote on the nominees for months, leaving Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill without a deputy and slowing work throughout the department. 
Mr. Dam, deputy secretary of state in the Reagan administration, had most recently been a law professor at the University of Chicago and was a director of Alcoa, where Mr. O'Neill was chairman before retiring at the end of last year. 
The other nominees approved today were Peter Fisher as under secretary for domestic finance; Jimmy Gurule as under secretary for enforcement; Michele Davis as assistant secretary for public affairs; Rosario Marin as United States Treasurer; Henrietta Holsman Fore as director of the Mint; Carole L. Brookins as United States executive director of the World Bank; and Randal K. Quarles as United States executive director of the International Monetary Fund.
Senator Helms has been trying to make sure that provisions of a trade law passed last year opening the United States textile market to Caribbean nations would not harm textile producers in North Carolina.
He has been pressing the Customs Service, which is drawing up regulations defining the types of fabric covered by the trade law, to enforce the law in a way favorable to domestic producers. 
In a letter to Senator Helms today, Mr. O'Neill pledged that the administration would not issue final regulations covering the definition but would work with the senator to come up with compromise legislation.
In a statement, Senator Helms said 40,000 jobs in North Carolina and 120,000 jobs nationwide could rest on the definition.

HEADLINE: Jobs Data for July Hint That the Economy May Be Stabilizing 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
American companies continued to eliminate jobs by the thousands last month, but the economy also showed some tentative signs of stabilizing, the government said yesterday.
 Private-sector payrolls fell by another 73,000 jobs in July, roughly similar to the pace in recent months. Manufacturers -- which often provide a glimpse of where the economy is heading -- cut their fewest number of jobs in 10 months, while layoffs in the much larger service sector increased, according to the seasonally adjusted numbers in the Labor Department's monthly jobs report. 
 The nation's unemployment rate held steady for the second consecutive month at 4.5 percent -- surprising analysts, who had generally expected it to rise. The jobless rate and the payroll number are calculated from separate surveys, and the two do not move in tandem every month. 
Still, the unemployment rate has risen since October from a 30-year low of 3.9 percent, and economists expect it to continue increasing for the remainder of the year. In recent weeks, DuPont, JDS Uniphase and PricewaterhouseCoopers, among others, have announced further layoffs.
But yesterday's report, which was the first broad look at the economy in July, suggested that conditions might no longer be deteriorating as rapidly as they were earlier in the year. In addition, the Labor Department said on Thursday that first-time claims for unemployment insurance had fallen in the weeks since it conducted its survey of the job market in July.
"This month's numbers are obviously better than expected," said the labor secretary, Elaine L. Chao. "That suggests some stability." 
She added, "Whether it's an improvement, at this point I think it's a little premature" to say,
Stocks fell slightly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average off 38.4 points, to 10,512.78; bond yields were unchanged. Analysts said the jobs report added to the evidence indicating that the Federal Reserve would probably reduce lower its benchmark interest rate by another quarter of a percentage point at its meeting later this month. But barring unpleasant surprises in the weeks ahead, the Fed's campaign to restart the economy -- through rate cuts totaling 2.75 percentage points over seven months so far -- is nearly over, analysts predict.
Despite its promising hints, the labor market in July offered little to suggest that an economic recovery had already begun. Including a 31,000 increase in government payrolls, the economy lost 42,000 jobs last month and now employs 132.4 million workers. Since March, it has lost an average of 65,000 jobs a month. From the end of 1996 until March, the economy had added about 235,000 jobs a month.
The government also revised its employment statistics for May and June yesterday, saying the job market was somewhat better than had been initially thought. The private sector lost 120,000 jobs during the two months, not 149,000, and federal, state and local governments created 68,000, not 43,000.
"You can find a few glimmers of hope beneath the surface," said Richard D. Rippe, the chief economist for Prudential Securities, "but nothing absolutely definitive to indicate that there is an upturn or that one will emerge soon."
In recent months, the layoffs have spread to service companies, which account for about four out of every five jobs in the United States. In July, private-service employment fell by 26,000, led by cuts at temporary-employment companies (42,000), department stores (11,000) and supermarket and other food stores (10,000). Restaurants, hospitals and other health care companies continued to add employees.
An economic slowdown typically hurts manufacturers first -- because consumers and executives can more easily delay the purchase of new furniture than the payment of electric or medical bills, for instance -- but the contrast has been unusually severe recently. Manufacturers have been hurt by a strong dollar and the rapid corporate cuts in spending on software and equipment. 
Since April 1998, the portion of American jobs in manufacturing has fallen to 13 percent from 15 percent, said Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. It is "an extraordinary shift over a relatively short time," he said
The shift may now be ending, however. Manufacturing employment fell 49,000 in July, less than half the amount it had in the three prior months. This suggests "manufacturing is in the trough of the business cycle and should be poised to make a recovery," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
It is not clear, however, when manufacturing will begin to grow again. The Labor Department said yesterday that some of the deceleration in the sector's job cuts could have reflected the government's seasonal adjustments, which try to account for typical reductions in factory employment during the summer. 
Across all sectors, weekly earnings for nonsupervisory employees rose 0.3 percent, to $490.77 in July. The increase was smaller than the 0.5 percent increase in June, and many economists expect wage growth to remain mild as unemployment increases.
That, in turn, reduces the chance that the Fed's rate cuts will cause inflation to take off in the coming months.
"There's really no inflation risk in the economy," said Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch, adding that inflation patterns usually lag those of economic growth.
The Labor Department uses two separate surveys -- one of households and one of businesses -- to evaluate the job market each month, and the two surveys offered conflicting pictures yesterday. 
According to the household survey, which also produces the unemployment rate, total employment actually rose by a stunning 447,000 jobs in July. But because the household poll uses a much smaller sample, its month-to-month changes are often misleading, said Thomas J. Nardone, the Labor Department economist who oversees the survey.
Through much of this year, the household poll has reported worse news than the business survey, and this month's swing means that the business survey's earlier results are considered likely to be closer to reality.
In July, the unemployment rate -- which considers only those who are actively looking for work to be jobless -- for blacks fell to 7.9 percent from 8.4 percent. Among Hispanics, it dropped to 6 percent from 6.6 percent.
Even as the job market continues to worsen, it remains in one of its strongest conditions in three decades. July was the 49th consecutive month that the unemployment rate was below 5 percent. It never fell below that point in the years from 1973 to 1996.

PERSON: Robert Miles Runyan 

HEADLINE: Robert Miles Runyan, 76, Adroit Graphic Designer, Dies 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN HELLER 

 BODY:
Robert Miles Runyan, a graphic designer who changed the way that American corporations communicated by designing innovative annual reports, died on July 27 at his home in Ajijic, Mexico. He was 76.
 The cause was Shy-Drager syndrome, a neurodegenerative disease, said Gary Hinsche, his former business partner. 
 Mr. Runyan was a pioneer of visual corporate communications, the concept of an integrated package of logos, trademarks and graphics that establish the identity of businesses in the public's consciousness. 
In 1959, Mr. Runyan produced his breakthrough work, the annual report for Litton Industries, which changed how corporations presented their yearly financial statements to stockholders. Federal law required that this information be released regularly, but most such reports were dry and formulaic. 
The 1959 Litton report, however, looked more like a magazine or even an art book than a spreadsheet. 
Mr. Runyan played a "major role in redefining this genre," the design historian Philip B. Meggs said in "A History of Graphic Design."
He did this by creating a format that combined the editorial pacing of a magazine and the typographic and pictorial elegance of an art book. The Litton report was the first to contain distinctive graphics and modern still-life photographs of antique scientific artifacts, providing what Mr. Runyan called "symbiology," and illustrating a narrative about the young company, which was founded in 1954, and its relationship to the broader history of science. Mr. Runyan viewed the annual report as a tool to build faith and confidence among the employees and stockholders as well as to symbolize the company's overall mission.
Crosby Kelly, Litton's former manager of investor relations, said at the time that this annual report was "something like a flag," useful in bolstering morale. 
Mr. Runyan's work was among the first to present " 'the big picture,' the major social and economic trends of the times -- and then show how the individual company fits within this framework," said a 1971 article in Graphis, a design trade magazine. The report won numerous professional awards and accolades and brought Mr. Runyan hundreds of other commissions. His concept remains the standard in the graphic design field to this day. 
Robert Miles Runyan was born in Falls City, Neb., on April 18, 1925. He joined the Marine Corps in 1943 and later attended both the Art Center and Chouinard Art Institute in Los Angeles. In 1956, he established Robert Miles Runyan & Associates in Playa del Rey, Calif., initially designing advertisements and record covers. His first corporate assignment was for Litton, which was then an obscure Beverly Hills military contractor. Within a short time, he was in great demand for design typified by abstract iconography and crisp typography. During a single year his firm produced 48 annual reports. 
But despite a list of international clients that he worked for developing logos, identities and packages -- including Transamerica, Times Mirror, Mattel, Vuarnet of France, Unibanco of Mexico, the Los Angeles Rams, Rockwell International, and Caesar's Palace -- Mr. Runyan did not fit the stereotype of a company man. His version of the three-piece business suit was a tight-fitting cowboy shirt, stove-pipe jeans and lizard-skin Western boots, worn with a brush of a mustache that made him look like the Marlboro Man.
Both his office and his Victorian-style home were stuffed with his countless Americana collectibles, ranging from more than a dozen illuminated, working gas pumps to two hundred "Do Not Disturb" door-knob signs. Some of his collection turned up in his designs.
For the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, Mr. Runyan was given what he considered the chance of a lifetime, the opportunity to compete for the commission to design the official symbol. After 3,500 sketches he devised the "Stars in Motion" logo that appeared on everything sold at the games. Of this project, he said: "What I achieved can never be taken away. I'm etched in history."
Mr. Runyan is survived by his wife, Claudette; two daughters, Tevis, of Hartford, and Kimberly, of Playa del Rey; and a grandson.

HEADLINE: Now Playing In Clubland: Hard Times; 
Night Spots Confront Residential Growth And Higher Rents

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
When Wetlands, a TriBeCa club famous for fostering the careers of quirky bands, announced this week that it was closing, music fans were devastated, but those in the industry were hardly surprised.
 The building on Hudson Street that houses the club was sold to a group that wants to convert the space into apartments, and Wetlands and its late-night revelers didn't exactly fit into its plans. 
 To club owners, it is a familiar situation. They say it has become harder for nightclubs to survive in New York because of steeply rising rents and changes in zoning that have allowed residents to move into areas that used to be the preserve of industry and business.
With residential neighbors abhorring the same things clubs covet -- crowds, traffic, noise -- and with community boards exerting considerable influence on state and city licensing agencies these days, many areas of the city, especially downtown, are now virtually off limits. Other areas are willing to accept only clubs that open in existing nightclub space, owners say. 
"This is the toughest atmosphere for nightclubs in New York since Prohibition," said Robert Bookman, the lawyer for the New York Nightlife Association, a group representing about 100 nightclubs.
The city's Department of Consumer Affairs, which issues cabaret licenses, says that 319 establishments hold licenses this year, including nightclubs, strip clubs and other businesses with dancing, like restaurants, down from 333 last year.
Club owners say what is more telling is that fewer businesses even make it to the licensing stage because of the difficulties of finding a location. They note that the number of clubs remained virtually flat in recent years while the city itself was in a long period of economic growth.
But if the nightclub industry is looking for sympathy, it will be hard pressed to find any in the city, where quality-of-life issues became one of the hallmarks of the Giuliani administration.
The association of nightclubs said business became trickier in the early 1990's, when new city and state legislation made it harder for a club to obtain a cabaret license for dancing or a state liquor license. One law has also empowered the local community boards to reject a club that wants to open within 500 feet of three existing businesses that serve liquor.
"Residents and clubs just don't mix," said Madelyn Wils, the chairwoman of Community Board 1 in Lower Manhattan, which has successfully fought the openings of clubs. "Nine out of 10 times there are problems."
The Copacabana, the granddaddy of dance clubs in the city, exemplifies the struggle that club owners say is driving some of them away or out of business. In many ways, the Copacabana is in a category of its own. It has operated since 1940 (with a three-year hiatus in the 1970's after its original owner died) in a business where 5 to 10 years is considered a healthy life span. And it has served up the same music for the past 20 years -- salsa and merengue -- in an industry that caters to the latest fad.
But this year, the Copa became just another club pitted against the realities of the city's real estate market. Its rather unglamorous neighborhood of car dealerships and parking lots near the Hudson River suddenly became more economically desirable. So after nine years on a block of low buildings on West 57th Street, the club was forced to move out last month to make way for two new office towers.
John Juliano, who owns the Copa with two partners, said the search for a new home started about a year and a half ago after he was notified by the property's new landlord that the club's 10-year lease would be terminated early. The owners looked at more than 50 locations in spaces ranging from parking lots to the former Studio 54, which was tied up with the musical "Cabaret."
The search was restricted not only by residential encroachment, but also by the club's needs. The owners wanted at least 25,000 square feet. After holding 10-year leases at two previous locations, this time they wanted a lease no shorter than 25 years. They settled for a 47,000-square-foot building at 570 West 34th Street, near 11th Avenue, that used to house offices. The Copacabana will reopen at the new site next summer. In the meantime, it has moved its live music to another club, Ohm, on West 22nd Street, four nights a week.
"It's been a nightmare," said Glee Ballard, the Copa's general manager. "The biggest problem is that you have to go to an area available for a cabaret and a liquor license and then you want a wide open space." She said that the new spot, at a rent at least five times as high as the old site's, is in an industrial area where the club "can't annoy anybody."
"There's no such thing as going to prestigious neighborhoods," she said. "You can go there with a McDonald's or a big department store, but clubs, no. Everybody acts as if entertainment is not desirable."
Deputy Police Commissioner Thomas Antenen, the department's chief spokesman, said both the police and residents had become less tolerant of problems associated with clubs. "It's not so much what happens in the clubs," he said, "but the stuff that happens in the immediate areas: fights, people hanging out, making noise, maybe drinking."
Marty Arret, owner of the Latin Quarter on the Upper West Side, said that in his neighborhood, gentrification had drawn neighbors who opposed his club. The club, at one time known as Club Broadway, has a mostly Hispanic clientele and has been at the same spot for 20 years.
"They call us and say, 'Why don't you go to the Bronx?' " he said.
As it turns out, the Latin Quarter is shutting down on Aug. 31; its landlord decided to rent the space, on Broadway near West 96th Street, to a bank. Mr. Arret said he was looking for a new location but had found that most available places were going for at least double his current monthly rent of $25,000.
David Rabin, who is the president of the New York Nightlife Association and an owner of Lotus, a supper club, said it took him three years to find a site for the club. Lotus opened about two years ago in a former strip club on West 14th Street, in the meatpacking district in Manhattan. Since then, he said, rents per square foot have more than tripled in what used to be "a block full of prostitutes and meatpackers."
Mr. Rabin said he spent $5,000 a week on security and faced constant police inspections. He said he was pursuing his next business deal in Las Vegas.
Kathryn E. Freed, a city councilwoman who represents Lower Manhattan and has been a plaintiff in court cases against several clubs, played down the clubs' concerns. She said clubs and residential neighbors coexisted peacefully in many parts of the city, usually because the clubs had made an effort to minimize any disturbance to the neighborhood. "Night life doesn't have to be disruptive," she said.
Ms. Freed said there was still room for improvement. She said she favored tightening noise regulations and requiring waiting areas inside the clubs to eliminate the velvet rope crowds outside.
Neighbors like Ms. Wils say noise is not the only problem; they cite alcohol, drugs, lewd behavior and sometimes even shootings outside the clubs. In New York, as in other areas of the country, the rising popularity of Ecstasy and other illegal drugs has drawn a police crackdown.
Police officials said that in the past year and a half they had sought to close at least five major clubs for allowing the sale and use of so-called designer drugs on and around their premises. George A. Grasso, deputy police commissioner for legal matters, called the problem a continuing concern, but said it was not necessarily worse than in past years.
Club owners concede there are bad apples among them, but say the clubs need more police presence. In 1999, the nightclub association asked to hire off-duty uniformed police officers, as clubs do in other cities, but the Police Department declined. In a letter to the group, the department said the proposal was not "legally permissible" and could expose the city to "substantial additional risk of civil liability."
Mr. Bookman, the lawyer for the nightclub association, said the city's world-famous reputation for night life was bound to erode unless zoning variances were reined in, the police helped out and there was "respect for the industry as a taxpaying industry." According to a study by the night life association, the industry funnels close to $3 billion a year into the city's economy.
Mr. Juliano at the Copa said he regretted not having bought a building years ago. Now, he said, it would take $10 million to buy one and $5 million to renovate it.
Even for the Copa, that is out of the question, he said. "Just don't have the money."

HEADLINE: In U.S. Illegally, Immigrants Get License to Drive 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: GARNER, N.C., Aug. 1 

 BODY:
The roofer climbed down from the scaffolding around the new strip mall, pulled out his wallet, and fondled the little plastic card inside as if it were enchanted. Though he does not speak English, he was delighted to point to the words on the card: "State of North Carolina Driver License," and underneath, his name, Alejandro.
 "I used to have a Mexican license, which the police didn't like," he said through an interpreter, declining to give his last name because he is in this country illegally. "But here in North Carolina they said I could have this, a real license, and I couldn't believe it. Now I get insurance, and I don't have to worry so much when I get in the car." 
 Three other workers on the same job site in this suburb south of Raleigh said they also had licenses despite their illegal status, and said they get paid as much as $2 an hour more because of the extra versatility the license gives them on the job. 
For these and hundreds of thousands of other illegal immigrants who have taken advantage of North Carolina's liberal rules for a license, driving is no longer a furtive affair, conducted under cover of night and only when absolutely necessary. Their card and the sense of identity it confers allows them at least a partial entry into the mainstream of the United States, a sense of security above the underground of menial jobs and makeshift communities.
The validation conferred by a license, of course, is precisely why most states do not provide them to immigrants in the country illegally, out of concern that it would induce more people to cross the border in violation of national law. Only three other states -- Tennessee, Utah and Virginia -- give licenses to any state resident who can pass the driving test, regardless of their legal status. Other states, including Illinois and New Mexico, have considered the possibility, weighing North Carolina's argument that the licensing and testing process will improve highway safety and see to it that more drivers have insurance.
"In 9 out of 10 cases, people who move here for jobs and opportunities are going to drive, whether they have a license or not," said Wayne J. Hurder, North Carolina's director of driver's license certification. "We think it's in the best interests of everyone in the state if we can get them to learn the laws of the road and get insurance. It's not our job to get into national immigration policy -- this is a purely practical decision."
But that argument, which has been made most vociferously by President Vicente Fox of Mexico, has failed to persuade many of the largest states, where benefits to immigrants remain a touchy emotional and political issue, rather than a matter of practical policy. Even in some states that have begun to extend some benefits, like in-state college tuition, a driver's license is still considered a touchstone of citizenship that remains jealously guarded.
Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service say they are not happy with licensing procedures like North Carolina's, but that there is nothing they can do about it.
Tennessee's decision in May to grant licenses to illegal immigrants may be an indication of their increasing acceptance in society, and the legislatures in California and Texas have also approved such measures in the last year. But the governors in the two states, a Democrat and a Republican respectively, vetoed the bills, and some states, including Georgia, Minnesota and South Carolina, have moved to tighten restrictions, making licenses far more difficult to obtain for those who cannot document their legal status.
"These are criminals, who slip stealthily and evasively into this country and remain here as fugitives, and I don't think we should reward that kind of behavior with the privilege to drive," said John Graham Altman III, a Republican member of the South Carolina House of Representatives. "North Carolina obviously isn't serious about observing the law, but I think if you encourage the invasion of the illegals, you'll just get more of them."
Earlier this year, Mr. Altman introduced a bill that would ban licenses for illegal immigrants, making explicit a policy already followed by the state. The measure passed the House but was not taken up by the Senate. Independent of that effort, the state motor vehicles division recently decided to require applicants to produce either a Social Security card or a letter from the Social Security Administration stating that the applicant is in the country legally.
North Carolina asks for a Social Security number to comply with a federal law seeking people who do not pay child support, but if an applicant does not have one, the state accepts other identification, including a Mexican military I.D. card and voter registration cards from other countries. In May, Gov. Don Sundquist of Tennessee, a Republican, signed into law a similar policy, producing waiting lines so long that some legislators wanted to repeal the measure. (The lines have since returned to a manageable size.)
The divergence in the states' policies can easily be seen in the waiting rooms of their motor vehicles offices. In North Carolina and Tennessee, branch offices are full of people speaking Spanish, and many can barely keep the Spanish translations of their driving manuals in stock. In South Carolina offices, there is far less Spanish to be heard, and many immigrants say they want nothing to do with the licensing bureaucracy.
"If you go in there and speak Spanish, they give you a big hassle and want to see all kinds of proof," said a welder from Mexico in Spartanburg, S.C., who crossed over illegally. "So we just drive anyway, and stay under the speed limit and hope no one stops us." He added that he had no auto insurance.
North Carolina immigrants, on the other hand, can not only get insurance, but many who were fearful of driving without a license are free from the dependence those who could drive, particularly in an area with almost no public transit. 
"My brothers used to take me places, and a friend of mine drove me to work every day," said a woman from El Salvador who repairs uniforms at a rental company and who got her license in Cary, another Raleigh suburb. "It was bad when I had to wait outside in the cold for a ride. But now I can go anywhere by myself."
The Legislature never formally approved the state's policy, but it began to evolve in the late 1980's when immigrants began arriving in the state in large numbers. Today the state has the nation's fastest-growing Hispanic population, and businesses are eager to see their work force licensed and insured.
Since 1997, Mr. Hurder said, the state has issued more than 400,000 licenses and ID cards to people lacking Social Security numbers, more than 260,000 of whom were Hispanic. Officials say they believe the policy has reduced the number of fake ID's and Social Security numbers often used elsewhere by immigrants.
Some of those, he acknowledged, were not North Carolina residents. The state's policy has become well-known among immigrants across the country, and people from Florida, South Carolina and the northeast have flocked to North Carolina to get a license and then return to their home states. A high school student from Huntington, New York, who was born in El Salvador, said he was in the Garner branch office today for precisely that purpose.
"I need a license in New York in case I get stopped," he said. "Back home, lots of people have a North Carolina license."
To restrict that practice, a bill is now under consideration in the State Legislature to require license applicants to show proof that they are North Carolina residents, which could be a pay stub or a utility bill. But legislators say they do not plan to require applicants to be legal United States residents.
"The ability to drive is very helpful to our newest residents in getting their lives established here," said State Senator Wib Gulley, a Democrat from Durham who is chairman of the transportation subcommittee. "They play a crucial role in our economy, which would be severely hurt if we put a wall up around the state."
In recent months, that message has been carried around the country by Dr. Juan Hernandez, appointed by Mr. Fox as the director of the Office of Mexicans Abroad. Dr. Hernandez said in an interview that he had met with about a dozen American governors, urging them to follow North Carolina's lead, but has encountered considerable resistance.
"Politically, they feel it's a very hot issue for them right now," he said. "But what we tell them is, these people did break one law coming here, but they shouldn't be forced to break other laws. These are the people who are building the roads of America, but they're not allowed to drive on them."

PERSON: VICENTE FOX QUESADA (56%) FIRESTONE, DAVID

HEADLINE: Matters of Law, And Semantics, In Health Bills 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
After six years of bitter debate over patients' rights, the House and the Senate have produced bills that seem very similar. But there are big differences, illustrated by two little words, "a" and "the." 
 Both bills would allow patients to sue health insurance plans in some circumstances. To win damages under the Senate bill, a plaintiff must show that a health plan was negligent and that such negligence was "a proximate cause" of personal injury or death. 
 By contrast, under the House bill, passed on Thursday, a plaintiff must show that the insurer's negligence was "the proximate cause" of injury or death. That could be more difficult. 
The delay or denial of care by an insurer might contribute to severe injury or disability. But the insurer could argue that its action was just one of many factors. It could assert, for example, that a patient already had a chronic condition, or that the patient and the doctor were at fault, because they did not supply all the information that was necessary to rule properly on a claim for benefits.
The difference between "a" and "the" exemplifies the biggest difference between the two bills -- a difference that House and Senate negotiators will try to iron out in coming months. The Senate measure would give patients freer access to the courts, with fewer limits on the damages they could recover from H.M.O.'s and insurance companies.
For years, health plans protected themselves against lawsuits by invoking a federal law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, known as Erisa. But in recent years, judges have pierced the shield provided by that law, ruling that an H.M.O. can be held "vicariously liable" for the negligence of its doctors and nurses, and directly responsible for arranging inadequate care.
Alan D. Bloom, senior vice president and general counsel of Maxicare Health Plans, a managed care company in Los Angeles, said: "The plaintiff bar was finally figuring out how to get around Erisa. This new legislation stops that momentum and probably gives the H.M.O.'s more protection than they are losing."
For example, Mr. Bloom said, the House bill would limit punitive damages, but most states have no such limits.
How "a" became "the" is a mystery.
When Representative Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, and House members from both parties introduced a patients' bill of rights on July 19, it included the exact words of the Senate bill: "a proximate cause."
But in subsequent negotiations between Mr. Norwood and the White House, the language was changed, and it became "the proximate cause."
John E. Stone, a spokesman for Mr. Norwood, said he did not know how or why the change was made. He agreed that the change could make it more difficult for patients to prevail in court.
"It's a very valid point," Mr. Stone said. "If this is a problem, it can be worked out in conference between the House and the Senate."
A White House official deeply involved in the negotiations could not explain the change. "That's not something that ever came up in our discussions with Dr. Norwood," said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The legal liability of H.M.O.'s might seem to be a technical question. But Representative Robert E. Andrews, Democrat of New Jersey, said it had major implications for consumers. 
"If the H.M.O. is the sole cause of your injury, you can recover," Mr. Andrews said. "But if it is one of many causes of your injury, you cannot." 
Even if few cases go to court, the possibility or the threat of lawsuits can have a profound influence on the behavior of health maintenance organizations, prompting them to approve more care and to pay more claims.
President Bush supports the House bill, with its more limited right to sue, and has threatened to veto the Senate version. Of course, he can significantly influence negotiations between the two chambers.
What difference does it make to patients? Assume, for example, that a person with cancer goes to a doctor, who recommends an expensive, potentially life-saving medical treatment. But the H.M.O. refuses to authorize it, on the ground that it has not been recognized as effective in research published in medical journals.
Under the Senate and House bills, a patient could challenge such a decision by asking the health plan to reconsider. If this "internal appeal" fails, the patient could seek review by independent medical experts. If this "external appeal" fails, the patient could go to court. 
Disputes involving a question of medical judgment would go to state court.
Federal courts would resolve disputes over administrative issues: Is the patient actually enrolled in the health plan? Is a specific service covered under the contract? What is the co-payment?
In trying to write a new body of tort law for H.M.O.'s, Congress is wading into a rapidly changing, immensely complex field. The law appears to be evolving in a direction favorable to plaintiffs. So lawyers say that anything Congress does could erode some of the rights patients have won in courts and in state legislatures.
The House bill would create a federal right to sue H.M.O.'s -- a "federal cause of action" -- in state court. Democrats said this would override provisions of state laws adopted by 10 states, including California, New Jersey and Texas.
The House and Senate bills would both allow injured patients to recover unlimited economic damages, primarily to compensate for medical expenses and lost earnings. The House bill sets a $1.5 million limit on payments for noneconomic damages like pain and suffering, with a separate limit of $1.5 million on punitive damages.
The Senate bill would not set any limit on noneconomic damages. It would allow up to $5 million in civil assessments resembling punitive damages in federal court.
The House bill allows states to set damage limits lower than the federal caps, but states could not set higher limits.
Multimillion-dollar jury verdicts for malpractice by doctors, hospitals and other health care providers are not particularly unusual. If Congress expands the right to sue without imposing strict limits on damages, Mr. Bush says, insurance costs will rise, and people will lose coverage. 
But sponsors of the Senate bill strenuously oppose limits on noneconomic damages. Such damages, they say, compensate victims for very real injuries like chronic pain, loss of a body part, paralysis and loss of reproductive capacity.
Moreover, the senators say, limits on noneconomic damages tend to discriminate against women who are homemakers, and against children and elderly people, including nursing home residents, because they do not necessarily lose wages when they suffer incapacitating injuries. 
The campaign for patients' rights, begun as a crusade to end H.M.O. "horror stories," may end in a Congressional conference committee that sounds like a law school seminar on torts and contracts.
The House and the Senate finally agreed this summer on the substantive protections that patients should have. In virtually identical language, they would guarantee that people with insurance have access to emergency care, medical specialists, prescription drugs and other services when needed.
With agreement on these issues, the dispute over H.M.O. liability looms as the biggest unresolved issue.
Republicans deplore the focus on litigation. "It's sue, sue, sue," said Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Senate Republican leader. "That's not the answer."
But Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, said the rest of the bill would be worthless without a means to enforce it in court. "A right without a remedy is no right at all," Mr. Dingell said.

PERSON: Paul Vallas 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
What for an Encore? Why Not 'the Education Governor'?

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
THE serious man wearing the funny red necktie sits in a chair in a sunny downtown office with his hands folded.
 His name is Paul Vallas. And he is wearing his children's tie, which drapes neatly down the center of a crisp white button-down shirt and bears pictures of smiling schoolchildren and an American flag. 
 Mr. Vallas, who looks more like a school principal than a politician, hopes to wear that necktie or one like it all the way to the governor's office in Springfield. He would like to become known as "the education governor." 
This is the same Paul Vallas who was hired six years ago by Mayor Richard M. Daley to turn around Chicago's troubled education system and who subsequently won praise even from critics for a tough, hands-on corporate style that led to raised test scores and the restoration of respect to the city's schools.
He is the same Paul Vallas who resigned as chief executive of the school system in June, then stepped away from the public light.
Now, just two months later, he is back, looking to fill a different set of shoes. He announced for governor this week.
If the idea of leaping from the management of the nation's third-largest school system to the governorship seems unusual, then listen to Mr. Vallas.
"I've been the chief executive for the second-largest governmental institution in the state of Illinois: Chicago public schools," he said. "For the last 10 years, I have balanced multimillion-dollar budgets."
"I've buried 65 children who have been the victims of gang violence in their own communities," he added. "I've had to deal with day-to-day management issues and day-to-day controversies that my opponents could never imagine. I think this well prepares me. It well prepares me to be governor of Illinois."
Besides all that, there is his prior experience as budget director for the City of Chicago, as the city's director of revenue, as executive director of the Illinois Economic and Fiscal Commission.
He likes his chances, as do those in his camp.
"Paul Vallas," said Jay D. Doherty, a political consultant to the Vallas campaign, "is the one Democrat who can win."
Mr. Vallas is banking on his reputation as the man who saved the Chicago schools, and on the media exposure that the effort earned him during the last six years. He hopes that his campaign message -- largely one of spreading across Illinois the education improvements he made here in his hometown -- will translate into votes not only in Chicago but downstate as well.
Not that winning the governor's seat will be easy: no Democrat has done so in nearly three decades. The last was Daniel Walker, back when bellbottom pants were in, along with long sideburns and disco music, and Mr. Vallas was less than half his current age, 48.
Democrats see an opportunity to win next year's election, though, particularly in light of a federal inquiry into bribes paid for commercial driver's licenses. The bribes went to employees in the office of the secretary of state, who was then George Ryan. Mr. Ryan, now the Republican governor, is expected to announce soon whether he will seek a second term. 
In any event, Mr. Vallas must first capture the Democratic nomination next March, against what promises to be a crowded field. He cites a poll showing him second only to a former member of Congress, Glenn Poshard. Mayor Daley so far has not publicly announced his support for any candidate, but even without the mayor's backing, Mr. Vallas says he is confident and up to the challenge. It won't be his first.
When he took over as Chicago schools chief in 1995, the system had a reputation as the nation's worst. He quickly went to work, enacting a zero-tolerance behavior code, imposing a more rigorous curriculum and putting an end to a policy of social promotion. In time, Chicago schools became a national model. 
BORN in Chicago, Mr. Vallas grew up on the city's South Side. He taught school in the 1970's and began his career in public service as a senior policy analyst with the State Legislature.
He and his wife, Sharon, a retired police officer, have three sons.
Earlier this year, Mr. Vallas dismissed public speculation that he was going to run for governor, saying he wanted to concentrate on his job as schools chief.
Then came his resignation, and soon news that he had joined the gubernatorial fray.
Why does he want to do it?
"By becoming governor, I'm going to be able to complete the job that I started at the local level," Mr. Vallas said. "I'm not talking about just completing the job for Chicago. I'm talking about completing the job for all local government and throughout the state of Illinois."
So the Paul Vallas for Governor Web site is up and running, and his campaign offices will open soon, he said energetically in that downtown office today, wearing his funny red necktie.
He thought of another Illinois Democrat, a former senator, and said with a laugh, "If Paul Simon could get elected with his bowtie, I can get elected with my children's tie." 
A campaign consultant standing nearby suggested that he get about 500 of the ties.
After all, it's a long road to Springfield.
