HEADLINE: Subsidies for Clean Coal Miss Mark, Critics Say 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 1 

 BODY:
Compared with many alternatives, a coal-fired power plant being built here will be anything but clean. It will emit several times as much smog-causing pollution and heat-trapping gas as the the same utility's new plant, fired by natural gas, a few miles away.
 But it is the coal-fired plant, not the gas-burning plant, that is being subsidized by the federal government, under a 15-year-old program that has spent $1.8 billion to promote so-called clean-coal technology in 38 projects. That aid would triple under the energy bill passed by the House of Representatives, to $5.3 billion over the next 10 years, including new tax credits. 
 The coal industry and the utilities say the subsidies are necessary to help make coal, the country's dirtiest fuel, but also its cheapest and most abundant one, as clean as possible. But critics say the program has fallen badly off the mark, by paying utilities like the Jacksonville Electric Authority here to install technologies they would probably be adopting on their own and by encouraging the burning of coal over environmentally friendlier alternatives. 
"Basically, there is no such thing as clean coal," said Kate Abend, an energy expert with the United States Public Interest Research Group, which is aligned with environmentalists.
Michael N. Lawson, major projects manager at the Jacksonville plant, said it was going to switch to the new coal-burning technology "whether we had Energy Department money or not." The utility is converting a second 300 megawatt generator at the plant without federal help.
The federal aid -- some $73 million from the Energy Department -- is covering a fourth of the $300 million cost of what will soon become the largest coal-fired power plant in the world to use what is known as circulating fluidized bed technology. The conversion to coal, at the utility's Northside generating station, on a waterway near the Atlantic Ocean, will increase the output of a power plant built in 1972 by 240 percent, while reducing its emissions of the pollutants that cause smog by 10 percent.
The technology, which burns coal at lower temperatures and uses limestone to capture many emissions, is about 50 percent cleaner than the technology used at a typical new coal-burning power plant. The converted Northside plant, with no visible emissions, will be cleaner than a nearby 1980's coal-burning plant, which has visible plumes.
But the converted coal plant will still allow 10 times the emissions of smog-causing nitrogen oxide as generators fueled by natural gas, like the Brandy Branch plant, which the utility opened in Jacksonville this year. The Northside plant will also emit more than twice as much carbon dioxide, which traps heat and contributes to global warming, and considerable sulfur dioxide, an ingredient in smog and acid rain that is not generated by natural gas.
Nor is the technology being installed here state of the art. A process known as coal gasification, being tested at plants in Tampa, Fla., and Terre Haute, Ind., has shown much more promise in reducing emissions of pollutants, including carbon dioxide. The ostensible purpose of the federal financing is to demonstrate clean coal's commercial possibilities, but years of delays have meant that even before the Jacksonville plant begins operating next year, others will have begun installing the technology without federal help.
The federally backed plant will become the latest of 400 fluidized-bed units operating around the world, most built without subsidies.
Walt Bussells, the chief executive of the Jacksonville Electric Authority, the eighth largest utility in the country, said the federal aid was "a deciding factor" in the project. But he said that in proceeding with a coal-fired plant and a gas-fired plant at roughly the same time, the authority was mainly concerned with avoiding the mistakes of the late 1970's, when reliance on one fuel -- oil -- left it vulnerable to soaring prices.
The Northside plant, built to burn oil and gas, is among a handful built or converted to burn coal in the last five years, a period in which utilities embraced the cheaper, cleaner-burning natural gas plants.
But more than half of the country's electricity is still generated by burning coal, and the recent volatility in natural gas prices has prompted some utilities to give coal a second look. In the last six months, plans have been announced for at least 24 new coal-fired plants nationwide, and most analysts expect that trend to accelerate if the Senate approves the new clean-coal subsidies. The details of the Senate version of the bill are still being worked out.
Whether building more coal-fired plants is good is a subject of debate.
The National Mining Association said large subsidies were crucial to an economically and environmentally sound coal industry. The Bush administration, which proposed $2 billion in new money for clean coal, has supported the even larger subsidies approved by the House, on grounds that they are needed to promote diversity in the country's energy supply.
"For the environmental benefits in particular, there's a natural reason to move this thing forward," said Robert S. Kripowicz, acting assistant secretary of energy for fossil fuels and the main overseer of the clean-coal program. "And because of our need for energy, it's important to promote a balance of technologies."
Mr. Kripowicz conceded that the federal clean-coal program had had many setbacks, including project delays and bankruptcies. The General Accounting Office has criticized the program, prompting Congress to take back more than $400 million of the roughly $2.4 billion it appropriated in the late 1980's. The money for the Jacksonville project was approved in the early 1980's, when the project was to be in Tallahassee, Fla.
If the department were making the decision today, Mr. Kripowicz said, it might not have financed what is now a widely used technology. But he pointed out that two-thirds of the cost of federally backed demonstration projects had been borne by industry and the states, and he said the investment had helped coal-burning power plants to cut their emissions since 1970 even as the use of coal to generate electricity had tripled.
Coal is not the only energy industry that would benefit from the House bill. Oil and gas producers would be exempted from certain royalty payments to the government and eligible for a variety of tax credits; so would investors in nuclear energy.
But most analysts see the coal industry as the biggest winner. It would benefit not only from the $2 billion to promote clean-coal technology over the next 10 years, but also from $3.3 billion in investment and tax credits to encourage the use of coal to generate electricity, subject to certain performance standards. That has caused resentment among advocates of natural gas, who believe the government should more actively embrace their cleaner technology.
Under the House measure, most of the $2 billion in development financing would be reserved for technologies that convert coal to a gas before burning it for electricity. These processes have already shown more success than other approaches in reducing emissions of pollutants that cause smog.
Coal gasification is also seen as the most promising technology for capturing carbon dioxide, which scientists regard as a major contributor to global warming, but which is not being reduced under existing pollution controls.
People who have studied the bill, however, say the standards of eligibility for the tax credits could include coal-burning generators no cleaner than many existing ones. Environmentalists who believe the industry should be driven toward cleaner technologies by regulation rather than subsidies particularly object to tax credits, saying they will give coal an advantage over wind and water power and other clean, renewable ways to generate electricity.
"The net result is that this would put coal back in a position where it would outcompete the better environmental performers in the marketplace," said David G. Hawkins, a former senior official at the Environmental Protection Agency who now works for the Natural Resources Defense Council. "It would make the situation worse by expanding the taxpayer subsidies for the world's dirtiest fuel."
But David Parham, chief executive of Foster Wheeler, a principal manufacturer of coal-burning systems and a beneficiary of the subsidies, argued that major federal aid made sense.
"Of course, gas is a cleaner fuel to burn than coal," Mr. Parham said. "But we need a balanced approach to generating electricity, and coal is still our biggest energy resource."

HEADLINE: Legislature Is Assailed By Pataki Over Budget 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki traveled the state today to attack the Legislature for passing a bare-bones budget over his objections and vowed the move would not coerce him into spending more than he originally proposed.
 "This is a thin attempt to try to force me to pass a budget that spends billions more than the state can afford," he said at a news conference in Niagara Falls. "It's not going to happen." 
 The governor did not move to block the budget in court, even though he said that he still thought that aspects of the budget were unconstitutional and that he was considering a lawsuit or a veto. 
The state comptroller, meanwhile, said the budget would keep the government running for the rest of the fiscal year, despite being full of painful cuts. The comptroller's decision meant the Pataki administration had to release paychecks to lawmakers that were being held until a budget was passed under a 1998 law.
As the dust settled from the parliamentary battle late Thursday night, the Republican governor appeared to be mounting a political rather than a legal challenge to the Legislature, trying in news conferences across the state to shift blame for the lean budget to legislative leaders. 
The Democrat-led Assembly and the Republican-led Senate overcame partisan differences to pass the stripped-down plan in a last-ditch effort to compel the governor to talk about adding some spending to his budget. For months, Mr. Pataki has said the state cannot afford to spend more than the $83.6 billion he proposed in January because of the shaky national economy.
Michael McKeon, the governor's chief spokesman, said, "The governor's going to make it clear to the people of this state in every corner of this state that he stands against the Albany insiders who want to spend more than the people can afford." 
The comptroller, H. Carl McCall, a Democrat who is planning to run for governor next year, said the $79.6 billion spending plan the Legislature passed was "not a good budget" but laid the blame squarely at Mr. Pataki's feet. He said the governor had avoided Albany and failed to broker a deal with lawmakers.
The budget essentially holds spending at last year's levels or lower in most state programs, except for a $382 million increase in school aid. It cuts about $4 billion from the governor's proposed budget, including several large blocks of money used for economic development and welfare programs. Legislative leaders are betting it will inflict so much pain on local governments that political pressure will mount on the governor to negotiate a supplemental budget that will include some of the lawmakers' priorities.
There is no question that the budget will make it difficult for Mr. Pataki to govern. Dozens of social service programs, from Medicaid payments to day care for the working poor, are facing a $1.5 billion shortfall this year unless an ancillary budget is passed, the governor's budget office said. 
But the Legislature also eliminated a number of large funds dear to Mr. Pataki over which it has little control. Among them is a $150 million fund for conserving wilderness, a $1.5 billion fund of unspent federal welfare money that can be used for social programs and more than $300 million in economic development grants. 
Mr. Pataki began the day with a fishing exhibition in Syracuse and then held news conferences in Rochester and Buffalo before returning to Albany late in the day to speak to reporters. All day, he hammered away at the Legislature for passing what he said was a budget full of holes that would cause many programs to run out of money. He also chastised lawmakers for taking a vacation before finishing the job.
Lawmakers, however, countered that it was the governor who had avoided working out a compromise while traveling around the state and country for ribbon-cuttings, fund-raisers and other minor announcements.
"Instead of hiding from his responsibilities, it would be helpful to the people he was elected to serve if he stayed in Albany negotiating a budget with the Senate and Assembly," Charles Carrier, a spokesman for the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said of the governor.
Underlying the struggle over the budget is a larger constitutional fight over which branch of government shapes the state's spending. The constitution gives the governor enormous sway over spending. The Legislature must act on his budget bills before proposing its own. Lawmakers also can only strike out an appropriation, reduce it or add extra money in a separate bill. The governor can veto any additions.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
EARNINGS AT ETHAN ALLEN INTERIORS FALL SHARPLY

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The home furnishings maker and seller Ethan Allen Interiors said yesterday that its fiscal fourth-quarter profits fell by a third, meeting its lowered estimate, but it also warned that sales and earnings in its first financial quarter would be lower than expected, because of softer economic activity. The retailer, which sells its furnishings through a network of 312 retail locations, said its net income for the fourth quarter ended June 30, excluding a $6.9 million restructuring and impairment charge, was $20.1 million, or 50 cents a diluted share. Wall Street analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected the company, based in Danbury, Conn., to post a profit in the range of 40 to 50 cents, with a mean estimate of 46 cents a share.

HEADLINE: Lack of Advertising Forces Theglobe.comto Shut Web Sites 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Theglobe.com, whose meteoric rise in its first day of trading helped fuel the frenzy for initial public offerings from Internet companies, announced yesterday that it planned to shut most of its Web operations. 
 The closings will cost 60 employees their jobs -- about half its work force -- and all but bring to an end one of the most closely watched Internet companies in Silicon Alley in Manhattan. The company plans to shut all its community Web sites, which were aimed at young adults, and many of those that offer games by Aug. 15, officials said. The sites include www.theglobe.com and www.webjump.com. 
 Chuck Peck, the chief executive of Theglobe.com, said yesterday that the company's troubles could be attributed to an online advertising market that "remains severely depressed, and there are few signs of a rebound in the near-term."
Mr. Peck said the company, which never reported a profit, was exploring the possibilities of being acquired by another company and selling its game properties.
On Nov. 12, 1998, Theglobe's stock was first offered at $4.50 a share. The price soared to $97 that day before closing at $63.50, making it the most successful public offering of stock ever. Theglobe was the first rising dot-com to go public in the aftermath of the stock downturn that followed the Asian economic crisis.
The stock's rise was influenced in part by the story of its youthful founders, Todd Krizelman and Stephan Paternot, friends who started the company together in a Cornell University dormitory room and then became overnight millionaires at age 24.
They put their first Web site online in April 1995 after they raised $15,000 from family and friends to buy equipment.
But by January 2000, with the dot-com bubble beginning to show slight cracks, Theglobe.com's quarterly losses were widening and its stock price had dropped to about $9. That month, Mr. Paternot and Mr. Krizelman, who served as co-chief executives, stepped down.
The company's stock rose less than a cent, to 13.5 cents, yesterday.

HEADLINE: Hevesi Is Pledging Efficiency And a Style That Won't Hurt 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, said yesterday that if he were elected mayor he would offer New Yorkers "the best of Rudy Giuliani without the worst."
 Mr. Hevesi said that as mayor he would work to continue the current administration's success in driving crime down, but would work to curb police misconduct at the same time. He pledged to improve the school system with smaller class sizes, saying that public education has been neglected for too long. And he said that he would use city money to create a trust fund to build more affordable housing. 
 "I intend, as mayor, to offer what's the best of Rudy Giuliani without the worst, to govern in a way that's very positive, as he has in some respects, and to abandon or reject some of the style or decisions that he has made that have been hurtful to the people of this city," he said. 
In a 90-minute interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, Mr. Hevesi cast himself as someone who could deliver the best of both worlds: a strong, efficient government that he said would be more sensitive and open. He spoke of fostering better relationships between City Hall and black and Hispanic residents, of forming a government that "looks like the city," of building consensus on issues like education.
He outlined a series of proposals, some of which could prove costly. He called for a "substantial increase" in schools spending, but did not say how much. He said that police officers deserved a "substantial raise" -- much more, he said, than the raise that the city recently agreed to pay other uniformed workers (10 percent over two and a half years). He said that he would set aside roughly $150 million a year into a fund to build affordable housing. And he said he would establish 200 storefront computer training centers to teach job skills. 
But Mr. Hevesi acknowledged that the worsening economy and anticipated budget gaps in the coming years might make some of his proposals difficult to put in effect. "If that happens, we will have austerity budgets, and we better have a mayor who knows how to handle those budgets," Mr. Hevesi said.
He said he favored some business tax cuts if they could be demonstrably linked to job growth. But he added that, if necessary, he would consider reinstating an income-tax surcharge to pay for his education proposals. And he said that he could not rule out further tax increases if the economy soured. "You never rule out anything," he said. "Anybody who rules it out is not telling you the truth."
Mr. Hevesi, 61, the comptroller for the past seven and a half years, said that he possessed a variety of skills that made him suited to be mayor. 
He said that his 22 years as a state assemblyman left him with an understanding of the legislative process and a good working relationship with state officials whose support is crucial to the city. In his current post, he said, he has not only managed a staff of 800 but has also been a "manager of the managers," since his staff audits all the other city agencies to look for waste. And he said that his experience as an educator -- he has taught political science at Queens College and Columbia University -- would guide his school policy. 
The extent to which Rudolph W. Giuliani continues to loom over the race to replace him was reflected in the amount of time Mr. Hevesi devoted to discussing the current mayor. Mr. Hevesi, a Democrat, found much to praise about Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, saying that the mayor "shattered the myth that you can't govern New York," made the city much safer, improved its image and drew large numbers of tourists back.
But Mr. Hevesi also found much to criticize, saying that Mr. Giuliani had not done nearly enough to improve the city's public schools, that he had been "in denial" about the problem of police misconduct and that he had alienated many people with his combative governing style. 
By contrast, he hardly mentioned the three rivals he will face on Sept. 11 in the Democratic primary: Public Advocate Mark Green; the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone; and the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer. Mr. Hevesi did single out Mr. Vallone, a fellow moderate who is also from Queens, for some criticism, questioning at one point how Mr. Vallone would pay for his education plan. 
And, without mentioning him by name, Mr. Hevesi criticized Mr. Ferrer for his campaign pledge to represent "the other New York," which Mr. Ferrer defines as the people left behind in the last economic boom. Mr. Hevesi said that he believed "this is one city and that it is not helpful -- that it is divisive -- to define it as something else, as two cities."
On education, the issue that he has defined as his first priority, Mr. Hevesi staked out different positions from some of his rivals. He said that he did not favor abolishing the Board of Education, for example, but would prefer to see it restructured and expanded so its members would be required to have backgrounds in education and management. "They wouldn't be the mayor's friend or crony or deputy mayor," he said. 
He said that he would explore lengthening the school day and the school year to help deal with the current overcrowding problems. 
Mr. Hevesi also said that he approved of the job done by Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, whose background is in business. But he would not say whether he would support keeping Mr. Levy on if he were elected mayor. And unlike some of his rivals, he added that he did not believe that a background in education should be a prerequisite for the chancellor's post. "I think a lot of what a chancellor has to do is management," he said. "Maybe the second in command is the educator." 
And Mr. Hevesi offered conciliatory words for the teachers' union, which has become a frequent target of politicians in recent years, and whose endorsement he is seeking. He said he thought the union, the United Federation of Teachers, should be included in efforts to reform the system and said that people who try to "demonize" the union were seeking a simplistic answer to a complex problem. He said that teachers should be paid more, but added that he would push to speed up the disciplinary process used to remove poor teachers. 
But, in the interview, he said that he would try to revamp poorly performing schools by consulting with nearly every "stake-holder" in the field -- calling on teachers, parents, administrators, legislators, the construction industry and others to map out a plan, and set a timetable for improvements. 
If the economy should slow further, Mr. Hevesi said, he would try to exempt the schools, along with the police and the Fire Department, from budget cuts. But he declined to say which areas he would cut, saying that it was "completely theoretical."
To build more affordable housing, Mr. Hevesi, like some of the other candidates, suggested setting aside the $100 million the city is expected to collect each year in real estate taxes now that the World Trade Center has been sold to a private developer. He said that he would add to that the roughly $50 million the city collects each year in profits from Battery Park City -- money that was always supposed to have been used to build affordable housing but which has more often simply gone into the general fund.
Still, Mr. Hevesi acknowledged that his proposals could change if the economy weakened. "I don't want to suggest that we're going into recession, because I'm not sure that we are," he said. "I think we have to be cautious."
To try to foster job growth, Mr. Hevesi said, he would support the creation of an Office of Science and Technology to help keep Internet companies in the city by helping them find investors and deal with logistical problems. And he suggested that the city should do more to encourage the growing film industry, by helping build more sound stages so that the productions that currently film on location here would be able to stay to film their interior shots.
Mr. Hevesi rejected the suggestion that, as comptroller, he was not critical of Mayor Giuliani, proudly describing their battles over bond refinancing and the city's watershed.
And he said that he would work hard to improve the relations between City Hall and the city's culturally diverse communities. 
"I think the mayor has to have a warm, trusting relationship with the leadership of every ethnic community, starting with the African-American and Latino communities in their diversity," he said. "And that's hard work, that's reaching out, that's hiring the best people from their communities into government so the government looks like the city. And that's an enormous talent bank that's been ignored by the mayor."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Ready for Brazil and Argentina Rescues 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund said today that it was prepared to lend $15 billion to Brazil and speed financial aid for Argentina as concerns rose that the two nations' financial problems had worsened and begun to spread through Latin America.
 The long-term aid packages announced this afternoon came with the blessing of the Bush administration, which has supported several large financial rescues even though administration officials have often said they intend to avoid international bailouts like those arranged in the Clinton administration. 
 Troubles in Argentina, Brazil and another recent aid recipient, Turkey, are reminiscent of the financial contagion that spread throughout the developing world in the late 1990's. 
Although some economists say the situation is less serious this time, emerging markets are finding it difficult to stoke growth through exports or attract high levels of foreign investment, with the United States, Europe and Japan all suffering slow growth or outright recession. 
Officials of the monetary fund and the Bush administration have said they are especially wary about the continued slide of Argentina, which received hefty multilateral loans that totaled $13.7 billion late last year but has failed to break out of a three-year-old recession. Investors are worried that Buenos Aires will default on its $128 billion debt.
Neighboring Brazil, though by most measures economically healthier, has seen its currency, the real, fall sharply against the dollar, making its sizable foreign debt harder to repay and leading the central bank to raise interest rates.
The managing director of the I.M.F., Horst Kohler, said the fund was ready to accelerate $1.2 billion in aid to Argentina. The money was already included in the earlier aid package, but by changing the terms of the package and speeding up the loan, the fund and the United States effectively acknowledge that the situation there has deteriorated.
The commitment to provide the $15 billion line of credit to Brazil, a surprise, represents the second time in three years that Brazil has successfully appealed for a multi-year emergency program. Mr. Kohler said Brazil could begin receiving loans next month, with the first installment totaling $4.6 billion.
The monetary fund organized a $41 billion rescue package for Brazil in late 1998. Until recently, that program had been viewed as a success, and it had been scheduled to end this year. But a team of Brazilian economic officials has been in Washington for more than a week meeting with officials from the monetary fund, the World Bank and the United States Treasury Department to discuss ways to extend the program.
Administration officials appeared to be fully supporting the new packages. President Bush discussed Latin American problems today with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain, the White House said. The administration sent Treasury Under Secretary John Taylor to Buenos Aires for consultations.
In a statement late today, Mr. Taylor called his talks fruitful and detailed. "I was happy to hear that the I.M.F. has recommended an accelerated disbursement to Argentina," he said.
As recently as last month, however, administration officials had expressed reluctance to provide more aid. Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, said Argentina needed to take steps domestically to improve its economy, viewed at the time as a rejection of the requests for fresh loans.
The Brazil package is the largest single emergency aid plan approved in the Bush administration. It may help restore investor confidence there when markets reopen on Monday. Such multilateral aid is intended to instill faith that the country will not default on its foreign debt, and officials obviously hope that sentiment will change so that Brazil will not be forced to draw on the aid.
"The Brazilian authorities are strengthening fiscal and monetary policies and implementing their structural reform agenda in the face of a difficult external environment," Mr. Kohler said.
Argentina's problems are more entrenched. It has not adhered fully to the terms of the aid package that it received late last year, and it shows few signs of being able to meet its commitments, including a promise to eliminate its budget deficit. But the pressure to continue lending is intense, in part because of the threat that a sudden default would send shock waves through Brazil and other neighbors.
Argentina has pushed the fund to provide an additional $6 billion in loans. It received just a pledge to speed up the committed loans. That violates an unwritten rule of international bailouts, that they are of limited use unless they give the markets a pleasant surprise.
While the aid package was smaller than Argentina had wanted, the White House said Mr. Bush endorsed the Argentine government's austerity programs, calling it the best way to stabilize the nation's economy.

HEADLINE: SENATE APPROVES FARM SUBSIDY BILL PRESIDENT BACKED 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 

 BODY:
The Senate's Democratic leaders bowed to a White House veto threat today and approved a farm-aid bill that contained $2 billion less than Democrats wanted, offering a preview of the far more divisive budget battles expected this fall.
 The struggle over the agriculture bill turned bitter in its final hours, with Democrats accusing the White House of abandoning farmers who have been hit hard by a drop in commodities prices. 
 Democrats said they had little choice but to approve a Republican $5.5 billion farm bill -- rather than the $7.5 billion Democratic bill that Mr. Bush had threatened to veto -- after they lost a procedural vote that would have allowed quick passage of the more generous subsidy plan. 
"The gun was held to our heads and the White House refused to compromise," said Senator Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat who heads the Senate Agriculture Committee.
President Bush welcomed the Senate's voice vote to approve the $5.5 billion bill as "a victory for our nation's farmers at a time when they need it the most."
The impasse had threatened to delay the Senate's traditional August recess, which will now begin as schedule on Saturday; the House began its recess on Thursday. As members of Congress jammed airports and train stations to begin their summer break, Mr. Bush made final preparations for his departure this weekend for an extended vacation at his ranch in Crawford, Tex.
The president and members of Congress will now have about a month to rest up before returning to the capital for what is expected to be one of the most rancorous budget debates in several years.
Later this month, government analysts are expected to release projections showing that the federal budget surplus will be much smaller than they had forecast only weeks ago.
The projections are expected to attribute the decline in the surplus to the faltering economy and to the $1.3 trillion tax-cut package that Mr. Bush pushed through Congress this spring.
The new findings would leave Congress and the White House haggling for months about a variety of unpalatable options -- from cuts in popular government programs, to raids on the Social Security and Medicare trust funds, to a drastic rethinking of Mr. Bush's plans to increase spending at the Pentagon.
"Lady luck seems to have taken a hike," said Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. Mr. Byrd, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, warned today of the possibility of a "13-car pileup" in the budget process this fall. 
"Because of the flashy tax cut and a sluggish economy, we are poised to spend the Medicare surpluses, disrupt our debt-retirement efforts and dive right back into the deficit doldrums," Mr. Byrd said on the Senate floor.
Joyous over other legislative triumphs this week in House votes on patients' rights and energy policy, the White House suggested that today's Senate vote on the farm bill was a sign that fiscal discipline might be taking hold in Washington at Mr. Bush's prodding, and that a balanced budget remained in reach.
The White House and Republican supporters of the agriculture bill said there was no need for larger subsidies because some livestock and crop prices had increased in recent months, easing what had been a crisis for many farmers.
"I praise the Senate for agreeing to the House bill and look forward to signing this helpful measure into law," Mr. Bush said.
There were no similar words of praise for the president from Senate Democratic leaders, who appeared startled by Mr. Bush's recent string of victories on Capitol Hill after several weeks in which the president seemed disengaged from major policy issues before Congress.
The Senate debate today over the $2 billion difference between the rival agriculture bills gave a hint of the struggles -- and the rhetorical venom -- to come.
While conceding defeat on the issue for now, Democrats said that the White House's refusal to support $2 billion more in farm aid was proof of the Bush administration's cold-heartedness.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, said he would fight to find the extra money for farmers when the Senate returns next month, despite the veto threats. He described Mr. Bush as willing to expand government programs only so long as they benefited his wealthy corporate supporters.
"If it's an oil company, he'll spend money," Mr. Daschle said. "But when you want to give additional money for agriculture or when you fight for additional resources for education, the president says there's nothing there, we can't commit the resources. Well, that dichotomy is one that's not lost on the American people."
Senator Harkin said the bill that was passed today, which originated in the Republican-controlled House, was "totally inadequate to meet the needs of our farmers across the country." He said the White House was willing to provide farmers with "just enough to keep them in the basement."
Though the subsidies in the bill were labeled as emergency aid, they have in fact become routine in the five years since Congress passed legislation that was intended to end farm subsidy programs that date to the 1930's and 1940's.
Ending the subsidies has proved impossible in the face of intense pressure from lobbyists for farmers and agribusiness companies.
And so each year, Congress approves a bill offering "emergency" aid to farmers: $7.1 billion last year, $8.6 billion in 1999 and $5.7 billion in 1998. This year's aid level, $5.5 billion, is about a fifth smaller than last year's, which Republicans said was appropriate given the recent increase in some farm prices.
"Obviously we've had good livestock prices across the board, milk prices have been fairly good recently and even on the grains, we've seen some slight increase in prices," Ann M. Veneman, the secretary of agriculture, said. "I would say there's some easing of the downturn."

HEADLINE: A Focus on Management as the City Heads Into an Unsure Economic Future 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with Alan G. Hevesi, the comptroller and a Democratic candidate for mayor. The interview was conducted by editors and reporters of The New York Times, and it was the last in a series of interviews with the major candidates.

Q. Four candidates on the Democratic side, all familiar, all experienced in politics. What are the stakes here? Why should people get interested?

A. . . . First of all, there are differences here and there, are choices that are quite dramatic, choices to be made in this election. I intend, as mayor, to offer what's the best of Rudy Giuliani without the worst, to govern in a way that's very positive, as he has in some respects, and to abandon or reject some of the style and decisions that he has made that have been hurtful to the people of this city.
I also believe this is one city and that it is not helpful, that it is divisive, to define it as something else, as two cities. I fully appreciate how complex and diverse the city is. . . .

Q. May I stop you ----

A. Yeah.

Q. ---- and push you back a couple of steps? You said you would take the best of Rudy Giuliani and reject the worst. Tell us in specific terms what you would do that reflects the best and what you would do that rejects the worst.

A. O.K., giving credit where it's due, I think Rudy's major long-term contribution for the city is to have shattered the myth that you can't govern New York, that if you've got the smarts and you've got the strength, you can govern New York. It's very hard, it's very tough, but you can do that. . . .
Rudy's very smart, he's focused. He gets enormous credit for the reduction in crime, which is a baseline change and shift in the city, the 72-percent reduction in the murder rates I think has been a tremendous boon to the city. It's tremendously important, and has to be sustained. . . .
However, and there are huge howevers, stylistically my view of Rudy Giuliani is that he has only one M.O. He decides on a public policy; he doesn't do it by consensus, he doesn't do it by bringing in the best and most knowledgeable people in the city, which is an enormous talent bank. And he makes the decision and he single focuses, which is a strength and then it's a weakness because his only M.O. is if you disagree with him, he fights with you and he tries to humiliate you. . . .

Q. Do you have other things beyond style? In other words, how would a Hevesi ----

A. Yes, I think his unwillingness to deal with public education, I think, is a very serious criticism that I would make of him. . . . Obviously there were some positive changes in the public school system. But I think what the mayor did was systematically create the impression that he was powerless to affect school policy when it's not true. And when he had to, he affected school policy. . . .
The issue is smaller schools and paying teachers sufficiently so we can deal with the shortage of teachers. You've got 21,000 teachers who are eligible to retire. What induces them to stay on when we have 85,000 kids right now who don't have classrooms and the number keeps growing because the city is a magnet? Where is the program to train parents to navigate the school system, to have expectations for their kids, to help with homework, create an environment in the home? That's a critical variable at any learning process.
Where is the longer school day? Where are the management techniques? I mean, this idea of overcrowding with the Board of Education, whose only answer is give us $11 billion, we'll build new schools. Well, you've got to be a little bit creative as a manager. . . .

Q. What do you think of the teachers?

A. I think there are some great teachers and some terrible teachers. And if you talk about the union itself, my attitude toward the union is I come out of the labor movement, so I have a sort of an appreciation that a labor leader's job is to protect their members. And sometimes I'll disagree with how they do that. But the answer to that is not to demonize the union, for a couple of reasons. I don't think they deserve it. These are professional people. Most teachers are idealists. The starting teachers are working for $31,000 a year, in New York. That's why we're losing a lot of them. . . .

Q. You want to have -- spend more on schools, spend at least the same, more on cops, raise their salaries. Where's it going to come from in this climate?

A. No. 1, hopefully, first, we do have surpluses for this -- for the fiscal year that just ended. And hopefully for this next 12-month period. Two, I think we're going to have to be much more cautious and austere in subsequent budgets. And that means as mayor, the first thing I will do in January is instruct my commissioners, should I be the mayor, to offer budget submissions at the same dollar figure as the year before. That we go into these discussions with an inflation rate saving. And then make the judgments as to where we provide exceptions. . . .

Q. So if you're mayor, can New Yorkers expect, in three or four or five years, either substantial cuts in services or increases in taxes or some combination of those things?

A. If the economy goes sour, they could expect that from whoever the mayor is. I think that's the reality. That's what you expected when we were in recession. That's what you expected with Rudy Giuliani. There were dramatic reductions in services in the first two years of the Giuliani administration. Hopefully that doesn't happen. . . .

Q. What are your priorities for cuts?

A. The reason I'm not itemizing now is, No. 1, it's all theoretical. Lots of people get upset. I think the first cut would be, with some exceptions like police, fire and public schools, probably start with an across-the-board strategy that everybody has to come up with plans to live within the number figures from the prior year as a baseline. . . .

Q. Would any services be inviolate from cuts? Would you take any and say, "No matter what happens, I'm not going to touch this service?"

A. Yes, policing -- although there are reforms internally that you could make that will offset some of the losses. And schools is driven by law. If you have more kids in the schools, you have to have teachers and classrooms.

Q. Taxes in an austere period -- are you open to increases if necessary?

A. All I wish to suggest is if we needed to, I would reestablish that income tax surcharge.

Q. But you're not ruling out any other tax increases, depending on the situation of the economy?

A. You just absolutely don't want to do that, but you don't rule out anything. You never ever rule out anything. Anybody who rules it out is not telling you the truth. You don't know what the circumstances -- how bad does it get. But you make every effort to avoid across-the-board tax increases. . . .

Q. How do you respond to people who might suggest that sometimes you get too caught up in the minutia, percentages of debt, the different sections of the budget, and that you don't have necessarily broader thoughts about policy and the effect of the policy on the different areas of government on the citizens?

A. I don't know who those people are, I've never heard that. I think that that's the claim of someone who is not knowledgeable about government. That somebody who is knowledgeable ----

Q. The mayor says that about you at times, that you're lost in your budget numbers and that you don't really understand the broader picture.

A. No, the mayor's purpose in doing that is to avoid whatever the criticism I'm making. It's a bit called diversion. He either says that or he says, "Oh, you're being political." He said you're being political about 1,100 times in his term. Being political means they're criticizing me, they're really right. I have no answer to it, but I've got to respond in some way. I mean, that's nonsense.
I've just outlined for you a global view of this city, where we ought to be going. I haven't even gotten into detail about how we ought to interact as a people in the context of our ethnic diversity. And there again I'll be a critic of the mayor. I think the mayor has to have a warm, trusting relationship with the leadership of every ethnic community, starting with the African-American and Latino communities in their diversity, or the complex communities. And that's hard work, that's reaching out, that's hiring the best people from their communities into government so the government looks like the city. And that's an enormous talent bank that's been ignored by the mayor. . . .

Q. Are there people, though, who work for him, say, Commissioner Kerik, who seemed to give the mayor credit for some of the policing in the city, or Chancellor Levy, who you might keep in your administration if you were elected?

A. Everything's open. I think Kerik's done a good job. I like Harold Levy. I'm carefully not identifying a short list of people I would hire, that's the ultimate -- I'm just not prepared to do that until I get elected. . . .

Q. You like Harold Levy?

A. I like Harold Levy.

Q. Does that mean you think he's done a good job?

A. I think on many fronts he's skillful and has done a good job. I think he probably shouldn't have mixed into the politics. . . .

Q. And your view is that if the mayor were a different person, then the current structure, the Board of Ed., a chancellor, could exist, that they should stay? . . .

A. What I would seek to do is have an 11-member board -- I proposed this seven or eight months ago -- an 11-member board, six appointed by the mayor, with one major additional variable that's different. Which is, each of the 11 members of this board would have their credentials fixed in statute. They wouldn't be the mayor's friend or crony or deputy mayor. They would have to have some established credential that allows them to contribute expertise to the job of the board, which I would also restrict and define. . . .

Q. Let me take you back to policing. All the candidates have professed admiration for Rudy Giuliani's police management. But when you scratch the surface, they often would do things very differently. . . .They aren't so happy with a lot of quality-of-life initiatives. Where do you stand on the particulars?

A. . . . I think now it's a question of, on the margins, continuing to reduce the crime rates; we want to keep doing that. But you do that by heavier doses of prevention. That's community policing, that's requiring precinct commanders to be in regular, institutionalized contact with community leaders, church leaders, elected officials to develop a focus, to develop priorities, to develop strategies. It's to put cops on the beat who have good relationships with the store owners and with the local community groups so that there's an exchange of information so there's a trust. It's establishing that the behavior of the police is no less aggressive than it was, but aggressive when it's necessary, not aggressive routinely, which causes a great deal of tension and friction and suspicion, particularly in the minority communities. It means fewer street sweeps probably. It means shifting -- it could be the same tactics, but on a precinct level.
Now, those are decisions that I don't make as mayor: my commissioner makes, his commanders make, the community leaders make. We create a climate where they can do that. 
My style of management, by the way, is not to tell my investment bankers or the lawyers who deal with the claims operation how to make the specific decision. I create the climate where they can use their expertise, because they're much more expert than I am in running their operations. . . .

Q. Do you believe the police deserve a raise beyond what the uniform coalition has bargained for?

A. Yeah, probably. Yes, I do.

Q. Substantially more?

A. Yeah, and again, don't hold me to numbers because I don't want to get into negotiations through this on-the-record interview. But here's a Police Department. If you believe in performance standards, however that's measured, the Police Department of the City of New York has done an extraordinary job in terms of performance, it really has over time. . . .

Q. We've spent a lot of time, understandably, talking about public safety, talking about education. Let's say you think those are the first two most important things. What's three, four and five?

A. Job growth. Developing strategies to sustain jobs and industry in the city and encourage new industry to come to the city. It is -- the resources we get to meet our mission come from the wealth in the city. When Wall Street pays out $13 billion in bonuses, we tax that. That pays for case managers and teachers and cops and firefighters. And that is -- let me phrase it this way: information technology and the revolution we're going through is New York City's great opportunity. It's also a great danger. The opportunity is we're smarter than anybody, we'll find a way to profit from somebody's new invention. If they didn't invent it here, they'll bring it here to market it, they'll bring it here to do the I.P.O., they'll bring it here to hire the lawyers to beat the I.R.S. We'll profit from it.
The danger is, however, for example with Wall Street, no Wall Street firm with modern technology needs to be in New York. They can be in Boise, Idaho or Fiji. That's not the threat. The threat is they take one stop on the PATH train out to Jersey.

Q. Has your campaign been fair? There's obviously assertions that you have not properly charged services to the cost of the campaign, the Campaign Finance Board as of Monday meets to decide whether or not to give you matching funds. . . .

A. The answer is I don't know. They're doing an audit of our campaign. They're doing audits of every campaign. Most of the time these audits in the past with every campaign have found a problem here or a problem there or a technical ignoring of some provision or they come up with a new interpretation. I know former candidates for mayor, there's an incumbent mayor that has had huge fines. Is there a willful intent on it? The answer is no.

Q. An important issue we haven't touched is housing. Everybody agrees there's not enough of it and it's too expensive. Do you lean toward greater use of city housing subsidies to create government, in essence, government housing?

A. . . . What we have proposed is to amortize the debt using some revenue streams that either exist, which I'll mention, or that are potentially brand new. It's better to be lucky than good.

Q. Are you talking about the World Trade Center?

A. The World Trade Center, yeah. And my understanding -- here's the World Trade Center run by the Port Authority, pays the city a fee in lieu of taxes, pilots, payments in lieu of taxes of $30 million. And that when Silverstein management company takes over, that they're going to pay real estate taxes of about $100 million. So that's $70 million new money for the city.
Battery Park City . . . throws off a profit that's approaching $50 million, each year, that comes to the city. The mayor puts that in the general fund. I think if you take that plus the $70 million new or the $100 million total from the World Trade Center plus the $50 million, amortize it -- and by the way the $50 million goes up each year -- it's $37 million, it's $41 million -- that you have right there a billion and a half dollars in a housing trust fund. . . .

HEADLINE: Q & A; 
Reading Statistical Tea Leaves

BYLINE:  By Karen W. Arenson; Karen W. Arenson covers higher education for The Times.

 BODY:
Harold Hodgkinson likes to say that "demography is destiny." As a demographer focused on education, he has looked at how births, ethnic backgrounds, family income and other factors shape education. He is convinced that careful scrutiny of such data can lead to better education policy. A former dean at Simmons and Bard colleges, Dr. Hodgkinson led the National Institute of Education under President Gerald R. Ford. Since 1987, he has directed the Center for Demographic Policy at the Institute for Educational Leadership in Washington. 
 What is the most important demographic trend affecting higher education? 
 The No. 1 demographic change is probably the increase in ethnic diversity in America. If you look 20 years out, 63 percent of the new population growth in the United States will be Hispanic and Asian. And virtually all of the diversity in America is concentrated in 10 states. Hispanics are now the largest minority group in the United States, and 34 percent of them live in California, 19 percent in Texas, 10 percent in New York and 7 percent in Florida. All of the other states are under 5 percent. Of the Asian population in America, nearly half live in three metropolitan areas, San Francisco, Los Angeles and New York. And 75 percent of the black population is in the Southeast and the Mississippi Delta. 
What does that mean for colleges?
There is a move afoot to have every college be a mirror of the national population distribution. Given that 80 percent of kids going to college do so in their own state, looking like the country as a whole becomes a challenge in a state where minorities are 10 percent of the population. It also raises the issue of whether you should have the same proportion of minority faculty. The recruitment of minority faculty becomes a real crisis, because graduate schools are not turning out that many minority Ph.D.'s. One area where there will be a real problem is in developing new teachers. There has been a fairly pervasive decline in the number of blacks and Hispanics majoring in education -- a decline of about 30 percent.
You say you like demographics because population trends are predictable. Have there been any surprises in the last 20 years?
There was only one surprise: the percentage of children living below the poverty line. 
The strong economy pushed it down somewhat in recent years, but for decades the number was about 20 percent of American children. Any lessons there for colleges and universities?
For the lowest 20 percent, the amount of household income required to send children to college has increased, while their income has not increased at all. Tuition as a proportion of income has risen. But as we look at programs to help the poor, we have to remember that they are not all minorities. We tend to associate poverty mostly with minorities. But the largest number of poor children are white. Of the 14 million poor children in 1999, 8.9 million were white, 4 million were black and 3.9 million were Hispanic. But the children in poverty represented 16 percent of all white children, 37 percent of all black children and 36 percent of Hispanic children. 
What are some of the other demographic trends? 
People are moving much more frequently. About 43 million Americans move every year. That means people are changing jobs, and employers need to know who they are and what they can do. So they need a piece of paper -- a college diploma or a certificate stating their skills. That is putting pressure on universities and colleges for those pieces of paper to mean the same thing. But there is almost no way you can guarantee that they do. It will only be a matter of time before states require tests to show what students have learned in college. But that would be terrible. 
Did anyone predict there would be so many adult students?
Nobody in 1980 assumed that the number of adults going to college would be so high today. Of the 15 million students in college, almost half of them are adults with kids and jobs. The Joe College stereotype -- the 18- to-22-year-old full-time student in residence on a campus -- accounts for only 20 percent of the 15 million students. 
Has the increase in older students run its course, or do you think it will continue?
I think it will continue. A lot of people are beginning to come back to higher education for a capstone experience in their 40's, 50's and 60's. Not for a better job, but for a vindication of their life. I was speaking at a commencement a few months ago and an older man walked across the stage to receive his doctoral degree. Someone shouted out, "Way to go, grandpa." I just love it. There is no reason to think that higher education was designed solely for the post-pubescent adolescent.
What does that mean for colleges faced with serving such students?
Older students have different needs. A whole lot of 30- and 40-year-olds have been out of education a long time. They may have a lot of innate smarts, but they don't remember the quadratic equation. So a lot of remedial education is to get 40-year-olds to remember how to write a good theme, and that is fine.
Many of the immigrants who come to the United States count on higher education to help them make it. How well does it work for them?
American higher education performs a unique function. No other country takes such a diverse group of people and turns them into the middle class. In the 1900's, it worked for Italians, Germans, French and English-speaking immigrants. Now it is working for Koreans and the Hmong. It is even working for the black population that is already here. Twenty percent of black households now have a higher income than the average for white households. That's never been true before. The mobility machine is clicking along like it should. We're very cynical, especially about our education system. But we need some appreciation for the kind of miracle we accomplish that doesn't happen in other countries -- it's all due to our system of education. 
So is college really available to all?
The percentage of college students who are minorities is virtually the same in every state as the percentage of high school students who are minorities. In California, for example, 54 percent of high school graduates are minorities, while 53 percent of college students are minorities. In Minnesota, 10 percent of high school graduates are minorities, while 9 percent of college students are minorities.
If you had a billion dollars to invest in education, how would you spend it?
I would spend most of it on the years before college, not on colleges. Money spent on Head Start and Trio and other precollege programs saves lots of money later on. To remediate someone at age 20 when their last 14 years were misused is really a chore. It can be done. But it is not efficient. College is really the icing on the cake.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Juice in Dry Statistics" shows the U.S. public high school graduation rates and college continuation rates in 1998, by state. (Source: Thomas G. Mortenson, Postsecondary Education Opportunity)
