LENGTH: 4259 words

HEADLINE: Volunteers on Vacation 

BYLINE:  By Randy Kennedy; Randy Kennedy, a reporter for The Times, writes the Tunnel Vision column in the Metro Section.

DATELINE: Mongouge, St. Lucia 

 BODY:
A young teacher sat atop a windswept ridge on this Caribbean island and read to a group of student volunteers part of the stirring speech that Robert F. Kennedy delivered to an earlier generation of students at the University of California in 1966:
 "You live in the most privileged nation on earth. You are the most privileged citizens of that privileged nation. . . . You can use your enormous privilege and opportunity to seek purely private pleasure and gain. But history will judge you, and as the years pass, you will ultimately judge yourself, on the extent to which you have used your gifts to lighten and enrich the lives of your fellow man." 
 Considering the setting, it was hard to keep from wondering whether this was quite what Kennedy had in mind. 
In the distance, behind the teacher and the students, the blue Caribbean shimmered. Set off against it like a Turner seascape was the grandeur of Gros Piton, one of two volcanic peaks that make St. Lucia probably the most picturesque tourist destination in the Caribbean.
The families of the 19 students, who had come from high schools around the United States, had paid some $3,500, plus at least $700 in airfare, to send the teenagers to this island for four weeks with an international community service organization called Global Routes.
Before traveling to Mongouge, a rural village where they would live for two and a half weeks to help build a community center for older residents, the students spent a week getting used to the island at Balenbouche Estate, an inn on a beautiful, wooded former sugar plantation that overlooks the ocean. The students hiked and swam beneath a waterfall and snacked on passion fruit from a farmer's trees.
And as soon as they finished with their volunteer project, they would spend the remaining days having what the brochure described as "fun, adventure and reflection," snorkeling, sailing and sightseeing on nearby Martinique.
Even after reading the enticing brochures back home, the students seemed a little surprised that helping the world was turning out to be so, well, alluring.
"It's been a lot cozier than I thought," said Kate Wheatcroft, 16, from Westboro, Mass. "I thought we were just going to be eating rice and beans."
This is not to suggest that what the students experienced was anything like the Caribbean vacations many had been on with their parents. In the village, a good number of the students lived in cinderblock homes with no running water, and many were seeing poverty up close for the first time. Even at their sugar plantation retreat, they had no air-conditioning, no hot water for their showers and armies of fire ants to fend off.
But their time on the island was at least as many parts exotic, multicultural summer camp as it was Peace Corps. And it is those two ingredients, in a wide variety of proportions, that are fueling a growing cottage industry for affluent high school students who -- instead of packing off to camp or to Europe with mom and dad -- want to spend their summers bettering themselves (and in many cases their college applications) by helping to better the world.
Such summer programs are doing more than simply helping high school students find new ways to perform community service, which is often required by their schools. They are also doing more than adding a fancy new international twist to candy striping or pitching in at the local soup kitchen.
They are, in essence, creating a new philosophy for the next generation about how to exercise global concern. Yes, you are privileged and you should use your gifts to help others around the world. But there is no reason not to have fun and adventure and some degree of American comfort at the same time. Yes, it is a good thing to help build a community center or clear jungle for a soccer field. But that does not mean you shouldn't spend your money -- usually a much larger sum than you are giving to the volunteer project -- to relax and sightsee while you are there, to go elephant riding while in Nepal or on safari in Kenya.
"It's really hard to look at this as a kind of junior Peace Corps," said Sandy Bass, editor and publisher of Private School Insider, a monthly newsletter that reports on schools in the New York region. "It's different. But maybe it's the only way it will work. Many of these kids are not going to go to another country just to sleep on the ground and work all day."
Companies that arrange foreign trips with time devoted to volunteerism have grown from a mere handful in the late 1980's to more than 50 today, with hundreds of excursions every summer, some costing up to $6,000 for six weeks. The trend has been spurred partly by the heavy emphasis American high schools now place on volunteerism -- also called service learning -- as an important element of secondary education. And the programs seem to be where many students are looking to find that element. The organizations, both nonprofit and commercial, provide not only the experience but also something almost as important: certificates attesting to the number of hours spent volunteering. 
The trips, especially to more exotic locales like Southeast Asia and Africa, have become the summer thing to do, according to the students in St. Lucia. "It's a really popular trend where I live in Connecticut," said Amanda Listfield, 16, from Weston, Conn., a boarding student at the Hill School in Pottstown, Pa.
There is a great deal of disagreement among educators over whether these kinds of programs truly teach students the value of volunteerism or simply provide them with glorified vacations. That debate echoes the broader discussion over whether community service should be required at all.
Judging by the thousands of applications this summer for trips from Tortola to Tanzania, students do not seem to be as concerned about the questions.
"When people go to Africa, one of the first things they think of is a safari," said Kenneth Hahn, a director of Global Routes, a nonprofit organization based in Berkeley, Calif., that began in 1986 by taking one group of students to Kenya and this summer has 18 groups visiting 13 countries. "It would be a bit of a raw deal to go all the way to Africa and not get that sense of that part of Kenya," said Mr. Hahn, whose organization is one of the most respected in the field.
He added that the programs' creators view the cultural aspects -- especially the time students spend living in villagers' homes, learning about language and values and teaching a bit about their own -- to be as important, if not more, than the labor and money they contribute. The tourism and adventure elements that usually bookend every trip are intended to be a part of that cultural education, too.
"The way we look at it is frosting on the cake," he said. "They've worked very hard to make their cake, and then they get to eat a little frosting."
Whoa, hot dogs and French fries!"
It was a breezy and balmy Saturday afternoon, July 7, the fifth and last day of orientation at the sugar plantation for the students who had traveled to St. Lucia.
The next morning, they would load up their backpacks and suitcases and move several miles to the three rural villages -- Mongouge, Morne Sion and Ponyon -- that would be home away from home until almost the end of the month.
There was a low-volume hum of anxiety about what was to come. An exercise the previous night had presented the group, composed of 15 girls and 4 boys, with some uncomfortable cultural situations they might encounter with their new neighbors: "A community member who is extremely helpful every day on the work site is asking you to marry him every day." ("Are they really going to ask you to marry them?" asked one girl.) 
So it was perhaps fitting that their next-to-last meal before leaving was so all-American. The dogs and fries were served on the veranda of the estate house, a genteel 18th-century French manor surrounded by flaming-red Flamboyant trees and ambling horses.
The majority of students who gathered around the tables were from New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania. Most attended suburban public schools, although six went to private schools, including two boarding schools. They were, by and large, upper middle class, though three described themselves as middle class. There was one African-American and one Asian-American among them. And their parents were generally well-paid professionals -- lawyers, doctors, publishers, architects -- though there was a cook, a security guard and a teacher.
About three-quarters of their schools required community service hours, and nearly all of the students had taken part in volunteer projects at home -- some minor, some impressive. A few had traveled within the United States for volunteer projects like Habitat for Humanity and a couple had made this kind of trip before. Most said volunteerism was an important part of their lives.
But college, clearly, was on the minds of nearly every student. On the wish lists were destinations ranging from Stanford, Columbia and other highly competitive universities to small liberal arts colleges and state schools. 
Most took pains to stress that their main reason for taking the trip was not to make themselves more attractive to colleges. And anyone who did it just for that reason, they said, was not going to fool any college admissions officer. "If any club in school has the name 'leader' or 'service' on it, everybody's in it because they think it will look good on college applications, and I'm just sick of things like that," said Kate Wheatcroft. 
But the students said they believed that community service, be it just down the road or in Dominica, would help present them as more fully rounded applicants. 
"My college adviser said that community service is going to be my hook," said Sean Chan, 17, who attends Lawrenceville, a prestigious boarding school in southern New Jersey, and who has been on two other Global Routes trips. (He said he wants to make a career of running such programs.)
Those students on their first foreign service trip said they had chosen St. Lucia because they saw it as a perfect introduction to helping the world: tropical, fun, beautiful, but also a place where there was poverty and a culture at least somewhat unlike their own. One 17-year-old girl had spent the summer before in France with another service organization, Global Works, sprucing up an archeological site. She said the culture was not much different, and she hadn't worked very hard -- "Mostly, it just ended up being digging weeds."
Another student, Alison Herland, 17, from Clarks Summit, Pa., said she had originally wanted to go to Thailand on a Global Routes program that would have cost about $6,000. But she had college visits to make during the summer -- New York University, Tulane and Boston University are among her top choices -- so she needed a shorter trip.
"And also, I think that the Caribbean is beautiful and the culture is different," she said. "Not so different, but enough to get a kind of a culture shock."
The culture shocks that St. Lucia administered as the students began the volunteer portion of their trip were of the kind that seem increasingly more common in a postmodern world. Some of the shocks, in fact, were not from St. Lucian culture at all but from their own, reflected back at them.
For example, St. Lucians love reggae and calypso and soca music. It turns out they also love American country-and-western music. And so, as the students began their first scorching day mixing cement in tiny Mongouge, they were exposed to a strange new music that most had never listened to before: Dolly Parton, George Jones and Merle Haggard blasting out of the sound system from a nearby house. ("While you're cheatin' on me," sang the Louvin Brothers, "I'm praying for you.")
The modest local homes, in which the students were living in groups of twos and threes, were also an unexpected mix of the crude and the comfortable, with elements of privation in one room and big American appliances in another. There was poverty, undeniably, but not the desperate kind that Derek Walcott, the Nobel Prize-winning poet, mentions in his writings about growing up on St. Lucia.
Tammi Wyka, from Montvale, N.J., was one of those who had no running water in her house. "The bucket shower was insane," she reported after the first night in the village. "It's not something I want to do again."
But later she mentioned how nice the family's stereo was. "They have the same stereo system I have at home," she said, smiling. "I told them, I'm like, 'Dude, I have that back home!' "
Despite such recognitions, it appeared that the students were clearly learning things about lives very unlike their own. And also about a kind of labor that many had seen before only at a comfortable distance. 
They stacked cinderblocks and lumber and carried bags of cement heavier than some of the girls. They took turns with a wobbly pickax to carve a sewer pit into the rock-hard earth next to the center. They learned how to follow orders from the construction foreman, a somber local man named Lawrence Alphonse. And they saw the beneficiaries of the building they were helping to erect: elderly villagers, on their way up the hill, shaded from the strong sun under their black umbrellas.
Also, of course, because they were high school students, the young volunteers occasionally seemed to be playing their parts in an episode of "Real World."
"Sam, take it off!" the girls yelled as one student, Sam Scott, pulled off his T-shirt.
Because of the $300 that each student had to contribute to the project -- a sum in addition to the price of the trip and that most had solicited from friends and family -- the students seemed much more invested in what they were doing. That money paid for all the supplies and tools to build the center. Perhaps in part because of those contributions, the villagers were very welcoming of the students. (The families who put up students in their homes were also paid for doing so.)
It was the second year that Mongouge and the nearby villages had been host to a group of students from Global Routes. Mary Pierre, a former health aide who serves as unofficial mayor of Mongouge and plays a large role in deciding what projects the villages need -- last year, students built outhouses -- said the students and townspeople got to know one another well in a short time. "When they were leaving, last year, everybody was sharing tears," she said. "The students were very hard-working. I did not expect so much from them."
The students had not known what to expect from the villagers, either, and seemed surprised at how easy it was to fit in. They started picking up phrases in French patois, spoken in rural areas almost as often as English, the official language of the island. They spent their evenings eating dorado and stewed chicken and dasheen -- and sometimes macaroni and cheese -- with their families. And also, usually, watching American sitcoms on television. (Several families have cable.)
The girls who stayed in Mrs. Pierre's home immediately took to calling her mom. And during the first night spent there, local teenage girls braided the American girls' hair into cornrows, a fashion trend that quickly caught on among the girls in the group.
But the group also found that the level of comfort they enjoyed in the community meant learning harsh lessons about how some St. Lucians viewed America, or at least how the St. Lucians thought Americans viewed them.
One night, a local man told some of the students about the time he had spent working in the United States. 
"He said, 'People come here and we're all nice and friendly to you,' " recounted one student, Katrina Reiser, 15, from Lincoln, Mass. "But when he went to America, he said, people were unfriendly and they were racists. He said they were like beasts."
Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., believes programs like the one in St. Lucia can open the eyes of privileged students who would probably not learn much about poverty or see their country from such a critical perspective during a European semester abroad or traveling with their parents. 
But he and many other education officials question whether most community service trips teach the right lessons about volunteerism. Do they serve only to make students feel good about themselves for having accomplished something? Do the programs really teach anything about how the world works?
"The point of a Peace Corps kind of service is that you have something to offer, some special skills or something of value to teach," he said. "And on the learning side, the only programs like this that really work are intensive programs of service and learning that are integrated, such as studying economics while working for a poverty program in some country."
Elizabeth Hollander, executive director of Campus Compact, a coalition of 800 colleges and universities advocating service learning, said that ideal community service is "an opportunity to be active in the community and to reflect on the conditions you're seeing in the community and asking yourself the larger questions."
"To us," she said, "the larger questions are: Why do these conditions exist, who should be fixing them and what's my responsibility as an American citizen? It's not just sending them to a place but helping prepare them for what they're going to see, what their role is and how they can be responsible in that role. And what kind of connection to the project is made by the community, so it becomes something that was not just done to them?"
Mr. Botstein said students should first concentrate on community service within their own community. 
"It's not that the Caribbean isn't a good place to go," he said. "Yes, there is poverty in the Caribbean. But for goodness' sake, there's Caribbean poverty right here in the United States."
Calling the trips no more than junkets, he added: "Any student who needs to have this experience to write about in their college essay is not going to get admitted to a first-class university." (Putney Student Travel reprints on its Web site a sampler of admissions essays from happy customers who got into the college of their choice.)
Other college officials say that even the most vacationlike volunteerism program can still teach positive values. "I don't think it's possible to misuse this opportunity," said Peter V. Johnson, senior associate director of undergraduate admissions at Columbia University. "Some students do this because they think it's going to look good on their resume. But even if they do, they're going to derive a benefit from this experience 90 percent of the time."
The proportions of work and play in the programs vary widely. Along the spectrum, Global Routes falls somewhere in the middle, with slightly more time spent working and living in the communities than on recreation, tourism and summer-camp team-building activities.
Other programs, like Amigos de las Americas, which has sent volunteers to Mexico and Central and South America since 1965, charge comparatively modest costs to cover expenses, and participants spend nearly all the time in the community that is being helped.
At the other end of the spectrum is Rustic Pathways, a commercial operation that offers trips to Australia, New Zealand, Africa, Thailand and the Fiji Islands. The company advertises community service "add ons" to its purely recreational trips, in which students can, for example, surf in Fiji for 10 days for $2,195 and then participate in a seven-day community service project in a Fijian village at the end of the trip for an additional $995. The program's Web site calls the project "a community service 'snapshot' in a welcoming, clean and interesting environment." 
Compared to, say, Habitat for Humanity, which provides no recreational extras and costs nothing but a small donation, the community service trips can seem -- and do, to many parents -- very expensive. 
Mr. Hahn says the costs of his organization's trips pay for the staff members who care for the students, the families who lodge them, local transportation, food and insurance policies, as well as for the tourism and recreation portions, like guided hikes, boat trips and safaris. Global Routes, like a handful of other nonprofit programs, helps find grants for some applicants who can't afford the trips, or provides scholarships when space is available.
Some parents believe the companies, many of which visit high schools and arrange "coffee nights" to promote their offerings, simply charge too much for what they provide.
"Why spend all that money to go to some exotic place when there are people you can help right in your own backyard?" said Lynda Ludwigson, whose son, Jake, as a student at the American School in London, had pushed to take a community service trip to Tortola, in the British Virgin Islands. Classmates were going, anxious for every advantage on their college applications. But Jake's parents were skeptical, and he instead spent three weeks last summer tutoring an impoverished Afghani student in a local school. He wrote about the experience in his essay to Georgetown University, where he will start in the fall.
One American School classmate, Matthew Christoph, went to Tortola three summers ago and then to Kenya. "There are so many kids going on these things," he said. Some students went to Tortola for the wrong reasons, he admitted, and a few girls were kicked off the trip, apparently for drinking. But Matthew said he got a lot out of his experiences. "The President of the United States hasn't even been to half the countries these kids have gone to," he added.
For many parents, apparently, the costs of such experiences clearly do not outweigh their benefits. "We get some families that if we double-billed them, I don't think they would notice," said Chris Yager, director and founder of Where There Be Dragons, which runs adventure programs in Asia with an element of community service.
And despite the costs and the questions about their value -- for building better citizens and bolstering college applications -- the movement is showing no signs of slowing down.
"When we started this in 1986, it wasn't any more or less popular than any of our other programs," said Mr. Hahn of Global Routes. "Today we have more students doing community service programs than we have in all of our other travel programs combined."
The students in St. Lucia have no trouble explaining why.
"It feels so good to be doing this," said Alison Herland. Later, she glanced past the rising cinderblock walls they were building to the green mountains and blue waters beyond.
"Look at this view while we're working!"

At Your Service
Scores of companies offer exotic travel for teenagers with a community service component. (If nonprofit, part of the cost may be tax deductible.) Programs, for high school and sometimes college students, tend to run three to six weeks June to August, with applications due by January or February. Web sites offer details.

HEADLINE: Community Schools 

BYLINE:  By Philip Nobel; Philip Nobel is a New York design critic.

DATELINE: Craryville, N.Y. 

 BODY:
On a Friday afternoon toward the end of the school year, the streets were quiet in this rural upstate town. There were two or three cars at the gas station, four at a local diner, and the odd tractor-trailer rolling through the empty fields toward the Massachusetts border, 10 miles away over the crest of the Taconic Hills.
 But in the Taconic Hills Central School, whose sports fields straddle County Route 11A, the community life that seemed lacking elsewhere was in full view. The school's two media centers were filled with researchers young and old. A community room, just inside the public entrance, showed signs of a welcome party for some French exchange students, and later that day it would be host to a local food co-op. The school's "aquatic center" and weight room -- the envy of any big-city health club -- would also open later for public use: $1 for district residents, $2 for everyone else. Preparations were also under way for a summer concert series at the school's 1,000-seat auditorium that can, weather permitting, open into an outdoor public amphitheater built into the front of the school. 
 And all around, the 1,850 students in kindergarten through 12th grade were going about the business of learning in a school that represents a bold new direction in school design. 
The United States is in the sixth year of a school building boom. While budget overruns in New York City have threatened to stall construction, the pace nationally is not expected to slow through 2003, according to the annual education construction report by American School and University, a magazine on school facilities. With so much once-in-a-lifetime municipal financing being applied to school construction -- $36 billion was spent last year, up more than 20 percent from 1999 -- this period will define for decades the shape of the schools that shape young minds. And most new schools, public and private, are being built along the lines of Taconic Hills. 
"About 2,000 new school buildings were built in 2000, and I would say that every single one had to make concessions to the community to get funded," said Joe Agron, the magazine's editor in chief. "It's not a far stretch if you think about it. Seniors don't have school-age kids anymore."
An idea that first emerged in the late 1960's but didn't fly until the 90's, the concept is variously known as community schools, community learning centers, shared facilities or full-service schools. Where older buildings endeavored to create an icon to represent "education" within the community -- but kept that community at bay by creating an insular world of learning within -- these new schools are attempting to bring the life of the community into the building itself.
This can take the form of schools that integrate public libraries, performing-arts centers and recreation centers -- community functions that have long existed informally in schools but are now being expanded with an eye to extracurricular patrons. Municipalities are finding it easier to sell taxpayers on the idea of a school if it gives back something more tangible than education.
"It's a survival thing," Mr. Agron said. "What schools are finding is that the only way they can get a bond act passed is to build in community centers, offer evening classes or open the recreation center to the public."
At Taconic Hills, the integrated community solution helped break a construction impasse that had lasted for nearly 30 years. The site was bought in 1968, but no agreement was reached on what to build or how to finance it until 1997; after 11 other design solutions foundered, the combined approach suggested by J. Louis Turpin of Rhinebeck Architecture and Planning was approved.
"The reality is that schools need to serve the broader community," Mr. Turpin said, "whether it's to fulfill economic or educational needs."
Last year, to free up more classroom space, New York City's chancellor evicted community groups that were not needed for instruction. And in new construction, the city has only dabbled in the trend, segregating common areas in anticipation of public access. But in May, ground was broken in Jamaica, Queens, on the High School for Law Enforcement and Public Safety/Police Athletic League Community Center. The 900-student school, being built on the league's site, is aimed at low-income children interested in law-enforcement careers. While the school and league will not overlap, they will share recreation facilities to get "maximum bang for the buck," says Dan Andrews, spokesman for the Queens borough president, who threw in $5 million in discretionary funds; the league is contributing $4.25 million to the $108 million project.
In Nashville, the Park Avenue Elementary School has spaces for a host of community functions -- a free health clinic, continuing education and recreation as well as a small police post. The hope was for students to learn, by their proximity, to trust the police, but also to add more police presence to a low-income neighborhood. 
Park Avenue and four similar Nashville schools were conceived as part of a larger settlement of a longstanding desegregation court order: along with enhanced educational options and facilities, the community thrust is intended to help level the playing field for inner-city students. "It brings the parents into the schools," said Tracy Libros, director of student assignment services for Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools. "It brings services to people rather than people to services." The downside, she notes, is the expense of running programs not usually found in schools.
Other districts have introduced more commercial services. The Fort Crawford Elementary School in New Kensington, Pa., completed in January 2000, was designed from the ground up to accommodate after-hours use as a business teleconferencing center ($200 an hour, plus line charges). The room, which can be entered without passing through class areas, is set up to receive satellite transmissions and for two-way teleconferencing. During school hours, the technology can be put to use for educational exchanges or virtual field trips. Private industry donated the equipment.
The increase in integrated-service schools concerns some educators. Roger Hart, director of the Children's Environmental Research Group at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, balks at the idea of opening schools to outside functions that could pave the way for the increasing commercialization of schools.
"If it's a need relating to social development in the community, I love that idea," he said. "But if it's purely a business relationship, it could be deleterious -- it's confusing to students. There should be sufficient funding for local schools to survive without turning to business. I get scared when what is clearly the public domain is moved in on by private resources." 
Dr. Hart, co-author of "Cities for Children: Children's Rights, Poverty and Urban Management," ticks off what he thinks should be brought into the discussion: "Who's protecting the neutrality, if you like, of the school? Are the peripheral uses compatible with education and appropriately conceived? There is potentially a problem if there is too much activity not connected to learning going on. There's also good evidence that small schools are better for students, particularly for lower grades."
To accommodate the extra services, multiuse schools tend to be large. At 330,000 square feet -- about the size of a medium-sized shopping mall -- Taconic Hills is the largest public building in its 230-square-mile district. In this rural area, it offers students an alternative to hanging out at the mall.
About a third of the school consists of spaces that are at times available to the public, including the performing arts center. The theater was intended to bring the arts closer to the students but also as a way to appeal to the broader community, which includes an arts-oriented weekend crowd that flocks to this region not far from Tanglewood and the other cultural institutions of western Massachusetts.
"We were a tax bill to them and now we have something to offer," said John T. Oates, the superintendent of schools for the Taconic Hills district, as he showed off the auditorium. "They can enjoy our tennis courts, and our pool, and this theater." 
As the boom in school construction continues, the simple logic of the integrated school -- the economies of scale, the appeal to taxpayers, the perceived benefits to students -- may sway more school committees to put all their eggs in one basket. "There's that adage, 'It takes a village,' "Mr. Turpin said. "How can you do that if you're segregating people from the school?"

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Taconic Hills auditorium opens into a public amphitheater, designed to lure the community into the school but also a concession to get financing. (H. Durston Saylor); Top, the flip side of the performing arts center at Taconic Hills Central High School. Above, young and old mingle at the media center at Park Avenue Elementary School in Nashville. (H. Durston Saylor; Neil Brake for The New York Times)

PERSON: NOBEL, PHILIP

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 3092 words

HEADLINE: A Graphic Life 

BYLINE:  By Peggy Orenstein; Peggy Orenstein is a contributing writer for the magazine and author of "Flux: Women on Sex, Work, Love, Kids and Life in a Half-Changed World."

 BODY:
Bob's diner on Polk Street is just two blocks up from where tourists catch the cable car for a joy ride to downtown San Francisco and just beyond where the hustlers and junkies stroll. Plastic grapes festoon the walls above cracked gray vinyl booths. The chow is strictly short order. In the center of the restaurant, her tweed coat slipping onto the speckled linoleum, a 40-year-old woman sketches in a notebook. When she looks up, time bends. Phoebe Gloeckner has expectant hazel eyes and brown hair shot through with red highlights. She wears round antique spectacles over a small Band-Aid where her 2-year-old accidentally jammed them into the bridge of her nose. She may be an established medical illustrator and mother of two married to a chemistry professor, but she also, quite startlingly, has the face of her 15-year-old alter ego, Minnie, the subject of Gloeckner's semiautobiographical cartoons. Minnie, who was booted from some of the finest Bay Area private schools. Minnie, who was sexually involved with her mother's boyfriend. Minnie, whose best friend dosed her with Quaaludes then traded Minnie's body for more drugs. In fact, if you set the Way Back machine to a quarter-century ago, you could find the teenage Phoebe sitting in this very spot, scribbling in her diary, bearing witness to her life. Bob's was her refuge; safely above the street scene's DMZ, she wasn't likely to run into anyone here who would question what she was writing or why. 
 Now, in 2001, Gloeckner is only visiting her former stomping grounds. She lives on Long Island these days, where she is finishing "Diary of a Teenage Girl," a hybrid between a conventional and graphic novel based on the very journals she penned in this diner. The book mines the same territory as "A Child's Life and Other Stories," Gloeckner's first book, a story collection in cartoon form that R. Crumb says includes "one of the comic book masterpieces of all time." Like Crumb's, Gloeckner's work is challenging stuff, graphic in every sense of the word. But while the images are similarly explicit -- and have raised comparable charges of obscenity -- the context could not be more different. The Minnie stories describe an adolescence that is at once traumatic and picaresque. They explore the power a girl feels in her emerging sexuality as well as the damage inflicted by those who prey upon it. In the process, they raise unsettling questions about vulnerability, desire and the nature of a young woman's victimization. "Phoebe looks square in the face of extremely disturbing subject matter," says Kim Thompson, co-publisher of Fantagraphics Books, the largest publisher of alternative comics. "But she has this illustrative style that's so beautiful. It's like going to a movie that looks like Merchant-Ivory but turns out to have a Charles Bukowski story." 
 Confessional comics are an intriguing, surprisingly supple medium in which to tell young women's stories. Gloeckner is arguably the brightest light among a small cadre of semiautobiographical cartoonists -- including Debbie Drechsler and Julie Doucet -- who are creating some of the edgiest work about young women's lives in any medium. The narratives are often presented as diaries, that quintessential literary form of female adolescence. (There is virtually no tradition of diarists among teenage boys.) Perversely, even their marginalization -- as cartoonists, as literary cartoonists, as female literary cartoonists -- works in these artists' favor. Free from the pressures of the marketplace, they can explore taboo aspects of girls' lives with the illusion of safety; since their work is usually hidden behind racks of "X-Men" in shops that smell like a sweat sock, few people are likely to stumble across it. "They're like what independent films were before they stopped really being independent," says Drechsler, whose collection "Summer of Love" will be released this month. "You have total freedom. Nobody cares what you're doing because nobody's going to make money off of it."
That's how it has been for Gloeckner for years. Some call her a "cartoonist's cartoonist," a backhanded compliment that both acknowledges her exacting skill as an artist and the fact that, even for comics, her work has not sold especially well. "Phoebe is one of the most accomplished artists in terms of mastery of the medium," says Bill Griffith, the creator of Zippy the Pinhead. Griffith was among the first to publish Gloeckner's work, when she was in her late teens. "Her drawing conveys a lot of the underlying feeling of what's going on in the same way a movie can have a shot without dialogue that's a major turning point or a major insight into a character. It's a delicate balancing act. The pictures have to propel the story without overtaking it. That balance -- it's almost a tension -- occurs when a cartoonist is equally good as a writer and artist, and it's very rare."
Richard Grossinger, publisher of North Atlantic Books/Frog Ltd., which put out "A Child's Life," says: "In a perfect world, she would have as large an audience as R. Crumb or Art Spiegelman. She's that good. But we haven't been successful in letting that world know about it."
"Diary of a Teenage Girl," which will be published next spring, could change that. Inspired by, among other things, the illustrated novels of the Victorian period, it takes the form a step further. Instead of a fully illustrated graphic novel, like Spiegelman's "Maus" or Daniel Clowes's "Ghost World," Gloeckner's book is largely text that periodically bursts into comics the way a musical bursts into song: with no warning whatsoever, as if it's normal. Because its raunchier themes are explored through prose rather than through images, "Diary" has a better shot at being picked up by conventional bookstores than "A Child's Life" did. Gloeckner is the first to admit that's an exciting opportunity. She's also the first to question whether it's one she wants. 
In conversation about her work, Phoebe Gloeckner shifts arbitrarily between referring to "Minnie" and "me." "I was so needy," she remembers of herself as a teenager, followed immediately by, "In that sense, there was nothing particularly remarkable about Minnie." Because of the permeable boundary between fact and fiction in Gloeckner's life, I find myself, at times, picking peculiar arguments with her. "One of the things that interests me about Minnie," I say, "is that she is very pretty. We talk a lot about the damage done to girls by unrealistic standards of beauty but not about the vulnerability that comes when you actually meet them." 
Gloeckner replies: "I don't think Minnie was beautiful. I honestly don't."
"Well," I say, "I think she probably was. She turns heads wherever she goes." We both laugh awkwardly at the perversity of speaking in the third person. 
Gloeckner considers this for a moment. "I always hoped people would think I was pretty, but I always felt painfully ugly," she says slowly. "Painfully. Whether that was the reality or not. I know a lot of girls feel that way. I could not deal with my appearance or my sexuality. I just wanted someone to see who I was for real and love me for it. So I would talk to anybody, go anyplace with anybody in the hope that they would see me and help me." She shakes her head. "And I can't even say how I meant that."
Gloeckner is the daughter of a librarian from a blue-collar family (her mother) and an unemployed artist from a blue-nosed one (her dad). They divorced when she was 4. Eight years later, her mother remarried and moved the family from Philadelphia to San Francisco. The early Minnie stories portray a stepfather who was arbitrarily cruel and who leered at Minnie and dropped sexual innuendos. In real life, the marriage quickly deteriorated, and to shield her from the tension, Phoebe was shipped off to an elite boarding school. By the time she returned home at 15, her mother was dating again. 
There is an image that Gloeckner returns to in her work that acts as a kind of pivot point, a defining moment both in her own life and her character's. She drew it in one of her first comics at 16. It appears again, in writing this time, in "Diary of a Teenage Girl." It is not one of the more lurid images in her repertoire, but it may be the most chilling: it shows one of her mother's boyfriends, someone Minnie trusted and admired, running a casual finger across her bare midriff. It is his first tentative crossing of a line, quite literally sending out a feeler to gauge the girl's vulnerability. "When he first made those advances, my initial thought was, 'This is not right,"' she says, "but then I thought, 'Maybe it is and I don't know.' Minnie had been bombarded with adults who had no boundaries and were overtly sexual with children. You get used to that, and at a certain point you think of yourself and value yourself solely as a sexual being."
Whatever tenuous stability Minnie had felt at home crumbled as that initial touch turned into an affair. In "Minnie's 3rd Love, or Nightmare on Polk Street," a story in "A Child's Life," Gloeckner's alter ego is seen on her knees in the laundry room of her apartment building. Next to her is a "Hello Kitty" diary. Minnie looks tearfully up at her lover-surrogate father, on whom she is about to perform oral sex, begging him to tell her he loves her. In her right hand, she clutches a bottle whose label reads, "The kind of good cheap California wine that makes girls cry and perform oral sex on jerks." To escape both her shame and her obsession with her mother's boyfriend, Minnie runs away to Polk Street with another girl, a teenage junkie with whom she falls in love. She takes whatever drugs come her way, then is pimped by the girlfriend for more. "I was in a lot of pain, so I would do anything," Gloeckner says about her own life at that time. "If someone said, 'Shoot up this' or 'Take this pill,' I'd do it. I guess I didn't really care." 
Though Frog Ltd. was eager to publish "A Child's Life," its printers balked. One refused outright, the other agreed, but backed off after staff members objected to the graphic imagery in "Minnie's 3rd Love." Eventually, the second company did print the book after work hours. Gloeckner had caused controversy before: in 1995, British customs officials seized an anthology of comics that included an earlier version of the same story, claiming the laundry-room panel was child pornography. "There's resistance to something that's drawn that wouldn't exist if it were written," says Frog's Richard Grossinger. "If you're talking about child sexual abuse, 'Bastard Out of Carolina' is in many ways harsher than Phoebe's work. If you drew that, you'd be marginalized."
A British judge eventually ruled in favor of the book's distributor, but last year, when "A Child's Life" was confiscated at the French border, there was no such reversal: the book never was allowed into the country (although, interestingly, R. Crumb's comics depicting his sometimes violent sexual fantasies are readily available). "Some people think what I draw is pornography," Gloeckner says. "But there are children who experience this, who have this penis in front of their faces. They see it, so why can't I show it to make the impact clear?" 
It's a question she hasn't fully answered herself. Gloeckner describes her creative process as a wrestling match between the compulsive demands of her own vision and a fear of those who might label it "dirty." There's the voice of her publisher, who has -- no pressure -- mentioned that without the images of erect penises, her books would be easier to market. There's the voice of her mother, who has "not been pleased" with the Minnie stories. There's the voice of herself as a mother, fretful over what her daughters will think when they are old enough to see her work. There's the voice of her own shame. "I'm constantly fighting with it," she says, "But if I censor myself, it makes me feel sick. Actually physically ill." 
Ultimately, Gloeckner says, she has no choice but rigorous honesty, including this: Gloeckner doesn't flinch from the blurry lines between experimentation and exploitation. A panel in "A Child's Life" shows Minnie reading "Lolita." In "Diary," Minnie describes her excitement at provoking desire in adult men in a bar (as well as her revulsion when they respond). She confides the thrill of picking up strangers in Golden Gate Park. And she admits to actively participating in the affair with her mother's boyfriend after he made the first move. Even at her most debased, Minnie sometimes seems to be having fun. As her fellow cartoonist Clowes says: "Phoebe doesn't paint herself as either a hero or as a victim or say that this guy is evil and this guy is good. She's just there in the world as she should be, and you have to interpret the events she depicts." Minnie's complicity doesn't change the fact of her abuse, but it does provide insight into its dynamics. It's a daring subtheme, and it is part of what makes Gloeckner's work ring true, what makes it transcend the genre of most child-abuse memoirs. 
In a way, the European border patrol was onto something -- Gloeckner's cartoons may be devastating, but they can be arousing as well, because that, too, is part of Minnie's experience. The most explicit images threaten to implicate the reader, transforming a sympathetic eye into a voyeuristic one. That quality may be what offends censors and raises red flags among the bookstore buyers who won't carry her work. "Maybe it is titillating," Gloeckner admits. "It can be titillating for the child in a way. But it's also confusing, destructive and horrifying and can be rape and everything else. So to draw things as either black or white is a lie. Because that titillation is in you. I'm not saying it's good, but it's there."
Even so, Gloeckner remains ambivalent, veering in our conversations between self-righteousness and embarrassment, between dreaming of a larger audience and hoping no one she knows will ever see her books. When asked what her suburban neighbors think of her comics, she laughs. "I just tell them I'm a medical illustrator," Gloeckner says. "I don't think they would let their children play with my children if they knew what I drew."
Of course, she's telling this to a reporter from The New York Times, which has a substantial circulation on Long Island. Chances are she's about to be outed. "I know, I know," she groans. "But I haven't lived there that long and I don't know anyone really well. . . . " She trails off for a moment, snared in her own loopy logic. "Well, I don't know how many people will recognize my name," she concludes, weakly. "So I think it's not going to be that bad."
There was no great epiphany, no moment of being scared straight, no hitting bottom, despite how low she sank. Hers was an incremental awakening. At 17, Gloeckner was still prowling Polk Street, shoplifting on the side. She remembers thinking that in another year, if she were caught, she could be jailed, and that scared her. Then there was her grandmother, a doctor back in Philadelphia, whom Gloeckner admired and wanted to emulate. Instead, she seemed to be taking after her father, who had become irretrievably lost in drug and alcohol addiction. And Gloeckner knew she had a gift; even at her lowest ebb, she drew comics on paper bags or in her diary. "They weren't very good, but they sustained me," she says. "I felt good about that part of myself -- and only that part of myself -- but it was something I could feel good about. It made me feel there was some hope that I could do something if I tried." 
She managed to squeak through what she describes as a "school for incorrigibles" and did well enough on her SAT's to enroll at San Francisco State. "I don't know exactly how I made that leap back to normal life," she says. "I wish I did. I suppose that even though I got kicked out of all those private schools, they had given me a sense that there was something else to strive for. Other kids I knew didn't have that." 
Eventually, Gloeckner studied art and medicine, earning a master's in medical illustration. It's a career that suits an artist as meticulous as she. ("It's really hard for me not to fill up every space with crosshatching," she jokes.) But more than that, it's the perfect day job for a person compelled to make the hidden visible, then present it for public display. "I was always aware that the interior was as much a part of my body as the exterior," she says. "I've always done things like try to imagine what it looks like inside when I'm swallowing. Or what it looks like inside when you have sex. So I wanted to understand the interior better. I guess interior life in general."
There is a triptych of Minnie in "a child's Life." In the first drawing, she is eating candy dots, those bits of colored sugar peeled from strips of paper, and looking up at a chevron of migrating birds. In the next, which faces it, she holds a Tootsie Pop. Both are archetypal images of childhood. But turn the page and "Little Minnie" is about to kiss a grown woman, her mouth wet and open, her eyes glazed in anticipation. Is Minnie a child or an adult? Innocent or carnal? "That adult woman is me," Gloeckner says. "I was having a hard time doing the book. I was really nervous about it. So I thought: 'How do I feel about this little girl? Well, I like her, and I want to tell this story for her sake. And I just have to look at it that way and not worry about what people will say.' So that picture is supposed to be me as an adult kissing Minnie. In a sense, it's myself kissing myself. And there is something sexual about it because we're blending in my brain. So I could see that people would interpret it differently." She shrugs. "But that's O.K." 
It may be that you have to be 40 before you can reconcile with 14, before you can reach back in time and offer a consoling embrace. Gloeckner imagines teenage girls would be the natural audience for her work if it were more readily available in conventional bookstores. But for the most part, it doesn't cross their paths. Even so, the dedication of "Diary of a Teenage Girl" reads, "For the girls after they've grown." 
"Although I was exposed to all those things when I was a kid, I don't think everyone should be, even through a book," she says. "So the dedication is hopeful in that sense. It is for girls, but let them stay as ignorant as they can be of these things until they're stronger or know more. Unless, of course, they're forced to grow up too soon."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
T.W.A. Is Slowly Nudged Into Aviation History

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
IN late June, a Trans World Airlines jet rolled out of a hangar in Kansas City, Mo., with a new look. Gone was the red, gold, blue and white of T.W.A.'s old paint scheme. In its place was a polished aluminum fuselage with red, white and blue stripes along its length.
 Apart from the T.W.A. decals on the tail and near the nose, the plane looked as if it belonged to American Airlines. And that was the point. Since AMR Corporation, American's parent, bought T.W.A. in a bankruptcy sale in April for $742 million, it has been working on a grand plan to integrate the two airlines with the least disruption possible. The new design was the latest and most visible sign of many coming changes. 
 Airline mergers are notoriously messy -- as well as expensive -- and the combination of American and T.W.A. will be the biggest in history. When the job is done, American will have 130,000 employees and 900 aircraft, making it the world's largest airline (United previously held that position).
But before that can happen there are literally hundreds of things that need to be changed, from replacing the food carts on T.W.A.'s airplanes to aligning maintenance schedules to standardizing the cockpits. 
American knows how badly things can go wrong. After it bought tiny Reno Air in 1998, its pilots charged that the company had violated their contract and staged an extensive sickout that forced American to cancel thousands of flights.
To avoid disruption, American has adopted a go-slow approach. It has opened its airport clubs to T.W.A. club members and begun moving T.W.A. and American ticket counters and other operations next to each other at some airports. But American estimates that it will be two years or more before T.W.A. is fully integrated. Until then, T.W.A. will operate as a separate airline.
So far, American has received high marks from industry analysts for the way it has handled the process. "They seem to be putting it together pretty well," said Terry Trippler, who follows the airlines from Minneapolis for the Web site OneTravel.com. 
But Mr. Trippler and others say the difficult hurdles are still to come. Perhaps the biggest is scheduled for early December, when American plans to move T.W.A. to the Sabre computer reservation system. Until then, the two airlines cannot really combine schedules or trade in-depth information about passengers because T.W.A. uses a rival system, WorldSpan. 
Three years ago US Airways switched to the Sabre system after months of training. But after the switch was flipped, passengers were still inconvenienced by foulups that were not completely ironed out for months.
Another challenge will be how unions at the two carriers integrate their members. The pay and schedules of pilots and flight attendants are determined by seniority, which a merger can affect. The unions representing the pilots, attendants and mechanics at American gave their blessings to the merger, but they must work out integration schemes with their T.W.A. counterparts.
As these changes happen, T.W.A.'s identity, forged over 76 years, is slowly disappearing. American said it would complete the makeover of T.W.A.'s fleet of 160 planes by April. The new design makes it easy to replace the T.W.A. decal with the familiar AA logo on the tail and "American" near the nose after the interiors and cockpits are converted to American's specifications. American has said that by fall it will have removed seats in all T.W.A. jets to offer the same expanded legroom in economy class now found on American aircraft. 
T.W.A. flights are already circulating the American in-flight magazine and on July 1, they switched over to American's in-flight movies -- an improvement for T.W.A. passengers because American changes its movies twice a month while the cash-strapped T.W.A. was on a monthly schedule.
The two airlines' schedules remain largely unchanged. One of the biggest areas of overlap is in the Caribbean. T.W.A. cut service from Miami, Aruba and the Dominican Republic to Puerto Rico, routes already served by American. It also ended a daily flight from Kennedy Airport to Puerto Rico, leaving 10 daily by the two airlines. T.W.A. also eliminated one of its five daily flights from Boston to Puerto Rico but added one from Boston to the Dominican Republic.
American has not yet decided what changes it will make at T.W.A.'s hub in St. Louis. Because T.W.A. operated only one hub, the airport was congested. Most experts believe that American will reconfigure the schedule and use St. Louis to relieve pressure on its hubs in Chicago and Dallas. 
One thing T.W.A. passengers do not have to worry about is their frequent flier miles. While T.W.A. Aviators miles cannot be used for American flights, T.W.A. passengers can choose to get American AAdvantage miles from T.W.A. flights. Holders of American miles can use them for T.W.A. flights. 
American plans to end the Aviators program Nov. 30. After that, all outstanding Aviators miles will become AAdvantage miles. "The bottom line we give to the Aviators members is your miles are safe," said Mark Abels, a T.W.A. spokesman.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 8-5-01; 
Out of Retirement

BYLINE:  By Nelson W. Aldrich Jr.; Nelson W. Aldrich Jr. is the author of "Old Money" and a contributing editor at Worth magazine.

 BODY:
I was brooding about money the other day, when it occurred to me that my friends and I, most of us in (let's call it) upper upper-middle-age, are being remarkably stoical about our nest eggs now rotting away in the stock market. Other vicissitudes of aging get us going volubly enough, in a way I fear we'll soon find pathetically inadequate to the occasion. But the stock market's blow to our retirement security seems to have left us unmoved.
 Maybe the implications haven't sunk in. There hasn't been much about it in the newspapers and magazines I read, despite the revelation, last month, that in 2000 the average 401(k) lost money for the first time in its history. The columnists seem more concerned with gauging the depth and duration of the slump than with its consequences for upper upper-middles. 
 Surely this is a journalistic mistake: my age group is not very large, but in matters of retirement, we're the canaries for vast multitudes of aging baby boomers. We and they, 40 million of us, presumably invested great hope for retirement in 401(k)'s -- and so, too, has President Bush, who is counting on 401(k)-like plans to privatize responsibility for Social Security. But if the president or the people were frightened or enraged by the downturn or drew any conclusions with respect to their retirement policies, it didn't show.
My friends may not have understood the implications either. "What do you expect?" my old college roommate growled. "Market goes up, market goes down. Nothing to get exercised about." Well, I could think of something: the upper upper-middle-aged might croak before the market recoups our losses.
I hadn't the wit to point this out at the time, but I'm not sure it would have mattered if I had. Our wealth group corresponds roughly to our age group: upper-upper middle. Perhaps he thinks we've got enough savings to save our retirement from a mere slump. Except he's too smart to believe that. In America, only monks possess a firm sense of "enough." For the rest of us, it's always just out of reach, like the grapes of Tantalus.
Most likely, my old pal is just blase. This country delights in keeping even its more comfortable citizens insecure -- motivated," the economists say -- and one of the ways it has done so since even before the arrival of 401(k)'s is by wiring our sensoriums to the pacemaker on Wall Street. Thus a certain sprezzatura in the face of its sickening irregularities may reflect long experience, as well as a good supply of ideological Dramamine. Losses, we know, are hardly worth talking about except as cases in point of the risks they run, which justify the rewards.
Until the news came out, I never cared much about the fate of my retirement funds. Why should I? I intended never to retire. At reunions and suchlike events, when people asked me what I was doing, I'd say: "Working. Can't stop." My voice betrayed a little pride, I'm sure, and a little pity for the friends who asked. Many are already retired, some (you can never tell who) unwillingly. These days, the corporate guardians of our livelihoods are shoving off the middle-aged, never mind the upper upper-middles. I have been sent up that creek myself.
But luckily I've always found a paddle. I love work. I love it for all the good things we have been told to expect from work: freedom, autonomy, identity, purpose, discipline, respect and self-respect. It braces my character, which needs bracing as much as any exile from welfare-as-we-knew-it. It gives me surcease from self-consciousness, morbid in my case. (I'm not going gently into the next stretch of creek after this, damn it; without work, I'd be there already.)
I suspect that many people expect to go on working if they can. I hear it from my children's generation. "I don't plan to retire," they say. "Besides, Social Security will be such a pittance by then, I won't be able to." Yet pride is there, too, the can-do entrepreneurial spirit.
But the news about the 401(k)'s has got me nervous. I'm delighted if it foils the plot to securitize Social Security, which strikes me as yet another instance of our becoming like post-Soviet Russia -- tearing apart our common wealth to enrich our corporate oligarchs and liberating the rest of us, as someone once said, to go sleep under a bridge. Personally, though, what the 401(k) slump does is wake me up to the false consciousness that work is the great thing I wanted to do in my sunset years. This is macho nonsense. I've been suckered by the grotesquely high moral, therapeutic and social value this country puts on work. In my case, anyway, none of the aforementioned virtues are relevant. It's too late to brace my character further. There are better ways than work to deny death. And my sort of work is too badly paid to make up for my savings shortfall.
But the worst part of my vanishing retirement, I see now, is that my work always had quotation marks around it, invisible to me. It somehow feels different to imagine that I won't be taken care of, that I work because I have to, not just because I want to. How will it feel now that it's for real and earnest, my cocktail party claim that I'm working, now that events have called me on it? Not good, I imagine. 

GRAPHIC: "Take the sum of human achievement in action, in science, in art, in literature -- subtract the work of the men above 40, and while we should miss great treasures, even priceless treasures, we would practically be where we are today. . . . The effective, moving, vitalizing work of the world is done between the ages of 25 and 40." From "The Fixed Period," William Osler's valedictory address to Johns Hopkins University, 1905Photo (Johnny Buzzerio/C.L.M./CORBIS) Chart: "NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN""In that charming novel, 'The Fixed Period,' by Anthony Trollope . . . the plot hinges upon the admirable scheme of a college into which at 60 men retired for a year of contemplation before a peaceful departure by chloroform. HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Kensington; 
An Old Neighborhood Is Rediscovered

BYLINE:  By JOYCE COHEN 

 BODY:
UNTIL they drove by the house they ended up buying -- it had a wraparound porch and five stained-glass windows -- Christopher James Quinn and his wife, Nanette Fuentes, were only dimly aware of Kensington's existence. They visited the house many times, bought it in March 2000, renovated it top to bottom and grew fond of their little-known neighborhood on the far side of Prospect Park.
 "Can't stop talking about Kensington!" Mr. Quinn said. "The area has some rough edges but is so obviously on the upswing that it's exhilarating." 
 The neighborhood remains solidly middle class, though the Italian and Irish immigrant families from a generation ago are giving way to those from around the world, as well as to New Yorkers moving farther into Brooklyn as they uncover the more affordable homes there. 
"Two new homeowners within two houses have moved in," Mr. Quinn said. "We've met lots of young couples, and there is this energy about the area, with people settling here for good."
Mr. Quinn, who does computer work for the city's Department of Transportation when he is not acting -- his small part in "The Sopranos" was featured in the promos for the series' first season -- said he and his wife had received a warm welcome. "Building the porch railing was a great way to meet many new neighbors -- as they passed by, they cheered us on," he said. "We've become good friends with the people across the street, a family from Trinidad. He's a plumber who did some work for me and wouldn't take money. When his computer breaks, I go over and fix it."
Mr. Quinn and Ms. Fuentes, who works in the development office at Long Island University, own a detached single-family house with a yard, driveway and garage. Across the street are attached row houses. The mix of styles is typical of Kensington, where rows of brick or brownstone homes face larger detached homes. Many houses have been remodeled, some with enclosed or bricked-in porches, fake flagstone facades, high fences and other details that do not always fit the rest of the home. A few yards are landscaped with topiary and flowers while others are decorated with lawn ornaments; some are strewn with toys or debris.
"Every house is different," said Mr. Quinn, who added that it was impossible to tell from the outside what awaits inside. "There are a lot of houses that have character and potential."
Houses in Kensington, both attached and detached, tend to be for one or two families. There is also a mix of prewar and postwar apartment houses, five or six stories tall. The rental market includes units in rent-stabilized buildings, co-ops and private homes. 
"Kensington is an old neighborhood," said Marcia J. Miller, owner of Open Options Real Estate, based in neighboring Windsor Terrace. "It is turning around now, and a lot of the properties need renovation. Some blocks are better than others."
Arrivals include "young urban professionals of all nationalities, same-sex couples, young married couples starting a family and religious Jewish people who desire large houses with a lot of bedrooms," she said. "They want to be near the park and want to see trees and flowers. They want to raise their children in a diverse neighborhood. I call it the league of all nations, a real Brooklyn diverse community."
Single-family houses "in a decent area" cluster in a range of $275,000 to $300,000, while two-family houses sell for $350,000 to $450,000, she said. A small home "needing a lot of work" might be $250,000, while a larger home in good condition would be closer to $500,000.
Ms. Miller has seen prices soar over the last two years. "It might be leveling off a little bit now but is still very much in demand," she said. Houses sell quickly. A month ago, she put a two-family house on an established block up for sale. "We put a sign on it and listed it in two papers, and we're going crazy," she said. "I got 33 calls the first weekend." The house, now in contract, sold for its full asking price, $449,950.
Rental prices have also climbed. "We have a newly renovated two-bedroom-plus-den in a limestone building, and the rent is $1,850," Ms. Miller said. "I can't believe the prices." But not everything is so expensive. "We just rented a two-bedroom in a so-so building for $1,300," she said. One-bedroom apartments rent for about $1,000 on average.
IN one typical postwar midrise building, one-bedroom co-ops are selling for about $45,000, while those with two bedrooms are going for about $65,000. But many of Kensington's more luxurious co-ops are in the large prewar buildings that line the grand and graceful Ocean Parkway.There, one-bedroom co-ops sell for $90,000 to $140,000, and two-bedroom units go for $110,000 to $175,000.
"Our prices had been pretty low, so we had room to grow," said Merrie Melman, who sells apartments in her Ocean Parkway building and elsewhere in the area. Ocean Parkway's apartments are "huge," Ms. Melman said, with large rooms and spacious closets. The coveted three-bedroom, two-bathroom units sell for about $250,000.
"We are getting a big exodus from Park Slope, which has prices comparable to Manhattan, and also from Windsor Terrace," Ms. Melman said. "Kensington is being discovered. The area is just jumping now."
It was price that brought Mr. Quinn and Ms. Fuentes to Kensington. They had been living in Canarsie, where Mr. Quinn grew up, and looked at first for a home in Windsor Terrace. But all they found were small row houses they did not like and could not afford. 
"I grew up in a detached house, and my wife grew up in a Manhattan apartment," Mr. Quinn said. "She loved the idea of having a house and a yard. But the first house we saw in Windsor Terrace was a three-quarter family house -- it was so small, it felt claustrophobic. We were wildly depressed by that but then started seeing biggish houses in Kensington in our price range. We bought this house thinking the block had great potential for quality of life, but we didn't have to wait for it to be a nice place to live. We realized it was there already." 
Kensington, originally settled by Dutch farmers, was once part of Flatbush, one of Brooklyn's six towns. Development started in 1851. Ocean Parkway, finished in 1876, forms a lush promenade, with its central drive, landscaped malls, benches, chess tables and paths for walking and biking.
Around the turn of the century, Kensington was named after the borough in West London. Home building started in earnest during the 1920's, attracting Irish and Italian immigrants. By the early 1980's, as the original immigrants died or moved away, the melting pot grew to include people from Asia, Europe, South and Central America and Russia, as well as Orthodox Jews. Conversations overheard on the street are seldom in English. 
"It wasn't a place where people stayed -- it was a place to get started," said Michael Consiglio, a neurologist who lived in his family's Kensington house for nearly 60 years and moved to Long Island just a few years ago after he was married. His grandparents were Sicilian immigrants.
"That's what's happening all over again," he said. "There are other nationalities coming to the area. They have gone from tenements to multiperson dwellings and own detached houses for the first time, so it's wonderful for them. Though the area is now ethnically mixed, the people are economically similar -- hard-working immigrants."
The cultural diversity was a draw for Paul Campbell, a visual artist, and his wife, Susan Campbell, an occupational therapist. Seven years ago, they moved from a loft in Williamsburg to a four-story detached house in Kensington. They have a yard, a driveway and a garage. 
"We really love living here," Mr. Campbell said. "Before we bought the house, I watched the kids getting out of school and have never seen such a diverse group of people waiting for their kids. That was something really appealing to us about the neighborhood."
Still, he said, "the flip side of the ethnically mixed neighborhood is the ethnic groups don't mix as much as one would like. Everybody seems to coexist peacefully and amicably, but apart from religious organizations there don't seem to be common meeting places, like art galleries, bars, cafes and restaurants."
THE Campbells moved, in part, for the school district. Many of Kensington's children attend P.S. 130 or P.S. 230, both in Community School District 15. Those living in the southernmost part of Kensington attend P.S. 179, in District 20. All three schools have programs for the gifted. The area has two parochial schools, Immaculate Heart of Mary and St. Rose of Lima, both with about 250 children in prekindergarten through eighth grade.
The New Kensington Neighborhood Association keeps an eye on quality-of-life issues, especially those that affect the elderly. The group pushed for smooth curb cuts and traffic signs along Ocean Parkway, one of the city's busiest thoroughfares.
The main shopping street is Church Avenue, which Mr. Campbell called "basic but not upscale." There are several supermarkets and chain drugstores, plus dozens of ethnic grocery stores and restaurants. McDonald Avenue is filled with Pakistani restaurants. Another commercial strip, Ditmas Avenue, has a branch of the Brooklyn Public Library.
Near Prospect Park, a takeout shop for ice cream and Italian ices -- Uncle Luigi's, on the border of Kensington and Windsor Terrace -- brings upscale foot traffic to a dingy stretch of Coney Island Avenue. Another nearby draw is Kensington Stables, which occupies a low-slung red barn as well as "the little gray barn" across the street. An hourlong trail ride in Prospect Park costs $25. An urban pony ride -- up and down the block -- is $2.
