HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO; 
A Chance to See 'Salesman' as if for the First Time

BYLINE:  By JULIE SALAMON 

 BODY:
WHEN CBS first broadcast "Death of a Salesman" in 1966, critics hoped its substantial ratings might ignite a new golden age of television. "The little box in the parlor suddenly stopped its raucous babbling and spoke with power and beauty," Jack Gould wrote in The New York Times. "The public response to the superb interpretation of the tragedy of Willy Loman could not have been more heartening."
 But "Bonanza" drew an even bigger audience that night. And television's raucous babbling has only amplified since. "Death of a Salesman" endures, however, and now audiences can once again watch the transcendent performances of Lee J. Cobb and Mildred Dunnock, who were recreating their original Broadway roles. 
 Last shown on television in 1973, the CBS production of the 1949 Arthur Miller play will become available today on videocassette through www.broadwayarchive.com and at some retail stores. On Sept. 30 it will be shown on Trio, a digital cable and satellite television channel owned by USA Networks, and it has been licensed by many PBS stations for later broadcasts.
The days of theater as a big television event are gone. (Indeed, the days of big television are gone: few shows of any kind command audiences of more than 20 million people, the number who watched "Death of a Salesman" on CBS 35 years ago.) Cable channels like Showtime and HBO occasionally offer theater pieces (including Brian Dennehy's powerful portrayal of Willy Loman in Showtime's filmed presentation last year). PBS continues to be an important source of televised theater through "PBS Hollywood Presents" from KCET, "Stage on Screen" from Thirteen/WNET and "ExxonMobil Masterpiece Theater's American Collection" from WGBH. ABC and CBS still dabble in theatrical productions, but stick to crowd-pleasers like "South Pacific" and "On Golden Pond" -- the networks have lost both the power and the will to foist high culture on the mass audience. "Death of a Salesman" in any form can't touch the public consciousness like "Survivor" or "The Sopranos." This revival of the old CBS production demonstrates the opportunities opened up by technology. People who love theater have new ways to find it.
For Basil Hero, the release of "Death of a Salesman" is a significant marker in his quest to find Broadway productions that were adapted for television and to restore the aging films and tapes using digital technology. The co-founder and president of Broadway Theater Archive, which is releasing "Death of a Salesman," Mr. Hero has spent several years trying to renovate and distribute hundreds of televised theater productions hidden primarily in public television archives. He obtained the cooperation of two major public television stations, KCET in Los Angeles and WNET in New York, and financing from Michael Fuchs, former chairman of HBO, and Chase Mishkin, a Broadway producer.
There was vast material to choose from, including "A Moon for the Misbegotten" with Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst (1975), "King Lear" with James Earl Jones, Raul Julia and Paul Sorvino (1974) and "The Iceman Cometh' with Jason Robards and Robert Redford (1960). These are among the 85 titles currently available through Broadway Theater Archive; about 60 more will be available soon.
Besides the expensive and delicate process of restoring the master tapes, many of which were quite fragile, there were legal hurdles to overcome. "The $64,000 question hanging over the operation was, would we get the cooperation of the writers and agents of the works?" Mr. Hero said. The rights he wanted most were those for the 1966 version of "Death of a Salesman," a work Mr. Hero, now 46, remembers reciting line by line as a teenager. He couldn't stop himself from quoting the play during an interview. "You can't eat the orange and throw away the peel," he said. "A man isn't a piece of fruit."
Television's interest in serious theater, which had been strong in the medium's early years, was revived in the mid-1960's by David Susskind, who produced a series of drama programs, with playwrights themselves shaping the television adaptations. Tennessee Williams approved cuts for "The Glass Menagerie." Arthur Miller wrote the television versions of both "Death of a Salesman" and "The Crucible."
Despite his cooperation back then, Mr. Miller was reluctant to have the CBS production exhumed. "Frankly, that production we're talking about is a condensed version and that bothers me a lot," Mr. Miller said in an interview. "However, there's a lot of very good acting going on in it and it will reach a lot of people, so I can't complain. But I would much rather have people see the whole thing, which is what Brian Dennehy did." The Dennehy version is not available on video, though Dustin Hoffman's idiosyncratic 1984 Broadway rendition, which was also shown by CBS, is.
Mr. Miller said he was persuaded because, while he has admired subsequent productions of the play, none of them have evoked the emotion he felt in 1949, watching his written characters emerge as flesh and blood. "The first one is the most passionately felt because that's the one when you discover the play, and after that you're basically playing with that discovery, so it's a different set of feelings," he said. "It's a bit like the first time you have a child. The following children are terrific, but it's not quite the same miracle as the first time."
So despite his reservations about the abbreviated CBS version, Mr. Miller decided its value outweighed his objections. "Anything with Lee in it, that really swung it for me," he said. "I thought other actors might want to see what he was like and that's the only chance they're going to get."
What a gift this is. Far removed from their historic context, the play's themes and these performances remain amazingly alive. Mr. Cobb's exquisite rendering of Willy remains a touchstone for the character. In this bearish man you see Willy's monumental self-deception, but also the sweet dreaminess and sexual force that explain why his wife, Linda, loves him despite everything. Linda could seem like a sap for defending the contradictory and foolish Willy at their children's expense. But Mildred Dunning conveys the necessity of her self-delusion with heartbreaking clarity. If she doesn't believe in Willy, what has her life been?
The shattering effects of Willy's flawed dream should resonate today, with young dot-commers or "old economy" employees who have been laid off, bought out or otherwise downsized. "Things are worse now, from what I've heard," Mr. Miller said. "There is no corporate personality at all. When you lose whatever value you have for the company, you go. At least Willy has a very hot argument with his late boss's son. Now there's probably no argument. Just turn off the light."
Critics continually reevaluate the play, analyzing whether it is a dated piece of social realism or a timeless psychological drama. But Mr. Miller's attitude toward Willy Loman has remained constant for more than a half century. "My feelings haven't changed that much, to tell the truth," he said. "I feel that Willy is foolish and he's wonderful and a terribly human person. I felt that, way back, and I still do."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 5 about the 1966 television adaptation of "Death of a Salesman" used an incorrect surname at one point for the actress who played Willy Loman's wife, Linda. She was Mildred Dunnock, not Dunning.

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
Guru in an Outpost Of Ballet Wisdom

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH CARMAN; Joseph Carman, a former dancer with American Ballet Theater, writes about dance.

DATELINE: CARLISLE, Pa. 

 BODY:
LONDON, Paris, St. Petersburg and New York are well known for their first-rate ballet academies, training many of the best dancers in the classical form. Add to that list Carlisle, Pa., a town with fewer than 20,000 people and a modest economy driven by state government jobs and the defense industry.
 For the last 46 years, Marcia Dale Weary and her Central Pennsylvania Youth Ballet have produced dancers well known in the ballet world. Sean Lavery, Tina LeBlanc, Deborah Wingert, Lisa de Ribere and Ethan Stiefel are just a few of Ms. Weary's former students. When artistic directors hear that a dancer has been trained by Ms. Weary, they prick up their ears and sometimes even make the pilgrimage here to recruit the prospect themselves. 
 At a gala performance at the Sunoco Performance Theater in Harrisburg last month, Ms. Weary invited an array of her illustrious alumni back home to dance excerpts from the classical and neo-classical repertory. Among those dancing were Ashley Bouder, Adam Hendrickson and Ryan Kelly from New York City Ballet; Kristin Long and Vanessa Zahorian, stars of San Francisco Ballet; and Adrienne Schulte from American Ballet Theater. 
There were sibling teams as well: Ms. LeBlanc and her sister, Sherri LeBlanc, from San Francisco Ballet; Abi and Jonathan Stafford from New York City Ballet; and Tara and Zachary Hench, soloists with Boston Ballet and San Francisco Ballet, respectively. The selections ranged from standards like "The Sleeping Beauty" and "Don Quixote" to Balanchine works like "Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux" and his seldom seen "Pavane."
Assembling the dancers was an emotional as well as artistic challenge. Most of the dancers, who consider themselves a big family but come from all over, had trained together with Ms. Weary since they were toddlers, recipients of what they call Ms. Weary's "daily medicine," a combination of rigorous discipline and practice of the language of ballet.
A majority of the students, ages 4 to 19, live in central Pennsylvania, and those who can't commute stay in dormitories at Dickinson College or in private homes. Students are required to attend at least 15 ballet classes each week. (A grant from the General Mills Foundation now provides scholarships for children from low-income families.)
"We're grooming for the professional world," said Darla Hoover, a former New York City Ballet dancer who is now Ms. Weary's associate director.
Mr. Stafford agreed: "The training really set us up for being in a company. You work from 10:30 in the morning to 10:30 at night, especially at New York City Ballet."
Although Ms. Weary clearly commands respect ("She would scare the living daylights out of us," said Ms. LeBlanc, a principal ballerina in San Francisco), she is not the cane-wielding taskmaster one might expect. At just over five feet tall with soft bangs, a softer voice and a touch of Southern gentility cultivated in her youth in Alabama, Ms. Weary has a childlike quality that belies her tough-love attitude toward teaching.
She opened her school in 1955, after studying in New York with Thalia Mara and attending seminars by George Balanchine. She realized that at the age of 19 it was too late for a career as a dancer, but she was determined to teach and so opened the school. In the beginning, she said, "it was trial and error."
"I didn't have wonderful bodies, like at the School of American Ballet," Ms. Weary said. "You have to figure out a way to make children who don't have good bodies look good. And that makes you think and work to develop ways of breaking things down for children. We still do that." 
Teaching children how to concentrate is paramount, she said, particularly at a time when children's attention spans have, by her account, grown disturbingly shorter. "A 7-year-old is like a 4-year-old was 30 years ago," Ms. Weary said. In class, she added, "I expect them to pay attention all the time, and after six months or a year, most of them have learned how to focus. They're not afraid of me, but they kind of are."
Ms. Weary keeps class work simple, often repeating the same lesson for a month until the students get it right. The method is effective, said Ms. Wingert, a New York City Ballet alumnus who frequently teaches at the school. "With that kind of repetition, you don't have to think," she said. "Tendu is just tendu."
Although the school has expanded to include a larger complex called "the Warehouse," containing six ample, climate-controlled studios with sprung wood floors to accommodate 560 summer session students, Ms. Weary prefers to work in the Barn, a renovated farm shelter that houses three small studios. There, she teaches the newest generation of 5-year-old ballerinas with names like Chloe, Tiffany and Allegra. In her mid-60's, Ms. Weary will get down on her hands and knees to help a child stretch her leg or articulate her feet. 
"In many ways, Marcia lives in her own time," said Ms. Hoover. "Her refusal to give up any of her values -- she never lessens them -- and what she imparts to her students haven't changed since I was 6."
Ms. LeBlanc added: "We knew that Marcia was a little eccentric. She's her own person and does things her way, and that was just accepted." (Ms. Weary's swift, steely glare at an established ballerina can instantly signal that she is breaking the school's dress code.)
In keeping with her aim to prepare dancers for professional companies, Ms. Weary does not advocate any one style of dancing over another. Her guest faculty, in addition to former students, includes ballet teachers from Cuba, Paris, Russia and New York. "That way you can be a chameleon," Ms. Wingert said. "You can absorb different styles." Ms. Zahorian, now a soloist with San Francisco Ballet, added: "She had us watch videotapes of Russian ballets, Balanchine works -- Cecchetti to Bournonville. It broadens your knowledge of dance."
Ms. Weary insists that Central Pennsylvania Youth Ballet is more a training ground than a company. Still, the group performs four times a year and is a member of the Northeast Regional Ballet Association. Alan Hineline has been engaged as a resident choreographer to produce classical works for the age group, and the dancers regularly perform full-length classical ballets. There is also a solid relationship with the Balanchine Trust, which has granted the company rights to many of its ballets. "They know the quality of dancers down here, so they don't usually flinch," Ms. Hoover said. "They know they can handle anything."
What is the secret to Ms. Weary's success? "I'm close enough to New York and yet far enough away that they just can't go running off to New York," Ms. Weary said of her students. "You can make the rules and they find out that the rules work."
Ms. Wingert said the demand for perfection is the key: "Marcia once said to me that you are only as good as your worst student." But to Ms. Le Blanc, elements of Ms. Weary's formula remain a mystery. "I still look at this lady and think, 'How does she do it?' " she said. "I still don't get it."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Available Office Space Jumps in Fairfield County

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THE availability rate for office space in Fairfield County has almost doubled in the last year, Stamford real estate companies say, adding that the jump is the most dramatic rise in a decade.
 Of the almost 44 million square feet of office space across the county's 627 square miles, 4.4 million square feet are vacant, up from 2.5 million square feet at this time last year, plus or minus some footage depending on variations in statistics compiled by the individual companies. 
 But executives of those companies are qualifying the statistics by saying that the news is not all that bad. The increase follows a year when the market was so overheated that bidding wars were commonplace.
The jump reflects a slowdown in leasing and a rise in subleasing and is regarded by brokers as manageable, at least for now. As long as downsizing tenants continue to pay rent, make buyout deals with their landlords or sublease space when they need to dispose of disused square footage, brokers believe the office market will ride out this choppy economic sea. 
"The key is layoffs," said James Fagan, senior managing director of suburban real estate at CB Richard Ellis. "Right now, people want to see how things shake out before committing leasing dollars. If a lot of layoffs continue to hit the market, you'll see less of a need for office space."
Jeffrey Dunne, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis, added: "People are exaggerating the dovetailing of two things: businesses contracting and the summer doldrums. They are overstating the negative this year because the market was so strong in 2000." But, Mr. Dunne said, "I don't think we're at the end yet." 
Noting that the investment market was still strong, he said, "we're selling about $100 million worth in Fairfield and Westchester, from 50,000 to 200,000 square feet, all 95 percent occupied."
Older buildings along Stamford's Summer Street, north of the business district, are having more difficulty and are less likely to recover as quickly as their more desirably located downtown counterparts, brokers say. Among them is 707 Summer Street, with its 75,000 square feet fully leased to the Cendant Corporation for one more year. Cendant had been leasing four Stamford buildings.
After three leases expired, it consolidated at 100 Connecticut Avenue in Norwalk three months ago. The Summer Street building, owned by the Hoffman Brothers, Stamford developers, is up for sale, "to relieve ourselves of the taxes," said Steven Hoffman. It is being marketed for subleasing to reduce some of Cendant's remaining lease obligation, he added.
Members of a focus group of 22 top executives of area companies brought together by Christopher P. Bruhl, executive director of the Southwestern (Connecticut) Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford, reported that the demand for temporary staffing, an economic indicator, was down countywide, and that the pace of business was slower than last year. But the group members said they expected solid growth by this year's fourth quarter or the first quarter of 2002.
"There are no cash-flow problems," Mr. Bruhl said, "no credit crunch, no loans being called by banks. Consumer confidence is supporting restaurants and service businesses. In retail, higher-priced sales are being made by fewer people. It's too soon to know if it's seasonal, value-oriented or driven by high-income customers."
According to statistics compiled by the association, unemployment in the county rose to 2.3 percent this year from 2.1 percent last year, representing 10,064 people of 447,138 countywide. How much of the total was office staff is not clear.
"There is no panic," said Kenneth M. Krasnow, regional managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. "We are not seeing rents go down. That's because a large portion of the space that's come back is sublet, not directly affecting most landlords. Landlords are protected with guarantees and security on a lot of these deals because they had the leverage to ask for what they wanted when they had people vying for the space."
STAMFORD asking rents averaging $25.50 a square foot annually last year have climbed to $36.75 this year, but countywide averages declined marginally in the second quarter to $31.38 from $31.65.
W & M Properties of Stamford and Manhattan, like other landlords, limits vacancies by leasing or renewing leases up to two years in advance. In today's market, it is negotiating buyout agreements with tenants with excess space. Information Resources, at W & M's Merritt View in Norwalk since 1996, paid $100,000 to be let out of 11,000 square feet of its total of almost 50,000 square feet. 
"It would have cost them more," said Jeffrey Newman, executive vice president of W & M Properties, "to pay commission on a sublease for the remainder of the lease, plus retrofitting the space and having to take a shortfall in rent from the $33 a square foot they are paying to the $27 or $28 they would be able to charge in a sublease, plus having primary liability if the sublease tenant defaults."
Xerox appears to be the largest potential source of available space. Its 255,000-square-foot headquarters at 800 Long Ridge Road in Stamford, built, owned and occupied by the company since 1978, has been for sale since March 29. "Our opinion is it's best laid out for a single tenant," said Kara Choquette, a spokeswoman for the company. "It can accommodate 630 people, but we employ only half that now, so we are looking for a building half this size." 
The former Champion International building, which became the International Paper building last year and after changing hands again in January is now called 400 Atlantic Street, has 180,000 square feet empty out of 500,000 square feet. "We are talking to people locally and in New York who could be full-floor or smaller users," said Scott Landis, head of the Landis Group, which now owns the building. Asking rents start at $45 a foot and rise to $48 a foot on the third floor, where landscaped outdoor terraces are included in the leases.
Existing tenants include International Paper's world headquarters, with 132,000 square feet on four floors; UBS Warburg, with 75,000 square feet; and Arthur Andersen, with a full floor of 37,000 square feet. New leases include the regional headquarters of the law firm of Wiggin & Dana and the United States headquarters of Abbey National, one of Europe's larger banks. 
Foot-dragging among possible tenants might abate by the time two office buildings under construction in Norwalk are completed. A sixth building of 255,000 square feet at the five-building complex called Merritt Seven on Route 7 will be ready for occupancy next summer. And a 350,000-square-foot building at 3545 Glover Avenue, next to Merritt 7, will be ready in 22 months, said its developer, Carl Kuehner, president of Building and Land Technologies in Norwalk.
Stamford, of course, bears the brunt of the slowdown and the greater amount of available space, jumping to 12.9 percent rate from 6.5 percent last year. Eastern Fairfield County has the lowest availability rate in the county at 8.8 percent, due in part to the preleasing of a 150,000-square-foot building at 4 Enterprise Drive in Shelton and attractive rents around $25 a square foot.
Greenwich continues to command the highest rents in the county, ranging from the low $50's a square foot to the low $70's. But CB Richard Ellis says that the asking rate for space at Greenwich Plaza, an office complex at the Central Greenwich railroad station, just dropped to $69 a square foot from $72. 
SUBLEASE space of 135,000 square feet at Greenwich American Center on King Street, the 605,000-square-foot former headquarters of the American Can Company, is being marketed by Cushman & Wakefield at only $35 a square foot "because of the location in the northwest corner of town, away from the business district," said Jay Hruska, executive director for Cushman & Wakefield in Connecticut. 
Availability in northern Fairfield County rose two percentage points, to 13.4 percent, according to statistics from Insignia/ESG, mostly due to the closing of the Microcast Company, which returned 92,000 square feet to the market at 33 Turner Road in Danbury. 
Dean J. Shapiro, executive director of Insignia/ESG's Connecticut-Westchester operations, said: "I'm not sure we know how much rents have fallen because there hasn't been enough leasing activity. A lot of what we've seen has been renewals. I'm looking for new tenants floating through this market." 
Ed Tonnessen, executive vice president at Albert B. Ashforth Inc., added: "There is no doubt that demand has cooled and vacancies have increased. Couple those factors with the sublet influence and prices are going to depress. But it's not the Nasdaq."

HEADLINE: Housing Shortage Is Alive and Well 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
A LEGISLATIVE commission that studied the affordable housing issue in Connecticut last year concluded that despite laws that make it a lot tougher for towns and cities to reject developers' proposals, there is still a 68,000-unit shortfall of affordable housing in the state. 
 Housing advocates said that the nearly 2,000 units of affordable housing and at least another 5,000 units with rents below market value have been created as a result of the 1989 legislation. They said that although those units have made only a small dent in reducing the overall need, without the law the shortage would be even worse. 
 They said there are many reasons the gains have come so slowly, including the persistent battles waged by many towns and their zoning boards against not only affordable housing, but against any new housing at all. 
Housing advocates, such as the commission's co-chairman, Patrick Flaherty, a Democratic state representative from Coventry, and Jeffrey Freiser, executive director of the Connecticut Housing Coalition, said that only 30 of the state's 169 municipalities are at the 10 percent affordable housing level that allows towns and cities to be exempt from the mandate.
They said some towns are so far from the 10 percent number that it is unlikely they will ever reach it. But they said that when the law was created, the expectation was not that every town reach the 10 percent minimum standard, only that they would be motivated to take some action to lessen the shortage.
"It's not just that towns are so resistant to affordable housing, it's that they are strongly opposed to new housing of any kind that is making our efforts to make significant progress difficult," Mr. Flaherty said. "For the most part I think these towns just don't want to have to pay for the increase in their populations, particularly adding children to their schools systems that could impact taxes."
Mr. Flaherty said he was frustrated by affordable housing opponents who "on one hand say that the affordable housing law is having this devastating impact on their communities because they are being forced to allow so much new housing, but at the same they say the law is not helping to create enough units and isn't working. You can't have it both ways."
Opponents of the law said they are not against affordable housing, just to a mandate they said has not been effective.
"Promoting many of these developments as affordable is misleading at best," said Trumbull First Selectman Kenneth Halaby.
He said his town was making efforts to add "real affordable housing in smaller clusters instead of luxury apartments in massive developments that hurt the town."
Mr. Freiser said the efforts by towns to prevent the housing units hurt the entire state because the lack of housing discourages companies from relocating to Connecticut when they learn their employees cannot afford to live in many parts of the state.
"That was one of the main reasons the law was created in the first place," Mr. Freiser said.
He said that according to the 1990 Census, the last census from which the state's housing numbers are available, nearly half of the total 405,000 renter households lived in either sub-standard conditions or pay rent considered to be excessive.
"Everybody says they want to see more housing provided, but many of the towns just want to do whatever it takes to keep taxes from going up," Mr. Freiser said. "Eventually, the lack of housing is going to seriously impact the state's economy. Maybe that's what it will take for people to realize the lack of housing is a crucial issue."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
Making Way for Bigger Ships

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
WITH traffic through the port of New York expected to double by the end of the decade and continue growing, and with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey having voted to accelerate a plan to dredge channels to accommodate a new generation of big ships, the authority is making other changes to speed the flow of cargo across its docks.
 Efficient movement of cargo across the docks and into the economy is essential if New York is to remain the premier port on the East Coast, government officials and private consultants agree. 
 This will require changes in the transportation network, with an emphasis on movement of goods by railroad and water. The increased volume of freight may also provide an opportunity to develop contaminated land known as brownfields near the port. 
Most of what is officially called the port of New York is in New Jersey. The 2,100 acres that constitute the ports of Newark and Elizabeth swarm with activity on a typical day. Giant crablike machines swallow up cargo containers the size of truck trailers and swiftly move them off the dock to waiting rail cars or trailer chassis. 
Ultraconcentrated orange juice from Brazil is diluted with local water at the port, and wallboard is manufactured there as well, using imported gypsum rocks that are ground up and placed between sheets of cardboard.
The Port Authority, which operates the region's major seaport on what were once marshy lands in the two cities, is planning for rapid increases in imports as the region's demand for consumer goods grows and manufacturing increasingly shifts to Asia.
Late in July, the agency voted to spend $2.3 billion to dredge the harbor's channels down to a depth of 50 feet, to accommodate the new class of giant container ship, which can carry 5,000 to 7,000 trailer-size containers, compared with 3,000 to 4,000 on a typical ship now in use. The new ships are expected to be in service by the end of the decade. Failure to accommodate them, agency officials said, would divert the ships to other ports along the Atlantic seaboard, depriving the metropolitan area of the jobs and other economic benefits of trade.
Worse, they said, is the likelihood that the contents of containers unloaded in another port would find their way back to this area by truck, worsening an already choked highway system.
To accommodate increased shipping traffic, the authority is trying to move nonessential warehousing and distribution operations out of the port itself to nearby locations. The result, brokers report, is an increased interest in industrial land close to the port, although most bemoan the scarcity of suitable sites.
This, in turn, has prompted some planning agencies to propose channeling some of this demand to abandoned or underused land that is chemically contaminated but could be adapted for processing freight. Known as brownfields, these sites dot the region, the result of manufacturing and chemical processing. Many are near both the seaport and Newark Airport, which is on the west side of the New Jersey Turnpike.
"A warehouse is a good use for a brownfield," said Ann Strauss-Wieder, a freight and transportation consultant, at a recent conference on the issue at the New Jersey Institute of Technology. "You cap the site with a concrete floor for the warehouse and parking lots outside. The issues are how much it is going to cost to remediate and how long it will take to get permits."
Benjamin Katz, a senior managing director of Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company, said: "I'm bullish on space near the port and the airport as well. Some of those imports need processing, so we are going to see modern, high-bay warehouses. And we may recapture some brownfields, using just the surface for containers."
But some real estate executives are skeptical that large numbers of developers will be willing to invest in sites where the likelihood of turning a profit is unclear. "Brownfields take a long time to bring back into a revenue-producing use," said Irving Weiss, a senior vice president at SBWE, a real estate services company with extensive experience in industrial properties. 
And, he said, municipalities in the area tend to favor office and retail development over industrial projects. In Elizabeth, he said, land near both the seaport and airport -- and the Jersey Gardens shopping mall -- has been rezoned for these more lucrative uses and is unavailable for industrial purposes.
The immediate issue may be dredging shipping channels to accommodate larger ships, but the ships are just a reflection of increased trade, said Richard M. Larrabee, director of the authority's Port Commerce Department. He said that American consumers' seemingly unquenchable thirst for imported goods, as well as changing patterns of trade, are expected to increase the amount of cargo coming through the port.
The big new ships are simply a more economical way to move that river of cargo. The Port Authority estimates that the volume of cargo could rise from the present level of about 2.5 million boxes a year to about 6 million by 2010, and as many as 16 million by 2040.
EVEN at its current level of activity, the port is an economic engine for the region. The Port Authority estimates that ocean trade accounts for $23 billion in economic activity annually and provides, directly or indirectly, jobs for 166,500 workers in the 17-county metropolitan region. Freight growth by 2040 could add as many as 238,000 jobs, the agency said.
Until recently, most goods originating in Asia were sent by ship to ports on the West Coast, notably Los Angeles and Long Beach, Calif., and cargo intended for sale in the Midwest and on the East Coast was shipped east by train. But, according to Port Authority consultants, the rail leg of the trip could account for more than half the total cost.
Shipment by water is cheaper, and shipping companies are increasingly inclined to send vessels westward through the Suez Canal to markets in Europe and the United states. "We are seeing a significant increase in the amount of cargo coming directly by sea to here," Mr. Larrabee said. "The ships are coming now. And the big ships, which are a response to trade, will be coming soon."
On a recent afternoon the ship Leverkusen Express, which is owned by the Hapag-Lloyd line and based in Bremen, Germany, moved gingerly out of the port in Elizabeth with what appeared to be a full load and with the assistance of a tug.
"That's about the biggest we can handle now," said Robert W. Harley, a supervisor at the terminal. The ship, about 960 feet long, can carry about 4,800 containers. To accommodate the ships that will carry 6,000-plus containers, the port will need, in addition to deeper channels and berths, larger cranes that can reach all the way across the wider ships. 
Because the big ships are so costly, the shipping lines want to keep them moving and reduce the number of ports of call, the Port Authority said. This puts New York in competition with cities like Baltimore, Norfolk, Va., and Halifax, Nova Scotia, to be the hub port for goods intended for the eastern part of North America.
"Over time, container traffic will become more and more concentrated in fewer and fewer ports," the Port Authority said in a report, "Building a 21st Century Port." And because shipping companies want to limit their investments in terminal operations, ports capable of handling the big ships will likely be the destinations for smaller ones as well.
With the Maersk-Sealand ship line signed to a long-term lease and with P&O lines moving in, the Port Authority is rearranging the upland parts of its ports in Newark and Elizabeth. Warehouses covering about 50 acres are being torn down to provide more space for container storage and handling, and a grade-level rail crossing is being converted to an overpass to eliminate traffic jams several times a day.
Even so, the agency's ability to expand operations is limited. There are plans to expand the container port at Howland Hook on the north shore of Staten Island and perhaps add a container port at the Military Ocean Terminal, which the federal government is returning to the city of Bayonne, N.J. There are also studies about reviving the docks in Brooklyn, but transportation difficulties may limit this possibility. 
Port Authority officials have said they would like to move the automobile unloading operations out of the main port area to the Port Reading area of Woodbridge Township, N.J.
Although the auto transport ships are huge, they are not as densely loaded as the container ships and can use shallower channels and berths. "Those ships draw about 35 feet, not 45 like the big container ships, and they would be fine down there," said Daniel Maynard, a government and community relations manager for the Port Authority.
In the meantime, the answer is to keep the containers moving, rather than sitting at the dock for days after being unloaded from a ship, port officials said. "We move 1,300 containers per acre a year," Mr. Larrabee of the Port Authority said. "Singapore does 15,000, although that is a different system." He said the Port Authority is making investments in equipment and systems to increase the port's capacity. "What we need to do is improve to 3,500 containers per acre a year over the next decade," he said.
Given the highly trafficked nature of the streets near the port and the jams on the turnpike, any increase in cargo that puts more trucks on the road will only increase a congestion problem that already costs the regional economy $10 billion a year, Port Authority officials said.
Currently, 87 percent of the cargo unloaded from ships in the port goes out by truck, with only 12 percent by rail and the remainder by other means, including barge.. Rail-car loading facilities are being built close to the docks to increase the use of rail, but several transportation specialists said that CSX and Norfolk Southern, the companies that bought and divided up Conrail, have not been rushing to increase the capacity of their tracks or freight yards. 
Another complication, the specialists add, is pressure from state and local governments to use freight tracks for commuter trains at certain times of the day.
IF, inevitably, there are going to be more shipments by truck, efforts are under way to keep trucks in the vicinity of the port off of public roads. In New Jersey, state transportation officials have begun construction of Portway, a trucks-only route between the port and transportation hubs, such as the CSX's rail yard in Kearney and Norfolk Southern's Croxton terminal in Secaucus. 
The project will use existing roads such as Doremus Avenue in Newark but with upgrades to roadways and the replacement of damaged or partly dismantled bridges to handle containers too heavy to use the highway system in New Jersey.
Containers weighing more than highway load limits must be partially unloaded so they can be shipped. Many planners hope that the same buildings used to unload containers will also be used to add value to the products, by, say, sorting clothing and adding price tags.
The Portway project would include a new lift bridge over the Passaic River -- the Coast Guard insists on such a bridge since it considers the waterway navigable -- and a trucks-only entrance to the turnpike. State officials said the project might be ready by the end of the decade.
A huge increase in container imports would increase pressure to put trucks on the highways because, unlike most railroads, trucks can deliver goods to their final destination. But Port Authority executives are developing plans to rely more on waterways than highways to get the containers out of the port to regional distribution centers.
"We have looked at the way ports in Europe, places like Antwerp and Rotterdam, have handled their distribution," said William E. Ellis, a Port Authority planning manager. "They use their rivers and other waterways as alternatives to trucks."
The agency has developed a plan it calls the Port Inland Distribution Network. The idea is to move containers out of the New York port as quickly as possible by train or barge to regional distribution centers. From these regional centers, the containers would be moved by truck, but the trucks would be operating in less congested areas.
Among the locations being considered for these regional centers are Albany, which would require a barge trip up the Hudson River. Other possible sites include Camden, N.J., Bridgeport or New Haven, Conn., and Fall River, Mass.
The goal, Mr. Ellis said, would be to ship about 40 percent of the containers out of the port by barges with self-loading capabilities and 20 to 30 percent by rail, with the remainder being moved by truck.
Long distance shipments by barge, such as between New York and Boston and Baltimore, have been undertaken by private-sector companies, Mr. Ellis said. Whether shorter distances will prove economical as well has yet to be demonstrated, he said.
The regional distribution plan might help solve another related problem, the pileup of empty containers near the port. The containers are accumulating because the nation imports more than it exports and shippers find it cheaper to buy new containers in Asia than ship the empties back. As a result neighborhoods near the port find themselves facing mountains of containers, sometimes stacked seven high.
The inland distribution system would shift the empty containers closer to places where things are still actually made. Upstate New York has close to a balance of trade, Mr. Ellis said, so empty containers could be used for outgoing loads. "A producer could pick up an empty at Port Albany and use it to ship goods out," he said.
Although the Port Authority, attuned to decades of bistate tensions, is always careful to mention projects in New York as well as New Jersey, New Jersey-based planning officials note that 90 percent of the container traffic in the port comes through Newark and Elizabeth.
John V. Hummer of the North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority said that unless brownfields close to the port are developed for warehouse-distribution facilities, highway traffic will grow even worse. "Based on current real estate trends, many of these businesses are choosing to locate on greenfield sites on the fringes of the region where land and development costs are lowest," the agency said in a recent report produced in conjunction with New Jersey Institute of Technology.
THIS raises the prospect of goods being shipped by truck to the southern part of the state or to eastern Pennsylvania for processing, only to return by truck for final sale.
Mr. Hummer said the planning agency had found a site as large as 800 acres in the Kearney area and another of 160 acres along the Hackensack River in the same town. He said the agency is looking into the feasibility of developing the brownfield sites for industrial distribution and processing, including the land's likely value if development is permitted. The land will not be developed, he said, unless it will be worth more than the cost.
Some brokers are advising clients with property near the port to lie low while the market develops. "I have a client with a building in Kearney who asked me what he should do," said Donald Eisen, manager of New Jersey operations for Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services company.
"My advice to him was to do nothing," he said. "In five to 10 years it will be worth gold."

HEADLINE: Jobs Up Amid Hints Of a Slump 

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THERE has been mostly good economic news in Westchester in recent months, with the only worrisome notes being a rise in unemployment and an increasing commercial vacancy rate in downtown White Plains.
 Statistics for June show an all-time high in jobs, 428,300, which surpasses the previous record set in December 2000, when the county had 424,500 jobs. In March it had 415,200 jobs. 
 Westchester has now recouped all the jobs lost in the recession of the early 90's, showing an 18 percent growth -- 66,000 jobs -- since the recession's low point of 362,000 jobs in January 1994. Of the jobs recovered, more than 41,800 have been added since January 1998, the county's figures show.
Since June, Westchester jobs jumped 1.6 percent, a growth rate exceeding that of the state and nation for the same period. Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the State Department of Labor, said Westchester is one of the top job producers among the 16 metropolitan areas in the state. He noted that the county's job growth rate topped the statewide figure, which increased 1.1 percent over the same time period, as well as the national rate of 0.3 percent.
Yet, unemployment is rising slightly, according to figures from the State Department of Labor. The jobless rate in Westchester for June was 3.1 percent, up from 2.8 percent in May, and Mr. Surdey said, "We're beginning to see some signs of softening."
Manufacturing jobs, for example, were down in June by 500 or 1.4 percent from last June, when there were 35,800 jobs. Finance, insurance and real estate jobs were down to 26,800 in June from 26,900 a year ago.
But construction jobs in June were up to their highest level since 1988, to 26,500 -- 5.2 percent more than last June, Mr. Surdey said. The services job category (health, social, high-tech and business services, and software development) grew to 159,400 -- up 2.6 percent from a year ago.
The commercial vacancy rate in buildings in the central business district of White Plains was 18.9 percent at the end of the second quarter of this year, up from 17.3 percent at the end of the first quarter and 15.1 percent at the end of the fourth quarter of 2000.
"We always have to keep an eye on what's happening nationally," Mr. Surdey said. "Eventually that affects Westchester and New York City. There is no area that's insulated from an economic slowdown, even though Westchester is performing above state and national levels."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Curative Health Services Posts Break-Even Quarter
Curative Health Services (Nasdaq: CURE) of Hauppauge said Tuesday that its second-quarter revenues edged up slightly to $24 million, compared with $21.6 million in the same quarter last year.
 The company, which operates a national network of 100 wound-care centers in hospitals, reported net income of $10,000. 
 Curative spent $670,000 during the quarter on legal expenses, largely responding to directives from the Justice Department relating to Curative's $37.3 million merger agreement four months ago with Millennium Health, a specialty pharmaceutical distributor in Santa Clara, Calif.
Joseph Feshbach, Curative's chairman, said recent discussions with Justice Department officials had been constructive, although a company spokesman would not elaborate further.
Mr. Feshbach also said he was "cautiously optimistic" that revenues would increase in the next quarter.
He added, "We believe the wound-care business continues the process of stabilization."

Around the Island
Technology Flavors & Fragrances (Amex: TFF) of Amityville has reported net sales of $4.1 million for the second quarter, down from $4.5 million for last year's comparable quarter. Profits were $72,000, or 1 cent a share, down from $413,000, or 3 cents a share, for the same quarter last year. Philip Rosner, the company's chairman, cited "continued weakness in our industry and the general economy." T.F.F. creates flavors and fragrances for the beverage, perfume, pharmaceutical and food industries. . . . Symbol Technologies (NYSE: SBL) of Holtsville has reported a $59.6 million net loss for the second quarter, in line with expected results. Revenues were flat compared with last year's second quarter, and the company took a $67.1 million after-tax inventory write-down. . . . Smithtown Bancorp has reported that earnings rose 15 percent to $1.4 million, or 93 cents a share, for the second quarter, compared with the same period last year. . . . The Comtech Telecommunications Corporation (Nasdaq: CMTL) of Melville said last week that it had received about $5 million in new military contracts for its movement tracking system.

LENGTH: 1170 words

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
For Women, Extra Hazards on the Golf Course

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
THEORETICALLY, it is possible to do business on Long Island and never take a swing at a golf ball. But Christine McInerney wonders why anyone would test the theory.
 Ms. McInerney, a partner in Ruskin, Moscou, Evans & Faltischek, a Mineola law firm, is not exactly neutral on the subject. As the founding president of the Long Island chapter of the Executive Women's Golf Association, she recruits members by tapping the pent-up demand among local businesswomen to get out on the links. 
 "Golf is where business gets done," Ms. McInerney said. "On Long Island in particular, women are largely excluded from that. It just isn't as common for women to play golf. When you go to corporate-sponsored golf outings, you look around, and you just don't see a lot of women." 
Organizations like the Executive Women's Golf Association are trying to change that by allowing women to learn the game and its social niceties in a no-pressure, single-sex setting. And in doing this, they are coming face to face with resistance from country clubs that are apparently not eager to see the old ways change.
Last year, the Long Island chapter Ms. McInerney founded was among the fastest-growing of the national association's 98 chapters, enrolling over 200 members its first year. Nearly 100 more members have joined this year. Another group, the seven-year-old Businesswomen's Golf Association of Long Island, has nearly 400 members.
Nationally, women are heading to golf courses in increasing numbers. About six million women now play, accounting for nearly a quarter of the nation's golfers, according to the National Golf Foundation. 
The influx of women has roiled the tradition-bound world of country clubs, where most business golf is played. Despite some pressure from organizations like the United States Golf Association, many private clubs continue to maintain sex-based policies and practices, a number of women contend. 
Susan Slavin, a civil-rights lawyer and partner in Slavin, Angiulo, & Horowitz, a Jericho law firm, said she has heard from a number of women who complain about how they are treated at Long Island country clubs. "It's appalling," Ms. Slavin said of the "blatantly discriminatory policies and practices" that prevail, she contends, at membership clubs like the Glen Head Country Country Club and the Huntington Crescent Club. 
"The Huntington Crescent Club does not allow women to be members unless they are the daughters of current members," Ms. Slavin said. "And they have a men's grill, where women are not allowed in. The Glen Head Country Club until a few months ago also had a men's grill, where women could not walk in."
At the Glen Head club the grill is now open to members. Ed Closs, the club's general manager, said that three or four of its 235 members were women. "That seems to be how people join," he said. "If a woman wants to join the club, she can do so."
Louis Kerner, the club's president, said: "I think it's an economic issue. I don't think a single woman wants to spend $50,000 to join and pay $20,000 a year membership and not have other women to play golf with." 
John Tangorra, the manager of the Huntington Crescent, did not return three calls seeking comment. 
While many women who play golf say that sex discrimination is waning, some still chafe at inequities. These are their chief complaints:
*They feel unwelcome or are ignored in clubhouse restaurants.
*The best tee times are reserved for men.
*Membership privileges are open only to women who are married to members or are the daughters of members.
Few women will address the discrimination issue publicly for fear of being labeled bad sports and finding doors permanently closed to them or to their husbands or parents.
"Most women won't speak up about this because they're afraid of being ostracized and their husbands ostracized," Ms. Slavin said. In August 1989, Ms. Slavin filed a discrimination charge with the New York State division of human rights on behalf of Nancy Saunders, a real estate broker who joined a Westchester country club where she intended to entertain business clients. In her complaint Ms. Slavin alleged that the club refused to allow Ms. Saunders to play on Saturday mornings or Wednesday afternoon, two of the most-desired tee times.
In its ruling the human-rights division said that it had no jurisdiction over the private club. The case is now in the hands of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, and it could be heard as soon as this fall, she said. 
Despite the obstacles women who have taken up golf say that by playing regularly in with other women, they are learning the game and its etiquette. And this, they say, is the best way to defuse resentment from the male golfing establishment. 
"For years, men have had men's clubs that play on Saturday mornings, and women are pooh-poohed," said Sally LaMay, who founded the Businesswomen's Golf Association of Long Island. "Do you know what G-O-L-F really stands for? Gentlemen Only, Ladies Forbidden."
For many golfers, etiquette matters as much -- some would say more -- than the final score. "The most common blunder is talking too loudly," said Ms. LaMay, a vice president at the Bank of Smithtown until her retirement five years ago. Beginners are prone to other social lapses, she said, like getting in the way of fellow golfers, obstructing the green with their carts and fumbling over which club to select.
"And you can't spend too much time looking for the ball," she added. "You get five minutes, and that's a long time. Then use a new one."
Although women may plan to play in mixed foursomes eventually, they say they feel more comfortable learning the ins and outs of the game in the company of other women. Tracy Dellomo, an assistant vice president at Merrill Lynch in Melville and a member of the Long Island Executive Women's Golf Association, cited the endurance of old stereotypes.
"If four women go onto a course," he said, "they immediately get a look from the men, like 'Oh, they're going to slow us down.' It can be intimidating. Often the guys don't play better than the women, but they know the rules. If you're a businesswoman, you don't want to go into a situation where you're at a disadvantage."
Still, the appeal of the game seems only to grow, particularly for businesswomen. "Golf is a great way to get to know someone," Ms. McInerney said. "You watch someone play, and you learn so much about their style. Do they line up the shot very carefully, deliberate over which club to select, or jump right into it? Do they select the most challenging shot or the easiest?"
For many years, Mary Jane Hartigan, a Manhasset consultant who helps clients improve their public speaking skills, played in golf tournaments, but today her golfing is usually business-related. Ms. Hartigan, whose business is called Speaking Professionally, said: "These days, I'm more interested in enjoying the afternoon with the people I'm playing with, and getting to know them as people. The final score isn't the only thing anymore."

HEADLINE: MEMO FROM WATERBURY; 
Another Mayor, Another Fine Mess, but Hey, There's Hope

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
BELIEVE it or not, there is a bright side to Waterbury's latest mess. And who better to recognize it than Gov. John G. Rowland, perhaps the city's greatest champion and most loyal native son.
 "It's not like we lost the guy who was running the budget," Mr. Rowland said in an interview last week. "It's not like we lost the guy who was making the critical decisions." 
 The guy who was lost, of course, is Mayor Philip A. Giordano, who was arrested July 26 on federal charges that he lured a child for sex. And the bright side is timing. While Mr. Giordano's future is uncertain on many fronts, as mayor he has not mattered much since March 9 and has mattered even less since July 18. 
March 9 was the day that Mr. Rowland signed a law passed by both houses of the State Legislature to save Waterbury from financial collapse. Most important, the law gave a state oversight board almost total control of the city's finances.
July 18 was the day that Mr. Giordano, a 38-year-old Republican, announced that he would not run for a fourth term.
"Musical chairs have been played in the city of Waterbury for some time," he said. "Unfortunately the music stopped under my administration and I couldn't find a chair to sit in."
It is unclear whether Mr. Giordano knew at that point, a week and a day before his arrest, that he was a target of a federal corruption inquiry. What is clear, officials concerned about Waterbury's future say, is that by the time the corruption investigation took an unexpected twist and resulted in Mr. Giordano's arrest on sex charges, the fate of the city was already largely out of his hands. 
"There is no loss," Governor Rowland said. "His being in jail is not a loss to the city at all." 
In the wake of Mr. Giordano's arrest, the state oversight board moved to consolidate its control of city finances by appointing Robert Dakers, a member of the board and an official with the state's Office of Management and Budget, as Waterbury's emergency financial director.
Sam S. F. Caligiuri, the president of the Board of Aldermen who has been serving as acting mayor, said that Mr. Dakers had already been serving in the role and that the unanimous decision by the board formalized the arrangement, giving Mr. Dakers added authority over fiscal policy.
Mr. Rowland said the city is already on the road to fiscal recovery. "We will weather this," he said. He also pointed to $45 million in state bonds recently approved for downtown redevelopment.
Mr. Giordano's arrest may have left residents of Waterbury more dispirited than ever. And the revelation of a wider, ongoing federal investigation into municipal graft has further tarnished the city's reputation.
But local officials said they were starting to pick up the pieces.
"Everyone is devastated by this," Mr. Caligiuri said. "But you got to get up the next morning and dust yourself off and do what you have to do."
In an interview last week in the mayor's office, Mr. Caligiuri, a 34-year-old corporate lawyer who is not running for re-election to the Board of Aldermen, said, "Waterbury has got problems, but they are all problems that can be fixed."
The weeks and months ahead will be painful, Mr. Caligiuri said, but he noted that the process had already begun. On the same day that Mr. Giordano was arrested, Waterbury residents began receiving their new tax bills, including a 30 percent increase, to help balance the city's budget.
"The first thing I envision is stabilizing the city's financial condition and paying the piper, so to speak, for years of financial mismanagement," Mr. Caligiuri said. "So the first step is to pay the price of the sins of the past, but to do so in a way that holds on to our citizenry and keeps them intact."
This will not be easy. In addition to the current property tax increase, Waterbury is facing its first revaluation in more than two decades. As a result of the city's depleted commercial tax base, the tax burden on homeowners is going to increase, with tax bills expected to double for some.
"Then," Mr. Caligiuri said, "we have to aggressively develop an economic vision for this city that is proactive and positive and is not simply reactive and based on having a Home Depot here and a mall there. It's got to be more aggressive than that."
Such a plan, Mr. Caligiuri said, could not possibly be developed in the five months left in Mr. Giordano's term. And so the burden will fall to Mr. Giordano's successor, even as the powers of the new mayor will be severely limited by the state financial oversight board.
The candidates include three Democrats: Larry DePillo, a self-employed computer consultant; Mike Jarjura, a state representative; and Ron Napoli, a longtime alderman; and one Republican: Dennis Odle, an executive with I.B.M. The Democratic primary is Sept. 11.
Mr. Jarjura, who sponsored the bill for the state's emergency financial takeover in Waterbury, said he saw a brighter future.
"The story of Waterbury is not the story people are hearing," he said. "We have an excellent skilled work force and a plentiful work force. We have very affordable housing. We have an excellent infrastructure in terms of roads and bridges.
"We have the ingredients that are necessary to do economic development on a massive scale. What we need to do is market those areas out to the business community across the United States and internationally. I think once that message gets out there we will be on the road to economic recovery."
Like the other mayoral candidates, Mr. Jarjura is also calling for efforts to prevent future corruption, including revision of the City Charter and greater accountability for elected officials. 
But even some residents who profess deep loyalty to Waterbury said they doubt the city will be able to bounce back quickly. Ellen Gambini, a 59-year-old librarian and lifelong Waterbury resident, said that she has childhood memories of Mayor T. Frank Hayes, who was sent to jail for corruption. "He used to walk around like he was King Tut," she said. 
Mrs. Gambini raised two children in Waterbury. All four of her grandparents were born here. And she has no plans to move. But she said she believed that the city was still suffering from its last corrupt mayor, Joseph J. Santopietro, who was convicted in 1992 and sentenced to nine years in prison. 
"I don't think we've really recovered yet from the Santopietro administration's wrongdoing," he said. Ten library workers were laid off in the last year because of budget cuts, she said, and many municipal offices are understaffed. "I don't think the oversight board knew how far down we were," she said. "We had taken off all the cream. We were down to skim milk." 
She said that she was worried about what the Federal investigation would reveal and that she was apprehensive about all of the current mayoral candidates. 
"Are these people they are bringing forth now any better?" she asked. "It's going to take an awful long time to dig out of all our other problems." 
Mr. Caligiuri, Mr. Rowland and Mr. Jarjura said the digging had begun.
"The future does look bright," Mr. Jarjura said. "Sometimes they say the darkest minute is before the dawn. I think we are going through one of the darkest moments in our history."

HEADLINE: Affordable Housing Fight Will Not Let Up 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
MORE than a decade ago, the General Assembly passed legislation forcing many towns and cities that lacked substantial affordable housing to approve such housing developments in their communities.
 Ever since then towns, many of them affluent, have been crying foul, insisting the mandate provides undue advantage to developers who use the law to force local zoning boards to approve high density, massive housing developments that only include a minimum of affordable units that are not really all that affordable. 
 Town officials maintain the developments put an undue strain on town services, are far too dense, worsen already existing traffic and pollution problems and add too many students to their already swelling school systems.
But proponents insist housing, particularly affordable housing, is so desperately needed in many suburban towns that even moderate-income households cannot afford to pay the rent there, let alone buy a home or condominium.
These advocates said the affordable housing mandate that forces towns to approve developments that include affordable housing, which can cover a vast range of rents as low as a few hundred dollars a month to more than $2,000 -- may be even more needed today than when originally established in 1989. 
Towns with fewer than 10 percent of their housing stock deemed affordable under complex state guidelines can be forced by the courts to approve the developments, even after the applications are denied by local zoning boards and town councils. They said the law is needed to counter opposition in suburban towns because of racism, classism, fear of diminishing property values and often just an effort by towns to reject anything they believe will lead to bigger budgets and higher taxes.
"The fundamental issue is that towns have to understand their borders are not immigration borders and the state has a right to intercede after seeing a pattern of thinly veiled racism and other motives behind their denials of affordable housing," said Jeffrey Freiser, executive director of the Connecticut Housing Coalition, a private organization.
Others say the law just helps developers.
"The only people benefiting from this law are developers who are using it to force massive projects down the throats of small towns by providing a few units of what they call affordable," said Rick Altschuler, a lawyer from Orange who opposes the law.
Now, both opponents and supporters of the law are wondering what the impact will be of a State Supreme Court ruling made last month that upheld a Superior Court judge's decision ordering the town of Orange to allow a proposed 168-unit affordable housing development that its zoning board had denied. 
The issue is not unfamiliar to the state's highest court, which seven years ago, acting for the first time under the affordable housing statute, issued a landmark decision that allowed a 10-unit affordable housing co-op to be built in West Hartford, ruling there were not valid reasons for the Town Council to have denied the application. That is how the Flagg Road apartments proposed by the nonprofit West Hartford Interfaith Coalition (a group of members from local churches and synagogues) ended up being built in 1994 despite strong community opposition and denial by the West Hartford Town Council.
Mayor Robert Bouvier of West Hartford, a member of the council at the time, said the council was not against affordable housing -- and still isn't -- but denied the application based on its density at a small location. The council last year raised some eyebrows when it also denied the development's application to add six parking spaces at the site, again citing lack of space.
"This has been an absolute miracle for me; it's made it possible for me to have a real life again," said Nancy Geissler, 52, a former human resources worker who lives on Social Security disability after losing a leg to diabetes.
Ms. Geissler, who lives on one of the development's two disability units, said that paying 30 percent of her income for rent now instead of more than two thirds as she did before "has allowed me to have more than the $50 I was left every month after rent." 
But in many of the larger affordable housing developments, tenants often pay between $1,000 and $2,000 a month and many of the units are advertised as luxury apartments, said critics of the affordable housing law.
In the past, the rents were based on an area's median income, but in 1995, the State Legislature changed the formula and it is now based on the lower of either the area median income or the state median income. But the change did not apply to units already built.
Several legislators, including State Representative T. R. Rowe, a Republican representing Trumbull, and various zoning and town officials in communities like Orange, Trumbull and Milford, have introduced legislation to repeal or at least modify the affordable housing law on numerous occasions.
Last year a special legislative commission issued a report on the issue and made some recommendations it said would make the law better, including a provision that allows even towns below the 10 percent minimum affordable housing requirement to place a three-year moratorium on the developments if they meet a complicated formula that includes increasing the affordable housing stock by 2 percent, with a good deal of those added units targeted for low-income people.
Opponents insisted the changes are only cosmetic -- an assertion refuted by commission members -- and does not go nearly far enough to address the real problems in the law, which they said unfairly gives developers the upper hand by putting the onus on local zoning boards to approve applications for developments that set aside at least 30 percent of its units as affordable. Towns with less than 10 percent of its units deemed affordable are subject to the state mandate.
"It's just a terrible law that doesn't even do what it was intended to do, and the way it is written we could add affordable housing developments every year for the next decade and not have enough units to be unshackled by the law's 10 percent minimum requirement," said Mr. Rowe, a member of the legislature's committee on housing who has unsuccessfully introduced three separate repeal bills the last few years.
Mr. Rowe said that in his town there had been about a half dozen projects built under the mandate, including a project that includes more than 300 units, and pointed out that Trumbull was the only town in the state that had added enough units to place a three-year moratorium on the projects, which is expected to go into effect shortly.
Now, towns around the state are wondering how the higher court's recent ruling could affect the debate, and ultimately, the law itself. In that case, the state's highest court last year interceded on its own to consider a pending Appellate Court appeal filed by Orange in its legal battle to stop a Wilton developer's court-ordered plan to build a 168-unit affordable housing complex on a 9.5 acre Prindle Hill Road site off exit 41 of the Connecticut Turnpike.
Though the town's zoning commission originally denied the application, a Superior Court judge ordered the town to approve it, and the Supreme Court has now upheld that decision -- though in the ruling the court provided the town with language officials said they believed will allow them to still prepare a new strategy to stop the development through the creation of a new industrial park plan, which would include the site where the housing development would be built.
Orange First Selectman Mitchell Goldblatt said: "It's not that we're against affordable housing; we're against massive housing projects of any kind in an area where we targeted the creation of an industrial park."
Mark Forlenza, vice president of development for AvalonBay Communities, which is behind the Orange development, said he has heard that answer before.
"Town officials always say things like that in defending their opposition to affordable housing, but the truth is they will go to any lengths to stop us," Mr. Forlenza said.
His company has built affordable housing projects in Trumbull and Wilton, is about to start construction in New Canaan and is proposing similar projects despite opposition in Darien, Stratford and Milford.
Timothy Hollister, a lawyer for AvalonBay who was an adviser to the legislative panel that drafted the law 12 years ago, said the law was designed to force local zoning boards to be more inclusive precisely because they were being exclusionary, and he said the law is working.
"The law was made necessary because of the exclusionary actions of local zoning boards that would rarely, if ever, approve affordable housing projects, even when it was blatantly obvious that their communities desperately needed more housing," Mr. Hollister said. "Some people may not like the law, but I strongly believe it was and continues to be necessary."
Mr. Forlenza said his company was forced to spend millions of dollars in legal fees in an effort to battle denials by towns, spending more than $1 million on the Orange case alone. He said that while the claim by critics that developers like AvalonBay are mainly interested in making profits, "it is also true there is a dire need for housing throughout the state, particularly in southwestern Connecticut where we are providing affordable housing for low- and moderate-income individuals and families."
Many city and state housing proponents agreed with that.
"We have seen virulent opposition by communities and town officials to both small, nonprofit sponsored developments that are 100 percent affordable, and also to the larger projects with 30 percent affordable units," Mr. Freiser of the Connecticut Housing Coalition said. 
But not all communities have opposed affordable housing. In Stamford, which has been among the leaders in the state in providing not only affordable housing, but overall housing in recent years, Ellen Bromley, the city's social services coordinator, has worked as a housing advocate and pointed proudly to the more than 4,000 affordable housing units and hundreds more that are being built.
"We're aware that around the state there is often opposition," Ms. Bromley said. "But we believe government needs to be active in providing housing for its citizens, it's something our city has been strongly committed to."
Ms. Bromley has served as a liaison since 1997 for the city, developers and the Stamford Housing Authority, which she said have worked together to provide more housing for the very poor and elderly, but also for moderate-income people, too.
"We have a need for affordable housing throughout Connecticut to cover a wide range of income levels because our population and its housing needs are so economically diverse," she said. "I'm proud to say that in Stamford we haven't needed the state statute to ensure affordable housing, but we are certainly aware there are places that do."
