HEADLINE: The World; 
The Route to Real Safety May Be the Open Road

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
AMERICAN truck drivers and their union, along with a number of Democrats and Republicans, have been battling to keep Mexican trucks in Mexico. In doing so, they have shaped the debate so that it seems to be about safety and not protectionism. But another way to think about it is as a fight over economic power and how to use it in a rapidly globalizing world.
 The fundamental premise behind international trade pacts like the North American Free Trade Agreement is that when countries work together, the result of their combined efforts is greater than what any of them could deliver to their people by controlling their economies alone. In other words, under this theory, the best way to stronger, more equitable economies is not by relying on traditional methods of sovereign control, in which strong powers dictate to weak ones, often sowing resentment, resistance and retribution. 
 Rather, nations in cross-border compacts knowingly cede some control over how their economies work in exchange for advantages like open access and equality of treatment that are supposed to level the playing field for everyone. And that, in turn, increases trade and spreads the wealth. 
That's been the theory, anyway. Now, as the agreements begin to mature, it is becoming clearer that power is not shared equally. And so the strongest members, when they worry about surrendering sovereignty, may be worrying for nothing. Their economic might, it turns out, is often not diminished at all, but simply transformed into a kind of stealth power, enabling them to exert even greater influence and achieve broader goals.
Take the border ban. The truckers want the United States to use power in the old way to keep out Mexicans drivers and their rigs, requiring them to undergo special safety inspections on the premise that many are unsafe. Underlying this is a calculation that this gives the American trucking industry, and its drivers, a more secure future. The decision by the United States, dating to the Clinton administration, to ignore the provisions of Nafta that would have freed long-haul trucks from Mexico, the United States and Canada -- the third leg of the Nafta trinity -- to cross the borders unhindered, clearly violates the agreement that took effect in 1994. And, in the minds of many experts, it is also likely to hurt the American trucking fleet more than it helps it. 
What often gets overlooked, these experts say, is that the border ban is reciprocal -- and that the American trucking industry is in a position to play that to its own advantage. Aaron Dichter, Mexico's under secretary for transportation, said American trucks operating in Mexico face the same restriction as Mexican trucks in the United States. They can cross the border but cannot leave a narrow commercial zone that extends no more than 20 miles. Like Mexican drivers on the other side, they drop loads at transfer points, from which domestic trucks and drivers complete the delivery. 
Mexican trucking executives say that even if border blockades are lifted by the end of this year, as President Bush has promised, only a few of the biggest Mexican rigs could make deliveries deep into the United States. The patchwork of regulations, including a requirement that trucks be licensed in every state where they operate, intimidates most truckers. 
WHAT is most likely to happen, say Mexico experts like George W. Grayson of the College of William and Mary, is that the better-financed and more competitive American trucking outfits will enter the growing Mexican market either through joint ventures or in head-to-head competition. "I'd be surprised if, two or three years after the border was opened, 80 to 85 percent of long hauls from Mexico weren't handled by the U.S. trucking fleet," Professor Grayson said. 
Of course, this example echoes the basic argument for the efficiencies of global trade that have been put forward by all recent American presidents, from Ronald Reagan to George W. Bush. "If you relax your total control, you can more effectively enhance your economy and your development," said Robert A. Pastor, an Emory University political scientist and former member of the National Security Council. 
In the old days, when bashing the United States was a stock in trade for many Latin American populists, Mexico built walls around its economy to keep from being smothered by the United States. But those walls didn't feed their people. However much that protectionism gratified Mexican nationalists, "they found themselves deteriorating behind the walls and eventually had to dismantle them," Professor Pastor said. As a result, since Nafta came into effect in 1994, exports from Mexico have grown faster than from any other nation. But in the same period, American investments in almost every sector of the Mexican economy have grown too. 
Similarly, Canada has long resented American arrogance and for many years tried to keep the United States out. In the 1970's, the nationalist government of Pierre Trudeau severely limited foreign investment in Canadian oil and controlled prices. Exploration and drilling all but stopped, and the industry stagnated. 
After entering free trade agreements with the United States, Canada lost the power to erect such obstacles. But its energy exports have boomed, and it is now the United States' No. 1 foreign supplier of oil and natural gas.
Pierre S. Pettigrew, Canada's minister of international trade, sees the growth of American power and accepts it because of the benefits it brings Canada. "There are certain things that can no longer be legislated because we've signed international agreements," he said. "But in so doing, the U.S. ends up being even more powerful because you have another kind of relationship that is growing, that is developing, that is strengthening all elements of the three countries." 
While such a system produces winners in all three countries, it also produces friction, especially when it seems that a state's sovereignty has been compromised. Mr. Pettigrew was in Washington last week to meet with his American and Mexican counterparts to tinker with the part of Nafta that gives unelected tribunals the power to secretly resolve disputes between international investors and governments. 
Still, most nations -- including the United States under President Bush -- are eager to join international trade agreements, if only as a measure of self-protection against the growing power of competing trade blocs in other areas, like the European Union.
THAT doesn't mean, however, that the Bush administration likes all international agreements to the same degree, especially compacts that are not about trade. President Bush has steadfastly refused to submit to international agreements like the Kyoto protocol on greenhouse gases, the small-arms control pact and other treaties. The inconsistency has angered allies and given opponents issues to focus on. 
"The White House should follow its own advice consistently," said one, Thomas F. McLarty III, who was President Clinton's chief of staff. "It's pretty clear that in an interconnected world, the U.S. is going to have to engage with, and not dictate, to our partners."
In contrast to the Clinton administration's approach to international agreements, the current administration clearly prefers to pick only those compacts where surrendering control may actually increase American economic power, while passing on those that simply acknowledge the globe's interconnectedness.

HEADLINE: Sunday Q&A 

 BODY:
 Sunday Q & A appears in this section weekly. Readers are invited to send in questions about national or international affairs; those selected will be answered by Times correspondents who specialize in those issues. Information about submitting questions appears below.

Collateral Effect of Atomic Explosions

Q. Recent talks between India and Pakistan bring up the question of possible use of nuclear weapons. If there were, say, 2 to 20 atomic explosions in that part of the world, aside from the disastrous consequences at the point of detonation, what would be the likely effects on other continents?

A. James Glanz, a science correspondent for The Times, responds:
 By breaking a taboo that has existed for more than half a century, a nuclear exchange of that magnitude would make the world an infinitely more dangerous place and lead to consequences no one could foresee. With millions dead by blast, fire and radiation poisoning on the Indian subcontinent, civilizations there could collapse into chaos, potentially destabilizing governments around the globe.
The physical effects outside the region would be the least of the world's worries -- assuming the horrific situation did not spark nuclear war elsewhere. Before 1963, when a treaty banned the testing of nuclear weapons in the atmosphere, radioactive strontium, a fission byproduct, wafted around the globe and generated international outrage. Closer to the explosions, a radioactive isotope of iodine rained from the sky onto plants eaten by cows and goats, which then produced radioactive milk. Those distressing episodes would be replayed in the wake of a nuclear war between India and Pakistan.
The global economic consequences of such a disaster are incalculable. The world would somehow have to intervene to help more than a billion people whose governments had neglected their interests in the most repugnant way imaginable.
Finally, the United States and other Western countries would rightly fear that the end of the nuclear taboo would mean an increase in proliferation, possibly leading to an era in which nuclear terrorism became a credible threat. The effect of a shadow that dark on humanity's fortunes is beyond reckoning.

The Meaning of the Five Olympic Rings

Q. What is the origin of the five-circle Olympic logo?

A. Jere Longman, a sports reporter for The Times who has covered eight Olympics, responds:
The five interlocking Olympic rings symbolize the union of the original continents that participated in the modern Games -- Africa, the Americas, Asia, Australia and Europe -- as well as the meeting of the athletes from those continents, according to the United States Olympic Committee. Baron Pierre de Coubertin, founder of the modern Games in 1896, designed the symbol in 1913.
The five colors of the rings, always appearing in the same order from top to bottom and left to right, are blue, black, red, yellow and green. The colors chosen by the International Olympic Committee no longer carry a special meaning, although previously, at least one of the five colors was found in the national flag of every nation participating in the Olympic movement.

The Ins and Outs of Warning Labels

Q. Why are there so many consumer warnings on products sold in the United States, and why do the admonishments on so many of them seem so obvious?

A. Greg Winter, a consumer products correspondent for The Times, responds:
 Consumers are filing fewer product liability cases than they have in years, but the fear of them is still strong. Many consumer product manufacturers put warning labels on their products just to make sure they are not vulnerable to lawsuits.
Of course, some of those warnings would appear to be self-evident, and few of them are actually required by the government. But regulators often suggest, sometimes quite strongly, that manufacturers put them on anyway, even if they seem obvious. 
The way most government agencies see it, intelligence, or even common sense, is not a prerequisite for buying, so leaving it to the consumer to figure out what is safe is merely an invitation to more accidents. For many a regulator, protecting consumers has little to do with having faith in them. 
Still, most warnings are voluntary, and in some cases they are actually a mixed blessing for consumers. Take the trend to adding words like "may contain peanuts" on a number of foods, particularly cookies, candies and other products with nuts. The disclaimer is meant to protect people with food allergies, who sometimes die from eating just a small amount of everyday ingredients that most consumers take for granted. 
That would seem to be a service to allergic consumers, especially because specks of nuts often get into products where they are not supposed to be, usually without the manufacturer's knowledge. But as more and more companies slap these warning labels on their foods, shoring up against lawsuits, people with food allergies complain that they are left with fewer and fewer things to eat. 
Allergic consumers complain that instead of actually making sure their products do not have nuts or other undisclosed ingredients, manufacturers are taking the easy way out, protecting themselves at the expense of those who most rely on their diligence.

HEADLINE: Drug Use Begetting AIDS in Central Asia 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: TEMIRTAU, Kazakhstan 

 BODY:
The five nations of Central Asia may be at the brink of an explosive growth in AIDS, medical experts and government officials say.
 "There is a growing drug trade, declining standards of living and social chaos," said Jay Dobkin, director of the AIDS program at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, who has visited the region three times in recent months. "It's hard to know if there is going to be an explosion, but it's smarter not to wait and see." 
 So far, the official number of people with AIDS or who are H.I.V. positive is relatively low in most of the countries -- Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan -- but experts believe the figures are underreported. 
Two decades after AIDS began taking its toll on the rest of the world, these isolated nations -- all formerly republics of the Soviet Union -- are still hobbled by taboos, meager resources and authoritarian bureaucracies. They have been slow to develop programs to counter the steep rise in drug abuse and to educate people about AIDS. 
In Kyrgyzstan the government allots just $26,500 for AIDS prevention and awareness programs, and throughout the area there are almost no treatment centers. 
In June the United Nations concluded there was a basis for more people getting AIDS in all five countries. It cited the rapid increase in drug use, high levels of sexually transmitted diseases, widespread prostitution and a population with more than half its people under 25.
Oxsana, 27, said she started using drugs seven years ago, at the age of 20, here in Temirtau. There was nothing to do, she said. "I decided to try with my friends the first time," she said. "It was easy to buy drugs." 
By the time she started using a mixture of opium and flour in 1994, there were plenty of abandoned apartments where drug users would congregate. Nobody had heard of AIDS in Temirtau and, as in the culture of drugs elsewhere, they shared needles. 
The specter of AIDS follows the path of heroin and opium trafficking from Afghanistan to Kazakhstan and its Central Asian neighbors, all of which are way stations for drugs headed to Russia and Europe. 
As inevitably happens, transit countries have turned into user countries. Where there were almost no intravenous drug users a decade ago, today there are an estimated 300,000 among the region's 55 million people. 
In Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan, the most fragile and poorest countries in the region, a full-blown AIDS crisis could overwhelm medical resources and cause political and social instability, experts warn. For now, the crisis is worst in Kazakhstan, a nation of 17 million people.
The United Nations estimates that 3,500 people here are H.I.V. positive or have AIDS; the Kazakhstan government puts the figure at 1,700 and unofficial estimates are as high as 10,000. Official figures put the totals at about 100 people in each of the other four countries in the region, though those figures are also thought to be low. 
Ground zero is Temirtau, a city of 160,000 in central Kazakhstan. It is a laboratory for the effects of the social and economic woes that swept across the region like a medieval plague after the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991. 
Temirtau was built during World War II, to produce steel using coal from nearby mines. When the Soviet Union collapsed, so did the city's economy and the social institutions. Almost overnight, people were trapped by unemployment, poverty, crime and disillusionment. 
Temirtau, near the primary road from Afghanistan to Russia, proved fertile territory for the drug business. Some people sold drugs to survive; more used them to cope. 
Oxsana's boyfriend, Sasha, a 28-year-old intravenous drug user who still manages to hold onto his job at a steel plant, said drugs are easy to find and cheap to buy. After eight years of using opium, he said he needs about $3 a day to maintain a level mood, more to get high. 
Sasha and Oxsana have watched many friends die from AIDS. There is no rehabilitation program to help them get off drugs, but they visit a city-run needle-exchange program to get free syringes and condoms. 
The center, in a converted kindergarten, financed by the United Nations and a local steel company, provides checkups and some medication for people with AIDS or who are H.I.V. positive. Space and resources are limited and there is no treatment capacity.
No one is sure how the virus that causes AIDS came to this isolated town on the steppes. 
Abdygaliev Berik, the deputy mayor, and Svetlana Krukovskaya, a supervisor at the AIDS center, said the prevailing theory is that a businessman contracted the virus in Moscow and brought it back here. 
The first known case in Temirtau was discovered in 1996 when a drug user was arrested and tested. Since then the number of cases has grown and the latest figures show that 918 people are H.I.V. positive, nearly 1 in 1,600, and 106 have died of AIDS-related illnesses. 
Experts are convinced AIDS is equally severe elsewhere in Kazakhstan. Most cases are discovered when drug users and prostitutes are arrested and tested. Temirtau is the only place where international attention led to widespread testing of the general population. 
"H.I.V. and AIDS in Kazakhstan are not just in Temirtau, unfortunately," said Valeriya Gourevich, a doctor who runs a public health program in Almaty, the country's most populous city with 1.2 million people. The program is sponsored by the New York-based Soros Foundation. 
She listed six other cities, from Aktobe in oil-rich western Kazakhstan to Pavlodar near the Russian border in the northeast and Shymkent in the south, where heavy drug use indicates widespread AIDS. 
In Kazakhstan, 80 percent of those found to be H.I.V. positive are intravenous drug users, experts say. But data from Temirtau presented at a United Nations conference in June found an increasing percentage of cases transmitted by sexual activity. The disclosure alarmed experts because it indicates drug users are spreading the virus to spouses and lovers, increasing the potential for an epidemic. 
The risk of contracting AIDS is high throughout Central Asia partly because deeply rooted attitudes prevent appropriate education and preventive techniques, said Dr. Gourevich. Parents rarely discuss sex with children and cases sexually transmitted diseases are increasing sharply.
Evgenia Misurevich, 26, was one of the first people in Temirtau to find out she was H.I.V. positive. She said she had never heard of the virus or AIDS before she got it in 1996 from sharing a needle. 
Drugs first arrived in Temirtau a decade ago and Ms. Misurevich said she was eager to try them. "It was a new thing and we thought it was cool," she said.
She said she got the virus from a cellmate in prison, where drug use was rampant. Ms. Misurevich was serving a four-year sentence for theft to support her drug habit.
"I understood something was wrong when the doctor said I needed to go to a separate cell," she said, waiting for a checkup in the bleak examining room of the AIDS center. 
Ms. Misurevich stopped using drugs after contracting the virus in prison. But she said she returned to drug use when she was released last year, though she said she used her own needle. Five months ago, she entered a rehabilitation program run by the Roman Catholic Church, one of two religion-based rehabilitation programs in the country of 17 million. She said she is drug-free and feels well. 
Despite the highest incidence of AIDS in the region, Kazakhstan has no government-operated treatment centers. 
The situation is the same in Almaty, 600 miles south. Medical officials said there is no place where people who are H.I.V. positive or have AIDS can get treatment and few education programs. 
Dr. Dobkin of Columbia-Presbyterian said a bureaucracy has grown up around the issue without taking concrete steps to tackle AIDS yet. "There are a lot of people with AIDS on their business cards, but I couldn't find any evidence of anybody getting any treatment," he said. 
"We have never figured out what leads to an epidemic in one place and not others, but there is no time to waste here."

HEADLINE: Dallas Bleeds as Job Cuts Rake Tech Sector 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: RICHARDSON, Tex., Aug. 3 

 BODY:
Early last year, with the Dallas area unemployment rate hovering at about 3 percent, companies in the Telecom Corridor here in the northern suburbs were so frantic to lure talent that one of them asked whether it could pay professors at the University of Texas at Dallas $5,000 for each recruit, said the school's engineering and computer science dean, William P. Osborne. "I said: 'It's a free country. I can't stop you from doing that, but I'm absolutely opposed.' "
 But now, pink slips are being handed out like last year's signing bonuses. With the severe downturn in telecommunications that began late last year, the flow of cash from investors and orders from customers has ceased, throwing out of work thousands of prosperous employees who had never likened their job security to working at a dot-com. The local unemployment rate in June stood at 4.2 percent, still moderate but up 50 percent, from 2.8 percent, in six months, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. 
 Compared with the rest of Texas, Dallas has always had a fairly diversified economy, with plenty of jobs in financial services, real estate, transportation, retail and energy. In recent years, the region has also capitalized on the nation's technology boom, establishing in Richardson a niche for designing, building and selling telecommunications gear. 
Since the end of last year, however, more than 10,000 Dallas-area high-technology employees have lost their jobs, industry officials say, most of them in and around Richardson at companies including Nortel Networks, Alcatel and Ericsson. The region's experience illustrates how the carnage from the collapse of the corporate spending-and-investment binge, led by technology, has spread far beyond places like Austin and Silicon Valley.
Today's unemployment report indicated that across the nation, corporations continued to cut their payrolls in July, although the unemployment rate was steady. Economists are debating whether the continuing cutbacks in corporate spending, especially on technology, will leave the economy at a standstill, or worse. 
The economic reversal has been especially abrupt for victims like Denny Buck, 50, who made a six-figure salary working at Alcatel, the French telecommunications giant, which has announced about 1,400 layoffs here in the last four months. Mr. Buck fears he might have to sell his house if he does not find work. He has some optimism, but he notes there are now thousands of similarly skilled people in his predicament. "It doesn't help to have all those people battling for the same jobs," he said. 
Fiona Sigalla, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, confirms that Mr. Buck is not alone. "High tech in general -- but telecom in particular -- provided a tremendous positive stimulus for economic growth here during the last five years," she said. But with the telecommunications bust, "we've gone from having an industry hiring rapidly and building lots of space to an industry contracting and laying off large numbers of people." 
In Texas, as in much of the country, technology has become an increasingly important part of the economy. In the state's electrical and electronic equipment industries, total industrial production has soared 125 percent since 1987, according to the Dallas Fed. By comparison, oil and gas extraction experienced only a 4.9 percent gain over the same period. 
The telecommunications industry's sharp downturn helps explain the rise in the nation's unemployment rate over the last year, from 3.9 percent in October to 4.5 percent last month. Across Texas, the June unemployment rate stood at 4.6 percent, according to the Dallas Fed, up from 3.7 percent at year-end.
As one of the nation's more rapidly growing areas, Dallas is likely to continue to outperform much of the nation, economists say. "Dallas is large enough and diverse enough to withstand this, particularly if this is temporary, and we think it will be," said Ray Perryman, head of an economic consulting firm in Waco, halfway between Austin and Dallas.
He predicts the region's economic output will grow 3.5 percent annually over the next few years while employment grows at slightly more than 2 percent, aided by gains in businesses including those that support aviation and international trade. That growth is "well below the last couple of years, but a lot of cities would love to have it," Mr. Perryman said.
But in addition to the layoffs, there are other clear signs of the industry's retrenchment affecting the region. Office vacancy rates in Richardson and neighboring Plano have more than doubled in the last year, to 14 percent from 6 percent, according to Tracy Fults, an executive director in the Dallas office of Kennedy-Wilson International, a real estate firm. 
Tenants in the two cities have vacated about 580,000 square feet of office space, the rough equivalent of a 30-story office building, since the beginning of the year, and plans for another 450,000 square feet have been stalled, Mr. Fults said. 
Last year, for example, Cisco Systems announced plans for a seven-building campus in Richardson. But the company recently scaled back those plans, putting two of the buildings on hold, and said it would build, but not occupy, one of the others.
Similarly, venture capital investment in Dallas has plunged, in line with a nationwide pattern. In the second quarter, Dallas companies received $176 million in venture capital investment in 17 deals, according to VentureWire, a New York firm that tracks venture capital investment. In the period last year, Dallas companies got $469 million in 37 deals.
The Dallas area's emergence as a telecommunications center goes back to the early 1980's. Richardson was uniquely prepared to capitalize on the breakup of American Telephone and Telegraph. It boasted not only Texas Instruments, which remains one of the largest employers, but also Collins Radio, then a division of Rockwell International, which specialized in military telecommunications and was one of the few companies that had technological sophistication to rival AT&T's. 
Civic and business leaders had also worked to establish a new branch of the state university system, the University of Texas at Dallas, to train technology workers. Situated in Richardson, the university is now one of the largest producers of computer science graduates. In all, more than 600 technology companies are within five miles of the school, employing more than 80,000 workers.
But their rapid growth ended abruptly last year, as the flow of capital from Wall Street ceased while large companies curtailed spending on telecommunications equipment. Some customers pushed large amounts of inventory back to their suppliers. 
"The basic problem was manufacturers were building and service providers were buying and installing on forecasts for demand that just could not go on forever," said Dean Osborne, who believes an industry rebound could be a year or more away. "You won't see the telecom industry have this bad a downturn again in our lifetime."
One of the region's business leaders, however, said that the impact of the cutbacks might be overstated because as many as 40 percent of those who have been laid off have found new jobs in the industry. 
"There is a perception in the tech world that nobody is hiring, but I don't think that's true here," said Ron Robinson, who as president of the Technology Business Council, a trade group in Richardson, has played a large role in luring new employers. In particular, many small companies are hiring, he said. 
But at after-work retreats like Nedley's, a bar and restaurant here, farewell gatherings have replaced the celebrations of a year or two ago for co-workers who had landed jobs with promising start-ups. 
Employees who are stunned to find they have lost their jobs often want to go out for drinks with their colleagues, said Ned Gilblom, the restaurant's owner. "If they just drop the bomb on them," he said, "they say, 'We need to go to a bar.' " His lunch business, he added, is off 30 percent. 
Many of those laid off this year have been socked with another setback as the value of their past compensation -- much of it based on shares of company stock, including 401(k)'s -- has plunged. "I know friends who have lost millions; it's awful," said Stephanie Schweizer, 36, who was laid off by Nortel Networks in April after six years with the company and has yet to find another job. Shares of Nortel, which closed Friday at $8.04, have fallen 90 percent in the last year.
Until recently, Ms. Schweizer said she had considered her job secure. "I never thought telecom was going to go away," she said. "We were a family. We were just soaring. Everyone was making their numbers. It was just such a positive place to work." 
Recently, she ran into a former co-worker who had taken a job selling women's clothes at a local mall. "It's really sad to see someone basically be reduced to working as if they had never gotten a college degree," she said. "It's like a death. Every day, I'm talking to people about who is on the chopping block next."

HEADLINE: CNN Aims at Young Viewers As It Revamps News Format 

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
To hear AOL Time Warner executives talk about their plans to revamp CNN's Headline News, you might think they were talking about plans to start a music channel. 
 They have promised splashier graphics, a multisectioned screen that resembles a Web site, background music of techno and alternative rock guitar. The channel has been promoted in commercials featuring Moby, the D.J. and singer, and New Order, the alternative pop band. 
 One anchor will be Andrea Thompson, until last year an actress on "NYPD Blue," who was hired by CNN after spending 11 months in a local news boot camp in New Mexico, where she gained her only professional experience in journalism.
The changes at Headline News, shepherded by two Hollywood entertainment executives and scheduled to begin Monday, are among the most aggressive attempts in television news to lure a younger audience. The reason behind the revamping reflects a fundamental problem for TV news divisions: their audience tends to be older but television is increasingly driven by advertisers demanding a younger audience. The median age of Headline News viewers this year is about 54; CNN's is 64. 
The issue has become an urgent one for the news divisions, whose corporate parents are increasingly under pressure to produce financial growth. But it also raises a tricky question: How do you reach younger people, many of them weaned on MTV, without alienating the core older viewers?
How Headline News bridges the divide will be closely watched in the television industry. Headline News is much like all-news radio, giving quick reports on the major stories. The channel will continue to report breaking news and give viewers the crucial headlines of the moment. But it will also place greater emphasis on entertainment, health and fitness, the environment and technology, with in-studio correspondents who specialize in these subjects.
It will be easy to trip up. Networks trying similar strategies have at times been ridiculed. ABC News drew the scorn of critics and had a near-revolt among its staff in the spring of 2000 when it featured the actor Leonardo DiCaprio as the host of a prime-time special on the environment. He even interviewed President Bill Clinton. In ratings parlance, it bombed.
But CNN says the new Headline News will be more subtle and alluring. "What we're trying to do is be more fascinating, be a little broader in our definition of what's interesting to people and attract people of all ages, period," said Walter Isaacson, the new CNN chairman and former editorial director of Time Inc.
The new look was not developed by Mr. Isaacson, who only signed on at CNN last month. Mr. Isaacson, however, applied the same theory to Time magazine, and is believed to have given it a greater youth appeal.
CNN's new approach was developed with help from two executives who have specialized in teasing younger viewers to television sets -- Jamie Kellner and Garth Ancier. Mr. Kellner, the chief executive of Turner Broadcasting System -- the AOL Time Warner division that oversees CNN -- led the Fox and WB networks, which brought to television "The Simpsons" and "Buffy the Vampire Slayer." Mr. Ancier, the new Turner executive vice president, was a top programmer at both networks, as well as the president of NBC Entertainment.
Still, CNN executives said they did not expect too many in Generation Y to tune in. They said they were mostly aiming at those on the older side of Generation X, in the 35 range, and baby boomers.
The main bet is that younger viewers want news fast, to fit their busy lives. So reports will be short and fast-paced. The screen will be bordered by panels with bits of information all at once -- weather, stock indexes, quick headlines -- in a more extreme version of the Internet-style information bars on the Fox News Channel, MSNBC and CNN.
Last month, at a gathering of television reporters and critics in Pasadena, Calif., Turner Broadcasting executives introducing the new network look were heckled over its fast pace and busy screen. But Mr. Kellner argued back. Mr. Kellner, 54, acknowledged that the new style might not appeal to older viewers. "People my age," he said, "are going to have a harder time, maybe, buying in. But my 29-year-old daughter is going to sit there glued to it, and it's going to be servicing her needs to get a lot of different information."
By the standards of television news, a 29-year-old is a spring hatchling. The median age of the audience for the television news generally hovers around 60 and above. 
In years past, the age of the news audience was not much of an issue. But advertising executives have put a growing premium on younger viewers, who they say are more open to messages but harder than ever to reach because they have so many new media choices while leading very busy lives. Corporate owners, meanwhile, under pressure from Wall Street to increase revenue and profit, are less willing to exempt their news divisions from the forces of the marketplace.
And while news divisions could once rest easy in the knowledge that the apathetic young people would tune in eventually, when they had families and more income and a greater stake in society, that is no longer the case. The younger generations now have a wealth of options for news, from the Internet to the Comedy Central channel's "The Daily Show With Jon Stewart," a nightly satire that became such a source for campaign news last fall that Nielsen, the predominant audience measurement service, included it in its ratings report for election night.
"I think that there is more awareness of the demographic performance of news programs on the part of news people, certainly," said Andrew Heyward, president of CBS News. "And on the part of parent companies, too, than there was five years ago. That's to some degree the increasingly businesslike scrutiny that news divisions operate under."
Mr. Heyward said that pressure might be increasing with the success this last year of so-called reality programs like CBS's "Survivor," which have done exceptionally well with younger viewers -- proving to the news divisions' corporate parents that younger people can be drawn to nonfiction programming if it is tailored to their tastes.
In fact, the CBS morning news program, "The Early Show," has relied heavily on coverage of "Survivor" to increase its younger audience, which, Mr. Heyward said, has helped it significantly raise revenue.
Driving the strategy of news executives is their belief that younger viewers -- who came of age in the relatively peaceful times and prolonged economic growth of the 1990's -- are not as interested in traditional news areas like Washington politics and foreign affairs.
MSNBC's more straightforward evening news program, "The News With Brian Williams," draws an older audience than do the network's feature programs, like the biography program "Headliners and Legends" (among this past week's subjects were the actresses Halle Berry and Elizabeth Montgomery) or "MSNBC Investigates" (last Tuesday night featured the murder of a Los Angeles police officer who became a strip club mogul.) They have helped give MSNBC the youngest of the news audiences, with a median age of about 51.
Network news traditionalists often scoff at MSNBC's approach as pandering. But Erik Sorenson, the MSNBC president and general manager, said that television news must accommodate the needs of baby boomers and Generation X.
"For our parents' and grandparents' generation, it was relatively straightforward," he said. "We were in a dangerous cold-war era, our shores were not considered safe, we could still remember the Depression so the actions of our government in Washington were crucial."
The younger generations, he said, "grew up much more skeptical of Washington, feeling less threatened, much more secure, both economically and physically, and we have a much broader definition of what's relevant."
The experiment at Headline News, however, involves a very different sort of beast -- one that has essentially served as a generic wire service of straightforward news reports whose viewers may be scared off by all the pizazz. 
CNN, however, seems to believe it can afford to experiment with Headline News, available in 78 million homes. Though the network remains profitable because of its low expenses -- it uses the news produced by its larger sibling CNN -- the audience for Headline News, has declined in recent years. At any given time its average audience has 170,000 people, down from 219,000 people in 1996. CNN's is 319,000 so far this year.
So AOL Time Warner executives hardly seemed upset by all the criticism they received for hiring Ms. Thompson, the actress, as an anchor -- even after nude photographs taken of her years ago for a 1986 film, "Manhattan Gigolo," surfaced on the Internet last spring. After all, attention is attention.
At the Pasadena news conference, Ms. Thompson, 41, was asked if she thought her experience on "NYPD Blue" helped her get the Headline News job. "Certainly I am not a seasoned journalist," she said. "If my stardom or past has something to do with that, then what I say is, you know what? Use me, baby."

HEADLINE: New Melting Pot of Museums Downtown; 
A Cultural Hub Takes Shape in Manhattan's Oldest Quarter

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Never mind the Met, the Frick, the Guggenheim. New York's new Museum Mile is taking shape from Chambers Street to State Street.
 With little fanfare, Lower Manhattan has become a cultural destination in its own right, coming out of a strong economy and capitalizing on the growing popular interest in heritage and history. A dozen museums are now operating, and several important ones will be arriving in the next few years. 
 In fact, keep the Guggenheim in mind. It may end up as the 800-pound, titanium-skinned gorilla on the downtown museum scene, providing a critical cultural mass that has not yet been reached, though it certainly feels close. 
"There's a significant synergy when you have cultural institutions within walking distance," said David G. Marwell, director of the Museum of Jewish Heritage -- A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, which opened in 1997 at Battery Park City. "People can plan an entire day around them."
It seems almost inevitable that the oldest quarter of New York should emerge as a museum nexus, something more than a stopping-off point on the way to the top of the World Trade Center or over to Liberty and Ellis Islands. Served by almost every subway line, Lower Manhattan is compact and eminently strollable, its bewildering ancient street patchwork rendered more navigable with way-finding signs installed by the Alliance for Downtown New York.
Hotels are opening. Restaurants and stores are doing business on weekends. It is even possible to see a movie without using a MetroCard.
Though no one seriously proposes that Lower Manhattan will soon overtake the Upper East Side as a destination for cultural tourism, it has some special advantages in being wrapped by waterfront.
"We have boat models that are 300 feet long," noted Peter A. Aron, trustee and chairman emeritus of the South Street Seaport Museum.
Lower Manhattan also has a form of transportation unavailable along Fifth Avenue. Three percent of visitors to the Museum of Jewish Heritage arrive by ferry, said Abby R. Spilka, the director of communications. "I dare the Metropolitan Museum of Art to give you that statistic," she said.
Another distinct characteristic is that almost every museum downtown is historically connected in some way to the building it occupies or the land on which it stands. "We have heritage down here," said Valerie Lewis, assistant vice president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, which runs the Lower Manhattan Business Improvement District. "That's our niche."
And this seems to be the moment for heritage. "New Yorkers are coming to understand and appreciate that they do have a history," said Robert R. Macdonald, director of the Museum of the City of New York, which is planning to move from the Upper East Side to the Tweed Courthouse behind City Hall in two years.
John Haworth, director of the George Gustav Heye Center of the National Museum of the American Indian, has noted many visitors from Brazil, France, Germany, Britain, Canada and Mexico. "There's a lot of interest in what's really American," Mr. Haworth said.
The Heye Center (pronounced "high") is a branch of the Smithsonian Institution that sprawls through the Beaux-Arts chambers of the former United States Custom House on Bowling Green. As it happens, this marks the end of what was once the Wiechquaekeck Trail, an important Algonquian trading route.
A cultural hub unto itself, the Heye Center is currently presenting Seth Eastman's watercolors of the Dakota, decorated Plains Indian shirts and a show examining the relation between American Indians and the medium of photography.
The museum moved in 1994 from Audubon Terrace at Broadway and 155th Street, where 35,000 people visited a year. "We attract that many visitors in a month down here," Mr. Haworth said.
Audubon Terrace will soon be losing another institution, the American Numismatic Society, to Lower Manhattan.
Early next year, the society will move into the seven-story former Fidelity and Deposit Company Building at 140 William Street, on the corner of Fulton Street, where it plans to build its own museum.
For the next five years, beginning Oct. 18, the society will present "Drachmas, Doubloons and Dollars: The History of Money" in a 5,000-square-foot exhibition space at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, at 33 Liberty Street.
By December, the New York City Police Museum will have moved out of the former Cunard Building at 25 Broadway and into its own home in the former First Precinct station house at 100 Old Slip, on the East River, where it will have 8,000 square feet of exhibition space.
Also by the end of the year, a designer may have been chosen for the Museum of Women: the Leadership Center, cater-corner from the Museum of Jewish Heritage, said Timothy S. Carey, president of the Battery Park City Authority.
In March 2002, the Irish Hunger Memorial will open in Battery Park City. Though not strictly a museum, the 96-by-170-foot installation will have a real 19th-century stone cottage from Attymass, Ireland, as the centerpiece of a landscape meant to evoke the Irish countryside. It was designed by Brian Tolle, 1100 Architects and Gail Eileen Wittwer.
The authority also plans to set aside 3,000 to 4,000 square feet in a future development to serve as a world hunger information center, Mr. Carey said.
Later in 2002, the Skyscraper Museum will open at the base of the Ritz-Carlton Downtown, on the third corner of Battery Park City's museum crossroads. This $7 million, 5,800-square-foot space, by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, will be the first true home of an institution that has bounced around the skyscrapers of Lower Manhattan since its opening four years ago.
The year 2003 should prove to be a cultural watershed for downtown.
In the fall, the Museum of the City of New York is to open in the Tweed Courthouse, which is nearing the end of a meticulous city-financed restoration. The museum will have up to 40,000 square feet of exhibition space, more than twice what it has at Fifth Avenue and 103rd Street. The design is by Ralph Appelbaum Associates and Cooper Robertson & Partners. There will be a restaurant, a gift shop and perhaps a visitors center in conjunction with NYC & Company, the convention and visitors bureau.
In September 2003, the Museum of Jewish Heritage plans to open a $60 million, 70,000-square-foot east wing to its existing museum, designed by the same architects, Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo & Associates. Within the new wing will be the Edmond J. Safra Hall for public programs like films, concerts, lectures, dramatic productions and discussions.
Toward the end of 2003, the South Street Seaport Museum plans to complete a $20 million renovation of Schermerhorn Row on Fulton Street and the adjacent A. A. Low Building. This 30,000-square-foot space, designed by Beyer Blinder Belle, is to house an ambitious permanent exhibition, "World Port New York." Also in 2003, the Heye Center will open a $3 million education center in a 6,400-square-foot space under the grand rotunda.
At that point, the Guggenheim proposal -- a cloudlike fantasy designed by Frank O. Gehry that would be constructed on connecting platforms over the East River -- will still be going through governmental review. The $678 million project would include a 570,000-square-foot building and more than six acres of public park and outdoor sculpture areas.
Big as it would be, the downtown Guggenheim is envisioned by Thomas Krens, director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, as the portal to something even larger, said Laurie Beckelman, deputy director for special projects.
Imagine new cultural sites on Governors Island, she said, and art galleries in the Port Authority pier sheds at the foot of Brooklyn Heights, all linked across the harbor by ferries or water taxis. "It will go beyond Manhattan," Ms. Beckelman said.
Which raises a question. How long is a Museum Nautical Mile?

HEADLINE: In Bronx Revival, Ferrer Is Credited With Only a Supporting Role 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
A few steps from the South Bronx curbside where Fernando Ferrer kicked off his run for mayor sits the site of his childhood home -- the long-vanished wellspring, he says, of his campaign for the city's highest office.
 Mr. Ferrer left his childhood home, a five-story walk-up at 588 Fox Street, in 1965, moving with his mother and sister to a nicer apartment a few blocks away. Eleven years later, with thousands of people fleeing the crumbling borough, the first of four fires raced through the Fox Street building. In 1978, now gutted and charred, it was demolished and swept away. 
 "I saw my own neighborhood go up in smoke," said Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president since 1987. "I took it personally. It really did ignite all that I'm about in public life." 
As he travels New York's four other boroughs in his quest to become mayor, Mr. Ferrer has taken much of the credit for the Bronx's renaissance. He is selling the image of the rebuilt borough as a model for serving "the other New York" that he says was left out of the city's economic surge of the 1990's. Mr. Ferrer promises that if elected, he will set aside $13 billion to build 150,000 homes and apartments over the next 10 years.
Mr. Ferrer's old building never came back, but Fox Street did, and so did the rest of the South Bronx. In a transformation that is now nearly legendary, the Bronx rebuilt itself, adding nearly 70,000 new or rebuilt homes since 1987. The exodus ended, too: since 1980, the Bronx's population has risen by more than 160,000 people.
There is once again a hum of activity on Fox Street, a long string of town houses and apartments framing a scene of commerce and commotion. Mr. Ferrer's old building may be gone, but in its place stands a modern, two-family town house in immaculate shape. "It's a touch of suburbia here," said Frances Nater, a retired nurse, whose home occupies the spot where Mr. Ferrer once lived.
Mr. Ferrer offers few specifics on his exact role in the Bronx's comeback, even though it is the central event of his political career. He tosses out mostly general statements. "I packed the pipeline tight with projects," Mr. Ferrer said during a recent interview. "I was in the middle of everything."
In fact, the reconstruction of the South Bronx was a sprawling and complicated undertaking, costing hundreds of millions of dollars and summoning the efforts of hundreds of people. Interviews with some of the central players suggest that in his 14 years as borough president, Mr. Ferrer was a relentless advocate for rebuilding the Bronx, though he lacked the power to direct the effort himself. He was not the star, say many people who worked with Mr. Ferrer at the time, but he was not on the sideline either.
"He could have been an impediment, but he was an asset," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who helped bring about the Bronx's renaissance in the 1980's. "He was cooperative." 
According to several of the players, when Mr. Ferrer became borough president in 1987, the most important decision affecting the future of his borough had already been made. The year before, the Koch administration had set aside more than $4 billion as part of a 10-year plan to rebuild the city's crumbling housing stock.
Over the next decade, as Mr. Ferrer reigned as borough president, the Koch administration and its successors channeled millions of dollars to neighborhood groups and developers willing to work in the area. When the dollars first began to flow, many of those neighborhood groups were made up of little more than pioneers and stubborn residents who refused to abandon their homes.
Today, 15 years after Mayor Koch's initial commitment, much of the Bronx's refurbished housing stock is still controlled by these once-informal groups. Their leaders give most of the credit for the Bronx's revival to themselves and to former Mayor Koch. Mr. Ferrer, they say, often played a supporting role, helping them negotiate with the city government and helping shape the projects to their desires.
"I give Koch a lot of credit; he set the money aside," said Ralph Porter, executive director of the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes, one of the early nonprofit groups, which now manages 1,170 units in 38 buildings across the South Bronx. "But Ferrer always fought for us."
After 1990, even blocking projects was largely beyond Mr. Ferrer's power. In that year, New York City significantly changed the structure of its government, and Mr. Ferrer -- along with the rest of the city's borough presidents -- saw much of his power stripped away. Mr. Ferrer's power in land-use decisions was reduced to a largely advisory role.
"He didn't oppose anything," said the Rev. Louis R. Gigante, founder of the Southeast Bronx Community Organization, or Sebco, which manages about 3,500 apartments. "Freddie's borough was destroyed. He wasn't going to turn down the money."
Still, Father Gigante and others who participated in the reconstruction of the South Bronx credit Mr. Ferrer with doing what he could with his relatively meager resources. Mr. Ferrer directed much of the money still at his disposal -- about $28 million over 14 years -- to renovate old apartments and build new ones.
Often Mr. Ferrer acted as a middleman, fending off the heavier-handed efforts of City Hall. In the late 1980's, when city planners were preparing to earmark buildings for exclusive occupancy by homeless people, Mr. Ferrer helped persuade the planners to allow for more diversity. And in the early 1990's, when city planners wanted to bulldoze much of a 33-block area near Yankee Stadium, Mr. Ferrer helped persuade City Hall to give way. He helped devise a new plan for the area, called Melrose Commons, that allowed the residents to stay put. Today, about 200 homes have been built or reconstructed, with 1,100 more in the works.
"The people in the area were really angry, and Freddie got the city to back off," said Harold DeRienzo, founder of the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a South Bronx nonprofit group that renovated more than 2,000 apartments.
Many people also credit Mr. Ferrer with the wisdom to back off himself. Some of the people active in housing issues in the 1990's say that Mr. Ferrer rarely tried to delay projects or steer contracts to his friends. Some of the same housing experts point to Harlem as an example of where interference by elected officials sometimes derailed rebuilding. "In Harlem, they wanted to turn it into a political patronage operation," Mr. Koch said. "Freddie did not in any way. By not demanding, he got a larger share."
Mr. Ferrer, who now lives in Riverdale, says he sometimes returns to Fox Street to draw inspiration. The more permanent residents have taken notice.
Roberto Reyes, who lives at 546 Fox Street, recalled the afternoon four years ago when Mr. Ferrer stood on his back porch and listened to him complain about the junkyard behind his home. "Ferrer told me he would do something about it, and we shook hands," Mr. Reyes said, looking over the edge of his porch. "Two weeks later, they started building a shopping center."

HEADLINE: Few Local Issues at Anti-Immigrant Gathering 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SACHS and AL BAKER 

DATELINE: CENTEREACH, N.Y., Aug. 4 

 BODY:
An anti-immigration gathering drew only about 100 people here today for an educational conference that included speeches condemning illegal immigrants as invaders and criminals who are destroying suburban neighborhoods. 
 The turnout was a disappointment to members of the Sachem Quality of Life Organization, a Farmingville group that wants the government to deport illegal immigrants and end what it calls the "atrocities" the immigrants have brought to the suburbs. 
 About 30 minutes before the meeting was scheduled to begin, Ray Wysolmierski, a Sachem spokesman, was ebulliently predicting a rousing event. 
"It's going to be a great American moment," he said. "We're going to change history today." 
An hour later, he dismissed the small showing as unimportant. 
"People are symbolic," Mr. Wysolmierski said. "I don't care if I get one or 1,000."
Several years ago, the Sachem group started pressing municipal officials for help in controlling the day laborers who congregated on the streets of Farmingville waiting for work. It has since forged links with a number of the groups that led California's anti-immigrant movement in the mid-1990's and have been seeking a national platform ever since. 
The main speakers at the meeting represented the John Birch Society and several of the California groups, which describe Mexican immigrants as the front line of an occupying force. 
The groups have been struggling to revive the same passions about immigration that once fueled California's Proposition 187, which denied public schooling and other services to illegal immigrants. The 1994 proposition was passed by voters but was later rejected as unconstitutional by a federal court.
Now the anti-immigrant forces are focusing on proposals under discussion in Washington to allow illegal Mexican immigrants a chance to become legal residents. Several speakers, including members of the Sachem group, described the ideas as treason. 
"They are willing to sell our sovereignty to the highest bidder, and we all know who the highest bidder is: Mexico," said Barbara Coe, president of the right-wing California Citizens for Immigration Reform. 
She went on to refer to illegal immigrants as robbers and rapists. 
Estimates by demographers and the Immigration and Naturalization Service put the number of illegal immigrants in the United States at 6 million to 11 million. The majority of those are believed to be of Mexican descent. 
Most of the speakers here today, all veterans of the California immigration battles, framed their comments about illegal immigrants in terms of their state's politics. One, admitting that he knew little about New York, complained about the Los Angeles City Council to an audience that dwindled, over the course of the day, to about 30 people. 
Critics of the Sachem group said the attempt to make Farmingville a rallying point for a national anti-immigration movement would probably fail. 
"If you're talking about 1,500 Mexicans in Farmingville as a national issue, it's insane," said Edward Hernandez, who heads a group called Brookhaven Citizens for Peaceful Solutions. 
The concerns raised initially in Farmingville were legitimate, he said, but the Sachem group forfeited its place in any community dialogue by allying itself with contentious figures like Mrs. Coe. 
"You have to take them out of the equation because they've taken an extreme position that says there is no alternative but deportation," Mr. Hernandez said. 
The conflict over illegal immigrants that has roiled Farmingville over the past three years -- encapsulated in a bitter fight to block the building of a hiring hall for laborers -- reflects the demographic shifts occurring across the country as Hispanics settle in communities long unaccustomed to immigrants. 
While the numbers in places like Farmingville are not large, the influx of Hispanics has had a dramatic effect. In 1990, according to adjusted census figures, Hispanics made up just 6.7 percent of the Farmingville population. Ten years later, they represented 8.1 percent. 
Farmingville remains overwhelmingly white, but the changes have clearly unsettled many residents. The booming economy helped exacerbate the tensions by attracting an influx of illegal workers who ended up crammed into small apartments in residential neighborhoods. 
Tthe local issues played only a marginal role in the gathering today in a Veterans of Foreign Wars hall in Centereach. Sachem leaders and their guest speakers instead framed the day-laborer dispute as a reflection of a government conspiracy to abandon the suburbs to an immigrant invasion and forfeit American sovereignty through globalization. 
Members of the John Birch Society sold pamphlets and books warning of a communist threat and a United Nations "crusade against God and family." 
Many speakers blamed the media, "ethnic special-interest lobbies" and liberals, among others, for the modest attendance. 
"When there's been a campaign to depict us as hatemongers and racists, it scares away a lot of people," said Glenn Spencer, director of the California-based American Patrol and one of the most outspoken proponents of the view that Mexico wants to invade the United States.
"They don't want to be associated in any way. I wouldn't be surprised if that had an effect on our turnout."

HEADLINE: The 'Hidden' Poor Aren't Hidden 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Unmasking the Poor," by Bob Herbert (column, July 30):
 It is not surprising to learn of the plight of the "millions upon millions" of poor people in America today. Mr. 
Herbert refers to Barbara Ehrenreich's adventure as she tried to survive working for $6 to $7 an hour. 
The reality, however, is that these people are not "hidden" and their day-to-day struggles exist. Perhaps television and newspapers should keep us informed of this crisis on a more regular basis. Instead of broadcasting programs like "Survivor," the networks could devote more time to genuine "reality" programs. 
My suggestion is to educate the "well-to-do" about the daily hardships of the poor that have been brought to light through the writing of Ms. Ehrenreich. Perhaps we'll learn that the poor are not hidden, just conveniently misplaced.

CHRISTOPHER P. PATELLA
Newburgh, N.Y., July 30, 2001

HEADLINE: The 'Hidden' Poor Aren't Hidden 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Those not moved by Barbara Ehrenreich's account of trying to live for two years on $6 or $7 an hour, discussed by Bob Herbert (column, July 30), need to check whether they have a caraway seed for a heart. 
 Her account should silence all arguments against raising the minimum wage and increasing food-stamp allotments; against companies that contract with cities and states having to pay a living wage of $10 to $12 an hour; against increased financing for early childhood programs and 24-hour day care; and against reforming Temporary Assistance to Needy Families so that it raises people out of poverty instead off just knocking them off the caseload file. 
For the poor, these programs are vital to survival. 
Ms. Ehrenreich's book should be required reading for every member of Congress. Maybe then it will be ready to pass legislation to lift the poor out of poverty. 

KENNETH J. RUMMENIE
Buffalo, July 30, 2001

PERSON: Richard N. Barton 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
New Journey of a Travel Pioneer

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
FOR Richard N. Barton, the success of Expedia Inc., the online travel agency he created five years ago in Redmond, Wash., is not unlike the satisfaction of painting a house.
 It was on the opposite coast, in New Canaan, Conn., 10 years before he went into the travel business, that Mr. Barton discovered his entrepreneurial skills as he painted other people's homes during summer vacations. 
 "I had a crew of four, including myself," Mr. Barton, 34, said in a recent telephone interview. "It taught me how to run a business, hire people, manage clients, do quality work. I fell in love with running my own thing. And painting made me feel really good, especially when I was finished." 
Mr. Barton has reason to feel good now, but he is still not finished. Expedia, which he founded while working as a product manager for the Microsoft Corporation, has grown into one of the largest travel agencies in the country. And last month, Microsoft agreed to sell control of Expedia for an estimated $1.3 billion to USA Networks, the cable television company, which wants Mr. Barton to expand Expedia further, via television.
Expedia, now with headquarters in Bellevue, Wash., has already become what Mr. Barton calls a "travel superstore on the Internet," selling everything from discount air fares and vacation packages to island hideaway rentals. Its work force has swelled to 800 from its original 50. Its offices, once confined to Microsoft's headquarters in Redmond, now extend to Las Vegas and to outposts in Canada, Britain and Germany.
Unlike many other e-commerce ventures, Expedia makes money. With one-time accounting adjustments excluded, Expedia earned $15 million in the quarter ended June 30, compared with a loss of $13.1 million in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue more than doubled, to $78.5 million.
But Mr. Barton's continued success is not assured. Expedia is in an intense rivalry with Travelocity, a bigger Internet travel agency, which is also profitable, and Orbitz, a new Web site started by the five largest American airlines. Henry Harteveldt, a travel analyst at Forrester Research in San Francisco, called Expedia and Travelocity "the Hatfields and the McCoys, with not quite the same level of vitriol. Orbitz throws a wrench into this competition."
Expedia's new relationship with USA Networks has clearly rattled investors in Travelocity. While Expedia's shares closed Friday at $44.60, little changed from the $44.89 closing price when the deal was announced July 16, Travelocity's have fallen 19 percent since then, to $26.30, on fears that Expedia had a powerful new competitive edge. But Michael Stacy, senior vice president for consumer marketing at Travelocity, based in Fort Worth, said of Mr. Barton's group: "We have to stay one step ahead of them and so far we've demonstrated that we have."
Mr. Barton said the USA Networks deal could create opportunities to sell travel that competitors lack. USA Networks' Ticketmaster business, for example, could enable Expedia to sell Las Vegas vacations that include music or sports events. "I like the Dave Matthews band," Mr. Barton said. "Hopefully, there will be Dave Matthews packages available on Expedia with two nights at the Bellagio, airline tickets and tickets to see the concert. That's cool."
Travel industry analysts say Expedia's success so far partly reflects what they called Mr. Barton's correct analysis of the Internet's unique ability to attract travel customers. 
"I think Rich is pretty visionary," said Robert LaFleur, an analyst who follows the online travel industry for Bear Stearns. "He saw the Internet was the perfect medium to sell travel, because buyers and sellers are dispersed, and travel is an information-intense product."
It also helped that the incubator was Microsoft, where Mr. Barton went to work in 1991 a few years after he graduated from Stanford with a degree in industrial engineering.
Mr. Barton came up with the idea when Bill Gates asked him to develop a CD-ROM business involving travel guides. Mr. Barton convinced Mr. Gates that the CD-ROM idea would fail but that an online travel agency might succeed. Expedia began operating in late 1996 and went public three years later at a price of $14 a share. Microsoft then owned 70 percent of Expedia's stock.
USA Networks will use its own stock and other securities to buy up to a 75 percent stake in Expedia. Microsoft is thus obtaining a minority stake in USA Networks; it will still use Expedia to sell travel on the Microsoft Network, its online service.
Mr. Barton's former boss at Microsoft, Brad Chase, attributes his success to qualities he likens to those attained by the scarecrow, lion and tin man in "The Wizard of Oz."
"He's got a brain, he's smart and has good strategic skills," said Mr. Chase, who until April was a senior vice president of Microsoft and is a member of Expedia's board. "He has a lot of courage and is willing to make tough bets. And he's got a heart; he's a warm guy." 
At travel industry conferences, Mr. Barton often shows photographs of himself on vacation with his wife, Sarah, a Seattle obstretrician, and son, William, who coincidentally was born the day of Expedia's initial public offering in 1999.
Mr. Barton also is known for his ability to motivate, epitomized by his willingness to shave off his hair just before embarking on Expedia's road show in advance of the initial public offering. He had promised his staff he would do that if they finished a project on schedule.
"His hair was still spiky when he went out on the road show," said Greg Maffei, a former chief financial officer of Microsoft who is chairman of Expedia's board.
Some acquaintances say Mr. Barton's youth and relative lack of experience are potential liabilities. "He's not seen it all, he doesn't have the bruises, the ups and downs in business the old-timers do," said Gerald Grinstein, a board member of Expedia and Delta Air Lines and the non-executive chairman of Agilent Technologies. "But the fact that he listens very carefully is a strength."
How Mr. Barton fares under the management of USA Networks, of course, remains to be seen. Its chairman and chief executive, Barry Diller, a legend of the broadcast entertainment industry, is 25 years older than Mr. Barton and clearly has his own agenda for Expedia.
"As good as Expedia's services are," Mr. Diller said, "they have a long way to go to serve the customer in every possible configuration."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Barton, chief executive of Expedia, in its Las Vegas call center. Mr. Barton founded the company, now one of the largest travel agencies in the country, while working for Microsoft. (Lori Cain for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush administration showing willingness to enforce law on visiting Cuba 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
Few of the tens of thousands of Americans who every year break the law by visiting Cuba ever hear a peep from the federal government, whose prosecution of a Treasury Department prohibition against spending tourist dollars there is scattershot at best.
 But according to administration officials, lawyers and travel agents who arrange trips to Cuba, examples of that ban being enforced have multiplied this year and could become more prevalent in the wake of an announced crackdown by President Bush several weeks ago. 
 "We've observed a marked increase, over the last five to six months, in the number of phone calls and inquiries we get," said Nancy Chang, a lawyer with the Center for Constitutional Rights in Manhattan, which does legal advocacy work for Americans facing fines for going to Cuba.
These travelers usually call the center after receiving letters from the Treasury Department threatening them with penalties, typically about $7,500. About a month ago, when the number of cases that the center was working on reached 400, it stopped accepting more. 
Figures from the Office of Foreign Assets Control, the arm of the Treasury Department that enforces the restriction, show that the number of letters sent to Americans it suspects of violating that ban has been rising markedly. In 2000, the last year of the Clinton administration, OFAC sent 188 letters, according to Tasia Scolinos, a spokeswoman for the agency. Between May 4 and July 18 this year, she said, it sent 443 letters.
That still represents a fraction of the Americans who violate the restriction. Although the United States government has no estimates for how many Americans visit Cuba illegally, an analysis of figures from the Cuban government suggests that perhaps 40,000 to 50,000 did so last year.
Cuban soil is not actually off-limits to Americans. But the Treasury Department forbids United States citizens to spend money there without authorization, effectively barring tourist travel. Even prepaid tours booked in another country are illegal without authorization. On paper, although not in practice, a violation can lead to a fine of up to $55,000. Theoretically, violators could also face criminal prosecution and a fine of up to $250,000 and 10 years in prison. 
The Treasury Department permits Americans to spend money in Cuba if they are traveling there for such reasons as academic excursions, cultural exchanges, religious missions, journalistic ventures and visits to relatives. In all but those last two cases, a license authorizing the trip is required. 
And tour operators have become more savvy about -- and more successful at -- sending groups under these auspices. Such travelers can fly directly to Cuba from the United States on charters from New York, Los Angeles and Miami.
But a greater number of tourists go without authorization, traveling through the Bahamas, Canada or Mexico. Cuban authorities do not stamp these travelers' passports, making it difficult for American officials to determine if an American has been to Cuba.
One way that American officials catch offenders is by watching for tourists who arrive in the Bahamas or Canada on flights from Cuba and then proceed directly to a connecting flight to the United States. A Brooklyn woman who was recently threatened with a fine said that she was caught that way. The woman, who insisted on anonymity, said that a United States Customs agent in Montreal had stopped her, said he knew she had been to Cuba and took down her name and address. 
Weeks later, she got a letter from the Office of Foreign Assets Control requesting information about how much money she had spent in Cuba, which is usually the prelude to a fine. The Center for Constitutional Rights is handling her case.
Ms. Chang said that although OFAC typically assesses travelers with a $7,500 fine, it often accepts a payment of between $700 and $2,500. Travelers can try to avoid paying a fine by exercising their right to request a hearing; lawyers and Cuba experts said that the agency, short on personnel, had not actually held such a hearing in 10 years.
But administration officials said that that could change. When President Bush announced his crackdown, which critics attribute to his desire for good political relations with Cuban-American leaders in southern Florida, he said he would devote more resources to enforcement of the ban.
Even so, some lawyers and other experts said that Americans traveling to Cuba without authorization would still probably be playing a game of odds that was decidedly in their favor.
