HEADLINE: Al, Again 

 BODY:
Al Gore is coming back. We should have expected him. Bill Clinton came back last week, at a giddy welcoming party from the neighbors of his new Harlem office. The former president was looking so charismatic that it seemed it would be only a matter of time before Mr. Gore would pop up, too, so we could make unfavorable comparisons of his people skills.
 While Mr. Gore has been vacationing in Spain, growing a beard and working on a book with his wife, he has also been laying the groundwork for his re-emergence into public life. Later this month, he'll run some training sessions in Tennessee for young political activists. He intends to campaign for Democratic candidates this fall, and to start a new political action committee to help Congressional candidates in 2002. All this has naturally led to speculation that Mr. Gore is preparing to run again for president. 
 A lot has happened since the former vice president withdrew from public activity after George W. Bush's inauguration. Congress passed the tax-cut plan that Mr. Gore had denounced during the campaign. Mr. Bush shelved the international treaty on global warming that Mr. Gore had done so much to nurture. Last week, the House approved an energy bill that gave environmentalists the shivers.
Mr. Gore has always been one of his party's smartest and most articulate leaders -- on foreign affairs, communications issues and finance, as well as the environment. But he kept his reactions to himself, saying he wanted to refrain from criticizing the new president so America would have time to recover from the trauma of the Florida recount. Meanwhile, Mr. Bush and his allies used that time to promote programs that may have an effect on the country long after Florida has become a historical footnote.
Some Democrats were furious at the silence from the top. Others are still so angry about the loss of the White House that they don't have room for additional ire. It is probably fair to say that a sizable chunk of his party would be perfectly happy if Mr. Gore stayed out of sight indefinitely. He is, after all, the man who wrested defeat out of the longest economic boom in American history, the champion debater who managed to go 1 for 3 against George W. Bush.
Mr. Gore's fans point out that Richard Nixon rebuilt his political career after narrowly losing a race he should have won against John F. Kennedy. (It is a measure of Mr. Gore's luck that even his friends wind up comparing him to people like Mr. Nixon. And that 500,000-vote winning margin in the popular vote will mean a lifetime of being lumped with fellow Electoral College victims Samuel Tilden and Grover Cleveland.)
Obviously, Mr. Gore has a right to leap back into the presidential sweepstakes and take his chances. The number of invitations he gets to campaign for Democratic candidates in high-profile races over the next year will be one indication of how good his standing in the party is, and his success or failure as a drawing card may indicate something about the public's sentiments. It could be a tough comeback. There are plenty of other people, including virtually every Democrat in the Senate, who think they could have run a better race last year and are ready to try to prove it.
But Mr. Gore is sorely needed as a voice on behalf of the issues he championed in 2000. The Democrats have missed having a leader in the national debate over the Bush policies, particularly in foreign affairs and the environment. And if Mr. Gore decides to opt for being a sort of elder statesman rather than a presidential hopeful, he will never have to hear another critique of his wardrobe.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
In Both Substance and Style, Successor Will Be No Giuliani

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
For months, the six major candidates for mayor of New York City have encouraged voters to measure them by Rudolph W. Giuliani's yardstick. Even as they criticized Mr. Giuliani's style, they sought to assure New Yorkers that the change in leadership at City Hall next year would not bring an end to the policies that are widely credited with moving the city in the right direction.
 But a weeklong series of interviews with the candidates by editors and reporters of The New York Times suggests that the differences between Mr. Giuliani and the men trying to succeed him are more stark than the candidates want voters to think -- and go beyond the criticisms of Mr. Giuliani's style that they all have incorporated in their appeals. To varying degrees, and on many issues -- from police management to housing policy to the role of government in dealing with social problems -- the candidates presented ideas and views of government that were often quite different from anything New York has experienced in the past eight years. 
 On one level, the fact that the four Democratic candidates are beginning to promise a departure from Giuliani policies is not surprising, given their political backgrounds, their previous entanglements with the mayor and the fact that they are moving into the final five weeks of a party primary that has not yet seemed to capture the attention of voters. 
But even Herman Badillo, a Republican and the candidate who was the most effusive in his praise for Mr. Giuliani, moved in a flash from presenting his prospective mayoralty as an extension of Mr. Giuliani's to pledging to change the racial composition of the Police Department, and to require all 40,000 officers to undergo sensitivity training. Those are initiatives that would be hard to imagine coming out of the current City Hall.
The Democrats have spent the past six months trying to simultaneously criticize and praise a mayor who clearly remains popular among many voters. 
"I intend, as mayor, to offer what's the best of Rudy Giuliani without the worst," Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, said on Friday, in a remark that any of the six candidates could have made.
Still, the details that they laid out over the past week suggested that the exit of Mr. Giuliani would lead, as the mayor himself has predicted unhappily to his associates, to a return to policies that were in place before Mr. Giuliani became the city's first Republican mayor in nearly 20 years.
They talked about an increase in government services to help the poor, large public subsidies for housing construction and transportation, and rolling back tax cuts Mr. Giuliani had advocated. They talked about putting police officers back on the beat, and moving away from some aggressive police practices of the past eight years, even as they described the drop in crime that took place under Mr. Giuliani's Police Department as one of his biggest achievements.
Even Michael R. Bloomberg, Mr. Badillo's opponent in the Republican primary, advocated spending more money on the homeless, and financing and pushing ahead with big municipal construction projects even if the city's economic situation should turn bad, a contrast with the austerity that Mr. Giuliani preached during the last bad fiscal patch in New York.
Although the candidates uniformly described repairing the city school system as the biggest task facing the next mayor, they shied away from endorsing the proposals that Mr. Giuliani championed without success in this city dominated by Democrats and with a powerful teachers' union: experimentation with school vouchers and merit-pay raises for individual teachers. And, except for Mr. Badillo, none of the candidates displayed much of an appetite for challenging union policies, like cumbersome disciplinary procedures for bad teachers, which some educators argue must come to an end if there is to be a turnaround in New York's schools.
The extent of any differences that the candidates might have with the outgoing mayor has, until now, been masked by the perception that the city is moving in the right direction under Mr. Giuliani. Unlike, say, in 1993, when Mr. Giuliani was first elected, or in 1989, when David N. Dinkins defeated Edward I. Koch for the Democratic nomination, there is no great cry for change, no unpopular incumbent to run against.
This is creating complications for all the candidates as they try to come up with a campaign theme to ripple this placid race. With the exception of Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president who has approached the race as if Mr. Giuliani's name is on the ballot again, the candidates have taken a much more nuanced approach in criticizing a mayor who continues to occupy a large platform and shows no sign of staying on the sideline in the race to succeed him. That has usually meant criticizing his personal style, or his relationship with minority residents, while crediting him for an improvement in the areas of crime and quality of life.
But the series of interviews also made clear that there are gradations in the candidates' feelings toward Mr. Giuliani. At least three of them -- Mr. Bloomberg, Mr. Badillo and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker and a Democrat -- would like Mr. Giuliani's political support, or at least the support of the New Yorkers who have voted for him, and did not seem too eager to make him an issue.
By contrast, Mr. Hevesi and Mark Green, the public advocate and a Democrat, would like the support of Democrats who have not been happy with Mr. Giuliani -- and who, most politicians believe, will vote in large numbers in the primary on Sept. 11 -- as well as the potentially significant group of voters who approve of the mayor's performance and might have voted for him again if he were not stepping aside because of term limits. 
Thus, Mr. Green has moved from being persistently critical of Mr. Giuliani during his years as public advocate to trying (though not always successfully) to ratchet down his attacks on Mr. Giuliani, part of an attempt by Mr. Green to present himself as a more temperate and moderate public figure. 
By contrast, Mr. Hevesi, who has been criticized by some Democrats for standing in the shadows while his party colleagues battled Mr. Giuliani on a variety of fronts before the start of this election season, went out of his way in the interview to enumerate differences he said he had had with the Republican mayor over the years.
In inching away from Mr. Giuliani, all six major-party candidates are also beginning to draw some distinctions among themselves, providing an indication of the different ways they might govern the city. On the question of taxes, the centerpiece of Mr. Giuliani's economic policy, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Badillo ruled out any tax hike over the next four or eight years, and said they would push for further tax cuts in the years ahead, describing that as the best tonic for an ailing economy.
Mr. Hevesi said he would consider, in an economic downturn, pushing for a higher surcharge on the city's personal income tax, to pay for increased spending on schools. Such a surcharge would be similar to one that was used to finance an expansion of the Police Department under Mr. Dinkins.
Mr. Ferrer said he opposed the reduction in the income tax surcharge pushed through by Mr. Giuliani this year and would want to reinstitute the tax to pay for after-school programs for schoolchildren.
Mr. Green would not rule out raising taxes, though he said it was very unlikely. He said he was not certain whether he would push for any tax cuts.
Of all the candidates, Mr. Bloomberg had by far the most dire outlook on the city's economy, taking note of a series of signs -- declines on Wall Street, a drop in tourism -- that he said signaled that the next mayor would have to devote much energy to dealing with the budget. But Mr. Bloomberg sounded like the career public officials he is competing against in declining to spell out areas in city government that he might look to cut, should that prove necessary.
While the candidates, for the most part, declined to say what they would cut, they did use the interviews to name city departments that they said would be immune from cuts, offering suggestions of their top priorities for City Hall. Mr. Vallone said the city parks system, which he described as already beleaguered by budget cutbacks under Mr. Giuliani, would be spared further cuts. 
Mr. Green and Mr. Hevesi said they would not cut spending on the Police Department or public schools. Mr. Green also ruled out cuts for programs for elderly New Yorkers, while Mr. Hevesi said he would not make cuts in the Fire Department.
Mr. Badillo, sounding like Mr. Giuliani, said nothing would be exempt, while Mr. Bloomberg said he would protect the Police Department from cuts if the crime rate started moving up.
Even as they were vague about what they might do to save money, the Democrats and Mr. Bloomberg offered a variety of ways in which they would supported increased spending. All the candidates said teachers were not paid enough, arguing that that accounted in part for New York's inability to retain enough teachers to staff its schools. Mr. Ferrer said there should be a 30 percent increase in teacher salaries in exchange for some contract givebacks. His rivals declined to put a number on the table, saying it would complicate the collective-bargaining process.
Mr. Hevesi said the city's police officers should get larger raises than other uniformed officials, breaking from the way New York has historically negotiated contracts with its unions. He declined to offer a figure, or say how he would pay for that. Mr. Green offered arguments on both sides of that issue, saying that if elected, he would appoint a "labor czar" to advise him. 
Mr. Green pledged to hold class sizes to 19 students through the third grade. He said he would divert money, now being used to pay overtime to police officers to fight street crime, toward tuition assistance programs for young police officers. Mr. Ferrer called for weekend and after-school programs for children. Mr. Hevesi said he would establish 200 storefront computer centers around the city to help New Yorkers become computer literate.
On housing, nearly all the candidates seized on the promise of new revenues from the sale of the World Trade Center, promising to use much of that money to finance new housing. Mr. Bloomberg, though, said he would not support committing that revenue to housing, because the city should encourage private development by relieving regulations that he described as cumbersome.
Mr. Green separated himself from his Democratic colleagues by saying he would push to use the World Trade Center money to finance public transportation projects. He said he would support a large, subsidized housing construction project but would not say how he would pay for it. Instead, he vowed that should he win, he would appoint a committee of people to advise him on where to find the housing money.

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
When Love and Work Clash in the Valley

 BODY:
 It has not been an easy year for Bruce Claflin, the chief executive of 3Com, the Silicon Valley networking equipment company that has been hit especially hard by the economic slowdown. But Mr. 
Claflin, 49, said during a visit to New York last week that the most difficult period for him was in January, just after he was appointed to the job. Worried about a sharp falloff in business, Mr. Claflin moved to cut thousands of jobs. He was among the first prominent technology executive to say publicly that things were looking bad. But what really gnawed at Mr. Claflin, he said, was that his wife preferred to believe the less gloomy outlook offered at the time by John Chambers, the chief executive of 3Com's rival, Cisco Systems. "My wife said she loved me, but that John Chambers knew a lot more than I did," he recalled. "Then it was personal."

HEADLINE: A Scholarship And a Crisis 

BYLINE:  By Peter Lagerquist; Peter Lagerquist, a freelance writer, contributes regularly to Middle East International, a London-based magazine.

DATELINE: Ramallah, West Bank 

 BODY:
The Palestinian uprising that erupted last fall put an abrupt end to Bill Clinton's efforts to secure a foreign policy legacy -- a lasting peace in the Middle East. Almost one year later, scores of Israelis and hundreds of Palestinians have been killed, with thousands wounded. 
 Against this backdrop, the first of the Clinton Scholars -- prospective leaders of Palestinian industry, civil society and government -- are returning home from graduate school in the United States, as dozens more leave to begin their studies. The Clinton Scholarship aims to strengthen American-Palestinian relations and to encourage social and economic development in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. But the students -- future entrepreneurs, teachers and public servants -- face a daunting mission: since the uprising, relations with the United States have been strained by continuing Palestinian confrontations with Israel, and the Palestinian economy they are charged with rebuilding has collapsed. 
 The scholarship, under the auspices of the United States Agency for International Development, or U.S.A.I.D., grew out of the 1998 Wye River memorandum, an agreement signed in Wye River, Md., committing Israel and the Palestinian Authority to restart then-stalled peace negotiations. To bolster Palestinian support for the accord, President Clinton pushed through Congress $400 million in development assistance to the West Bank and Gaza Strip, a significant portion going to people-to-people programs, including $15 million for a scholarship. 
"The intent was to further Palestinian development by fostering a free-market economy, training skilled businesspeople to be its future captains of industry," said Pat Kabra, a consulate spokeswoman in Jerusalem. "Over all, this is the kind of thing U.S.A.I.D. supports through its educational initiatives around the world. It improves the ability of that country to act as a business interlocutor for us."
The scholarship, which the Bush administration is to review once funds are exhausted, will fully finance 95 students: 80 have been accepted since the program began in June 1999, with 40 expected to be enrolled this fall in American universities and 20 more in preparatory courses. Applicants are screened with an emphasis on undergraduate performance and their ability to articulate how their training would benefit their community. As with the agency's other educational programs, politics are not discussed, and participation in the uprisings does not necessarily disqualify Palestinians from entry into the United States, according to consular officials. 
The Palestinian territories have some of the highest university enrollment rates in the Arab Middle East, and as elsewhere in the developing world, American master's degrees are highly sought after. With average annual incomes of $2,000, most Palestinians would find the scholarship difficult to pass up, despite wariness about furthering an official American agenda in the region. "The U.S. has certain goals for the world and especially the third world -- to think like them and embrace the free market -- so they send us to U.S. universities," concluded Raed Awashreh, a Clinton Scholar who arrived in the United States this summer. But he envisions the scholarship as a chance to build mutual understanding. "All the time I have wanted to know more about American society," he said. "I will meet new people and be open-minded to other religions and cultures." Laila al-Haddad, who is a year into her master's in public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, is similarly ambivalent. "Did I get the scholarship to implement their values?" she wondered. "But I'm doing what I want to do. This is something that is good for Palestine."
For this year's recipients, the chance to study in the United States has been especially hard fought. Frequent fighting, coupled with Israeli road blockades, has made travel both time-consuming and dangerous. The Academy for Educational Development, an American organization that administers the program from offices in Ramallah and Gaza City, reports fewer applicants than when the program started. "People can't get to our offices to pick up the paperwork," said Jamilah Abed, a training assistant with the organization. Some candidates in the fall class had to be interviewed over the phone; since March, this has become standard procedure out of fairness to all applicants. And since the Graduate Management Admissions Test, or G.M.A.T., is not offered in Gaza, business school candidates who live there have not been able to fulfill their test requirements. 
The uprising has only intensified already existing social and economic problems. With peace and Palestinian self-rule in the mid-90's, the West Bank and Gaza Strip began to see some development, but the Palestinian Authority was soon criticized as corrupt and its security forces as repressive. The territories continued to depend on Israel for jobs and access to international markets. Now, the closing of roads and border crossings has brought the economy to a standstill. About 100,000 Palestinian workers have lost jobs in Israel, and one in every three Palestinians has fallen below the poverty line of $2 a day, according to World Bank estimates. 
"It is ironic," Ms. al-Haddad said. "This scholarship was meant to be Clinton's legacy. At the same time, as we arrived in the U.S., we saw this legacy crumble before our eyes, along with the society and infrastructure we were supposed to build."
Amid the disillusionment and violence, some of the Clinton Scholars spoke about past and future challenges, their goals and their encounters with America.
Raed Awashreh, 31, was arrested by the Israeli Army during the first Palestinian uprising, from 1987 to 1993, and released after three years in military detention camps. After the establishment of the Palestinian Authority, he joined a high school refresher course for former detainees, which allowed him to enroll in 1995 in Bir Zeit, the premier Palestinian university, located just outside Ramallah. With a major in business administration and minor in journalism, he went on to work as a journalist and researcher. Mr. Awashreh, who would like to teach, will study public administration this fall at the Monterey Institute of International Studies in California, where he is taking a class this summer in English as a second language.
"I was participating in the first intifada. For one year and a half I was wanted by the Israelis, living on the run. Sometimes I slept under buildings or trees. During the interrogation they tortured me -- beatings, they hung me from a pole. I don't like to speak about it, because it is very private, and it is the past. But I remember in particular the 'zinzana,' a room the size of a box, so small you can't lie down, where they put me for a week. 
"The prison was both good and bad, however. We ran a good education program, which helped me when I went to university. Some of the books came from the Red Cross, others the prisoners smuggled in without the knowledge of the army. Some materials the prisoners themselves wrote. I read art, economics, psychology, sociology. 
"In the prison I also started working as a journalist. I wrote a magazine without the knowledge of Israeli guards. There were a number of other contributors -- in truth, every person in the prison wanted to be a journalist. Today, if you look at the people working for television and radio stations here, you'll find they are all graduates of the prisons. 
"I started to work for the Bank of Jordan as a credit analyst. I liked it. They give you the chance to work and to improve yourself. They paid for me to take English language courses at the British consulate.
"There are two problems with journalism. First, the money is not enough -- I have a family. Second, there isn't sufficient freedom of expression here, not enough democracy. In 1998, I participated in a Bir Zeit student march. It was in solidarity with Nablus University, whose campus had been raided by the Palestinian security forces. We marched on a government building under the banner of 'Democracy.' Two months later Palestinian security forces arrested me on the pretext that I had participated in an illegal march. I was only kept in jail for 14 days, but they put me in a zinzana, too smiling , though it was slightly bigger than the Israeli one.
"As for politics, I am not impressed by any American administration, because of what I have seen on the ground here in the West Bank and Gaza. This scholarship is perhaps the first good thing America has done for us. However, I think U.S. society is not well informed about us -- they imagine us as not quite human perhaps. I think Americans are quite straightforward, and I hope that I can maybe give them a better understanding of myself and my country."
 Hisham Jabi, 31, was hired in 1994 by the Modern Arabian Business Corporation, or Mabco, an office technology equipment retailer and service provider, to open a branch in the territories. By the beginning of the uprising, it had grown to 40 employees with $2.5 million in annual revenues. In 1999, Mr. Jabi co-founded the Palestinian Information Technology Association, or PITA, a trade group of 45 companies, and has since become a spokesman for the local high-tech industry. ("Yes, there is one," he said, smiling. "I've had Americans ask me that. Do they think we live in tents?") Mr. Jabi, whose family runs a successful trucking company, is now in Boulder, Colo., at the Economics Institute, where scholarship winners in business administration take courses to improve their G.M.A.T. scores and chances of landing in a preferred university. As head of the Ramallah chapter of the Rotary Club, he is also giving talks at the local club and volunteering at a hospital -- "not only to meet Americans but to do something that makes you belong to their community."
"At the moment I stepped into class at Bir Zeit, the first intifada started. We had to get our classes sometimes in lecture halls, sometimes in churches, sometimes in public facility buildings. It took me six years to finish my degree in accounting.
"One year later I was offered a job to establish Mabco in Palestine. They had high expectations of the new era in Palestine after the peace process. But despite our autonomy, we had tremendous barriers in establishing businesses here. We had to import our products through Israeli ports and airports. I had to learn Hebrew fluently in the first year to argue with them. I had to learn Israeli law by heart.
"I wanted to show Israelis that even Palestinians who could not have the chance to live in Georgetown or New York can be civilized and tell the world that we are professionals not only at bombs, but are able to communicate with the whole world in a professional business manner. I wanted to show my friends in Israel that we can do it. 
"People here are suspicious of trade with Israel and the U.S. There is talk of them trying to penetrate the Middle East, to establish economic hegemony. But if globalization really is this irresistible wave, then there is no hiding from it. We have to use it to our advantage and to learn from others. It was my activities in PITA that made me feel I have to go into an M.B.A. program. I have been traveling all over the world -- Thailand, Taiwan, China, Japan, Singapore -- meeting multinational organizations, and talking about information technology as a vehicle to develop the Palestinian economy. For me to realize this I need communication skills, better English, better managerial skills, better I.T. exposure, better multinational business exposure. If I stay in Palestine I will never get this experience. 
"It will depend on our performance, if the scholarship is to endure. Taxpayers in the U.S. understand figures. I will try as much as I can to talk business, to talk figures. I am hoping to put Palestine on the global map. It is in the heart of every Christian, Jew and Muslim. Now Israel controls the valves of our economy. We have no control of our own destiny. In the future, everything is possible, once they remove the tanks from our roads."
Laila al-Haddad, 23, the only Clinton Scholar at an Ivy League university, was born in Kuwait and attended school in Saudi Arabia and Bahrain. Both her parents, who are doctors, have returned to their homeland, Gaza. Ms. al-Haddad graduated magna cum laude from Duke University in May 2000. This summer, on a grant from the Women and Public Policy Program at the Kennedy School at Harvard, she is working in Ramallah with a democracy and human rights organization run by Hanan Ashrawi, spokeswoman for the Arab League and a former Palestinian politician. 
"The last question that the scholarship interview committee asked me was: 'You have a formidable background, and opportunities abroad. Why would you want to go back to Gaza?' I said simply that my roots are here, and that's where I think my education can be of most use. I felt a strong sense of responsibility after the intifada broke out. I wanted to be on the ground right now. The social and economic infrastructure is deteriorating now.
"I met Ashrawi when I was president of the Arab Student Society at Duke and we invited her to come and speak. I always found her very inspiring and have looked up to her since I was a teenager. People relate to what she says in humanistic terms, and that is something I see myself doing on a small scale. She gets criticized by Israelis for the positions she takes, but also by Palestinians. I am not surprised to hear it. It's only natural of a woman working in this field. 
"For personal reasons I wear a head scarf, and I have gotten very used to being perceived as backward and uneducated. In the U.S. I often get asked, 'What does it feel like to be oppressed?' It's a huge factor in developing myself to prove that not only Arab women but Muslim women can be leaders. It is also a perception in the Arab world that, both religiously and culturally, it's not where women should be. The way to deal with it is to set an example in how you conduct yourself. This is how I feel I am making an impact. 
"It's an important point for the Clinton Scholarship to get more women. I am constantly harassing them about this. There aren't many Palestinian women leaders in business, and as a program that primarily targets this field, they have problems getting female applicants. We have a high percentage of women with degrees, particularly compared to other Arab countries. The problem is getting them into the labor force. 
"I was and am still a believer in people-to-people contact, and being in a policy school has been a unique opportunity in that regard. There were people at the school who make decisions for the U.S. government, for the Israeli government. A number of them were lawyers and had worked as chief negotiators with the Palestinians. In the beginning of the intifada they were very confused -- they didn't know what was happening or why. They didn't see the frustration on the ground, that the fruits of the peace process were only reaped by the Palestinian Authority, not the population. Their only other contact with Palestinians was during the first intifada, serving as soldiers in Gaza. The only relationship they knew was of occupier/occupied. I felt that in the end, I made them understand. I used to go with workers in Gaza through the Israeli checkpoints when I was doing research. It gave me a different perspective.
"There are always ebbs and flows in any conflict, looking at Northern Ireland, for instance. Sometimes breakthroughs come after an extended period of violence. But I am positive in a cynical way -- Palestinians are pessoptimists."
Mohammed Said, 36, returned home in June from Colorado State University in Fort Collins as the first graduate of the Clinton Scholarship. A carpenter's son, he grew up in a West Bank village with six brothers and two sisters. He supported himself selling home improvement supplies as a student at Bir Zeit, but because of frequent Israeli closings of Palestinian universities during the first intifada, it took seven years to get his degree in business administration. He most recently worked as financial manager for a government citizens' rights organization. Mr. Said is considering teaching business administration or consulting.
"My father doesn't own any land and could just earn our daily bread, so we struggled. My mother is a housekeeper -- she is illiterate, but I respect her a lot. During the intifada, one of my brothers was arrested for two years, a second was wanted by the Israelis and on the run. We didn't see him for five years. My kid brother was arrested when he was 13 for throwing stones at the Israelis, and jailed for one and a half years. He lost his education, his future. He has opened a car workshop. It's a pity, because Palestinians have one resource, education. If you look at my village, in every family there are at least two children nowadays with university degrees.
"If you have democracy and raise awareness of human rights, you can build a new nation on a rock, not on sand. We Palestinians are better off than neighboring Arab countries, maybe because we have some 20 organizations active in human rights. But there are lots of violations. We lack institutions, such as a strong legislative council, and good public sector management. 
"To be frank I had been dreaming of doing an M.B.A. in the U.S. I tried many times and was accepted in many universities, but I didn't have the resources to go. I was unlucky for some time -- I was 35 when I got this scholarship. They have a lot of resources we miss at home -- the library, the Internet -- and I appreciate that the professors are always available. But the most important thing was the teamwork. We had to work in groups for a number of projects. We had some Chinese and Indian students and it was very rewarding to encounter and share differences, experiences and views. 
"I wrote a business plan for my course, to start an Internet service provider in Palestine, because being online with other cultures is very important to both society and economy in Palestine. One of our problems is that we have just one supplier through Israel, so I suggest making a strategic alliance with an Israeli firm. I can see opportunity on the horizon, not just financially, but as a national symbol of independence and modernization. In Europe after World War II, they sought to join economic interests to make sure they didn't fight again, and this worked. I believe this will work here, too. We have a lot to learn from the Israelis; they have a lot of experience in finance, information technology and industry. We cannot go on with bloodshed like this.
"When I came to the U.S., everyone had their stereotypes and prejudices. Everywhere I met people, in the market, in the stores, and I talked to them. When I went to the barber I initiated political discussions. It was foremost in my mind that as Americans they support Israel. And they had ideas about me. But I found that the majority of American people are very nice, very open-minded. When you listen to them, you see there is a logic in their views. They ask, 'Why should we, American taxpayers, care about what goes on in the world?' I think they should care, because they are, as they put it, leaders of the free world. Maybe it's in their interest to help others. I think it's in our mutual interest."

HEADLINE: Smithsonian Must Exhibit Ingenuity in the Face of Overlapping Gifts 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
The Smithsonian Institution has discovered that it is indeed possible to have an embarrassment of riches.
 The institution's National Museum of American History has accepted two gifts for permanent exhibitions that cover much of the same ground and would together take up about 10 percent of the museum's exhibition space. The gifts come from two of the museum's largest donors, so museum officials are now in the unusual position of trying to determine how to honor both contracts. 
 Earlier this year the Catherine B. Reynolds Foundation pledged $38 million for what was widely characterized as a hall of fame of achievers. Ms. Reynolds's contract with the Smithsonian says the money will finance "an interactive exhibition that tells the life stories of eminent Americans, describes their personal characteristics that contributed to their achievements and highlights those achievements." 
But the museum and its advisory board realized only belatedly that the project overlapped with one that was financed last year with part of an $80 million gift from Kenneth E. Behring, a California real estate developer. His was the largest single gift in the Smithsonian's history and followed a gift of $20 million he made in 1997. 
About $20 million of Mr. Behring's $80 million is to pay, his contract with the Smithsonian says, for a "thematic hall" that will focus on "American legends and legacies" and be "a tribute to deceased individuals who made great contributions to our country and who truly epitomize the 'American spirit.' " 
Under the terms of that contract the museum must allot 18,000 to 20,000 square feet to this exhibition. The contract with Ms. Reynolds says that her exhibition will encompass 10,000 square feet and include a related awards program. 
Copies of the contracts, which have not been made public, were made available by Smithsonian officials who do not want the projects to proceed. 
Ivan Selin, the chairman of the museum, said the museum did not realize the potential conflict between the two exhibitions until it was too late. "The museum didn't accept the Reynolds gift knowing that we had a conflict with the Behring gift," he said. "Only as we looked into it did it become clear that there was overlap and that the potential for duplication and confusion was high. We don't know how this is going to work out right now." 
The negotiations with Ms. Reynolds, particularly in the early stages, were largely carried out by Lawrence M. Small, the Smithsonian's secretary, and Sheila Burke, an under secretary, with little input from the museum staff and its board, Mr. Selin said. A result, he added, was "a lack of mutual understanding of what the Reynolds project would be before the Smithsonian agreed to the gift."
"It isn't fatal," he continued, "but it has left open questions that might have been answered before the contract was signed."
Museum officials acknowledge the risk of duplication. "We have to think this through to make sure the halls are complementary and that there not be repetition," Spencer R. Crew, the museum's director, said in a telephone interview. "We need to sit down and talk about that now."
Mr. Selin, a businessman and former under secretary of state for management and former chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said that his advisory board was prepared to monitor both projects closely. "If it seems to be turning out to be quite difficult to make these exhibitions complementary, we will become much more involved," he said. 
Asked whether it was possible to fuse or link the exhibitions, Mr. Selin said, "That's one of the many alternatives that the museum is giving consideration to."
But museum officials said linkage was no longer an option. "It wouldn't be a Behring-Reynolds exhibition hall," said Martha Morris, the museum's deputy director. Each contract explicitly names each exhibition's hall after the donor or donor designee, subject to approval by the museum's board of regents. 
Each of the Smithsonian's 16 museums has its own advisory board, but the boards vary in their level of involvement and oversight. The Smithsonian's board of regents, led by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, serves as the institution's governing body. Because the regents meet only three times a year, they do not study many issues in detail.
Mr. Crew said the museum considered consolidating the exhibitions several months ago, with Mr. Behring's focusing on dead Americans and Ms. Reynolds's focusing on living ones. But as Ms. Reynolds's project became more historical in nature, he added, "our thinking began to change." Ms. Reynolds declined a request for an interview. Sheila Tate, the spokeswoman for her foundation, said, "Mrs. Reynolds believes the exhibitions are complementary, and it is the museum's business to mesh the concepts."
Mr. Behring was traveling and unavailable for comment. His son, David, a member of the museum's board, did not return phone calls. Both Mr. Crew and Ms. Morris said they had not begun substantive discussions with Mr. Behring on how to define his exhibition, although such work had begun on Ms. Reynolds's project. Asked what might be proposed to Mr. Behring, Mr. Crew said: "There is nowhere in the museum where the breadth of American history is laid out. We could still highlight American achievers but do it in a timeline." 
Mr. Behring's attention has been focused on some of his projects at the history museum, including its redesign and renovation and another $20 million "thematic hall" that is to largely replace the existing military hall, encompass 18,000 to 20,000 square feet and be named for him "as he designates," his contract states. 
The museum has already fulfilled the clause in the $80 million contract that requires the words "Behring Center" to "appear prominently" at two entrances of the museum and to be used on all of the museum's signs, catalogs, Web sites, virtual tours and outreach and educational programs whenever the name of the museum is used. Both the Reynolds and Behring gifts have been criticized in the museum world. Some museum professionals charge that Mr. Small has allowed wealthy donors to dictate the nature and content of the museum's exhibitions. The museum, like the Smithsonian as a whole, receives about 70 percent of its funds from Congress.
Last spring a group of curators, historians and researchers wrote a letter to the regents complaining that the Behring and Reynolds gifts "breach established standards of museum practice and professional ethics." The Organization of American Historians has asked the regents to reconsider the agreement with Ms. Reynolds, calling reports about the role of private donors in shaping museum exhibitions troubling. 
The museum held a two-day session in June that brought together Ms. Reynolds, historians, designers, and museum officials. They agreed that the Reynolds exhibition would tell "inspiring stories" of living and dead Americans within a "broader historical context that explores changing perceptions of achievement over time," according to a memo drafted after the meeting. The story of Rosa Parks, the civil rights pioneer, for example, would frame her life within the broader civil rights movement, the memo says.
Since attracting teenagers is an important goal of the exhibition, "special attention will be given to high-profile exemplars and issues that resonate with teenagers," the memo says. The exhibition also is to include lesser-known Americans who show how one person can have an impact on events, and stories that embrace differences in "race, class, gender, age, national origin and economic station," the memo says. 
The exhibition is also to deal with people who had "less than noble motives," like the financier J. P. Morgan, the memo adds, and others who were considered "controversial in their time," like the architect Maya Lin or the songwriter and performer Bob Dylan, and others who became controversial later, like the aviator Charles A. Lindbergh. 
Ms. Reynolds said in an interview in May that her list of potential candidates included the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Jonas Salk, Martha Stewart, Oprah Winfrey and Michael Jordan. Her contract says the Smithsonian retains final approval over the exhibition.

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
A Caustic Look In the Mirror From Boomers

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Joe Queenan is 50 years old and sorely ashamed of it.
 "I loathe my generation," he said last week. "We became culturally frozen in time at a very early age and continue to think of ourselves as trailblazers. It's completely pathetic." 
 A writer who contributes frequently to GQ and Forbes, Mr. Queenan's latest book, "Balsamic Dreams: A Short but Self-Important History of the Baby Boomer Generation" (Henry Holt), chronicles the cultural irrelevance of his generation, which is -- at least to Mr. Queenan -- a whiny, narcissistic bunch of paunchy, corporatized losers.
And he is not alone in his distaste. 
A body of literature -- call it boomer bashing -- has emerged from the trenches of American popular writing. As the 80 million Americans born from 1945 to 1963 have begun to slip en masse over the dreaded benchmark known as the big five-oh, a squadron of journalists, editors and authors have begun to question the abilities and point out the failures of the Woodstock Generation. Because most of those churning out the criticism are boomers themselves, the bashing also has the distinct whiff of boomer self-loathing.
Along with Mr. Queenan's book, this year also saw the publication of "What if Boomers Can't Retire? How to Build Real Security, Not Phantom Wealth," by Thornton Parker (Berrett-Koehler Publishers), which criticized their reliance on the stock market as a kind of phantom wealth that could eventually derail the entire American economy. Pow! 
David Brooks's excoriation of yuppie boomers, "Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There" (Simon & Schuster, 2000), stayed on best-seller lists last year for four months, urging boomers to recognize themselves as hypocritical sellouts. Blam!
There was Marty Asher's darkly comic novel, "The Boomer" (Knopf, 2000), which opens with the birth of a baby boomer on a Friday and after a lifetime of excruciating banality ends in "a small, tidy cemetery with a view of the ocean." Ooof! 
In June of last year, Time magazine published an article called "Twilight of the Boomers" in which Daniel Okrent described the boomers as preening, self-congratulatory, cavilling solipsists. Sock-o! 
And that was the nice part. He then slammed his readers. "If you're like the overwhelming majority of boomers, your career has hit a brick wall, you haven't saved enough, your pension is underfunded, your health is deteriorating, even the medical advances that will probably extend your life will, in an especially cruel paradox, probably mean that later life will be meaner and more spartan."
Mr. Okrent, 53, said that boomers were pretty much fatuous, self-important and lazy, and that's why they arouse so much resentment from Americans in their 20's and 30's. 
"There is so, so much to loathe about the boomers," Mr. Okrent said, as he spoke by telephone from his vacation home in sunny Cape Cod, doing his own boomer duty to arouse resentment. "And there is this sudden spate of attention to boomers because they have finally reached real age. They used to think they would be young forever, and now they know they will not."
"My loathing is not for the fact of being a boomer," he said. "It is for the boomers' self-involvement, and for my generation's belief that we were special. It was just another generation."
Really? Even with the Vietnam War, Woodstock, Kent State? 
"We were powerful in numbers, and we had something to react against," he said. "That was the virtue of the Vietnam War. It gave us direction."
While the boomer-bashers are happy to skewer "their desperate and pathetic cult of the self," to use Mr. Queenan's words, there are also boomer apologists to prop up their ever-jowlier self-esteem and explain away their sins.
Priscilla Painton, an assistant managing editor at Time magazine who oversaw last week's Time cover story, "Do Kids Have Too Much Power?", said that Time's boomer readers were always hungry for more information about whether they are raising their kids to be spoiled brats. Last week, the answer -- according to Time -- was no. 
"The story really looked at the criticism leveled at baby boomers, that they have given their children too much power," Ms. Painton said. "And we came to the conclusion that these kids are turning out to be one of the healthiest generations, so maybe there is no blame to lay on the boomers."
Susan Faludi's last book, "Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Man" (William Morrow, 1999), advanced the theory that the male boomers, especially those born immediately after World War II, were emotionally disfigured by their fathers, cold and patriarchal men who taught their sons that power -- not the nurturing of family or community -- was the only goal worthy of male aspiration. So for that set of male boomers, their stunted self-absorption was not their fault, but that of their Archie Bunker-esque fathers. 
Betsy Carter, the editor in chief of My Generation, the boomer magazine published by AARP, said that boomer-bashing literature was the outgrowth of unprecedented navel-gazing. 
"You have never had a group that is so primed to be analytical and examine themselves," she said. "And we're also the first generation to be so vocal and so public about our failures and our misgivings."
Ms. Carter, 56, said that boomers' eagerness to talk about themselves may also be why other generations -- or other boomers -- tire of the ceaseless boomer meditations.
"We tell everybody everything," she said. "We can yack and yack and yack. If you're not one of us, it probably gets really boring."
Mr. Queenan said that it was precisely that endless yacking and the parading of bad taste as good taste that inspired him to write "Balsamic Dreams."
"When soft rock hit in the early 1970's, I think people just thought the generation was taking a nap," he said. "In reality, we were going to sleep. We never woke up again."
That soporific cultural stupor is why Sylvester Stallone is a highly paid movie star, Mr. Queenan said, and why Andrea Bocelli has become a cultural staple masquerading as high art when he should really be accorded the status of, say, Zamfir, master of the pan flute.
"I am still amazed that it is my generation that actually supported Sylvester Stallone's career and watched those movies," Mr. Queenan said. "That wasn't the way it was supposed to play out. We weren't all supposed to buy the same foods, watch the same movies, listen to the same music. I mean, does everyone have to listen to Andrea Bocelli? Does every boomer have to go to the same four towns in Northern Italy? Has any boomer ever gone to Southern Italy? Say, Sicily? There's a tremendous pack mentality."
David Brooks, the author of "Bobos in Paradise," said there was only more to come. 
"Boomers have to exhaust all varieties of narcissistic experience, and having run through self-adoration and self-love and all the other self-somethings, now they have to do self-loathing," he said. "They have just begun to tap into it."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
An annual survey forecasts slow growth in communications spending for the next five years.

BYLINE:  By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
THE investment banking firm of Veronis Suhler is forecasting an increase in advertising spending next year but a slowdown through 2005 in the growth of this spending and in the communications industry as a whole.
 In its 15th annual communications industry forecast, released today, the firm, which specializes in the media, predicted that advertising spending in the United States would increase 6.9 percent next year. 
 This would follow an 11.1 percent increase in 2000 -- which was driven by double-digit growth in broadcast television, consumer magazine, Internet and radio advertising -- and what it expects will be a 1.1 percent decline this year "as advertisers reduce their budgets in the wake of the economic downturn and dot-com shakeout."
For 2000 to 2005, the firm expects total spending to climb 4.9 percent a year; in the previous five years, growth was 8.9 percent a year. 
Through 2005, the firm also expects a slowdown in growth in the communications industry, including advertising spending, marketing services and specialty media like direct mail and the purchases of books, home videos or trade magazines. 
From 1995 to 2000, the firm said, the communications industry grew 7.9 percent a year, while for the period 2000 to 2005, it predicted that the industry would grow 5.5 percent.
Noting that communications was the second-fastest-growing sector of the economy from 1995 to 2000, Veronis Suhler projected that it would be only the sixth-fastest in the next five years. The firm attributed this decline to "a slower-growing economy, slower growth in advertising expenditures and tamer consumer spending."
James P. Rutherfurd, the firm's executive vice president, said the slower growth was a result of the maturing of certain industry segments and a slowdown in the general economy.
Mr. Rutherfurd said that the economy grew 6 percent a year from 1995 to 2000 and that Veronis Suhler expected growth of 5 percent a year from 2000 to 2005.
"Some communications businesses are getting more mature than they were in previous years," he said. "For example, cable is still the highest-growing business, but its growth is getting less because it's almost doubled in size in the last five years. Now it's penetrating a lot more households. The broadcast TV market is getting tougher and tougher. And the Internet, which barely existed five years ago, is in a maturing process."
In addition, he said businesses like books, magazines and newspapers are "very mature and growing at slower and slower rates."
But Mr. Rutherfurd said he did not find the slower growth alarming.
"In the context of five years of incredible boom times in the national and communications economy," he said, "it's pretty hard to replicate these growth rates, with some exceptions. It looks like for the industry as a whole it's steady-as-you-go growth, with pockets of high growth and pockets of slower growth."
One segment projected to have a high growth rate is cable, including cable TV access, advertising sales and licensing fees. These are expected to increase 9.1 percent a year through 2005, which will make cable the largest segment of the communications industry, replacing newspapers. Internet access and advertising are expected to increase 7.3 percent, while outdoor advertising is expected to rise 7.6 percent and sponsorships are expected to increase 9.4 percent.
Segments with the smallest increase are books, estimated to grow 2.4 percent; broadcast television, expected to rise 3.1 percent; and consumer magazines and newspapers, both expected to grow 3.7 percent.
Besides slower growth in the communications industry through 2005, Veronis Suhler is also predicting a decline in consumer spending on media. Consumer spending increased 7.8 percent from 1995 to 2000; it is expected to grow 5.4 percent through 2005.
Consumer spending on the Internet, which grew 44.7 percent from 1995 to 2000, is expected to increase 9.6 percent through 2005, while spending on home videos is expected to grow 5 percent after an increase of 7.7 percent in the previous five years. Video games, whose spending jumped 19.9 percent from 1995 to 2000, will increase 10.3 percent through 2005.
In addition, the firm found that people spent less time with media that have significant advertiser support -- broadcast TV, newspapers, magazines and radio. The annual hours spent on these media fell 9.2 percent from 1995 to 2000, while the time was expected to increase slightly, 0.4 percent, from 2000 to 2005. 
The time spent on media supported predominantly by consumers -- cable and satellite television, recorded music, books, home video and video games, film and the Internet -- increased 37.2 percent from 1995 to 2000 and is projected to rise an additional 12.2 percent from 2000 to 2005. 
Veronis Suhler also found that in 1995, 69.3 percent of consumers' time was spent with media with advertiser support, while this figure fell to 60 percent in 2000 and is expected to drop to 57.2 percent in 2005.
Mr. Rutherfurd said changes in consumer preferences "are clearly not a good sign for advertisers."
"Over time, people are spending more and more time with the media they buy themselves," he said. "Advertisers are going to have to fight harder and harder for attention in an increasingly cluttered world, even before they fight for attention among themselves."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
BT Offered $25.7 Billion For Its Fixed-Line Network
A consortium led by a major German bank has offered to buy the fixed-line network of British Telecommunications for $:18 billion, or $25.7 billion, people close to the discussions said.
 The offer, by Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, is more comprehensive than an earlier $11.4 billion bid for British Telecom's local loop -- the copper wires that connect 28 million customers to its network. BT rebuffed that offer, from an American group made up of Babcock & Brown, an asset finance company, and Chancery Lane Capital, an investment bank, late last month. Page C2. 

Ratings Plunge for Network Reruns
Ratings for repeats of the networks' series are mostly in free fall this summer, giving another headache to executives, who were already facing a sharp falloff in advertising dollars for this fall's programs. The summertime flight from the networks has been especially intense for dramatic shows that have been on the air a number of years. Even "ER," the most popular and expensive show in network television, is seeing its repeats hit all-time lows; ratings are down 16 percent. Executives are wondering whether the demise of the summer rerun means that the economic model for network TV, which has always been based on getting two runs of every series episode, is facing collapse. On Television. C6.

Slower Ad Spending Growth Is Seen
The investment banking firm Veronis Suhler is forecasting an increase in advertising spending next year but a slowdown through 2005 in the growth of this spending and in the overall communications industry. Advertising. C9.

Speculation on Condit Interview
With information trickling out ever so slowly in the case of the missing Washington intern Chandra Levy, speculation is building about who might get an interview with Representative Gary A. Condit, the California Democrat who was said by Ms. Levy's relatives to have had an affair with her. Some are placing bets on Dan Rather, the CBS anchor who has held off heavily covering the case. C6.

Web Merchants Turn to Offline Mail
Ever since e-commerce companies began to slump, e-mail marketing has been hailed as a low-cost way to reach consumers and bring customers back for more. The only problem is that the more time people spend on the Web, the more weary they grow of e-mail marketing. As a result, many online companies are hedging their bets with paper direct mail. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C4.

Telephone Fight Shifts in Brazil
Executives of Brasil Telecom, one of the largest fixed-line telephone companies in Brazil, are hoping that the purchase in late July of Telecom Italia -- by the Pirelli and Benetton groups of Italy -- will end a squabble between Telecom Italia and a Brazilian investment bank, Grupo Opportunity, which are partners in the fixed-line business. The fight has threatened the future of Brasil Telecom and Telecom Italia's plan to start building a wireless network in Brazil in 2002. New Economy. C3.

A Password With a Prison Number
The list of things that should not be used as computer passwords generally includes things like birthdays and names of the user's children. For Nicodemo S. Scarfo Jr., whom federal prosecutors are trying to convict on gambling and loan sharking charges, the list might include his father's prison ID number. C3.

AOL Sets Up Digital Book Farm Team
In a twist on the scramble to sell electronic books, the publishing division of AOL Time Warner is using digital publishing to test new books for sales potential, to recruit new writers and to connect with readers. C6.

HEADLINE: Brazilians Uneasy Despite Help by I.M.F. 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 

 BODY:
The $15 billion in loans that the International Monetary Fund unexpectedly offered Brazil on Friday puts some distance between this country and its troubled neighbor Argentina. But the deal is likely to fall short, financial analysts here predicted this weekend, of establishing the foolproof fire wall from the troubles next door that Brazil has been seeking.
 The monetary fund's latest support plan for Brazil is a result of a deepening recession in Argentina and of growing fears that the government there will default on $128 billion in debt. 
 The events of 1997 and 1998, when a financial crisis in Asia spread to Russia and eventually forced Brazil to devalue its currency by 40 percent, are still fresh in investors' minds. And so the action is intended to calm fears of a "contagion" that would spread from one afflicted economy to all developing nations. 
In announcing the new loan package late on Friday, after markets here and in the United States had closed, the fund's managing director, Horst Kohler, was careful to distinguish Brazil's situation from Argentina's. 
He praised what he called "Brazil's strong track record" and lauded the Brazilian authorities for "strengthening fiscal and monetary policies and implementing their structural reform agenda in the face of a difficult external environment."
That ringing endorsement for the world's eighth-largest economy promises to calm, at least temporarily, the stock and foreign exchange markets here, both of which have been buffeted in recent months by spillover from the crisis in Argentina.
Since February, for instance, the value of Brazil's currency, the real, has fallen by nearly 25 percent against the United States dollar, closing on Friday at 2.505 to the dollar.
The timing of the agreement and, above all, the rapidity with which it was reached, came as a surprise to many here. Brazil signed a $41.5 billion accord with international lenders in November 1998. But that agreement expires on Dec. 1, and President Fernando Henrique Cardoso said several times earlier this year that it would not be necessary to renew it.
But late in July, with Argentina's situation worsening, Arminio Fraga, the president of Brazil's Central Bank, made a quick trip to Washington, where he met with officials of the monetary fund. 
At the time, I.M.F. and Brazilian officials characterized the contacts as just preliminary consultations and indicated that the process of negotiating a new agreement, should one be needed at all, might take several months.
"With things unraveling in Argentina, it appears that both sides decided they had no time to waste," a diplomat here said this weekend. "Any delay was only going to feed uncertainty in the markets and make things worse."
The sudden announcement of the standby credit line for Brazil was not the only move the monetary fund made on Friday in an effort to calm markets. 
The fund also said it would lend $1.5 billion to Turkey, another developing country that has been shaken by economic woes, and accelerate a $1.2 billion disbursement to Argentina. But it offered no additional money to supplement the $40 billion package that Argentina negotiated with international lenders late last year.
In Buenos Aires, John Taylor, the United States under secretary of the Treasury, held two days of talks with Argentine officials late last week. Argentine officials said afterward that the Bush administration understood the nation's financial problems and supported austerity moves to trim the deficit by at least $1.5 billion this year.
Officials also told local newspapers that they were confident that the United States and other economic powers would agree that I.M.F. payments to Argentina would be accelerated to assure that it could meet its debt obligations for the months to come.
Though much is made of the contagion effect of the Argentine crisis, Brazil trades much more with Europe and the United States than it does with Argentina or its other partners in Mercosur, the South American common market. 
In recent years, with the world economy booming, Brazil has received as much as $30 billion in new foreign investment annually. Even more than the funds obtained in the 1998 rescue package, that money has helped Brazil reduce its current account deficit and meet the targets that it promised the monetary fund it would fulfill.
During the first half of this year, in contrast, Brazil received only $9.9 billion in direct foreign investment, according to Central Bank statistics, compared with $13.4 billion during the first half of last year. 
The Brazilian government has already reduced its estimates of such capital inflows for this year, from $24 billion to $20 billion, but it may be forced to lower them even further if the United States and Europe plunge into recession or their nervousness about Argentina continues.
In recognition of that situation, the bulk of the package from the monetary fund consists of a $12.5 billion "supplementary reserve facility" that the fund's statement described as a purely "precautionary" measure. Officials indicated this weekend that the money would be used only if Brazil encountered problems in its balance of payments this year or next, after which the new accord is scheduled to expire.
Reaction to the agreement has been muted here so far, in large part because no one outside the government knows the terms of the accord yet. The announcement of whatever new commitments Brazil has made to hold the public deficit and inflation in check is expected to come this week, but everything points toward continued austerity.
With the country heading into a presidential election year, any additional cuts in government spending and investment would probably strengthen the appeal of the left-leaning opposition, some parts of which are opposed to dealings with the monetary fund and support a moratorium on repayment of Brazil's foreign debt.
In addition, Brazil's 170 million people have been living with rationing of electricity since June as the result of a drought and lack of investment in energy production. 
The government has promised an expensive crash program to build new dams and power plants, but Brazilian newspapers this weekend have been asking whether the government will still be able to meet those commitments.
Nor does the latest loan "alter the structural and fiscal weakness from the recession that is unveiling itself" here, the daily Folha de Sao Paulo noted in an editorial published on Saturday. "If I.M.F. support is seen as a necessary condition to avoid a deeper crisis, then this support is far from being sufficient."

HEADLINE: Putting Her Money Where Maine's Woods Are 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WINTER HARBOR, Me. 

 BODY:
Roxanne Quimby was too excited to steer. Her minivan meandered along the road in Acadia National Park, her knees bracing the wheel as she waved to park rangers or pointed out shoreline rocks where seals sometimes bask. She feels something spiritual in parks like this, she said.
 "I do hug trees," Ms. Quimby said. 
 In some ways, Ms. Quimby is like any naturalist enjoying a park; she just happens to be a very rich one. And that is what frightens some Maine residents. 
Since co-founding the natural skin care products company Burt's Bees in 1984, Ms. Quimby says, she has turned a profit large enough to allow her to start giving back to the earth. So she has been buying chunks of Maine's North Woods, which she hopes will one day be included in a new national park.
She bought 5,800 acres of forestland near Baxter State Park for $1.63 million; 2,350 acres near the Appalachian Trail for $570,000; 285 acres encompassing Little Greenwood Pond for $375,000; and 77 acres at the base of Mount Kineo for $350,000. She has a $2.2 million land deal in the works. Since news of her shopping spree became public in July, she has become a popular topic on the opinion pages of local newspapers.
To some she is a hero, a reincarnation of Percival Baxter, the wealthy governor who bequeathed to Maine what is now Baxter State Park. To others, she might as well be a flatlander for all the respect she shows for Maine's heritage as a lumber producer. 
"Message from northern Maine to Quimby: Leave us and our way of life alone," Eugene J. Conlogue, the town manager for Millinocket, wrote in a letter to The Bangor Daily News. "We don't want your park or your unfortunate, inaccurate and unfair depictions of the hard-working people of our part of the state."
The controversy over that park began a few years ago, when the paper companies that own much of Maine's forests began putting millions of acres on the market. Restore the North Woods, a conservation group, proposed turning 3.2 million of those acres in the northern central part of the state into a national park. 
But many people who live near the proposed park area say it would irreparably change the economy of the region, driving out the paper products industry and the jobs that go with it. Several communities in northern Maine have passed resolutions opposing the park, and the state's Congressional delegation and governor have spoken against the idea as well.
That does not discourage Ms. Quimby, a member of Restore's board of directors, who points out that people initially fought Grand Teton and several other national parks.
"They talk about the economy as if there were something at stake," she said. "It's the shakiest and most fragile economy I have ever seen."
Ms. Quimby, 51, has scrutinized Maine's rural economy as a company president and as a single mother who worked three part-time waitress jobs. She came to Maine when she was 24, not long out of the San Francisco Art Institute. With $3,000 in savings she bought 30 acres of land and built a cabin with her future husband. For several years the two of them lived without electricity, hauling their own water, growing their own food, and, when their twins were born, watching diapers freeze on the clothesline.
She and her husband eventually split, and as her children grew, she knew that her income from making Christmas wreaths and other crafts would not pay for college. She traded at flea markets and waited on tables to make ends meet.
Then she met Burt Shavitz, a beekeeper. Mr. Shavitz had been selling his honey in bulk, but Ms. Quimby figured it would be far more profitable to sell it in small jars with decorative labels. 
"He said, 'Go for it, Roxy, and by the way, I've got 2,000 pounds of beeswax in the shed,' " Ms. Quimby recalled. 
She turned the beeswax into candles, and later lip balm, hand salve and other skin care products that were sold under the Burt's Bees label. By 1993, the company had grown too big to operate profitably in northern Maine, so they moved it to North Carolina. But two years later she was back. She settled in quiet Winter Harbor, just steps from Schoodic Point, a less-visited peninsula in Acadia National Park.
Having bought out Mr. Shavitz, Ms. Quimby is now sole owner of Burt's Bees, which had revenues of $23 million last year and expects around $32 million this year. She runs the company from her home, with regular trips to the offices in Durham, N.C.
Ms. Quimby says she is ready to put every cent she has into buying land. Even then, says Jym St. Pierre, Maine director for Restore the North Woods, she will not be able to buy all the land needed for the park, but she sets an example for others.
"I look at these as seeds; these are the seeds around which we'll be able to grow a pearl," Mr. St. Pierre said. 
Ms. Quimby does not mind being the sand in the oyster. Every day she stops by the bakery run by her children to read the newspaper and find out what her neighbors are saying about her.
What they say is that they will be left to run motels and join the tourist trade. When Ms. Quimby says earnestly that "half of them would make excellent tour guides," they wince. 
Whether or not the park becomes a reality, she says, she hopes her legacy will have more to do with trees than with beeswax, "I don't think people will be saying, 'She created really great carrot cream -- three cheers for her!' "

HEADLINE: Bare-Bones Budgeting 

 BODY:
In its 17 straight years of failing to pass a budget on time, the State Legislature has shown remarkable creativity in finding new methods of avoidance. Last week, in a burst of ingenuity, it approved something called a "bare-bones budget." It's a creation that lies somewhere between a real budget and an emergency appropriation, a package with just enough money to keep the state idling along at minimal speed until mid-September, when everybody may be in the mood to try again. 
 The budget cuts all extras, including not only the Legislature's pet projects but most of the governor's as well. Environmental initiatives and economic development would come to a screeching halt. Some programs to help welfare recipients get work would run out of money for new clients in the fall, and local schools would receive far less state aid than they had been hoping for. 
 The view from the floors of the State Assembly and Senate is that this emaciated budget was necessary for one key reason -- it had to be ugly enough to force Gov. George Pataki and his people to the conference committee tables to negotiate a full-blown budget this fiscal year.
The governor's staff argues loudly that there were less lofty motives, namely paychecks and the August vacations. Legislators' pay has been held hostage since the budget missed its April 1 deadline. Once a budget is passed -- and State Comptroller Carl McCall decreed that had been done as of Friday -- the backlog of checks can be distributed. Overdue vacations also loomed large on the legislative horizon. Members of the Assembly and Senate have been marching sullenly to Albany a day or two a week all summer. Now, despite protests of school leaders, civic groups and some of their own leaders, many suddenly flush lawmakers plan to head for the hills -- or seashore.
The budget process is back where it should have been in February -- with the governor and legislators arguing about the bottom line. Given the economic slowdown that could cut revenues, it is clear that the governor is correct to say that the Assembly Democrats propose spending too much money for fiscal safety. But Mr. Pataki's schedule of tax cuts, enacted in better times, is also beginning to make too much of a dent in the revenue projections. 
Schools face the worst problems from Albany's budget swamp, particularly in poorer upstate areas and urban districts like New York City's. This skimpy new budget, which sticks close to Governor Pataki's proposed operating aid for schools, falls far short of what is needed in these districts, which are struggling to keep up with new state standards. 
To assess blame for the latest budget sump in Albany is, of course, a futile exercise, since there is now so much of it to go around. But the Legislature should not be leaving town, and the governor needs to spend more time in the Capitol overseeing his share of the budget process, even if it means all parties have to cancel their fund-raising trips or summer cruises. Some critics have suggested locking everyone in an open-air arena until there is a reasonable budget. What seemed like an outlandish idea a few months ago is beginning to sound like a workable option.
