HEADLINE: Time of Growing Pains for Information Age 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS OVERBYE 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Conn. 

 BODY:
These would seem to be heady times to be a computer scientist. This is the information age, in which, we are told, biology is defined by a three-billion-letter instruction manual called the genome and human thoughts are analogous to digital bits flowing through a computer. And, we are warned, human intellect will soon be dwarfed by superintelligent machines.
 "All kinds of people," said Jaron Lanier, a computer scientist and musician, "are happy to tell us what we do is the central metaphor, the best explanation of everything from biology to economics to aesthetics to child rearing, sex, you name it. It's very ego-gratifying." 
 Mr. Lanier is the lead scientist of the National Tele-Immersion Initiative, a virtual reality system that has been designed for the Internet. 
He and six other scientists were sitting under a maple tree one recent afternoon worrying whether this headiness was justified. They found instead that they could not even agree on useful definitions of their field's most common terms, like "information" and "complexity," let alone the meaning and future of this revolution.
The other scientists were two computer science professors, Dr. David Gelernter of Yale and Dr. Jordan Pollack of Brandeis University; three physicists, Dr. Brian Greene of Columbia, Dr. Alan Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Dr. Lee Smolin of the Center for Gravitational Physics and Geometry at Penn State; and a psychologist and neuroscientist, Dr. Marc Hauser of Harvard.
John Brockman, a literary agent who represents these scientists, had convened them at the country house here that he shares with his wife and partner, Katinka Matson. Mr. Brockman said he had been inspired to gather the group by a conversation with Dr. Seth Lloyd, a professor of mechanical engineering and quantum computing expert at M.I.T. Mr. Brockman recently posted Dr. Lloyd's statement on his Web site, www.edge.org: "Of course, one way of thinking about all of life and civilization," Dr. Lloyd said, "is as being about how the world registers and processes information. Certainly that's what sex is about; that's what history is about."
Humans have always tended to try to envision the world and themselves in terms of the latest technology. In the 17th and 18th centuries, for example, workings of the cosmos were thought of as the workings of a clock, and the building of clockwork automata was fashionable. But not everybody in the world of computers and science agrees with Dr. Lloyd that the computation metaphor is ready for prime time.
Several of the people gathered under the maple tree had come in the hopes of debating that issue with Dr. Lloyd, but he could not attend at the last moment. Others were drawn by what Dr. Greene called "the glimmer of a unified language" in which to talk about physics, biology, neuroscience and other realms of thought. What happened instead was an illustration of how hard it is to define a revolution from the inside.
Scientifically, the information age can be said to have begun in 1948 when Dr. Claude E. Shannon, a researcher at Bell Laboratories, proposed that information could be defined as the number of ones and zeros -- bits -- that it took to encode a message in binary language. His mathematical formulation of that implied a link between information and entropy, a measure of disorder that plays a deep role in many areas of physics, like heat, gases and black holes.
Some scientists have suggested applying Dr. Shannon's definition of information to situations other than the sending of messages, to things like the human genome or even the universe. According to one interpretation of recent theories in high-energy particle physics, the universe can be portrayed as nothing more than a vast network of information flow -- that is to say, as a computer.
In principle, Dr. Smolin said, a piece of metal or an orange could be said to have an information content and the object's behavior, rusting or ripening, could be thought of as a computation. But he added, "We have not yet constructed physics on those grounds and have no idea if we will be able to."
The assembled scientists, however, argued that Dr. Shannon's definition of information, based on counting bits, did not give a meaningful result in every situation. For example, if you have two copies of a book, you have twice as many bits and thus twice as much information, but you are not necessarily better informed.
Not all bits are equal, after all. The words "I do," spoken in one context, say, by the participants in a wedding, have a much larger consequence than if spoken elsewhere. An article on the front page of a newspaper receives more attention than one of equal length inside.
The recently completed sequencing of the human genome furnishes another example of the futility of counting bits. The first analysis revealed far fewer genes than expected. The potency of the genome, biologists are saying, arises from relationships among the genes and from their interactions in the environment of a womb, rather than their sheer number. The different parts of the genetic code are, in effect, able to turn one another on and off.
Such effects, in a long computer code or in the various contexts of real life, Mr. Lanier said, "create lenses" that magnify some bits while the rest are lost in statistical noise and never affect the world. How to distinguish and quantify the bit that have an impact? Mr. Lanier suggested making a distinction between the maximum potential information in a system -- the total number of bits -- and the causal impact of those bits.
The ambiguities in the meaning of information make it even more difficult to define a way to measure another much bandied-about concept in computer science, namely complexity. Which is a problem, Dr. Pollack explained, because without a quantitative definition of complexity, scientists have no objective way to evaluate the intelligence of a new robot or a computer program or of the process that created them.
One difficulty, Dr. Smolin and the others pointed out, is that a simple program can give a complex result. Examples are the beautiful fractal patterns, depicting shapes within shapes within shapes, known as the Mandelbrot set, after the mathematician Benoit Mandelbrot. They can be generated by a simple computer code. So where does the complexity reside?
Another example, maintained Dr. Pollack, is life itself, which, he pointed out had begun billions of years ago as a pool of random chemicals, running its own "simple program" and baking in the sun. "Over time you would wind up with something that I would argue was more complex than the initial program," he said.
On the other hand there are things that appear simpler than their beginnings, like a fine novel whose polished prose belies the many drafts and years of struggle it took to write. Living organisms today are made of a relatively few number of genes and amino acids, but that is the result of billions of years of evolution in nature's computer.
Any useful definition of complexity of some system, the scientists suggested, should include some measure of how much energy or time or computation it took to produce or change the system. "I think complexity is mostly sort of crummy stuff that is there because it's too expensive to change the interface," Mr. Lanier said.
Woven among the day's discussions was a running criticism, often scathing, of the state of modern computer technology as it applies to ordinary people. Dr. Gelernter described current software as "crummy," and modern computers, laden with incomprehensible user manuals and unneeded features, as "more a source of irritation, dissatisfaction and angst than a positive benefit."
He was particularly scornful of the ubiquitous organization of information into folders and files, a notion he said belonged in offices of the 1940's. He said he expected it to be replaced by a scheme in which computers receive and catalog information chronologically in a continuous stream.
But his colleagues saw little hope for such a change, as attractive as it might be. The reason, Dr. Pollack and Mr. Lanier bothsaid, was that in the evolution of computer systems, as in biological evolution, old and inefficient features often became embedded in the system, like the blind spot in the retina of the eye. Natural selection, he said, does not optimize every aspect of an organism. In short, files now, files forever.
Dr. Pollack had come armed with a demonstration of the vicissitudes of evolution in the form of his lab's latest robot, a tinkertoy assemblage of arms and joints. It was the knobby result of a process of evolution that had taken place inside a computer commanded to design a robot that would move, then to simulate the behavior of the robot, tweak the design, simulate the behavior of the next robot, and so on. Another computer was then commanded to build the robot that resulted.
Let loose, the battery-powered "tinkerbot" stretched and folded sporadically, like a crab shuffling across the table. Someone asked what a pair of extensions sticking out sideways from the middle of the robot were for. "We don't know," Dr. Pollack answered. Then one of the robot's legs fell off, perhaps illustrating its lack of Darwinian fitness.
Extracting a conclusion from this daylong session was an exercise in information and complexity theory itself. Dr. Gelernter expressed dismay at what he called his colleagues' "defeatist" attitude toward current technology. "The idea that we can't change is indefensible," he said. "They know the field has been turned over every five years."
Mr. Lanier judged the day as "a notch upward" in his efforts to engage the physicists in a dialogue. Dr. Greene said the most interesting aspect was "how hard it was to define something that seems so obvious."
"I'm still trying to figure out what happened," said Dr. Pollack, who described the day as "searching for a vocabulary." He said he been surprised and heartened to find that other people were asking the same questions he was, even if they didn't get the same answers. "I felt like I found a soul mate," he said.

HEADLINE: More Than Just a Nuisance, A Virtuoso of Disease 

BYLINE:  By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
It is the height of summer, and the mosquito is out and about, determined to spoil everyone's good time.
 But for millions of people, including thousands in this country each year, the mosquito is far more than a pest. For them this insect -- a quarter-inch long and weighing a tiny fraction of an ounce -- carries serious disease and sometimes death. Mosquitoes and the malaria they carry may even be the leading impediment to economic growth in the developing world. And, medical science is learning, mosquitoes are full of surprises. 
 Two years ago, New Yorkers learned what Dr. Andrew Spielman calls the first law of mosquitoes: expect the unexpected. 
Until August 1999, most city residents found mosquitoes but occasional summertime pests, to be endured perhaps at an evening concert in Central Park. Then came the news that, somehow or other, a native mosquito, Culex pipiens, the so-called common house mosquito that hangs out in storm sewers and sump pumps but rarely bites people, had acquired an exotic virus that could cause a fatal brain infection, West Nile encephalitis. The virus, named for its discovery in 1937 in the blood of a feverish woman in the West Nile district of Uganda, had never before been seen on this side of the Atlantic. 
But how had the West Nile virus arrived on these shores? Did it enter by way of an infected traveler, by infected mosquitoes that hitched a ride on a plane or ship? Epidemiologists worry it is but the first of many exotic viruses that could use local mosquito species as an incubator and transport system for infecting countless people in the United States.
"It's amazing that it happened, and it may happen again and again," said Dr. Spielman, a Harvard professor and an expert on mosquito-borne illness. With the journalist Michael D'Antonio, Dr. Spielman has written a new book on the subject of his life's work, "Mosquito: A Natural History of Our Most Persistent and Deadly Foe."
"There are other viruses out there -- Rift Valley fever virus, Japanese B encephalitis virus, among them -- that could be imported," said Dr. Spielman, 70.
"However," he said in an interview, "there's no need to reach overseas for exotic viruses transmitted by mosquitoes. There's an enormous number of viruses here now that could bridge from animals to humans via the mosquito."
The 2,500 known species of mosquitoes (150 of them in the United States) cover the gamut of ecological niches and bite at all times of the day and night. Some, like Aedes aegypti, a transmitter of deadly dengue fever in Puerto Rico, reside in or near people's homes, making mass eradication by communitywide spraying a virtual impossibility. Aedes mcintoshi, a vector of Rift Valley fever virus, which has caused huge outbreaks in the Middle East, can survive in its egg stage for decades in a dessicated desert, hatching when it rains. 
C. pipiens, the mosquito that is host to West Nile in New York, seeks its blood meal in the evening. Dr. Spielman said, "It is the mosquito in built-up areas, but it rarely bites people." He has encountered it covering the walls of an African hut like a living carpet, as well as in Paris's subway, the Ginza shopping district of Tokyo and Confucius' graveyard in China.
Like other mosquito species, the female C. pipiens (only females bite) needs just one mating to acquire sufficient sperm to lay two batches of eggs. Each batch consists of about 240 eggs that form a canoe-shaped raft the size of a rice grain.
The eggs are deposited in any available water -- children's pools, trays under flower pots, birdbaths and storm sewers -- and take a week or so to go to larva to pupa to adult. The females bite almost anything to get the blood they need to support egg development. In the process they can acquire, incubate and then transfer several potentially deadly viruses.
In the New York area, the West Nile virus has been isolated from thousands of birds, both wild and zoo-dwelling, as well as from horses, cats, bats, chipmunks, skunks, squirrels, domestic rabbits and raccoons. It has spread along the East Coast from Maine to Florida, and as far west as Ohio.
Experts predict it will take a few summers at most for this viral import to invade most developed areas in the United States. While healthy children and younger adults typically get only a mild infection, the virus can be devastating in the elderly and chronically ill, especially people with diabetes. In its first appearance in New York in August and September 1999, about 60 patients, with an average age of 71, were hospitalized with a documented West Nile infection. Most had signs of encephalitis, and seven died. There were 21 cases, with two deaths, in the nation in 2000. This year, two human cases have been reported, both in Florida.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta reports that for every one person with an obvious West Nile infection, four others have a subclinical illness that goes undetected. The virus multiplies in and often kills birds, the so-called amplifying hosts, and multiplies further in mosquitoes that take blood from birds.
But West Nile is far from the worst mosquito-borne infection now in this hemisphere. Dengue fever, relatively unknown in the West until the 1970's, when an epidemic swept through Cuba and other Caribbean countries, produces a spectrum of symptoms, the worst of which is fatal hemorrhagic fever. Aedes aegypti, a daytime biter that prefers human blood, is the principal vector of yellow fever as well as dengue. Dengue is primarily a disease of the tropics, though it threatens to invade the American South.
In Puerto Rico, Dr. Spielman reports, the mosquito that transmits dengue can be found "virtually everywhere on the island, including in a flower vase in my San Juan hotel room during a meeting of the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene." At least one person attending the meeting was stricken.
Some experts believe dengue is fast becoming a plague of worldwide dimensions that with global warming may one day eclipse malaria as the most important mosquito-borne illness in people. Now, malaria claims two million lives a year, plus an enormous cost in lost productivity among those who become infected and ill but do not die. It is transmitted by the nighttime bite of an Anopheles mosquito, which threatens about 40 percent of the world's population.
In this country, West Nile is not the only form of mosquito-borne encephalitis that threatens people. Every summer, about 120 people are stricken with St. Louis encephalitis, a brain infection transmitted by C. pipiens, the West Nile vector. The virus can survive the winter in blood-gorged females that take refuge in barns, caves and other protected places. About 15 percent of victims die, and some survivors suffer lasting emotional disturbances.
La Crosse encephalitis, named for the Wisconsin city where it was discovered in the 1960's in a child who died, now occurs widely across the country. It is spread by a late-afternoon biter, Aedes triseriatus, a woodland dweller that breeds in water-filled tree holes and old tires.
The virus can be transmitted from the mother mosquito to her eggs, so no animal host is needed to perpetuate it. Nearly all victims of La Crosse encephalitis are children under 15, and 90 percent are males. One in 25 who are infected develop encephalitis, and 1 percent die.
Western equine encephalitis, spread by Culex tarsalis in the Western states, also can cause serious illness, especially in children. But here the risk of developing encephalitis from an infected bite is only one in a thousand, with a death rate of 5 percent.
The deadliest mosquito-borne viral infection is Eastern equine encephalitis, a disease of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts that can strike people of all ages with a mortality rate of 30 percent to 50 percent. Fortunately, it is still rare, and it is likely to remain so. The virus infects birds that roost near freshwater swamps, where the swamp mosquito Culiseta melanura dwells. But this insect almost never bites people. Rather, people acquire the disease when some other mosquito, known as a bridge vector, bites an infected bird and then bites a person.
The most feared mosquito these days, the aggressive Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is unlikely to cause more than an annoying, itchy bite. Although it carries disease in Asia, this pest, which arrived here in the 1960's in tire shipments from Japan, "is willing to feed on almost anything," and that willingness invalidates it as a host for infection, Dr. Spielman said. "Since the female mosquito usually feeds on blood only twice," he said, "if it bites the wrong host where the virus cannot multiply, it's a dead end."
It is perhaps of little consolation to know four facts about mosquitoes: the most common biter here, the well-named warm weather mosquito, Aedes vexans, along with A. excrucians of the northern woods and A. tormentor of the southern woods, are at worst bridge vectors; mosquitoes cannot transmit the AIDS virus; human blood is usually inferior to that from other animals for fostering mosquito egg development, and for many mosquito-borne viruses people are dead-end hosts.
This last fact means that viruses cannot multiply adequately in human blood to infect the next mosquito that bites. Thus, it is unlikely that a disease like West Nile arrived here via an infected person traveling from an endemic area, according to Dr. Kenneth L. Tyler of the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Denver.
In an editorial in June in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Tyler urged his fellow physicians to "remain alert for new outbreaks of disease in animals, which may herald related events in humans."
Do mosquitoes have a saving grace? Not according to Dr. Spielman, who said he knew of no species of plant or animal that was completely dependent upon the mosquito for survival. True, nectar-feeding male and female mosquitoes help to pollinate some flowers, and mosquito larvae and adults are fare for fish, frogs, bats, birds, dragonflies and other insects. But all would survive if suddenly every mosquito were to disappear from the face of the earth, not that this is likely to happen soon enough for people who have already lost a pint of blood this summer to mosquitoes that hatched after the spring floods in the South and Midwest.

With mosquitoes, says Dr. Andrew Spielman, an expert on the illnesses they carry, people should expect the unexpected. HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES 

 BODY:
 EURO DROPS. The euro declined against the dollar after German manufacturing orders fell in June for a fifth time this year. In New York, the euro settled at 88.23 cents, down from 88.37 cents on Friday.

HEADLINE: Tunnel Vision; 
Waiting for a Train, Waiting for Stardom

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
 If you go down into the subway with a notebook and a pen and try to ask people questions -- even if you display a card that identifies you as an employee of a major metropolitan newspaper -- you will get reactions that can be broken down into the following broad categories.

1. Please leave me alone, you nut, or I will scream.
2. What sort of a scam are you running, man?
3. That's nice. I'm late for work.
4. Am I really going to be in the newspaper?
 These reactions are not usually expressed out loud. They are conveyed by the eyes, the facial expressions or by the feet, walking away from you. The fourth reaction is the rarest, and always a little surprising when it happens.
This is what made it all the more interesting to spend an afternoon in the subway watching people from the television channel MetroTV produce a show called "Subway Q & A," a kind of cult hit on cable in which subway riders are asked funny or embarrassing questions or are propositioned to participate in wacky stunts.
The lesson learned was not a particularly original one, especially these days, but it was still amazing to experience firsthand: by and large, human beings will give their unqualified trust and cooperation to anyone carrying a professional-looking video camera.
An executive on Wall Street will agree to go bowling with an unemployed security guard and a man who lives in his van. Parents will hand over their children to be tended by total strangers. A woman will go fishing with you in Sheepshead Bay.
That this can occur even in the subway, the place where New Yorkers go to perfect the thousand-yard stare and the vow of silence, is a testament to something. To people's intense longing for their 15 minutes, maybe. But perhaps more to the feeling that nothing bad can happen in the presence of a television camera because, somewhere, tens of thousands of witnesses must be watching.
This feeling seems to be even more pronounced in the subway, where a faint shadow remains of the fear that once darkened the system.
The aura of television protection extends to those behind the camera, too: recently, the host of the show, Rich Collier, was trusting enough to put on a suit of body armor and go into the subway with a baseball bat, offering people the opportunity to take out their frustrations on him.
"That was probably the scariest thing I ever did in my life," said Mr. Collier, 36. But it was all for television, and, of course, everything turned out O.K. ("Rich is less neurotic than most talent," said Matthew Kells, the program's producer.)
The program being taped on Thursday did not require as much trust, on either side of the camera. But it was still a good demonstration of the principle. Mr. Collier and a crew of six jammed themselves onto 1 and 9 trains with a prodigious amount of equipment, a bunch of art supplies and a blank stretched canvas, asking ordinary riders to contribute their artistic gifts to make a collective subway painting. The idea was then to find someone who would agree to let the television crew hang the painting in their home.
Vanessa Morales, a recent high school graduate waiting for a train at the 181st Street station, was persuaded in under a minute to get down onto her hands and knees on the platform and sling paint at the canvas like Jackson Pollock. She even seemed to heed Mr. Collier's advice that to become a really good artist, she would need to drink more and generally "become a freaky recluse."
"I think I can try," said Ms. Morales solemnly, paint on her face.
During the afternoon, two midwives, a psychologist, a retired shipping clerk, a cartoonist, a young tourist from North Carolina and several others gladly missed trains and stops to help Mr. Collier in his mission. And then without much trouble he and the crew managed to find a woman named Juliet at the Pennsylvania Station stop who took them all to her mother's new apartment in Bayside, Queens, to hang the painting, which by that point had come to resemble a scary cross between a Basquiat and a Rorschach. ("Why not?" said Juliet's mother, gleefully.)
Of course, there were a few riders who simply would not be persuaded to join the global media village. One woman continued to read "The Picture of Dorian Gray" with no apparent lack of concentration caused by the huge Panasonic camera near her head. An elderly man told Mr. Collier, "I am not interested in whatever it is you're doing."
But many who refused seemed to be almost embarrassed by their unneighborliness. "I am so tired," explained Vebi Muriqi, a porter.
Even the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which can be touchy about taping in the subway, appears to have acquiesced.
"One time we decided to do a re-creation of the Revolutionary War in the subway," Mr. Collier said. "The M.T.A. said, 'So. You're going to chase people around the subway in powdered wigs?' "
"And we said, 'Basically, yeah.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rich Collier of "Subway Q & A" courts another collaborative artist. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Job Cut Announcements Climbed 65% in July 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
Job cut announcements jumped 65 percent to a record level in July, led by telecommunications, computer, electronic and industrial companies, a report by the outplacement firm of Challenger, Gray & Christmas said today. 
 Announced job cuts in July hit 205,975, up from 124,852 in June. July's total was more than three times the level of job cuts recorded in the same month last year, the report said. 
 "Job cuts tell us as much about the economy's future as they do about the present. Companies are looking at their staffing needs for the balance of 2001 and the numbers do not present a very positive picture," said John Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas. The survey began in 1993. 
For the first half of 2001, United States companies said they planned to cut 777,362 jobs, more than three times the number announced in the first six months of last year. 
The telecommunications sector overtook the technology sector in July in recording the highest number of job-cut announcements. With 44,908 job cuts announced in July, the total number of layoffs announced in the sector hit 175,350 for the first seven months this year. 
Technology companies announced 26,321 layoffs in July bringing the total to 101,044 for the year to date. 
"This is a very, very big surge in layoffs. Basically it says two things: One is that the employment situation is not going to turn around in the near future and will continue to get worse during summer months. It also means that claims will edge higher," said Eric Green, chief economist with BNP Paribas, referring to claims for jobless benefits. 
"But it does not mean much for the market. Everyone knows the labor market is weak and will continue to get weaker in the coming months," he added.

HEADLINE: Hypothesis: Science Gap. Cause: Japan's Ways 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
The paraphernalia of the scientist are nowhere in sight in the huge, anonymous office in central Tokyo where Hideki Shirakawa, a Nobel laureate in chemistry in 2000, spends most of his time these days.
 In between the tedious evaluation of research proposals, his task as head of a new national commission to re-energize Japanese science involves reflecting long and hard on why his country's laboratories have produced so few stars on his level. 
 "Fundamentally, Japanese culture is based on rice farming," said Dr. Shirakawa, 65, reaching for a time-honored explanation for a widely perceived aversion to individual initiative. "Rice cultivation requires a lot of water, and water must be shared evenly by everyone. Planting rice also required teams of people walking from row to row, at the same speed. And all of this has meant that uniqueness had to be suppressed." 
Officially, Dr. Shirakawa's brief involves nothing less than devising a strategy for Japan to win 30 more Nobel prizes in the sciences over the next 50 years. "The figure is way too high," he says with a shrug and a wry smile. "In the last 50 years we've only had six."
Dr. Shirakawa is diplomatic in raising the question of culture in evaluating why Japan, immensely rich with more than a century of universal education and the world's second largest economy, performs more like a modestly endowed middle-ranking country. Others in the scientific community are more scathing in their self-appraisal, and have begun calling for a revolution in the nation's laboratories and classrooms.
The problems they cite include excessive government control over both research funding and education, faculties still steeped in Confucian ideals of age grade promotion and piety toward seniors, and a generalized penchant for seeking incremental advancement of knowledge at the expense of bold experimentation.
But most important of all, disillusioned scientists say that Japan's research community has never managed to fully embrace peer review and criticism, whose sparks have always served to light creative fires in the West -- from Newton and Hooke to Einstein and Planck.
"There is a lack of competition and critical evaluation in Japan," said Ikuo Kushiro, director of the Institute of Frontier Research of Earth Evolution, a former vice president of Tokyo University, whose role in this highly centralized country roughly approximates that of Harvard, Stanford and M.I.T. combined. "Promotions don't depend on the size of one's contribution, but rather on their years of service, and scientists are very friendly, and tend to avoid debate. 
"I worked at the Carnegie Institution in Washington, and I knew two eminent scientists who were good friends, but once it came to their work, they would have severe debates, even in the journals. That kind of thing happens in the United States, but in Japan, never."
Although few outside Japan worry about the problem, the stakes are truly global. Just as Japan's economy, mired in recurrent recessions for 11 years, now constitutes a huge drag on the world's economy, the underperformance of the world's second richest country in scientific matters exacts a steep, but invisible cost in issues as diverse as fighting malaria and AIDS to understanding global warming.
"Global science needs as many competent players as possible to address the thorny problems of health and the environment, and to make accurate statements on issues ranging from world climatic change to species endangerment and antibiotic-resistant organisms," wrote Samuel J. Coleman, author of "Japanese Science: From the Inside," (Routledge, 1999) in a recent essay. "As long as Japan is unable to translate its wealth and talent into substantial scientific contributions we are all the poorer for it." 
On the surface, things might not appear so bleak for Japanese science. From the early 1990's, spending on research increased dramatically, as media reports here focused on the shoddy state of the country's university laboratories. Japan has sought to break out of the scientific ghetto of applied research, the long-favored emphasis on research with direct commercial applications. 
Japan now spends roughly half as much on scientific research as the United States ($118 billion compared with $229 billion in 1999, according to government statistics), more than twice as much as its closest rival in the West, Germany. As a result of those efforts, 9 percent of the articles published in scientific and technical journals worldwide in 1995 were by Japanese authors, according to the National Science Foundation, a United States Government agency.
The spending increase may yield future leaps in knowledge, and garner Nobels, which are often awarded for work done several years earlier. In the last decade, however, Dr. Shirakawa was the only Japanese scientist to win a Nobel, for his work with other scientists to create a plastic that conducts electricity like a metal. Scientists in the United States won 44 Nobels in the last 10 years, Germany five, and France three.
Nobel prizes are, of course, only one way to measure scientific output. But even a recent government paper here acknowledged that Japanese global influence on scientific research remains modest. 
"The Japanese government usually thinks it must increase funding to research," said Syukuro Manabe, a renowned climate physicist who has spent most of his career working in the United States. "But that alone will not enhance research productivity. Research funding must go to those who deserve funding rather than distributing it equally. They have to find some way to support the really distinguished researchers who deserve support, rather than those who do research for the sake of research. What we need to create is job insecurity rather than security to make people compete more."
Dr. Manabe recently returned to Japan after 40 years spent mostly in American government climate laboratories abroad to head the Frontier Research System for Global Change, a richly government-funded climate study institute. He created a stir last week, however, with a surprise announcement that he had decided to leave Japan once again for the United States. 
"In the funding system here decisions are made by a committee of distinguished scientists appointed by the ministry of education, but if we want to do better, we'll have to come up with true peer review system, like the one maintained by the National Science Foundation in the United States," Dr. Manabe said. "Many of my fellow scientists agree with me, but then they say I am too Americanized, and complain that real peer review in Japan won't work. 
"The reason we have difficulty establishing a peer review system has to do with a kind of an Asian culture. You don't want to speak openly in criticism of someone else's work. It is kind of a mutual admiration society, and that has real consequences."
At Japan's ministry of education, culture, sports, science and technology, a gigantic bureaucracy that controls most of the grants for research here, officials say they have recognized that simply throwing huge sums of money at science will not increase scientific output.
"We've introduced a term system for researchers in our national labs, and increased merit rewards for people with good ideas," said Nobuaki Kawakami, director of the ministry's division of planning and evaluation. "We've been trying to increase competitiveness and career mobility in science because we recognize this as one of the most important problems we have to tackle."
Repeating a grievance that was echoed by many scientists themselves, he said, "Our researchers tend to choose easy projects, which is to say, building on things that are already known, so that they can expect results quickly."
Many scientists applaud those kinds of changes, but insist that much more will need to be done in order to lift Japan to the ranks of a real power in science.
"Things are changing and that is very encouraging," said Okamoto Hitoshi, an expert in vertebrate development who at 43 is a relatively young laboratory chief. "But the slots available to young people, although no longer zero, are still very few compared to the United States. 
"Our level is not so low that you can get a promotion without doing good science these days. But it is true that the criticism between us is not so great. Teachers still tell you that eloquence may be silver, but silence is golden."

HEADLINE: Town Stakes Out Future on Higher Ground 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: GRUNDY, Va., July 31 

 BODY:
The rains keep falling here in the heart of Appalachia, turning old coal towns into flooded disaster zones and destroying hundreds of houses of stoic residents who can only accept what nature has cruelly delivered this summer. But not so here, not in this fading riverfront town that hopes to resurrect itself with an ingenious leap across the river in one of the most complex flood control projects in the nation. 
 Grundy, a western Virginia town with a population of 1,175, plans to move its downtown to higher ground by digging into a mountain just across the chronically treacherous Levisa River. The flattened mountain tract is to be the base for a new town center replete with wireless communications and usable land that will double the size of the current six-acre, flood-sodden commercial heart. 
 The Army Corps of Engineers, which wrestles with the nation's flood problems, says that in 65 years of flood control projects, this is the first time something so elaborate has been attempted by carving fresh space to save a town in such a tight turn of steep mountains and narrow hollows. Though the project is not without opposition, town officials say it is far from a pork barrel windfall and will, in fact, save Grundy as well as federal and state money by combining flood control with a highway project. 
"The trick all along has been how to do this without killing the town you're trying to save," said Chuck Crabtree, the town manager, as he watched surveyors take the measure of the mountain that looms just 100 yards west of the town's riverfront. "This is survival. We have to make it happen." 
With its $1.5 million annual budget, Grundy has managed to become the beneficiary of a $177 million project combining resources of the Corps of Engineers and the State Department of Transportation. The remake is to leave this old lumber and coal town higher and drier. In the end, a picturesque bend in the river that has often given way to flood waters is to become a futuristic swath of Appalachian levee with a highway on top. 
"We're on track, ready to cut the top of the mountain," said Mayor W. Harold Trivett of the plan to blast away 300 feet. "My shop will eventually be taken, but what can you do when you've been flooded out three times?" The mayor had to refinance his home and his clothing store after the 1977 flood, which killed three people and caused $15 million in damages. 
Jim Twohig, the corps' project director, said that after studying a variety of alternatives, from dams to channel widening, the mountain shaving approach was chosen as less expensive and more beneficial for Grundy. The corps has built more than 370 large and small dams in more than half a century under its congressional mandate of flood control. This project has thus far avoided the environmental litigation that many dam projects have spurred.
"This is going to be like a laboratory project because there are so many people interested in it in terms of utilities, of opportunities in communications and all the rest," said Steve Wright of the corps. "The more people find out about it, the more excitement is building."
Planners say the combined project will save tens of millions of dollars for the corps and Virginia. The state was facing a federal mandate to make a four-lane highway of old U.S. 460, the town's main street, a project local officials say would have bypassed Grundy and killed the town. Instead, the road is to lace across the top of a new eight-foot-high levee, just across the river from the transported downtown, with short bridges unifying Grundy's new center and old remains.
"Congressman Rick Boucher put all the pieces together and got everyone to look at the project in a different way," Mr. Crabtree said. After years of doubts and disputes, Mr. Boucher, a Democrat, proposed dovetailing the projects of corps and highway planners, who usually operate as powerful separate fiefs. 
One result is that the $25 million share required by the federal government from the town -- an impossible sum for Grundy -- will be put up in the form of land acquisitions that the state agreed to donate to the town because of the cost savings in combining the projects. The new land is to be created by flattening the mountain, then spilling the 2.3 million cubic yards of earthen residue into Wellmore Hollow, a nearby valley that is to be raised. 
More than three dozen storefronts and businesses and at least 16 homes are to be razed in the old town's floodway along the Levisa's east shore. Behind the levee, various structures will be spared, including the Grundy Bible Church and the historic Buchanan County Courthouse. At the edge of the levee, owners of attractive riverfront homes may sell to the government or accept flood-proofing and have their properties raised four feet.
Critics of the project, noting it would take up to 10 years to complete, say it is too elaborate and risk-laden with no certainty that the new town will fulfill development hopes for 50 housing units and dozens of stores and offices. While federal flood control money is assured, the state's continuing share for highway construction will depend on future legislatures, opponents emphasize.
"We need some flood-proofing but it could be done much less expensively," said Michael G. McGlothlin, a lawyer. Mr. McGlothlin contends that the old downtown charm will be lost while the cut mountain and the levee across the way will make the new town seem as if it sits in a rock quarry.
"This puts us in a state of limbo for years and years in the midst of a project that is all-consuming," Mr. McGlothlin said. 
But the doomed properties are mostly dowdy, Depression-era storefronts, Mr. Crabtree said. "We're building a new town and wiping out old blight," he said. 
With the region suffering unemployment in excess of 10 percent as coal mining fades, Grundy, the county seat, is the key to revival hopes extending well beyond its narrow straits. 
"My granddad was a coal miner and his blood, sweat and tears are in this country," Mr. Crabtree said. "This project means as much to the past as it does to the future," he said, looking down into the steep greenery of Wellmore Hollow where some of the new Grundy is to arise.

HEADLINE: A Tight Call As New Jersey Celebrates Its Affluence 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Which state is the richest?
 It looked yesterday as if New Jersey had hit the jackpot, at least according to news reports on an experimental Census Bureau survey in which a sampling of people across the country were asked a lot of questions about such things as whether they had a flush toilet in their mobile home, what kind of fuel they used and how much money they had made the previous year. 
 "A State of Affluence," one New Jersey front page crowed. "A Land of Plenty," said another. The nation's "epicenter of affluence" had "shifted a few golf courses to the southwest, to New Jersey," readers were informed. Even the state's Department of Labor concluded, "New Jersey's median household income ranked as the highest in the nation." 
Connecticut, the suggestion went, was slipping. And look who was on top. Never mind that New Jersey, Connecticut and Alaska have had the highest median household incomes for years, and that their numbers are too close to be reliably ranked.
And never mind that Connecticut's per capita income still tops New Jersey's, and that the Census Bureau itself had warned that the numbers from the new survey, conducted in 2000, might not be strictly comparable with earlier ones.
"Scientifically speaking, if you tested for statistical significance, the difference between New Jersey and Connecticut most likely would not be statistically significant," said Kirby Posey, a survey statistician in the income surveys branch of the Census Bureau. "When you're looking at rankings like this, you have to be careful."
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said that any difference between the two states' household-income figures was minimal.
"If you're No. 1 or No. 2 or No. 3, you're still very affluent," he said. "So the few dollars' difference between them on per capita income and median household income really does not differentiate one strongly from the other."
The numbers came from something confusingly called the Census 2000 Supplementary Survey, which is not the 2000 census but rather a test of a new way of collecting detailed census data. Under the program being tested, to go into effect later in the decade, the bureau would collect detailed data from a national sample of three million households each year.
According to the numbers made public yesterday, the estimate of New Jersey's median household income in the previous year was $54,226. Connecticut's was $53,108 and Alaska's $52,876. But because of the uncertainty of those figures -- given the limitations of any such surveys -- the ranges of certainty for all three states overlapped.
Mr. Posey and others said it was not possible to reliably rank median household incomes from those three states because of the overlap. Mr. Posey said, "You can say with statistical certainty that New Jersey's was higher than Nebraska's, but you can't say with certainty that New Jersey's was higher than Connecticut's."
"Connecticut has always been No. 1 in per capita income and New Jersey is usually second or third in per capita," Mr. Hughes said. "But on the annual Current Population Survey data, New Jersey's household and family income is usually higher than Connecticut's. So it's not surprising that New Jersey has the highest median household income."
Both measures are important methods of calculating overall wealth, he said. And both are used widely in such things as placing new stores and marketing services and products.
As for which state is now more lucrative territory, Mr. Hughes said yesterday, "Any chain worth its salt is going to want to be in both markets."

SUBJECT: LAYOFFS (92%); ECONOMIC DECLINE (83%) ADVERTISING; LABOR; LAYOFFS AND JOB REDUCTIONS 

COMPANY: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COS INC (92%); MULLEN/LHC (57%)

HEADLINE: Operating Profit Is Off at British Air 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 6 

 BODY:
British Airways, Europe's leading airline, which is seeking an alliance with American Airlines, said today that its operating profit fell 48 percent in the quarter ended June 30. The company blamed an array of factors -- from Britain's continuing foot-and-mouth disease crisis to higher fuel costs -- and said its situation would probably remain bleak until next summer.
 Analysts and investors said the results were roughly what had been expected, and British Airways stock rose 1.2 percent, to 343 pence ($4.90) a share. 
 As more European vacationers turn to fast-growing discount airlines like Ryanair and easyJet, British Airways has been moving decisively toward the upper end of the market, cutting the number of economy seats on its flights to concentrate on pampering business travelers. From July 2000 to last month, British Airways cut the overall capacity of its fleet 9.1 percent.
The bias toward business class helped partly insulate it from a falloff in tourist travel to Britain, particularly among Americans troubled by the sight of sheep and cattle carcasses being burned to combat foot-and-mouth disease. But a larger economic slowdown, particularly in the United States, tightened corporate travel budgets, the company said.
British Airways' strategy produced one surprise for analysts in the quarterly results: A sharp 12.9 percent increase in yield -- revenue the airline earns per passenger for each mile flown -- compared with the similar quarter in 2000. 
Against that, though, came a 0.6 percent fall in total sales, coupled with a 7.8 percent increase in costs, pushing operating profit down to $:50 million ($71.4 million) from $:97 million in the period last year. Higher fuel prices, exchange-rate shifts and capacity-reduction measures pushed up costs, the company said. After a gain of $:100 million from selling Go, a discount subsidiary, British Airways posted a $:26 million net profit; it lost $:42 million in the 2000 quarter.
Rod Eddington, the chief executive, said tougher times were ahead. "The real challenge will come in the winter period," he said. "It's too early to say with any certainty what that period is going to look like."
That gloomy assessment was echoed when KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said today that it would cut capacity 3 percent this winter.
British Airways usually earns the bulk of its profits in summer, but recent figures suggest that the slowdown this year has taken a toll on business- and economy-class travel.
The difficulties have added urgency to British Airways' plans, announced last Friday, to renew efforts to form a cost-cutting alliance with American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation. Mr. Eddington said the two airlines would seek an exemption from American antitrust laws in the next few days and would also ask British and European regulators to approve an alliance. Regulators are expected to require the two carriers to give up some landing and takeoff slots at London's congested Heathrow airport. 
"That is a matter for the regulators to decide what the price will be, and we will then decide whether or not the deal is worth doing based on the regulatory price," Mr. Eddington said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rod Eddington, British Air's chief, said its situation would be tough until next summer. (Newscast)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Britain: Bank Profit 

BYLINE:  By Alan Cowell (NYT) 

 BODY:
 After a $20 billion acquisition spree the last two years to move away from dependence on emerging markets, HSBC, the biggest British bank, beat some analysts' forecasts with a 4 percent rise in first-half net profit to $3.67 billion. 
The figure included a one-time gain of $667 million from disposals. Analysts said profits rose because of growing European business, particularly from the acquisition of Credit de Commercial de France, and lower-than-expected provisions against bad debts. John Bond, HSBC's chairman, warned, however, that the outlook for the financial services industry was unclear because of increasingly fragile economic conditions in certain emerging markets and the slowdown in the United States economy. Alan Cowell (NYT)

HEADLINE: National Briefing South: Alabama: Rights Leader Wins Support 

BYLINE:  By Kevin Sack (NYT)

 BODY:
 Civil rights veterans like the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Andrew J. Young and Joseph E. Lowery appeared at the annual meeting of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Montgomery to support Martin Luther King III, above, the organization's embattled president. Mr. 
King had been criticized by the chairman of the group's board as arrogant and ineffectual. In a speech on Sunday night, Mr. King said, "While we are busy waging minor fights inside, there are major fights outside." He set out an agenda for fighting poverty with technology, community empowerment, economic development and education. Kevin Sack (NYT)
